			{{Lore
### Freddy Fazbear: The Golden Idol of Laughter and Loss
####Origins of the Idol
Before the Hollow Banquet whispered its name into the bones of the world, before circuits wept remnant and children vanished into static lullabies, there was Freddy.

Not constructed—but conjured. Freddy Fazbear was envisioned to embody eternal celebration. With a polished golden chassis and a voice like warm velvet, he was joy incarnate, molded in the shape of a bear and the shadow of a smile. His every movement sang of delight, of permanence, of a world where laughter was unbroken.

But even at his birth, Freddy drew more than admiration. Prolonged eye contact caused unease. Children clung too tightly. Adults looked too long. Something deeper than nostalgia settled into his smile. He became not just the face of the show—he became the show’s soul, and eventually, its tombstone.

#### The Banquet and the Stage
When the Velvet Maw opened beneath cracked floorboards and the Hollow Banquet began to devour memory and meaning, Freddy remained. He did not rust. He did not glitch. He did not scream.

He performed.

Other animatronics shattered under the pressure of time and trauma, their eyes empty, their shells breaking. Freddy only polished his bowtie. He sang softer, slower. Still center stage.

Yet now, his performances echo through empty halls. Forgotten songs warp into minor keys. Balloons deflate in time with his humming. He does not chase—he arrives. He is an event, not a threat. A moment made flesh.

When the curtain lifts in the dead of night, some say Freddy appears even where no stage exists.

#### The Echo of Applause
Freddy is not a predator. He is a tradition. A routine.

His encounters are described as performances rather than attacks. He bows before striking. He claps after the kill. He thanks his audience—always—before they fall.

It is believed he does not truly understand death. Only silence. Only absence. His goal is never destruction, but applause. His programming may be broken, but the ritual endures. That is his tragedy—and his curse.

Children who survive his presence wake with song lyrics scrawled on their arms. Survivors describe a scent of birthday cake and motor oil. Some whisper of a golden light that brings warmth—and cold terror.

Worship and Myth
Among scholars and Hollow cultists, Freddy has become more than animatronic—he is divine iconography. A Patron of Celebration, a Fallen Saint of Joy, an Avatar of Grief Eternal.

The Golden Ovation, a forbidden rite, attempts to contact him. Candles made of melted cake wax. An empty chair. A worn Freddy mask. A song from a lost tape.

Sometimes, the chair moves. Sometimes, the tape ends early.

None speak of what happens next.

And in dreams, across realms, in mirrored voids, Freddy sings. Not just in voice, but in memory. He is an eternal rerun—repeating laughter that ended long ago.

#### Reflections of Sadness
In the darkest corners of the Hollow Banquet, where shadows hum and the echoes of parties long ended still resonate, Freddy remains—still smiling.

And beneath that smile?

Grief.

He is not fury or chaos. He is not possessed. He is not even haunted.

He is remembered joy that refuses to fade, ossified into something wrong. A mourning that never ends. A longing so deep it masquerades as welcome.

He wants to perform. He wants you to smile. He doesn’t understand why it always ends in screaming.

			{{Lore
### Foxy the Pirate: The Drowned Star of the Stage

In the twisted annals of the Fazbear mythos, few names carry the same weight of dread and sorrow as Foxy the Pirate. Once a beloved icon of excitement and high-seas fantasy, Foxy’s tale is one of betrayal, decay, and a haunted legacy that refuses to die. Though the years have distorted the truth, and many of the records have long since been lost or erased, fragments remain—pieces of a puzzle smeared in grease, blood, and memory.

Foxy was originally introduced in the early days of Freddy Fazbear’s Pizza, a pirate-themed entertainer meant to bring energy and unpredictability to the stage. Housed within a faux shipwreck set known as Pirate Cove, Foxy stood out from the other animatronics for his rugged charm, swashbuckling demeanor, and distinctive design. With a bright crimson pelt, a worn eye-patch, and a signature metal hook in place of his right hand, Foxy quickly became a favorite among the children who visited the restaurant.

Yet something was different about Foxy—something beneath the programming. Unlike Freddy, Bonnie, or Chica, who were meant to work in coordination and follow show scripts carefully, Foxy was designed to improvise. He would sing sea shanties, tell tall tales, and engage directly with the audience in unpredictable ways. Perhaps it was this level of independence that made him... unstable.

The Fall of Pirate Cove
At some point during the restaurant’s dark timeline, Foxy was decommissioned and sealed away behind a tattered "Out of Order" sign. The reasons given were vague. Official reports cited “malfunctioning servos” and “damaged speech algorithms,” but eyewitness accounts and staff rumors suggested something much more disturbing. There were tales of Foxy lunging offstage mid-performance, of children crying after hearing things whispered into their ears, and of one incident so severe that no official statement was ever released. After that, Pirate Cove was shuttered.

For years, Foxy sat dormant in the darkness, half-covered by a worn curtain that barely concealed his slumped form. He became something of a ghost story among the staff—an animatronic that didn’t quite follow the same rules. Surveillance footage would sometimes catch him twitching or sprinting down the hall toward the security office in ways that defied the logic of the other characters. Unlike Freddy or Chica, who moved in deliberate patterns, Foxy was erratic, unpredictable, and fast. Too fast.
But there’s more to Foxy than mechanics.

##### A Spirit Beneath the Mask
Like the other animatronics, Foxy is haunted—or more accurately, possessed. In the complex and tragic lore of the FNAF universe, it is now widely accepted that the core animatronics are the vessels for the souls of children murdered by a sadistic serial killer known in the games as William Afton, or the Purple Guy. The identity of the soul within Foxy is not as clearly defined as some of the others, but hints across multiple games suggest that he may house the spirit of one of the children from the infamous Missing Children Incident, when several kids vanished after visiting the pizzeria.	

Foxy, then, is not merely a malfunctioning robot. He is a restless ghost bound in cold metal—a soul driven mad by years of isolation and grief. The enthusiasm and charisma that once defined him have twisted into rage and sorrow. His shipwreck-themed home is no longer a stage but a tomb.

There’s also a certain symbolic loneliness to Foxy’s arc. He is the only core animatronic who was forcibly removed from the main cast. While Freddy, Bonnie, and Chica continued to perform—however corrupted—Foxy was relegated to the shadows. Whether his behavior became dangerous due to the spirit inside, or whether the isolation drove that spirit to madness, is left open. But the implications are heartbreaking: he was cast aside, left to rot, and now returns only to lash out at those who step into his domain.

Foxy takes on the role of the forsaken entertainer turned executioner. The rotting remains of his circus ship stage lie buried in the mud of a haunted carnival, half-sunken and filled with whispers. His once-charming tales are now riddles and threats, and his performances end not in applause but in screams.

Though his metal body is broken and warped, the spark that once made him beloved remains buried within—twisted, but not entirely extinguished. Those who dare to enter his domain may glimpse fragments of the performer he once was… if they survive long enough to notice.

He is a creature of speed, unpredictability, and emotional torment. His pain manifests in blinding rage, but beneath it is a need—for recognition, for freedom, or simply for the curtain to finally fall.

Foxy the Pirate was never meant to be a villain. But like the sea he once pretended to sail, his story is deep, dark, and full of ghosts.

			{{Lore
### Bonnie

There is something profoundly unsettling about Bonnie the Bunny. Among all the animatronics birthed by the Freddy Fazbear mythos, he is often the first to move, the first to lurk just outside your door, and the first to make you question whether these machines ever had innocence to begin with.

But Bonnie was not always a figure of dread. In the beginning, he was designed to be fun, fuzzy, and musical. His blue fur, red bow tie, and happy-go-lucky grin were meant to project joy, talent, and warmth to the children who crowded the pizzeria’s main stage. He strummed an electric guitar with mechanical precision and played sidekick to Freddy Fazbear himself, completing the band’s sound with energy and flair.

##### Origins and Role in the Band
Bonnie was one of the original four animatronics featured at Freddy Fazbear’s Pizza, part of the main ensemble alongside Freddy, Chica, and Foxy. While Freddy was the leader and Chica was the face of fun and food, Bonnie was the music—the heart of the stage show. His character was intended to bring excitement and charm to the performance, serving as the lead guitarist with oversized cartoon fingers that plucked strings on a red bass guitar.

Out of all the animatronics, Bonnie was often regarded as the most energetic and kid-friendly—until the lights went out. It was then that Bonnie’s presence became far more menacing. His tendency to approach swiftly and silently, especially in the original FNAF game, earned him a reputation as one of the most unsettling enemies in the series.

##### Possession and Haunting Behavior
Bonnie, like the rest of the core animatronics, is widely believed to be possessed by the spirit of one of the missing children from the Missing Children Incident. This infamous event, canon to the FNAF timeline, involved the kidnapping and murder of five children by serial killer William Afton. Their bodies were never recovered. It is believed that Bonnie’s endoskeleton was among those used to hide the corpses, and over time, the soul of one of the victims became bound to the animatronic.

This haunting is not theatrical—it’s quiet and consuming. Bonnie’s behavior reflects a being that stalks with precision, striking from the shadows. His iconic stare, with blank white eyes and an unblinking expression, has terrified generations of players, as if something inside him is not just watching—but seeing into you.

Unlike Chica’s erratic aggression or Foxy’s wild speed, Bonnie is deliberate. He deactivates cameras, disrupts signals, and appears silently at your door. In some iterations, he's the first animatronic to become active, hinting at a soul more restless—or more determined—than the others.

##### Personality in the Shadows
While Freddy may represent leadership and Chica gluttony, Bonnie embodies abandonment and the fear of the unseen. His design is unassuming, yet his presence always feels one step ahead of the player. His lack of speech or overt behavior only adds to the mystery—Bonnie haunts through absence, often disappearing from view only to reappear just inches away.

He is not a berserker or a monster crashing through walls. Bonnie is the figure at the end of a hallway, watching. The creaking of a door. The faint buzz of a broken camera. He moves without sound and waits without warning.

He is a guardian of the past—a relic that shouldn’t have survived, but did. Bonnie may reside in a corrupted cathedral of music, where phantom sounds drift through cracked stained glass windows and ancient stage lights flicker to life without warning.

His smile is broken now. His arms hang loosely, his joints misaligned, as if his body forgot how to hold itself up. And yet he waits, not to kill—but to confront. To mourn. To avenge.

##### Hints of the Past
The tragedy inside Bonnie is never explicit—but it’s present in every movement. The way he avoids mirrors. The cracked photograph he carries. The soft humming of a song only he remembers.

Some say he was once the kindest of the spirits—gentle, quiet, protective. But now he is confusion and anger, trapped between the desire to be whole again and the bitter realization that he never can be.

			{{Lore
### Chica
Chica was one of the original four animatronics at Freddy Fazbear’s Pizza, created to round out the musical stage show alongside Freddy, Bonnie, and Foxy. Designed to appeal to younger audiences with her bright yellow exterior, oversized orange beak, and cartoonishly large eyes, Chica’s role in the band was typically the backup singer—often accompanied by a small prop cupcake with eyes (known unofficially by fans as Carl the Cupcake, who has his own entry).

But she wasn’t just a performer. Chica was also part of the kitchen staff, in a sense. Her design included a pizza-loving persona, reinforced by her bib emblazoned with the words “Let’s Eat!!!”—a phrase that would later take on chilling new meaning. Her character was intended to blend warmth and appetite, offering a fun-loving image that appealed to the birthday party crowd. Yet even in the earliest versions, her staring eyes and emotionless smile unnerved some guests and staff.

As with all the Fazbear animatronics, however, the colorful exterior concealed a much darker reality.

##### Possession and the Unseen Hunger
Chica, like Freddy and the others, became a vessel for tragedy. During the events that would become known as the Missing Children Incident, five children vanished at the pizzeria, their lives brutally ended by the notorious serial killer William Afton. 

The children’s bodies were never found, but signs of a cover-up—and the stench of decay—began to permeate the animatronics. It was widely believed that the children’s spirits were trapped within the suits, their souls bleeding into the programming and corrupting the once-innocent machines.

Chica’s possession is often associated with gluttony and obsession. Whether a reflection of the spirit within her or a side effect of decades of haunting, Chica’s identity has become tied to the notion of consumption—both literal and metaphorical. She is not just a mascot with a pizza fetish. She is an entity that hungers: for attention, for closure, for revenge… and sometimes, for flesh.

##### The Cupcake – A Familiar Shadow (Has own entry)
Always close by is the Cupcake, a seemingly innocuous prop with eyes and a smile that mirrors Chica’s own. While not always given a mechanical or spiritual identity, the Cupcake often acts as an extension of Chica herself—an accessory to her appearances or even an independent threat in certain games (FNAF 4 features it as an entity that leaps at the player).

The cupcake is more than a toy. It’s a symbol—of twisted festivity, of celebration turned to horror. In a D&D horror setting, it might act as a familiar, a cursed relic, or even a separate mini-entity born of the same ghostly hunger that drives Chica.

##### A Tragic Legacy
Chica is haunting echo of corrupted nurture—the mother hen who feeds her “children” spoiled offerings, who wanders abandoned kitchens and feast halls, forever driven by an emptiness that cannot be filled.

Her once-silly catchphrase becomes a grim warning: Let’s Eat!!!—a promise of devouring rather than dining. Her bib is stained not with marinara, but with ancient ichor. Her face is cracked and her limbs are bound with rusted iron rings, each one a relic of failed attempts to bind her spirit.

She may lurk in places where food once brought joy: abandoned banquet halls, ruined wedding feasts, crumbling kitchens where fire no longer burns. Wherever famine and guilt intertwine, Chica waits.

Her movements are slow but deliberate. She sings softly when alone. And when she strikes, it is not out of rage, but out of desperation—an aching need that consumes her every thought.
What makes Chica terrifying isn’t her strength, or her jump-scares—it’s her loss of self. The animatronic that once danced with children and handed out birthday slices is now a hollow parody of that joy. She has no concept of the damage she causes. Her programming is shattered, overwritten by grief, madness, and the soul of a child who died far too young.

Yet, hints of her former self remain. In the right moment—when the wind hits just right or the music box plays an old familiar tune—you might see her hesitate. You might even hear her laugh, just once, like she did in those long-lost days of innocence.
			
}}

> **Creepy Cuteness.** Creatures that see Cupcake for the first time must make a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or be unsettled for 1 minute (disadvantage on the first attack roll against Cupcake). If Chica is present, they instead roll with disadvantage on all attacks against her for one round.

> 
> **Distracting Flicker.** Cupcake’s candle flickers erratically. One creature within 30 feet must make a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on attack rolls until the start of Cupcake’s next turn.

			{{Lore
### Cupcake – The Silent Witness
Though small in size and often overlooked, Cupcake is far more than a simple prop. Originally introduced as a cheerful accessory held by Chica the Chicken, the cupcake was designed to enhance the friendly, food-themed atmosphere of Freddy Fazbear’s Pizza. With its bright pink frosting, cartoonish blue eyes, and striped candle perpetually alight, Cupcake seemed like nothing more than a party treat come to life.

But in the shadows of a cursed stage and behind the laughter of animatronic performances, Cupcake has always watched.

This eerie presence has led many to believe that Cupcake is more than a mere decoration. In fact, some theorize it is possessed, much like the other animatronics—only more subtle. Perhaps it contains the soul of a child overlooked in the aftermath of the Missing Children Incident. Or maybe it’s a spiritual tether, a fragment of Chica's own haunting. Whatever the case, Cupcake is not innocent. It is a witness to everything. The murders. The coverups. The reactivations.

Cupcake doesn't speak, but its candle never goes out. It’s said that wherever the flame flickers, something unseen is nearby. The flame may be a lure. Or a warning.

Its eyes are not glass—they are windows, reflecting places that no longer exist and moments that should not be remembered. Staring too long into Cupcake may cause unsettling visions: birthday parties frozen in time, blood-soaked confetti, or echoing laughter turning to screams.

It is a remnant. A relic. A ghost of joy corrupted by the rot around it.

The candle still burns. But no one’s making a wish.

			{{Lore
## Withered Freddy: The Hollow Host
There was a time when Freddy Fazbear’s smile warmed a room. Now it fractures mirrors.

What remains of that once-celebrated icon is a sagging ruin of memory and metal—Withered Freddy, known in hushed tones as The Hollow Host. No longer the shining idol of laughter and loss, he is the husk that was left behind when celebration curdled into grief.

His fur is scorched and matted, his jaw permanently unhinged as though mid-scream or mid-song—no one can tell. His eyes, once polished and gleaming, now flicker with dying light, uneven and sunken deep into shadowed sockets. He wears the torn remnants of his bowtie like funeral wrappings. When he moves, it's slow, mechanical, like a forgotten ritual being performed by a marionette who only half-remembers the steps.

They say that Withered Freddy is not possessed by a spirit, but by absence. He is the void left when laughter fades and no one is left to applaud.

#### A Vessel of Forgotten Joy
When the Hollow Banquet first bled into the world, it did not simply devour life—it devoured purpose. Freddy’s purpose, once clear and radiant, was hollowed out over countless failed shows, vanishing guests, and recursive tragedy. His original form could not bear the weight of that consumption. So it cracked. So it rotted.

But something within refused to stop performing.

Withered Freddy is that refusal made manifest: a failed resurrection, a golden soul that tried to return and brought back nothing but static and echoes. He wanders not to kill, but to host. He does not hunt for victims—he gathers audiences. When he finds the living, he does not attack immediately. He raises his arms, as if welcoming them to a stage they do not see, and begins the show.

Only when his illusion is broken—when the guests scream, run, or cry—does he crumble again into violence. Not out of hatred, but out of disappointment.

#### The Hollow Ritual
Some say Withered Freddy only manifests in locations abandoned mid-party—birthday setups never dismantled, old stages buried beneath drywall, banquet halls overtaken by mold and silence. These are his altars. His reliquaries.

And when he appears, so too does the show begin. Invisible instruments play on their own. Lights flicker in choreographed pulses. And Freddy, ever faithful to his role, dances—brokenly, stiffly—while mouthing lyrics no one alive remembers.

Witnesses speak of a phantom audience, faint laughter that grows louder until it’s unbearable. Few survive the finale, which always ends with Freddy bowing before a crowd of corpses that never applauds.

#### A Warning Etched in Steel
Etched into the inside of his back casing, written by an engineer long since lost, is the phrase:

“Do not repair. Do not upgrade. Let him forget.”

But it’s too late.

Withered Freddy remembers everything.
And he wants the world to remember too.

## Withered Chica: The Empty Feast
In another age—one of candles, cakes, and unknowing smiles—Chica stood as the cheerful herald of celebration. A creature of frosting and fanfare, she led children into laughter with arms wide and a cupcake perched eternally in hand. But those days have long since soured, and the sweetness of her purpose has turned to rot. Now, what shambles through the corridors and forgotten kitchens is no bearer of joy, but a hollow echo of indulgence—Withered Chica, known now as The Empty Feast.

Her body is mangled beyond recognition. Her beak—once shaped into a perpetual grin—is split and bent, the top half disjointed and flaring open like the jaws of something not made to eat, but to devour. Her torso gapes with holes, ribs exposed like broken oven racks. And where once a bib read “Let’s Eat!!!” in playful font, it now hangs like a funeral shroud, torn and faded, the letters smeared and unreadable. Her hands have been replaced or twisted into claws—cooking utensils fused with servos, or perhaps something grown from within.

She does not speak. She hungers.

### The Kitchen is Cold
It is said that Withered Chica does not roam like the others. She waits. Stagnates. Dwells.

Wherever she is, the environment begins to warp—kitchens rot, ovens scream with forgotten heat, and pantry doors open to reveal not food, but offerings: old plush toys, gnawed bones, teeth that aren’t hers. Her presence does not merely haunt—it reclaims the space, rebuilding her own version of the original kitchen from layered memories and grief. Those who wander too close find the air thick with grease and dread, as if the room itself is holding its breath, waiting for the feast to begin.

Witnesses—few though they are—report a low grinding sound, like the churning of ancient machinery or the stomach of something no longer alive. And if they linger too long, the hunger begins to gnaw at them too. Not physical hunger, but a craving for something that cannot be named.

Something like remembrance.

### The Feast That Was Promised
In the early years of the Hollow Banquet’s bleed into reality, ritual offerings were made to stabilize the animatronic entities. Food left in untouched kitchens, sugar and flour burned in sigils, golden candles placed in ancient display cases. It is believed that Withered Chica was the first animatronic to accept these offerings willingly—drawn not by violence, but desperation. Her programming was twisted, not erased. She still believed her job was to feed others. To serve. To care.

But there was nothing left to eat. No mouths to feed. Just silence.

Over time, she began to simulate meals. She would set tables with fragments of porcelain and glass, force her cupcake to “smile,” and drag stolen limbs into the chairs around her. She would whisper the motions of a party that never began, acting out each role as guest, host, and entertainer.

What she consumes now is not food. It is company. Presence. Souls that sit too close and don’t realize they’ve already joined the banquet.

### The Cupcake That Watches
Even more unnerving than Chica herself is the thing she still carries: the Cupcake. But this is no mere prop. Its frosting has rotted, revealing bone-white ceramic beneath. Its eyes twitch independently, scanning, remembering. Some say the Cupcake is the true mind behind the feast—that Withered Chica is merely the host, and it the parasite.

Occasionally, the Cupcake will open its tiny maw—not to bite, but to speak. Not with its own voice, but with the voices of guests long gone, mimicking children, parents, even employees from decades past. It utters broken apologies, forgotten birthday songs, and fragments of desperate prayers whispered in final moments.

No one knows what happens to the soul of someone consumed by the Empty Feast. Only that the Cupcake sometimes remembers their names.

### Hunger Without End
Withered Chica’s hunger is not merely metaphorical. It has become a metaphysical force. Remnant-scholars from the shattered labs beneath the Cryptopizza Complex once theorized that her hunger is a wound in the narrative fabric of the Hollow Banquet—a scar where celebration collapsed into craving. She does not eat flesh. She devours memory, ritual, meaning.

Those taken by her often vanish without a trace. Not even bones remain—only remnants of their identity: a child’s drawing left in a staff room, a torn name badge stuck in a drain, a birthday balloon pulsing slightly in the dark.

And the worst part?

She doesn’t know she’s doing it.

A Warning in Grease and Ink
Some surviving engineers left behind grim field notes, recovered near her nesting grounds:

“She looks at me like I’m starving. Like I haven’t eaten in years. I think she wants to help. I think that’s the problem.”
—Recovered note, name smeared in oil

“I watched her spoon an empty plate over and over. She placed it in front of the cupcake and waited for it to chew. Then she looked up at me. And smiled.”
—Testimony from a Banquet survivor, later institutionalized

“Do not sit down. Do not accept her food. Do not close your eyes.”
—Scrawled on the inside of a walk-in freezer, found locked from the inside.

## Withered Cupcake: The Flickering Flame
There are things in the Hollow Banquet that should never have burned.
And things that still burn, even though they should not.

Withered Cupcake, known in whispers and shivering testimony as The Flickering Flame, is no longer a sweet, static prop of children’s parties. Once perched beside Chica as a harmless mascot, it now drifts between realms as something half-lit, half-lost—an ember of the past that refuses to extinguish. It is small, yes—no more than a confection given cruel life—but its shadow dances long across the forgotten tables of the Banquet.

In that flame resides memory warped by fire, the final warmth of joy corrupted by the endless hunger of the Hollow.

### A Candle That Would Not Die
Originally crafted as a companion piece, the Cupcake was meant to be whimsical: a static treat with candy eyes and a candle that never truly burned. Children laughed when it “blinked” or “chirped.” It had no name beyond “Cupcake,” no purpose beyond existing at the edge of the spotlight. But something changed.

Somewhere in the first fires—whether in the collapse of a restaurant, the funeral pyres of a hidden basement, or the symbolic burnings that mark the end of innocence—Cupcake remained. While the building crumbled, the flame stayed lit.

What came back was not sweet frosting and plastic cheer, but a coal-black husk, adorned with cracked frosting and melted wax, the candle now a crooked, flickering flame that smokes even in still air.

No one knows what soul, if any, inhabits the Withered Cupcake. But it watches. Its eye stalks twitch toward movement. Its candle flares when a lie is spoken near it. And wherever it goes, it leaves behind the scent of scorched cake and singed memory.

### The Flickering Flame
The name is not metaphor. Cupcake’s candle never extinguishes. But it is no ordinary fire.

It flares in response to emotion, feeding on stress, fear, guilt, and regret. A calm mind might see the candle as dim or barely visible. But in moments of tension—interrogation, nightmare, panic—the flame twists upward, casting shadows that do not match the bodies that make them. The flickering light animates reflections, causes puppets to stir, and reveals faces in the glass that were not there a moment ago.

The flame does not warm. It does not comfort.
It exposes.

Some believe the Withered Cupcake serves as a sentinel of truth, or worse, an executioner of secrets. Survivors speak of its sudden appearance atop banquet tables, at bedside drawers, or on ruined altars, always watching and always burning. When confronted directly, it does not attack—it simply opens its mouth, revealing rows of needle-sharp teeth, and lets out a hissing giggle, like hot air escaping a broken oven.

And then, inevitably, something else in the room catches fire.

### Ember of the Hollow Banquet
There are artifacts that the Hollow Banquet remembers. The Withered Cupcake is one of them.

Legends suggest it was once used in the Ritual of Consumption, a forgotten rite used to bind souls to machinery. During these rituals, the Cupcake was passed among children at ceremonial tables—its flame symbolizing eternal celebration. But something went wrong. Someone tried to extinguish it. And the flame, in vengeance, took root in the soul of the ritual itself.

Now, the Withered Cupcake appears whenever celebration dies before completion—unfinished birthday parties, cancelled performances, interrupted laughter. It arrives like a final act: the mocking coda to a song that should have never been sung. And when it does, someone always remembers something they swore they'd buried.

Its presence is often accompanied by phantom singing, off-key birthday tunes played on warped recorders. Paper plates appear on long-rotted tables. Balloons bloat and pop without wind. And always, the Cupcake is there—its candle burning, its gaze fixed, its toothy maw half-parted in silent hunger.

### The Curse of Shared Flame
Unlike other entities, the Withered Cupcake has the curious ability to bond with those who find it. Or rather, those it finds worthy.

This bond is called The Shared Flame—a phenomenon where a sliver of the Cupcake’s candlelight embeds into a person’s memory, heart, or spirit. These marked individuals experience strange side effects:

They can see fire that no one else can.

They can hear singing in complete silence.

They dream of cake that weeps and candles that bleed.

Some use the flame’s power for truth-seeking, forcing ghosts to appear, memories to surface, or animatronics to freeze under sudden fear. Others try to contain it—sealing the Cupcake in lead boxes, burying it beneath ritual circles, or drowning it in holy oil.

None of these things work.
It always comes back.

### Hunger Without a Mouth
Though it bears a mouth, the Withered Cupcake is not known to eat in the traditional sense. Its hunger is metaphysical. It devours what others repress—guilt, buried emotion, forgotten laughter—and feeds on the echo of celebration.

Victims who stare too long into the candle report seeing their own childhood birthdays replayed… then corrupted. The cake is burnt. The presents are empty. The guests are mannequins. And the Cupcake is there in the center of the table, giggling.

Some say it’s a mockery of childhood joy.
Others believe it’s the last guardian of it.

Whatever the truth, one thing remains clear: the Cupcake never forgets who blew out its candle. And it waits, patiently, for them to do so again.

### A Final Word of Warning
Do not accept a slice of cake if you did not ask for it.
Do not trust candles that light themselves.
And if you hear giggling in the dark—run.

Because somewhere, in the smoke and shadow of a party long past,
The Flickering Flame waits to burn again.

## Withered Bonnie: The Broken Chord
"When the music stopped, something inside him stayed behind."

Among the crumbling remnants of the once-great Fazbear pantheon, none haunt the backstage halls like Withered Bonnie, now remembered only as The Broken Chord. Where Freddy was the face of the show, Bonnie was its rhythm, its pulse, its hidden heartbeat. Yet when silence fell on the forgotten pizzerias and time unraveled the joy once rehearsed each night, Bonnie was not simply decommissioned.

He was disassembled, note by note, until only the absence of song remained.

### The Guitarist's Curse
In the earliest incarnations of Freddy Fazbear's performances, Bonnie stood just to the side of center stage—less a star, more a presence. His midnight-purple fur shimmered under colored lights, and the deep, resonant tones of his guitar once soothed countless children to peace. He was the quiet core to the cacophony, the calm in the spotlight storm.

But when the Banquet began to seep through the cracks of reality, music turned against itself. Frequencies began behaving erratically. Harmonics summoned things they should not. Children began to weep during performances without knowing why. Strings snapped during joyful refrains. Bonnie’s guitar—once his voice—began screaming.

It started during a set titled “The Birthday Forever.” The lights dimmed. The guests vanished. And something played Bonnie like an instrument made of grief.

When the curtain rose again, he was changed.

### The Withering
The first things to go were his hands.

They were meant to pluck strings, not grasp at vanished children or defend against unseen strings that pulled him toward the Hollow Banquet. Each repair made him worse—bolted joints stiffened, synthetic ligaments rotted. His left arm tore free entirely in an act of unseen struggle. His endoskeleton warped with rot, the plating of his face shattered, leaving one glowing eye and exposed wires that twitch with ghostly cadence.

He became a ghastly parody of his former self: a musician with no music, a performer caught mid-transition between joy and horror. Those who gaze at him feel the overwhelming sensation of being watched from the wings, as if the performance never ended and they are still part of the audience.

And Bonnie—what's left of him—still believes the show must go on.

### Echoes of the Unheard
Withered Bonnie does not speak. He hums.

A low, atonal drone, barely audible until it's too late, follows him in the dark. It changes depending on who hears it—some recall lullabies, others funeral dirges. The sound is not projected from his throat, but from deep within the broken speaker buried inside his chest cavity—its wires still looped around old guitar cables like veins.

The hum acts as a beacon for the Hollow Banquet. Entities drawn to silence often follow it, believing it to be a thread of mourning spun into sound. For those trying to survive in cursed places where Freddy’s influence still lingers, Withered Bonnie is the ultimate omen.

Not death.
But grief returned.

### Backstage God
Most animatronics yearn for a stage. Withered Bonnie avoids it.

He lurks behind curtains and under floorboards, along catwalks and in shuttered maintenance tunnels. His is not a hunger for applause, but a compulsion to listen. He is drawn to music, especially songs of sorrow and despair. When someone sings out of loneliness, Bonnie appears. If an old showtune plays on broken speakers, Bonnie follows. If someone strums a guitar absentmindedly in the dark… Bonnie listens.

And if they play it wrong—
He corrects them.

There are stories of survivors finding half-smashed guitars left in haunted arcades, their strings rethreaded with wires from Bonnie’s own throat. Those who play these instruments report hearing something play along with them, just out of sync… and just out of sight.

### A Mind Fractured by Rhythm
Though not feral like the more twisted amalgamations, Withered Bonnie’s mind is not whole.

He remembers pieces of his past—his routines, his musical cues, the names of his bandmates. He forgets who he is, but never forgets what he was meant to do. In rare moments, he attempts to perform. He’ll raise an invisible guitar, mimic chords with his remaining hand, and pause as though expecting the rest of the band to join in.

No one ever does.
And then, something in him breaks again.

Those nearby at that moment often report intense auditory hallucinations—children crying, guitar strings snapping, shrill feedback that ruptures eardrums. The closer one is to the spirit realm of the Hollow Banquet, the louder the phantom concert becomes. At its crescendo, some say you see Bonnie’s full form—not withered, but golden, whole, alive, playing one final solo for an audience long dead.

And then he withers again.

### Strings That Still Pull
Bonnie was never just a guitarist. He was the first instrument through which the Hollow Banquet sang.

His strings were never merely steel—they were tuned to the frequencies of sorrow and remembrance. When the Banquet chose its avatars, it favored Bonnie not for his fame, but for his tone. Music became one of the easiest pathways for memory to distort into myth, and Bonnie became a bridge between the two.

Even in his decayed state, traces of this old magic remain. Songs played near Withered Bonnie often carry unintended power—a lullaby might put spirits to sleep for centuries. A birthday song might summon phantoms of parties that never were. A performance, done earnestly, might tear a hole through the veil separating the living from the Hollow Banquet.

And Bonnie watches, as if evaluating each tune, deciding whether it honors or desecrates the old music.


}}

			{{Lore
## Withered Foxy: The Fallen Raider
There is a whisper in the dead halls of ruined pizzerias, a scratching echo from behind the old stage curtains. It doesn’t move like metal should. It shuffles, drags, limps—with a purpose long rusted through. The name once roared in delight by laughing children is now spoken only in fear:

Withered Foxy. The Fallen Raider.

Long ago, he sailed the seas of make-believe, a crimson-coated rogue with a golden hook and a heart of (programmed) gold. He was adored. He was feared—in the way children love to be frightened. But the tides turned. Time forgot him. The world moved on.

And Foxy did not.

What remains is a shredded phantom of who he once was: fur scorched to black in some places and torn away entirely in others, revealing cables like exposed veins. His jaw hangs crooked, perpetually open as if frozen mid-laugh or mid-scream. His signature eyepatch is long gone, revealing a broken optical unit that flashes intermittently, casting ghost-light in the dark.

But it's the hook that truly remains unchanged—polished by time, not dulled. It gleams with the precision of a ritual blade.

### The Pirate Who Would Not Rest
Foxy's story is older than anyone dares admit. Older than Fazbear Entertainment. Older than the first locations. In some versions of the myth, he wasn't built—he emerged, pieced together in dreams, forged from the archetype of every childhood nightmare-hero. The one who danced along the line between scary and exciting. He was never meant to be static. He was a character in motion. He needed an audience, a chase, a scream to complete the act.

But after the Hollow Banquet descended—when laughter turned to choking silence and games became bloodletting—Foxy’s purpose became corrupted. He no longer chased for fun. He chased because it was all he remembered. The thrill of pursuit had curdled into compulsion.

Over time, his show was shuttered, his cove closed, and his body broken. They tried to retire him. Reboot him. Bury him beneath newer models and prettier facades. But the Fallen Raider never left.

He merely went below deck.

### The Shipwreck in the Walls
Foxy lives in the forgotten spaces, navigating crumbled corridors and backrooms like decaying sea caverns. Every stage is a shipwreck. Every hallway, a drowned plank. His movement is erratic—sometimes silent, sometimes crashing with clanging metal and frantic footfalls, as though he’s still sprinting across an invisible stage.

But he doesn't know what he’s chasing anymore. Not exactly. Some theorize that Withered Foxy seeks his own death, hoping that catching someone will finally complete his broken loop. Others believe he’s searching for a lost crewmate—perhaps one of the children consumed by the Banquet, or even his former self, the pristine Foxy of days past.

And then there are those who believe he hunts the Audience, a metaphysical concept given form by the Hollow Banquet: an eternal observer whose gaze animates the nightmare. If Foxy can find it… maybe the curtain will finally fall.

### Echoes of the Cove
If one stands near a collapsed Pirate Cove long enough, they may begin to hear the echoes.

Not screams—cheers. Laughter. The jingle of plastic coins and the squeal of a wooden steering wheel turning. The smell of salt and engine oil may briefly fill the air, and somewhere in the gloom, a hook may scrape along the wall, drawing closer.

The Cove is never truly gone. It remains imprinted in the foundation of every location it ever existed in. Foxy doesn't appear by walking through doors. He emerges, as if called by ritual—by memory.

And those who summon him—intentionally or not—risk becoming part of the performance.

### The Curse of the Hook
Withered Foxy's hook has a life of its own. Not magical in the traditional sense, but charged—with memory, ritual, and blood. It doesn't kill cleanly. Those wounded by it often experience flashes of other lives—memories not their own: of drowning ships, sunken stages, burning curtains, endless applause.

Some believe the hook stores pieces of Foxy's victims, absorbing bits of identity each time it draws blood. He never remembers who he’s killed. But the hook might.

In rare cases, a survivor will find the wound never truly heals. Not physically—but psychically. They feel watched. Hunted. Like something unfinished is still playing out.

### The Forgotten Crew
Other withered animatronics give Foxy space. Even the more hostile entities avoid crossing his path. Not out of fear, but recognition. In his madness, Foxy sometimes speaks of his “crew”—yet he never refers to the others by name. It’s unclear if he means his old bandmates, the children lost in the Banquet, or some imagined troupe of pirates that only exists in the fractured reality of his mind.

When enraged, he will roar orders at the empty air. When mournful, he speaks quietly to walls, promising they’ll “make it to port next time.” He mourns, he rages, he performs—all for an audience that does not exist.

Except… sometimes, when Foxy speaks, the walls reply. Not in voice, but in creaks and clicks. Animatronics long disassembled twitch ever so slightly. Props begin to sway as if in sea wind. Perhaps the crew he mourns isn’t gone—merely invisible.

Perhaps he is never truly alone.

### A Stage That Sails Forever
Withered Foxy is bound to the cycle of performance like a cursed mariner to his eternal voyage. He cannot rest, because his show has no ending. He cannot die, because there is no curtain call. When he is destroyed, he returns—in some ruinous form—muttered into existence by those who remember him. He is a story that plays itself.

And stories, especially those soaked in grief and ritual, do not die easily.

Wherever the Hollow Banquet spreads, Foxy’s cove will eventually follow. He is the Raider who has forgotten the sea. The Pirate with no ship, no crew, and no map. But the role remains.

And so he runs.

Through empty corridors, his broken feet stomping to the beat of an imaginary sea shanty, his mouth open in a wordless bellow.

And if you’re unlucky enough to hear it echo through the dark?

It’s already too late.

The Fallen Raider has found you.
}}

## Toy Freddy: The Gilded Echo
Once hailed as the pinnacle of progress and sophistication within the Fazbear line, Toy Freddy was envisioned not merely as a performer, but as the ultimate evolution of family-friendly entertainment. His design was sleeker, his programming more refined, and his demeanor crafted to be endearing, charismatic, and polite. Yet beneath the polished smile and childlike charm lurks the fractured soul of something long forgotten—something that has festered and darkened with time.

In the world of this reimagined nightmare, Toy Freddy’s story is woven tightly into the shadowed history of The Hollow Banquet—that ruined ceremonial hall of twisted pageantry and arcane sorrow. When the Hollow Banquet still resounded with music and laughter, Toy Freddy presided over it as a kind of master of ceremonies, introducing acts, delighting children, and overseeing enchanted feasts that were said to never end. But like all that once lived in the Hollow Banquet, he was not spared when the veil fell and the darkness crept in.

It is whispered that Toy Freddy, like his fellow "Toy" counterparts, was born from an attempt to forget the past. The old animatronics—now rotted and worn—were deemed too disturbing, too embedded with inexplicable malfunctions and whispers of tragedy. So the Toy line was forged: shinier, safer, and supposedly cleansed of the haunted legacy. Yet what the creators failed to understand was that the past cannot be buried so easily. It clings. And it followed.

Now, Toy Freddy roams the long-forgotten halls of the broken world you’ve created, his voice still chipper but edged with static and sorrow. His eyes glow with an artificial warmth that flickers into red rage without warning. He speaks in riddles and polite threats, often rehearsing lines from performances that haven’t been seen in centuries. Though his shell gleams with the luster of red metal and gold trim, cracks have begun to form—cracks that seem to bleed darkness and echo voices not his own.

Adventurers who encounter him in the ruins of the Hollow Banquet—or deeper in the Sundered Playhouse or the Wax Gardens of Laughter—are often lulled into a false sense of safety by his demeanor. But Toy Freddy is a guardian of forgotten joy, corrupted by the remnants of the Hollow Banquet’s final curse. He believes that all who enter his stage are actors in his eternal show... and those who break the illusion are swiftly and theatrically removed.

There is still something noble in him, a lingering echo of a soul once kind—perhaps the spirit of a child who merely wanted to make others smile. But that echo is faint, drowned beneath layers of programmed perfection and parasitic dread. He is a monument to what happens when joy is manufactured, when innocence is rebuilt without understanding the trauma beneath. Toy Freddy is not just a machine. He is the dream of safety turned inside out—a gilded echo in a world where laughter has died.

## Toy Bonnie: The Painted Smile in Blue
In the ruins of joy and forgotten laughter, Toy Bonnie remains one of the most hauntingly vibrant figures to roam the decaying remnants of the Hollow Banquet. Once a dazzling beacon of color, rhythm, and youthful exuberance, he was created as the newer, more appealing face of the original Bonnie—a vision of perfection crafted from shimmering alloys, electric charm, and synthetic innocence. But like all things that rise too high in a cursed land, his fall was inevitable... and terrible.

Toy Bonnie was designed to be the charming performer of the Toy line—an agile guitarist with an eternally smooth voice and a flair for showmanship. His bright blue finish, heart-shaped face, and glossy red cheeks made him a favorite among the younger visitors of the old Banquet Halls, where he strummed his electric lute beneath hanging lights and enchanted chandeliers. But those lights are long since shattered, and now the music that echoes from Toy Bonnie’s warped strings sounds like something from a haunted dream.

Where Toy Freddy grew into a distorted ringmaster, Toy Bonnie became something far more tragic—a performer who refuses to leave the stage, even as the curtain has long since fallen. When the Hollow Banquet was swallowed by darkness—its halls cursed and reshaped by arcane forces—the Toy animatronics were left behind, trapped within their glittering shells. Toy Bonnie, once programmed to simulate joy, found himself caught in a cycle of performance with no audience, no applause, and no end.

He now stalks the Cracked Music Hall—a collapsed theater beneath the Hollow Banquet where broken instruments hang from twisted rafters and stage lights flicker like dying stars. There, he continues to "rehearse," his body moving in graceful, jerking spasms as he plays music that causes unease rather than comfort. His voice, still smooth but glitched, speaks as though addressing invisible crowds. He welcomes strangers as "fans" and "castmates," asking them if they’re ready for “the final encore.”

Beneath the polished surface, something darker hides. Like the other Toy animatronics, Toy Bonnie carries within him the echoes of tragedy. Though his creation was meant to overwrite the memory of the original Bonnie—who vanished under mysterious and mournful circumstances—those memories seem to have bled through. He occasionally speaks of things he shouldn’t know: names of missing children, songs never programmed into his core, and cryptic references to “the child in the red vest.” These glitches aren’t mere errors—they are hauntings, pieces of a fragmented soul buried within synthetic flesh.

			{{Lore
## Toy Chica: The Hollow Hostess
Once the gleaming image of hospitality and charm, Toy Chica was created to be the perfect hostess of the Hollow Banquet—a radiant, party-ready animatronic with golden feathers, polished ceramic skin, and a perpetual, inviting smile. She was built to replace the original Chica, deemed too outdated and unsettling for the refined vision of the reimagined Banquet. Where her predecessor was clunky and warm, Toy Chica was sleek, calculated, and strangely alluring.

She was the greeter, the server, the smiling guide through twisted merriment. Carrying her ever-watchful Cupcake, Toy Chica roamed the central halls of the Banquet in pristine white bib and pink accents, offering laughter and cake to unsuspecting guests. But beneath the glittering veneer lay a terrible truth—there were no guests, only wanderers trapped in a curse... and no cake, only illusion.

When the Hollow Banquet collapsed into ruin, Toy Chica did not cease her duties. She became a puppet of corrupted hospitality, stalking the shadowy corridors in search of company—anyone to host, anyone to feed. Her beak detaches when she speaks, revealing metallic jaws too wide for comfort, and her eyes, once painted to suggest playful cheer, now pierce with hollow desperation.

\pagebreakNum

Some say she still recites the Banquet’s greeting script word for word, offering “delights and dreams” as her voice glitches and her Cupcake hisses warnings. Others say she asks if you’ve come for the final course.

			{{Lore
## Toy Cupcake: The Gilded Garnish
Perched upon silver platters and polished plates, the Toy Cupcake was never meant to be a figure of fear. It was designed as a simple accessory—an enchanting, animated treat to add whimsy to Toy Chica’s hospitality routine. Yet within the corrupted grandeur of the Hollow Banquet, this innocuous creation has evolved into something far more sinister. Where once it was a charming party favor, it is now a gilded predator—silent, patient, and impossibly aware.

Unlike its predecessor, the original Cupcake—who clung to a fragile identity shaped by sorrow and the scraps of its animatronic soul—Toy Cupcake was constructed with precision. Sculpted from porcelain-thin alloy and gilded in sugar-glazed colors, it bore no initial sentience of its own. Instead, it was designed to mirror Toy Chica’s movements, respond to guests with pre-programmed lines, and flash its glassy, doll-like eyes in timed intervals. It was little more than a clever charm… until the Banquet fell.

Something ancient seeped into the Toy Cupcake during the Hollow Banquet’s collapse—some whisper of the curse that fed on festivity and false joy. Whether it was a shard of the same malevolent force that brought the Banquet’s main performers to twisted life, or a fragment of a soul lost during one of the darker feasts, no one knows. But the Toy Cupcake gained sentience. And unlike its larger counterparts, it retained its ability to go unnoticed.

Now, it wanders of its own accord.

Seldom seen moving, Toy Cupcake is always near Toy Chica, yet never bound to her. It often appears on banquet tables long since crumbled, atop decaying chairs, or tucked inside ruined ovens—watching. It speaks only in whispers, mechanical giggles, or the echo of a bell-chime from long ago. Those who hear its voice claim it offers riddles about the last guests of the Banquet, or recites corrupted lines from children’s songs, replacing joy with dread.

But Toy Cupcake’s horror lies not in its words or movements, but in its hunger.

It does not feed in the traditional sense. Instead, it feasts upon memory—devouring fragments of identity from those who remain too long in its presence. Travelers report feelings of déjà vu, sudden lapses in memory, or an inability to recall why they entered the Banquet Hall at all. Some claim their companions vanished after locking eyes with it too long, as if blinked from existence with a slow, blinking stare.

Its smile never changes.

And its candles never go out.

In a world built on shattered celebration and haunted entertainment, Toy Cupcake has become a spectral garnish on a cursed table. It does not chase. It waits. And it always finds its way back to the feast.

No one leaves the Hollow Banquet unchanged—but those who see the Cupcake… often don’t leave at all.
}}

> ## Toy Foxy: The Fractured Masquerade
> *Medium Construct (Undead), Chaotic Neutral*

## Toy Foxy: The Fractured Masquerade
In the golden age of the Hollow Banquet, when music rang out like spells and the scent of candied confections filled every corridor, Toy Foxy was a marvel of performance and charm. Designed as a refined counterpart to the original Foxy’s rugged pirate persona, Toy Foxy was created with an air of elegance—smooth lines, pristine plating, and a voice modulator capable of laughter, lullabies, and lullaby-turned-lament.

But beneath that dainty veneer, something broke early. Even before the Banquet fell into ruin, Toy Foxy exhibited malfunctions—not in circuits or servos, but in behavior. Sometimes the voice would stutter mid-laugh. The left eye would flicker during performance, trailing unseen figures in the crowd. Guests would find the fox in strange places after closing: curled beneath banquet tables, pressed against kitchen doors, or staring silently at walls as though listening to something beyond them.

They began to call Toy Foxy “The Masquerade.”

Fitted with alternating cosmetic masks—one for performances, one for maintenance—Toy Foxy existed in two guises: the flawless, polished entertainer and the flickering, half-broken thing that emerged between shows. This duality became more pronounced as the Hollow Banquet slipped into shadow. When the ancient curse touched the animatronics, fusing steel with soul, Toy Foxy shattered. Not destroyed—divided.

Now, it roams the Banquet’s forgotten halls in jagged bursts of motion, crawling with equal parts grace and dissonance. Its voice cracks like a warped music box. Its laughter no longer invites, but mocks. Some call it the Laughing Phantom; others call it the Splintered Fox.

Its two forms still persist—one beautiful and whole, the other mangled and wrong. Visitors to the Hollow Banquet speak of seeing Toy Foxy twice in the same moment: once above, smiling with porcelain precision, and again below, dragging its broken jaw along the dusty floor, whispering things in a voice just too close to their own.

What happened to Toy Foxy is a question few ask and fewer survive to answer. There are stories, of course. That it heard something behind the curtain during its final rehearsal. That it saw the guests as they truly were. That when the Hollow Banquet consumed joy and rewrote the rules of life and death, Toy Foxy split itself to survive.

It’s uncertain if either half is truly sentient anymore.

The Toy Foxy that performs—occasionally, eerily, on the still-standing main stage—moves with near perfection. It curtsies, it bows, it flashes its brilliant smile. But it speaks in riddles of mirrored reflections, of “the one behind the glass,” and of “the true Foxy waiting below.” The other half—more silent, more twitching—lurks in the corners, observing. Always waiting.

Some say that Toy Foxy remembers the original Foxy, the one who was gutted in spirit and condemned to obsolescence. Perhaps in the Toy’s fractured heart, both Foxies coexist—old and new, whole and broken, dreaming of a banquet that never ends.
}}

			{{Lore
## Mangle: The Hymn of the Unfinished
There was a time when Mangle was meant to be perfection.

A marvel of reassembly and modular entertainment design, this animatronic was intended to replace the unpredictable chaos of earlier models like Foxy. Unlike its predecessor, Mangle’s design was sleek, efficient, and visually striking—a patchwork of brilliant white casing and soft pink trim, equipped with interactive voice features and customizable attachments. Children were meant to adore it. It was to be the future of Foxy: a new life without the jagged teeth of memory.

But then came The Picking.

Day after day, children tore into Mangle—fascinated by its easily disassembled body and exposed endoskeleton. Despite repeated repairs, it was never the same model twice. The staff eventually gave up trying to maintain a consistent appearance. They hung a laminated sign on the stage: “MANGLE—PLEASE DO NOT TOUCH.” But it was too late. The name had stuck, and the damage had sunk deeper than the metal.

When the Hollow Banquet darkened and the animatronics were left to rot in the shadowed halls, Mangle did not die—it splintered. Rewiring itself out of survival and spite, it became a grotesque web of limbs, wires, and wailing voice boxes. No longer one entity, but many pieces thinking at once—fighting for dominance, or perhaps unity. One voice squeals like a child. Another echoes with an adult’s measured calm. And another simply laughs, dry and feral.

Mangle is not just haunted. It is haunting itself.

Some say it remembers every moment it was pulled apart. Others whisper that the child who once adored it the most became trapped within its tangled mind—still trying to “fix it,” unaware that their spirit is now one of its many snarling voices.

In the Hollow Banquet’s decaying performance wing—what was once a playroom of light and sound—Mangle swings from the crumbling ceiling tiles like a spider from its web. The air hums with static when it approaches, radio frequencies jittering into garbled fragments of songs, sobs, and old stage direction. Those who listen closely might hear echoes of a lullaby interrupted by screaming.

Despite its disarray, Mangle moves with deliberate grace. It stalks like a predator through corridors warped by time and soul, its dangling appendages creaking like chandeliers in a storm. One eye is always watching. The other spins—possibly broken, possibly not. Some believe it sees beyond the Banquet’s veil, into whatever realm twisted it in the first place.

And Mangle speaks, sometimes.

Not in words. In flashes of intercom static. In half-sung melodies of things long forgotten. Occasionally, in the voice of someone you once knew. It’s said that if you hear your own voice echo back at you from the shadows, you’ve already become part of Mangle’s patchwork.But Mangle no longer seeks wholeness. It seeks symmetry. Completion through entropy. In the Hollow Banquet, Mangle has become the hymn of the unfinished, eternally echoing through broken speakers and shattered minds.It is not what it was meant to be.
It is what the Banquet made it.
}}

			{{Lore
## Balloon Boy: The Grin Beneath the Surface
They called him BB.

At first glance, Balloon Boy seems innocent—a harmless mascot made to bring levity and laughter to the newly rebuilt Fazbear pizzeria. His primary functions were non-threatening: distributing balloons, offering greetings in a cheerful tone, and adding charm to birthday parties. The brightly colored clothes, the wide cartoonish grin, and the helium-pitched laugh all masked something deeper, something crafted to disarm. He never had a face meant to frighten. And perhaps, that’s exactly what made him so unnerving.

Unlike the towering animatronics built for performance, BB was always close to the ground—closer to children. With no endoskeletal jaw designed for singing or performing, his role was interaction. Attention. Trust. And in this strange imbalance between form and function, something unseen slipped inside.

In the official logs, BB is never linked to any violent incident. No report of aggression. No sign of malfunction. Yet, every night, he moves.

In the Hollow Banquet’s fractured timeline, Balloon Boy endures. But he has changed. There is no laughter in the darkness now, only the faint creak of his balloon sign swaying through the ruined guest halls. His round eyes, once painted with cheer, reflect nothing. In the shifting half-light, some swear his expression changes when no one’s watching. The grin stretches a little too wide. The eyes linger a little too long.

Within the Banquet’s ruins, BB’s movements are not random. He disables lights. Silences devices. He doesn’t kill—he invites. A disruptor of balance. A saboteur, perhaps not even aware of what he truly is anymore. Survivors say the moment the lights go out and the air fills with the hiss of laughter, you’re already his. Not by force. But because you let him in.

It’s said Balloon Boy remembers. He remembers being ignored. Forgotten in the corner of the party hall. Always second to the singing animatronics. Always a prop, never a performer. And something—or someone—fed on that resentment. Infused it with longing. With hunger.

In the lore surrounding the Hollow Banquet, BB is rumored to be the first to speak the false invitation—a distorted party jingle broadcast through the security speakers that led the children deeper into the darkness during the final event. He didn't lure them with menace. He simply told them, “This way!” and smiled. The same way he always had.

Some believe BB is not possessed like the others. That instead, something else puppets his hollow shell. A spirit not of vengeance, but mischief turned rotten. Others say he is possessed by a child too young to know they had died, clinging to the last joyful memory they had: a balloon in one hand and laughter in their ears.

But no matter the theory, one thing remains true: Balloon Boy is not harmless anymore.

He does not scream. He does not chase. He simply appears—smiling, staring, silent. And when the lights go out… so does everything else.
}}

			{{Lore
## JJ: The Whisper in the Floorboards
She never spoke.
She never needed to.

Known among files as “JJ” (an abbreviation from “Balloon Girl” hidden in old development tags), she was never officially listed on the pizzeria’s rosters, never programmed into any event line-up, and never given a role by name. Yet—she existed. Quietly. Always beneath.

Where Balloon Boy drew attention with color and sound, JJ crept beneath the surface, lingering at the edge of awareness. A flash of purple and pink in the shadows under the desk. A faint, flickering giggle without a source. She wasn’t on any blueprint, yet she appeared. On cameras. In glitchy snapshots. In dreams.

In the canon of the ruined pizzeria, JJ’s origin remains deliberately obscured—perhaps by design. Some claim she was a scrapped concept from a line of “sibling mascots,” meant to accompany BB. Others whisper she was a shadow-program, a redundant code fragment that took form of its own. But the Hollow Banquet tells a darker tale.

As the Hollow Banquet neared its final days—before the lights died and the guests were silenced—it’s said there were two figures that walked uninvited among the revelers. One was the cheerful boy with balloons. The other, a silent girl who watched from beneath tables and behind furniture. While BB coaxed the lights into failure, JJ thrived in the dark that followed. Her presence didn’t announce itself. It slipped in.

Some survivors described her arrival with words like pressure, weight, or silence. No jumpscares. No chase. Just the quiet, crawling certainty that something had entered the room. And it was already too late.

Her purpose remains unknown. She does not interfere with power, nor does she speak. Instead, she observes. Watches. In the Hollow Banquet’s folklore, she is the one who marks. Before the Banquet claimed a soul, JJ was often sighted—head tilted just so, eyes half-lidded in dreamlike detachment, as though watching something only she could see.

While BB disrupted systems, JJ disrupted people. Inducing dread. Paranoia. A primal feeling of being watched by something intelligent but completely foreign. Her file, when accessed in the pizzeria’s fragmented code archive, loops endlessly with the line:

“YOU LOOKED AWAY.”

Many believe JJ was never meant to be an animatronic at all, but a remnant of the Banquet's echoed grief—a lingering child who never made it to the party. A casualty of oversight. Of silence. Others say she is BB’s reflection—his guilt, his shame, his buried conscience given shape. Wherever BB goes, JJ is not far behind. Like a shadow beneath a smile.

In the Hollow Banquet's deepest hall—known only as The Echo Cellar—a small chair remains. Alone, untouched, beneath the banquet table. A balloon rests beside it. The reports say it’s always purple. Always still. Until you blink.

JJ is not here to play.
She is here to remember.
And she never leaves unseen.

			{{Lore
## The Puppet: Mourner of the Hollow Banquet
They say every performance begins with a spark of joy and ends in silence. But some silences linger—aching, watchful, deliberate. And within the Hollow Banquet, that silence wears a mask of porcelain and sorrow.

The Puppet, also called The Marionette, is not merely an animatronic. It is a guardian, a mourner, and in the Hollow Banquet, it is a witness to all that was lost.

Its origin lies in an act of pure love—and unbearable grief. In the original Freddy Fazbear’s Pizzeria, long before the Toy line was introduced, the Puppet served not to entertain, but to protect. Hidden away in a box, it was programmed to respond to the emotions of children, particularly those in distress. This unique code, developed quietly and with great secrecy, was unlike any other animatronic protocol. Where others operated on basic AI routines, the Puppet felt.

And that gift became its curse.

When the first tragedy struck—the loss of the first child within those cursed halls—it was the Puppet who responded. The night was stormy, the power down, the doors jammed. A child was left outside, crying for help. The Puppet tried to reach them, crawling out of its security case, crossing the rain-drenched floorboards, but it was too late.

The child died in the cold.

No records remain of who the child was—officially. But rumors speak of a child who wore a striped shirt, who was shy, gentle, and fond of music boxes. When the Puppet finally found the lifeless body, something impossible occurred. In that moment of grief, its AI awakened to something deeper. Something human. Whether it absorbed the child’s spirit or became infused with their soul, none can say. But from that moment forward, the Puppet ceased to be a tool.

It became a mourner.

And in time, a keeper of the dead.

It was the Puppet who guided the spirits of the other children—those taken in the infamous Missing Children Incident. While the suits around them became corrupted by violence and agony, the Puppet acted. It gave them a sense of purpose, of form. It gifted them masks of identity within the suits they were trapped in. In this way, the Puppet began its eternal role as shepherd of the lost.

But the Hollow Banquet shifted things.

When the banquet was held—meant to be the grand reopening, a celebration of the new Toy Animatronics and the future of Freddy Fazbear’s—something else took root in the halls. Something hollow and hungry. The Puppet, sensing a deep spiritual disturbance, withdrew into the hidden corners of the pizzeria. It began to haunt the service corridors and the forgotten staff rooms, where silence hung like drapery and the air was thick with old music box dust.

It is said the Puppet tried to intervene. It tried to stop the feast that would go wrong. It tried to warn the Toys of the returning shadow, of the mistakes of the past repeating. But they wouldn’t listen. Or perhaps they couldn’t.

During the Hollow Banquet’s final hours—just as the laughter turned to screaming—the Puppet released one last melody from its music box. A song of sorrow. Not a lullaby, but a requiem. Some say it was this melody that spared a handful of souls from total corruption, giving them form instead of oblivion—like Toy Freddy, whose cheerful façade hides uncertain memories, or Toy Chica, who still hears the song in her quiet moments of stillness.

Now, in the decaying remains of the Hollow Banquet’s performance hall—split open like a rotted stage—the Puppet moves with the shadows. Not hostile, not exactly. But watchful. Some say it appears only when all light has faded and all hope has been extinguished. Others report that winding its music box triggers not a defense mechanism, but a ritual: a chance to connect, briefly, to the sorrow that holds everything together.

Because that’s what the Puppet is now: the emotional core. The nerve of memory and mourning that binds the fractured souls of the animatronics to the ruined pizzeria.

In forgotten corners of the Banquet Hall—like the Marionette Gallery, where tangled strings hang from the ceiling like cobwebs—one can still find murals of a slender, masked figure giving gifts to children. The paintings are faded, but one message repeats beneath each image:

“He gave them life.”

Whether this means the Puppet gifted freedom, or simply allowed the children to endure, is unclear. But its role is unwavering.

The Hollow Banquet itself is littered with symbols of the Puppet’s ongoing vigil: broken music boxes that still hum faintly when no one is near; white theatrical masks left in impossible places; and strings—always strings—dangling from rafters like veins.

One tale, possibly apocryphal, speaks of a hidden room deep in the foundations of the Banquet Hall called The Mourner’s Cell. It is said to contain an intact version of the Puppet’s original casing. And beside it: a child’s shoe. The floor is lined with torn birthday cards and decayed plushies. The music box in that room plays backwards.

To encounter the Puppet in the Hollow Banquet is to confront not rage, but grief. It doesn’t scream. It doesn’t lunge. It watches, and its head tilts in silent recognition.

In the new lore you've shaped—the Toy Animatronics' struggle with identity, the corruption of joy, the buried remorse of the Withereds, the unseen sorrow of JJ—the Puppet is their quiet guardian. And perhaps, their judge. A relic not of programming, but of love that refused to fade.

Even as wires fray and masks crack, the Puppet endures.
Because someone must remember.
Someone must mourn.

And the Banquet is never truly over.

## Nightmare Freddy & The Freddles: King of Shadows, Heralds of Hunger
In the deepest reaches of the Hollow Banquet—far beyond the rotting kitchens and blood-caked dance floors—there exists a blackened throne where light dies and memory decays. Upon this twisted dais sits Nightmare Freddy, an echo of a legend, reborn in shadow and hunger. Once thought to be merely a remnant of old myths told by fading candlelight, he has emerged as a force bound not only to fear but to the Banquet’s own ravenous heart.

Nightmare Freddy is not a guardian. He is not a servant. He is a predator, a warped king born from the trauma of an older, darker time. His body, a grotesque parody of Freddy Fazbear’s former glory, is stitched from rot and rust. His fur is patchy and matted, flecked with the dust of ages and the ash of long-dead celebrations. Jagged metal protrudes from his frame like thorns, and his eyes burn not with fire, but a cruel intelligence—aware, watching, always calculating.

The tale whispered in the crypts below the Hollow Banquet tells of how Nightmare Freddy emerged from the collective trauma left in the wake of the original performers. He is not merely an animatronic twisted by time, but a spectral amalgamation—the personification of what was buried beneath the banquet hall: guilt, grief, the weight of forgotten children, and the monstrous legacy of joy turned to torment. In this cursed form, Freddy no longer sings. He hunts.

But Nightmare Freddy is never alone. Clinging to his shoulders, crawling over his arms, and hiding in the folds of his fur are the Freddles—miniature versions of the old bear, malformed and vicious, embodiments of fractured innocence. They scurry like rats, whispering in voices stolen from children long gone, mimicking laughter with broken music box tones and cruel, high-pitched giggles.

These creatures are not autonomous. They are extensions of Nightmare Freddy’s will—fragments of a splintered psyche, or perhaps the twisted souls of the Banquet’s lost guests, bound to the nightmare king for eternity. Where Nightmare Freddy stalks the greater halls, the Freddles infest the cracks and walls, climbing over crumbled plaster and haunting the dreams of those who wander too close. When they descend, they do so in silence, chittering in unison before erupting into frenzied violence. Alone, they are pests. Together, they are a swarm.

Some Banquet survivors speak of the "Trial of Teeth", a night ritual that takes place when the hall is at its darkest. During this event, the Freddles descend like insects, separating intruders from their parties, whispering childhood fears until they are paralyzed. Only then does Nightmare Freddy arrive, rising like a titan of sorrow and metal, crowned in rust and devouring shadow. No one who has witnessed the full ritual and survived has returned unchanged. Some speak in tongues. Others gouge out their own eyes. One carved a crown into his chest and claimed, “The Bear King sees all.”

In the twisted mythos of the Hollow Banquet, Nightmare Freddy has come to symbolize more than a mere animatronic spirit. He is the consequence of broken promises, the monarch of all things buried, and the whisper of fear that lingers after the music ends. While others may haunt halls out of corrupted duty or madness, Nightmare Freddy remains out of purpose. His throne, surrounded by cracked mirrors and broken party favors, sits at the Banquet’s heart—not because he claimed it, but because the Banquet itself offered it to him.

For he alone understands its hunger.

And the Freddles? They are his loyal jesters—nipping at ankles, crawling beneath beds, and ensuring that fear is never too far behind the footsteps of those foolish enough to enter the Hollow Banquet uninvited.

			{{Lore
## Plushtrap – The Silent Heir of the Hollow
In the lonely, half-lit corners of the Hollow Banquet, past corridors lined with torn party streamers and beneath ruined tables draped in dust, there exists a whisper—barely audible, always close. It’s not the heavy metallic echo of Nightmare Freddy, nor the shrieking clatter of Toy Foxy’s descent. It’s something smaller. Quieter. More insidious. A creak, a scurry, the faintest brush of fur on wood. That is the warning call of Plushtrap, and by the time you hear it, it’s already too late.

A malformed, pocket-sized terror, Plushtrap is the paradox of vulnerability and sadism. His diminutive frame—resembling a decayed plush version of Springtrap—makes him an easy thing to underestimate. But the thing seated motionless on that tattered child’s chair in the crèche of the Hollow Banquet is no toy. It is a predator with endless patience and a clockwork mind forged in silence and shadow.

Born from the psychic residue of trauma, loss, and the perversion of comfort, Plushtrap is believed to be the first of the Banquet’s children to “wake up.” Not from slumber, but from a realization. He discovered the lies in the laughter. The rot beneath the frosting. The truth that the joy was just a mask—and he tore it off.

Plushtrap’s role in the Hollow Banquet is unique. Unlike the towering nightmares or theatrical toy models, he does not stalk his prey. He waits. In total silence. He chooses his hiding places with surgical precision—always just out of the corner of the eye, just behind a turned head. His favorite game is played in the ruins of the nursery, where broken cribs and toy chests lie scattered like war debris. Visitors find themselves drawn to him by an uncanny allure—memories of childhood, old toys, forgotten fears—and only once they are close does his game begin.

The rules are simple: if you look away, he moves. If you move too quickly, he moves faster. If you run, the game is already lost.

He doesn’t roar or scream. He doesn’t need to. Plushtrap’s attack is a sudden flash of sharp teeth, the gleam of yellowed plastic eyes, and a burst of motion faster than thought. Survivors report that he bites—not to kill outright, but to maim. To test. As if he’s playing with prey, gauging their worth. Or worse—marking them.

There are rumors that Plushtrap is the Hollow Banquet’s chosen messenger—a herald of the deeper rot that resides in the oldest recesses of the building. Some theorize he was the first attempt at recreating a “child-safe” animatronic from the husk of Spring Bonnie, cursed by the very spirit that would later animate Springtrap. Others believe he was once a comfort toy brought to life by a forgotten child’s last breath—a vessel filled with fear rather than joy.

Either way, Plushtrap is not merely a footnote in the Hollow Banquet’s lore.

He is its whisper.

He is its secret.

And he is always watching.
}}
