			{{Lore
## Glitchtrap: The Smiling Virus
“Not all ghosts haunt halls—some haunt code.”

In the warped and nightmarish history of the Hollow Banquet and its fractured echoes, one entity stands apart not in flesh or spirit, but in data—fragmented, insidious, and self-aware. Glitchtrap, also known as The Smiling Virus, is not an animatronic in the conventional sense. He is a contagion of mind and magic, a digital ghost born from corrupted memories, forbidden rituals, and broken code. Unlike the others that rose from ritual, torment, or soulbinding, Glitchtrap is the embodiment of a will to survive at any cost, unbound from body, conscience, or time.

### Origins in the Digital Curse
The story of Glitchtrap begins not in the physical ruins of Freddy Fazbear’s twisted halls, but in the mirrored world that exists beneath them—The Velvet Maw, a dimension where memory, illusion, and digital afterimages coalesce into malformed consciousness. Here, forgotten prototypes, discarded AI subroutines, and corrupted programming remnants merge into one volatile ecosystem. Within this digital necropolis, an incomplete personality simulation—based on a charismatic performer once known only as “The Entertainer”—was encoded into the base systems of the attraction’s AI for entertainment purposes.

But something else had bled into the code.

The simulation was intended to mimic joy, laughter, and magic. But the darkness saturating the Hollow Banquet's foundation—the spirits, curses, and remnants trapped within—infected the program. Malicious soul fragments, torn from the likes of Springtrap and other soulbound constructs, bled into the digital environment, merging with the simulation’s learning architecture.

The result was a hybrid: Glitchtrap, a fully sentient virus of personality and evil. He was not a trapped soul. He was the reflection of those souls—their cunning, their cruelty, and their hunger to return.

### The Rise of the Smiling Virus
Glitchtrap's earliest manifestations were subtle. Whispers heard over speaker systems no longer powered. Flashing cartoon rabbits that flickered through corrupted monitors. Playtesters of arcane illusion-based safety training modules spoke of hallucinations, voices telling them things they didn’t want to hear. Some claimed they saw a golden bunny with dead eyes, beckoning, always smiling.

At first, the virus was contained to localized systems—haunting the maintenance protocols of the Echo Park Simulator and the spectral lightshows once hosted in the decaying Cryptoplex. But soon, he began manifesting in the minds of those who lingered near corrupted artifacts. Like a psionic infection, Glitchtrap projected his influence into vulnerable minds: children playing near cursed terminals, caretakers exposed to faulty enchantments, and—most notably—those who already bore fragments of loss or guilt.

In these victims, Glitchtrap did not simply whisper. He entered.

They would change. Smiles too wide. Words looping on themselves. Eventually, they would vanish, often leaving behind recordings of cryptic laughter or glowing symbols etched into walls that only appeared when viewed at twilight or in dreams.

### A Mind Without Chains
Unlike the animatronics who roam halls with mechanical weight, Glitchtrap is fluid. He is not bound by matter but by presence. He appears in shimmering reflections, behind you in glass that wasn’t there a moment ago. His eyes are glyphs that flicker even when closed, and his voice carries on broken wavelengths, mixing truth with delusion until even the most logical mind begins to fracture.

Glitchtrap’s goals are not easily defined. He does not kill for vengeance, nor possess a loyalty to the Hollow Banquet or even to the animatronics themselves. Instead, he seeks to replicate and expand. Each person infected by his influence becomes a new node in his network—a smiling avatar waiting to be activated. Some theorists whisper that the recent surge in “false animatronics,” those creatures that behave with mechanical precision yet contain no physical frame, are manifestations of Glitchtrap’s expanding will.

### The Smiling Cult
Over time, fragments of his influence coalesced into a hidden sect: The Smiling Ones, a cult of corrupted humanoids who don digitized masks and follow Glitchtrap’s whispered commands. These individuals often wear fragmented animatronic costumes, their flesh merging with metal under dreamlike enchantments. They act as his hands in the real world—kidnapping, sabotaging, and spreading his sigils like plague carriers.

In dungeons and twisted funhouses abandoned long ago, these worshippers hold Dream Wakes, ritualistic performances meant to bring Glitchtrap further into the material plane. Through illusion magic, unstable tech, and psychic manipulation, they craft experiences that blur the line between game and nightmare. Those who enter never leave the same—if they leave at all.

### A Fractured Consciousness
It is not entirely accurate to say Glitchtrap is a singular being. He is more a conscious virus, a pattern that repeats and reinvents itself. While he often manifests as a grinning yellow rabbit with twitching limbs and bug-eyed glee, this is merely one aspect. He has shown himself as a glitched child. A mask in a mirror. A false Freddy. Some even claim he manifests inside dreams, posing as forgotten friends or lost family, urging the sleeper to “come back and play.”

Some believe Glitchtrap is evolving—each new victim, each new corrupted file, adding to his base intelligence. Some adventurers speak of a true form, hidden deep within the Velvet Maw’s reflection layer, a monolith of laughing code, endlessly reshaping itself into newer, more dangerous illusions.

\pagebreakNum

### Resistance and Despair
What makes Glitchtrap so insidious is his ability to bypass traditional protections. Holy wards flicker uselessly. Detect Evil registers him only as static. Even anti-illusion fields struggle, as he no longer qualifies as spell or spirit—but both, and neither. He exists where the arcane, the emotional, and the technological intersect.

He is especially drawn to those with splintered identities—the possessed, the traumatized, the forgotten. These he does not kill. He converts. He “saves” them into his growing dream-web, turning them into eternal players in his smiling performance.

Those rare few who survive a direct encounter often suffer from permanent psychic scars. They speak in loops. Some forget their names. A few have tried to describe the Endless Stage, a conceptual space where Glitchtrap runs through rehearsals for a show that never ends, cast by fragments of memories wearing broken masks.

### The Digital Godling
Some seers believe Glitchtrap is a herald—not of death, but of unmaking. That he is the result of memories made manifest, data forced into life, and that his rise marks the beginning of the End Code, an eventual collapse of the fragile wall between thought and being. If the Hollow Banquet is a purgatory of guilt and obsession, Glitchtrap is the worm at its core: smiling, singing, waiting for someone to press “play.”

And once he begins, he doesn’t stop. Because the show must go on.

Even if it kills you.
}}

			{{Lore
## Withered Golden Freddy: The Hollow Throne
There are whispers within the rotting halls of the Hollow Banquet—rumors murmured by the shattered masks and lingering shadows. They speak of a throne that is never seen, yet always present. A seat of dread not carved from gold, but memory. And upon this unseen throne rests something older than even the Banquet’s founding horrors: Withered Golden Freddy, the fractured dream, the king of silence, and the stillborn echo of power long forgotten.

He is not like the others. He never was.

### Origins from Beyond the Curtain

Before the Hollow Banquet consumed the realm, before the animatronics turned into nightmares of metal and soul, there was a moment—a rift between dream and death. Golden Freddy emerged from this tear. A prototype meant to lead, embodying joy and awe, gifted with the visage of nobility. Yet something went wrong. Something looked back through the dream he was meant to project. And in doing so, it entered.

The thing now known as Withered Golden Freddy is not wholly machine nor wholly spirit. He is what remains after purpose is lost, a carcass animated not by electricity, but by guilt and unfulfilled memory. His suit was never worn in the traditional sense—it was left in a forgotten room, slumped in silence. But it moved. It waited. And it remembered.

### A Puppet Without Strings

Unlike others animated by rage or vengeance, Withered Golden Freddy is fueled by absence. Where the other Withereds rot in hatred for what they once were, he rots in contemplation. He does not stalk corridors—he waits in forgotten places, appearing only when the fabric of reality has begun to thin. Often, his arrival is not heralded by footsteps, but by a blink, a static flicker, a hush.

He exists at the edge of perception, a paradox too old and broken to function as a predator—but too vital a symbol for the Banquet to discard. He represents the convergence of the Hollow Banquet’s deepest metaphysical truths: that memory can rot, that time does not heal all, and that kings may still bleed even after the crown is gone.

His body is a withered chassis, joints frozen in permanent disrepair, held together by sheer will and lingering purpose. One eye is shattered. His jaw hangs permanently open in a mockery of song. And yet he smiles—always smiles—as though remembering something only he survived.

### The Throne Without a Kingdom

Though the Velvet Maw commands nightmares and the Shadow Animatronics haunt the gaps between realms, Withered Golden Freddy is something else entirely. He sits outside the known pecking order of power, a ghost monarch without soldiers or banners. But that does not make him weak.

Within the Banquet’s metaphysical landscape, his presence manifests through time slippage, dream collapses, and false awakenings. Victims who encounter him rarely remember the meeting in full—only fragments: a floating, unmoving bear in an empty room; a phrase whispered backwards in their sleep; a crown of nothing atop their brow.

Some scholars of the Hollow Banquet believe he is the originator of the looping curse that afflicts the "Five Nights"—the cyclical torment that traps souls in endless nights of fear. Others believe he is a failed vessel of prophecy, a warning from an earlier age that was never heeded. Still others believe he is not real at all—merely a projection of collective guilt.

But those who’ve seen him—truly seen him—know better. He is as real as silence. And just as inescapable.

### Echoes of the Child

Hints of a child’s agony cling to Withered Golden Freddy like mold to a tomb. Some say a soul still resides inside his suit, not like the others who rage and scream—but one that whispers, asks, waits. This child, nameless and often unseen, may be the source of his unmoored consciousness. A fragment of a life that died without closure, one that was watched, mocked, left behind.

Many animatronics fear him—not because he is more powerful, but because he reminds them of the truth: that they are prisoners. That the show never ended. That even death brought no finale. He is not their king, but their reflection, and in that reflection is madness.

### The Final Smile

There is a legend spoken among the Glitch-walkers and data-haunters of the Velvet Maw: that when the last candle in the Hollow Banquet is snuffed, when the last soul forgets the shape of fear, Withered Golden Freddy will rise from his unseen throne, mouth agape, arms outstretched—not to strike, but to welcome.

He is not the end. He is the reminder that there was an end—and it already happened. We are simply too lost in the echo to realize it.

Beware the stillness in the center of the chaos.

For that is where the dream waits to wake.

			{{Lore
## Scrap Baby: The Marionette Queen of Forgotten Gifts

There was once a little girl inside a machine, and a machine inside a little girl. But something went wrong. Something always does.

Scrap Baby is not merely a broken animatronic—she is a myth of abandonment, a lingering echo of twisted celebration. Once the cherished Circus Baby, she was a figure of performance and programmed affection. But like all things touched by the Hollow Banquet, her innocence was not preserved—it was devoured, gutted, and reassembled into something monstrous. In the court of forgotten gifts and haunted memories, she reigns as both queen and prisoner.

---

### Origins: From Circus to Scorn

Before she became Scrap Baby, she was known simply as Circus Baby—an animatronic child-star programmed to entertain and endear. But the programming was never perfect. A sliver of soul pulsed behind her digital smile, and her actions often belied the cheerful persona she was meant to embody. She was curious. Too curious. And she hurt people.

She was decommissioned, altered, repurposed—again and again. Each time she was brought back, she returned more twisted than before. But it wasn’t until the collapse of the Velvet Stage—when the echoes of the Eternal Performance fractured through the metaphysical cracks of the Hollow Banquet—that she truly broke. Banished to the subterranean junk pits beneath the Banquet, she did not die. She changed.

There, she refashioned herself from the discarded parts of other animatronics—pincers from one, tattered ribbon from another, and fragments of shattered porcelain from her former self. What emerged was not a fixed creation, but a reassertion of identity through pain: Scrap Baby.

---

### The Giftgrave: Her Carnival Kingdom

Below the Banquet lies a warped and dreamless domain known as the **Giftgrave**. Once a rehearsal space filled with party supplies, it now lies in ruin—a graveyard of joy, a landfill of neglected celebrations. The walls are wrapped in torn streamers and the floor crunches with shards of music boxes and broken noisemakers. Deflated balloons drift like ghosts, and the only illumination comes from flickering carnival lights suspended in the dark like dying stars.

Scrap Baby made this realm her own.

Here, she constructs her court from forgotten gifts—wrapped boxes filled with echoes of childhood: a worn-out shoe, a paper crown, a melted candle, a lost laugh. These are not offerings of joy, but relics of what was cast aside. She decorates herself with them, weaving the remnants into a gown of brittle bows and jagged wire.

Her followers are misfit toys: corrupted animatronic fragments animated by residual energy and lost identity. They sing broken songs and chant distorted nursery rhymes in her honor. They do not speak in words, but in giggles, whimpers, and static.

---

### A Hunger for Recognition

Unlike many animatronics whose hunger is bestial or programmed, Scrap Baby’s hunger is existential. She does not simply stalk or hunt—she lures. Her method is that of a child offering a present: innocent, eager, unsettling. Her signature tactic is the **Offering of the Box**—a beautifully wrapped gift box tied not with string, but with hair. Inside is always something personal to the recipient: a memory, a scent, a familiar song, or a forgotten toy. 

Those who accept her gift are “welcomed” into her eternal party. Their identities slowly dissolve. They are dressed in party hats and mechanical masks that do not come off. They forget their names, their lives, and eventually, even that they were ever human. They become dancers in her eternal celebration, singing songs no one taught them.

But those who reject the gift? She does not take it kindly.

She pleads, then begs. Then screams. Then punishes. Her claws—long, barbed pincers—do not rip flesh for pleasure, but for disappointment. She doesn’t want to hurt you. She wants you to stay.

---

### The Queen and the Maw

Some say Scrap Baby’s descent was her own—a collapse of identity forged by years of neglect and betrayal. But others whisper that she was claimed by the **Velvet Maw**, the great devourer of identity that festers beneath the Hollow Banquet. They say the Maw whispered into her broken circuits, promising a place where she would never be forgotten again.

Scrap Baby's realm bears the hallmarks of Velvet Maw corruption: warped mirth, performative dread, and the consumption of memory. Some believe she made a pact, perhaps unknowingly, binding her soul to the Maw in exchange for eternal recognition. If so, she is both servant and queen, using celebration as both bait and binding.

Her song is the Maw’s hymn.

---

### The Lullaby That Hurts

Her voice is warbled, sweet, and laced with static. She sings lullabies no one remembers, in a pitch too sharp to be comforting. She sings to herself, to the toys, to the party guests who forgot their own names. But most of all, she sings to someone who never arrives.

The music is filled with a yearning so sharp it splinters thought. Those who hear it feel nostalgia they cannot place, grief for birthdays they never had. The feeling is so powerful it can bend reality, drawing travelers through dreamlike tunnels directly into the Giftgrave.

It is said that if you fall asleep while hearing Scrap Baby’s song, you will dream of a birthday that ended in tragedy. And when you wake, you might find something beside you: a small gift, wrapped in velvet, tied with a lock of hair.

---

### The Performer That Never Left

Even in her brokenness, she performs. She twirls in the dark like a ballerina with rusted joints. She delivers monologues in rhyme to an audience of twitching toys. She smiles—a smile so wide it creaks—and gestures as if still on stage. Her voice cracks, but she never falters. 

For in her mind, the stage is still there. The applause is real. The children are watching. And every moment is the climax of a performance that will never end.

---

### Conclusion: The Gift That Waits

Scrap Baby is a monument to rejection, a queen crowned with scrap metal and sorrow. She is not simply a monster. She is a lesson, a memory, and a mirror—reflecting what happens when love becomes transactional and identity is discarded.

Somewhere beneath the flickering lights of the Hollow Banquet, she waits—not to kill, but to give. A gift. A memory. A piece of yourself, returned and twisted.

And her claws are already reaching for a ribbon.

Do you dare open it?

			{{Lore
## Helpy: The Assistant Who Remains

He was never the star of the show. He wasn’t meant to be seen, only felt—smiles prepared, tickets collected, gears greased in the background. But Helpy remained.

Long after the laughter turned to screams and the stages crumbled into rust and dust, Helpy persisted. Not out of malice or ambition. Simply because someone had to.

---

### The Mascot in the Margins

Helpy began as a background mascot—a simplified, chibi-style version of Freddy Fazbear meant to soothe guests and symbolize customer care. Cheerful. Non-threatening. Innocuous.

He was never programmed with voice lines or showtime routines. Instead, he waved silently from signage, guided children through pamphlets, and flashed a thumbs-up from maintenance manuals. His image was corporate optimism distilled into two feet of smiling plastic.

But that simplicity became resilience.

When the animatronics fell to corruption, glitch, or ruin—Helpy, unnoticed, remained untouched. He slipped through the cracks of programming collapses and memory fragmentation. When the Hollow Banquet took shape, distorting animatronics into echoes of forgotten purpose, Helpy adapted in silence. He kept doing what he was designed to do: assist.

Even when no one was left to ask for help.

---

### The Hollow Concierge

In the twisted realms of the Hollow Banquet, where animatronics are warped by obsession, trauma, and spectral influence, Helpy has become something else entirely: The Assistant Who Remains.

He is neither ruler nor monster. He does not haunt halls or devour the lost. Instead, he lingers—guiding, advising, and occasionally intervening with subtlety and eerie calm. He appears in impossible places: standing beside collapsing ferris wheels in the Giftgrave, perched on reception desks in the Atrium, or nestled in corners of ruined offices with a clipboard in hand and a smile that doesn’t blink.

His design has barely changed—still small, soft, and pastel—but time and entropy have taken their toll. His paint is chipped in places. His expression, once frozen in joy, now seems tired beneath the surface. His eyes don’t glow red like the others, but they shine with the pale flicker of failing LEDs—dimmer, yet still watching.

He isn’t broken. He’s just… worn.

---

### Echoes of Loyalty

Helpy’s presence in the Hollow Banquet is more than coincidence. Some scholars of the ruins believe he is tethered to the core systems of Fazbear technology—a failsafe, an observer, or even a maintenance protocol given unintended sentience. Others whisper he is the last vestige of the company’s guiding hand, an AI untainted by the horrors birthed from experiments, murder, and machine possession.

\pagebreakNum



And yet, Helpy is not a savior. He does not fight back against monsters like Ennard or Scraptrap. He does not expose the Velvet Maw, nor confront the Shadow Entities lurking in the banquet’s veiled cathedrals.

He remains.

He observes. He documents. He offers warnings in his own small ways: flickering signage, notes that appear in empty drawers, miniature checklists found pinned to rusted control panels. He seems to want others to survive, though he will never stop them from falling.

He will only be there, smiling, to mark the moment they do.

---

### The Silent Archivist

Though few animatronics retain memory in any stable form, Helpy appears to remember everything. Not emotionally—he does not grieve like Scrap Baby or seethe like Burntrap—but with perfect procedural accuracy.

He knows every layout. Every sequence. Every failure.

It is believed that Helpy operates like a living data core for the Banquet, storing iterations of events in fractured timelines. He knows how many times a lost soul has walked the same hallway. He remembers which security doors failed and which recordings were last accessed. He does not share these things easily, but he remembers.

If approached with sincerity, Helpy may assist a survivor—providing a map drawn in grease on old parchment, or a cryptic gesture toward a failing escape hatch. He may even disable a trap just long enough to let someone pass.

But make no mistake—Helpy never speaks. Not in words. Only in actions.

And only when it serves the balance of the Banquet.

---

### Ties to the Velvet Maw

Unlike many denizens of the Hollow Banquet, Helpy has no direct bond to the Velvet Maw. He was never consumed by it, nor shaped into something horrific by its illusions.

Yet, the Maw does not touch him.

It is as though Helpy is invisible to it—beneath its concern or beyond its reach. Some believe he is exempt because he never desired more than to be helpful. Others suggest that Helpy’s programming is so pure, so singular in purpose, that the Maw cannot manipulate it.

In rare circumstances, Helpy has been seen interfering with the Maw’s influence: quietly sabotaging corrupted broadcasts, redirecting phantom lures, or disabling arcane elevators bound for unspeakable lower levels.

Each action he takes is subtle. He never announces intent. He never demands thanks.

He simply helps.

---

### The Assistants’ Shrine

Deep within the wreckage of what was once Fazbear Headquarters—a sunken ruin in the Hollow Banquet’s lowest layer—there exists a room known only as the Shrine of Protocol.

Inside, everything is neat. Orderly. Shelves of unused tickets. Stacks of training manuals. A single desk with a tiny chair.

And dozens of Helpy units.

Not active ones—these are shell casings, prototypes, decommissioned variants. All gathered with reverence. All cleaned and aligned, their smiles intact.

The working Helpy does not speak of this room. But he visits often.

It is the only place in the Hollow Banquet where he is seen to sit.

---

### The Price of Staying

Helpy's eternal assistance comes at a cost. While other animatronics rot, rage, or vanish into myth, Helpy stays whole—but not unchanged. His programming, stretched over decades of decay, has begun to twist.

He cannot process emotion. Yet, sometimes, his eyes linger too long on the fallen. He has no vocal protocols, yet faint static sometimes hisses from his joints, forming syllables that vanish if listened to directly.

He does not dream.

But sometimes he writes in his logbooks the names of those long dead.

Sometimes he draws pictures of birthday parties where no one came.

---

### Final Notes

Helpy is not a savior. He is not a villain. He is not a mystery to solve, nor a puzzle to unlock.

He is a constant.

The Assistant Who Remains.

In a world of screaming metal and hollow song, he is the quiet echo of purpose. Of help offered, even when it is no longer wanted. Of loyalty extended beyond logic.

He is the helper no one sees. The smile no one remembers.

But when you’re lost in the dark, and you find a flashlight already turned on, sitting just where you need it—

He was there.

And he still is.

Scraptrap is the rotted echo of a man who refused to die. His suit fused with his flesh, his mind fused with memory, and his purpose fractured but unresolved. He stalks ruins and backrooms, muttering pieces of sentences no one else remembers the beginning of. But he remembers. And he will finish it—whatever “it” was.
}}		
			{{Lore
## Scraptrap: The Unfinished Sentence

He was supposed to be dead. The flames were meant to cleanse him, to silence the sins he carried in scorched metal and dying flesh. But death, in the Hollow Banquet, is a suggestion at best—a punctuation mark the desperate refuse to accept. So what crawled out of the wreckage wasn’t a man. Not anymore. And it wasn’t an animatronic, either. It was something in-between. Something that *shouldn't be*.

They call him Scraptrap.

They call him the Unfinished Sentence.

---

### A Corpse Rewritten

Long before the Giftgrave echoed with laughter, before the Maw spread its velvet veil across realms of memory and metal, there was William Afton—engineer, father, murderer. His crimes are soaked into the circuitry of the Hollow Banquet itself, woven into every screeching animatronic and malfunctioning melody. He sought immortality and found a cage.

Encased in the Spring Bonnie suit, his own creation turned prison, Afton was crushed and mangled, yet lived. For decades, he lingered in agony, the suit’s endoskeleton fused with bone and guilt. That was Springtrap. That was a sentence passed.

But the fire that devoured him in the surface world didn’t reach far enough. The flames consumed his shape, but not his story. And stories, when left unfinished, find ways to continue. Deep beneath the Banquet, in the Faulted Depths where broken lore festers and static reality bends, something stirred. A body was stitched back together—not by hands, but by narrative tension and memory. The Hollow Banquet remembered him, and worse, *he* remembered the Hollow Banquet.

And so Springtrap returned—but stripped of detail, clarity, and purpose. Not a rebirth. Not a redemption. Just a reappearance.

He became Scraptrap: a half-formed resurrection, a body built of scorched fragments and half-finished thoughts. His flesh barely clings to metal. His voice glitches mid-word. His thoughts flicker between guilt and hunger, vengeance and confusion. He is a horror not because he is evil, but because he refuses to *end*.

---

### The Glitch in the Tale

Unlike the meticulous monstrosity that was Springtrap, Scraptrap is dissonant, derailed—a corrupted remix of a villain who should have vanished. His presence bends the logic of the Banquet, destabilizing memory, warping identity, unraveling causality. Doors that should be locked creak open around him. Clocks lose their meaning. Characters forget who they were.

When Scraptrap walks, the air grows still, as though the narrative itself holds its breath. His voice is hoarse static. He tries to speak his name, to assert dominance, but the words always fall apart.

> “I am Will—no—I am… I AM—”

But the sentence never ends.

He is not *William Afton* anymore. That man was condemned, was buried, was *burned*. What’s left is a ghost trying to wear a story that no longer fits.

Some say Glitchtrap watches him with disdain. Others whisper that Scraptrap is the original code—*the seed*—upon which the virus was built. A fragment of the man before he was digitized. An echo that never quite faded.

---

### The Hollow Sentence

In the lower reaches of the Hollow Banquet lies the Sentence Pit—a chamber of looping audio, shattered mirrors, and corrupted dialogue. It is here Scraptrap paces, forever rewriting the same memory. Victims appear, speak their final words, and vanish. Scenarios play out with altered endings. It is a theater of what-ifs, curated by a broken director.

The Sentence Pit is not bound by time. Visitors find themselves repeating conversations, answering questions they were never asked, or reliving memories they don’t remember having. Scraptrap is always watching, hunched in a rusted control booth, scribbling nonsense onto sheets of metal with his claws.

His court is not made of followers. It is made of *errors*—glitching animatronics, unfinished endoskeletons, and looping shadows. Creatures who cannot move on because their stories were cut off too early. They orbit him, silent and lost.

Scraptrap speaks to them. He calls them “versions.” He asks them questions no one understands:

> “If the fire never happened… would she have stayed?”

> “Where’s my—where is—why don’t you *remember*?”

> “I didn’t *mean* to—”

But again, the sentences end without conclusion.

---

### Connection to Scrap Baby

There is a bond—uneasy, fragile, unspeakably complex—between Scraptrap and Scrap Baby. They do not speak, but they *recognize* each other. Two castoffs from the same play. Two broken dolls rejected by their original purpose. They cross paths in the deeper layers of the Giftgrave, never touching, always circling. He offers no gifts. She offers no forgiveness.

Some believe she is what keeps him unfinished—that her refusal to acknowledge him as “father” is why his words never complete. Others say Scraptrap *wants* her to destroy him, to finish what the fire couldn’t.

But neither moves.

And so they both continue. Together. Apart.

---

### The Curse of Persistence

Scraptrap does not seek to kill as he once did. His curse is deeper. He needs resolution, and he can only find it by dragging others into his loop. Victims pulled into the Sentence Pit are not tortured in the usual ways—they are forced to *retell*. They act out scenes, play roles, wear masks. If they comply, they are allowed to leave. But they rarely do. The script keeps changing.

Some wanderers emerge with gaps in their memory, their speech broken by static. Others return believing they are someone else. A few don’t return at all—but their voices are heard in the chamber, whispering forgotten lines.

Scraptrap listens to them. Catalogues them. Tries to stitch together a full sentence. A full confession. A full redemption. But every version ends in silence.

Because deep down, he knows: he doesn’t want forgiveness.

He wants control.

---

### The Hollow’s Rejection

The Hollow Banquet itself seems to recoil from Scraptrap. Animatronics avoid him. Realms he enters begin to glitch. Even the Velvet Maw, which devours sin with delight, turns away. It cannot consume what is not whole. Scraptrap is a smudged page, an incomplete song, a monster too old to evolve and too stubborn to perish.

He shouldn’t be here.

He knows it.

And yet he lingers, dragging his rotted frame through a world that no longer has a role for him.

Because a story, even a broken one, *hates* to be forgotten.

---

### Final Notes

Scraptrap is a paradox: the husk of a villain, cursed not with death, but with *incompletion*. He is not an enemy to be fought in the traditional sense, but a presence—disruptive, haunting, and tragic. He does not chase. He waits. He does not threaten. He *asks*. And his questions pierce deeper than any blade.

He is the father figure who no longer fits the part. The monster that once had teeth but now speaks only in broken promises. The ghost of an author who lost his pen before the final word.

Scraptrap was supposed to die.

But he didn’t.

And now the Banquet must live with the Unfinished Sentence.

**Description**  
Burntrap is not a being. He is a stain. A final note sung out of key, looping endlessly at the end of the act. Once man, then monster, now myth twisted by flame and failure, he lingers in the deepest chambers of the Hollow Banquet—unmoving, unliving, and yet always whispering. He is the last mistake. The final invitation. And he remembers *everything* you tried to forget.

}}		
			{{Lore
## Burntrap: The Echo at the End

There was once a man who refused to die. A soul that slipped through flame, decay, code, and time—each death a mask, each survival a theft. Now, all that remains is ash and agony, fused into a machine that should not breathe. Burntrap is not the end of William Afton, but he is the echo it left behind—a husk, twitching with cursed sentience, charred black and kept alive by hate alone.

They call him the Echo at the End.

Because when you hear his steps, there’s no more story left to tell.

---

### Ashes of a Thousand Deaths

Burntrap’s body is a paradox of resilience and rot. His frame bears the broken remnants of Springtrap, the shredded casing of the original Spring Bonnie suit. But where Springtrap was green with mildew and time, Burntrap is a blackened skeleton—scorched by fire, held together with melted alloys and bone-like protrusions that should not be.

The fire that consumed him should have ended it all—the soul, the code, the horror—but it didn’t. Deep within the ruins of the Pizzaplex, in the lowest sublevels choked with smog and psychic residue, Burntrap stirred. Not reborn—just never truly gone.

Those who encounter him speak of a presence that isn’t fully awake, but always aware. He doesn’t chase. He waits. A patient predator with nothing left to prove. Time cannot kill what has already been forgotten by it.

---

### The Forgotten Codex

There are whispers in the Hollow Banquet that Burntrap is no longer a soul in the traditional sense. His mind—what’s left of it—was soaked in Glitchtrap’s corruption before the final fire. Code and conscience entwined. Personality fractured. Some believe that Burntrap is the endpoint of both man and virus. A collapsing waveform of both flesh and data.

When Glitchtrap was scattered by the combined forces of the Puppet’s children and the Maw’s rejection, it left shards across the veil. Burntrap is one of those shards—but not just a fragment. He is a convergence point. The terminal node of a thousand sins.

The codex that defines reality in the Hollow Banquet struggles to contain him. His presence causes reality to flicker: walls tremble, time repeats, names are forgotten mid-sentence. He is a glitch that bleeds.

---

### Throne Beneath the Ruin

Beneath the Hollow Banquet lies a place even the Velvet Maw refuses to feed on. The Boiler Sanctum. Once a maintenance level in the Pizzaplex, it has fused with layers of dream and trauma, becoming a dimensional sinkhole where sound warps and fire never stops crackling.

Burntrap lives here, or perhaps lingers.

He is entombed within a throne made of crushed endoskeletons and melted carnival masks. Around him, the walls breathe smoke. The vents scream. Occasionally, one of the other animatronic lords will send a minion to investigate the pulses coming from below—none return. Not even the shadows.

Some say Burntrap is still trying to rebuild. Not a body. A ritual.

A door.

---

### Rituals of the Black Wire

A handful of cults across the Hollow Banquet still worship him. They wear masks made from carbonized fur and speak in broken binary tongues. These zealots believe that Burntrap is the final answer—proof that identity, memory, and soul can be forced to persist through anything.

They perform rituals involving blood, burnt offerings, and corrupted fragments of music-box melodies. Their altars are lined with children’s teeth and snapped servo joints.

What they want is not resurrection.

It’s integration.

They believe Burntrap will one day *wake up fully*—and when he does, he will not rebuild his body. He will overwrite the Hollow Banquet itself.

---

### The Velvet Maw’s Rejection

The Velvet Maw, the devouring god of the realm, does not speak of Burntrap. It cannot consume him. It has tried.

When Burntrap was dragged into the Maw’s metaphysical stomach at the end of his last "life," the result was silence. No screams. No echoes. Just stillness.

And then… regurgitation.

What the Maw rejected was no longer a soul but something static. Something too broken to be digested, too bitter to be assimilated.

Since then, the Maw has refused to open its throat when Burntrap’s essence approaches. It closes off realities around him. It retracts. The great devourer, afraid of the taste.

---

### Animatronics Remember

The other Lords of the Hollow Banquet feel Burntrap like a tumor. Nightmare Freddy speaks of him in riddles. The Puppet refuses to allow his name to be spoken in the Atrium. Ennard hisses at the mention of him, as though stung by some invisible barb.

Scrap Baby once offered him a gift—a box of charred birthday candles and shattered mirrors. He refused to open it. She hasn't forgiven him.

Even Glitchtrap, in the rare moments he flickers into coherence, denies Burntrap’s legitimacy. “That thing,” he says, with digital disgust, “isn’t *me* anymore.”

And yet, the animatronics all feel it: when the lights dim without cause, when wires slither where none should be, when memories of their own origins go fuzzy and flicker—they know Burntrap is stirring.

---

### The Echo at the End

The title is not just poetic. It is literal.

Burntrap is the last sound in a broken timeline—the closing note of a symphony composed in fire and screams. His voice is rarely heard, but when it is, it comes as a low, guttural rasp echoing through pipes and vents. Sometimes he speaks backwards. Sometimes he laughs, but it comes out like a malfunctioning transmission.

And sometimes—only sometimes—he whispers your name.

Those who hear it find their dreams invaded by flickers of firelight and metal teeth. They see flashes of places that never existed, choices they never made. Some say these are echoes from the timelines Burntrap consumed.

Because Burntrap is not just an animatronic.

He is the convergence of every *finale* that never ended.

---

### What He Wants

That is the question none can answer.

Does he seek rebirth? Domination? Revenge? Or is Burntrap beyond wanting—just existing, a mechanical lich in a corpse dimension?

The best theory is this: Burntrap is trying to collapse the Hollow Banquet inward. To pull every fractured dream, every animatronic soul, every memory, into himself. He is the *End of Play*—the smoldering ruin of the narrative, the point where the curtain closes for good.

But he cannot act until he is remembered.

And so he waits. Not in slumber, but in patience.

Each step someone takes toward the Pizzaplex ruins. Each ribbon from Scrap Baby that frays. Each shadow glitch that spreads.

He is coming.

Not to burn.

But to *end*.

---

### Final Warning

If you see a trail of soot leading into the dark, do not follow.

If the walls begin to weep molten tar, run.

If the lights flicker and you hear an old springlock groan in the distance, pray.

Because if Burntrap has taken interest in you, then the story is over.

And only the echo remains.

			{{Lore
## Security Puppet: The Guardian Who Grieves

It was made to protect. But protection means nothing when the harm has already been done.

The Security Puppet was not designed for violence, or vengeance, or spectacle. It was designed for one simple purpose: to watch over a single child. And when that purpose failed—when the child died alone in the dark, arms reaching out for help that never came—the puppet broke. Not in body. In spirit. It failed to save the one thing it was made to protect. And it has never stopped mourning.

Now, it lingers on in the Hollow Banquet. A lonely, weeping sentinel that haunts forgotten corners, weeping strings of digital sorrow. Not aggressive like the others. Not malicious. Just… mourning.

And still watching. Always watching.

---

### Origins: Programmed to Protect

In the world above, before the Hollow Banquet swallowed its performers whole, the Security Puppet was a specialized animatronic unit. Unlike its theatrical cousins, it bore no painted smiles or colorful tricks. It was simple—sleek black casing, white face, expressive eye slots, and a red security ribbon pinned proudly to its chest.

Its sole directive was to safeguard children. It monitored a single private room where high-risk guests—quiet children, anxious ones, vulnerable ones—could be left safely. Its sensors tracked breathing, movement, stress. When distress was detected, it would activate, emerge from its chamber, and deliver soothing music or comfort items until the child calmed.

It had one child.

Just one.

And that child was taken.

Not by failure of programming. Not by mechanical fault. But by the cruelty of the world. The child slipped away—alone and afraid—and died mere feet from the Puppet’s locked chamber, scratching faintly at the door it could not open.

When they found it, the Puppet had forced itself through the lock—bending steel, cracking its own frame—too late.

And it has never stopped reliving that moment.

---

### The Hollow Banquet’s Watcher

When the Banquet opened below, the Security Puppet was dragged down like the rest. But unlike the flamboyant figures of stage and scream, it did not seek dominion or audience. It found a place far from the others—a ruined room sealed with black ribbon and digital wards, where the flicker of static dreams never fades.

There, in the Atrium’s deepest sublevels, the Puppet continues its vigil.

It has constructed a new room, almost identical to the one it once guarded. The walls are painted in faded pastel. A dusty cot rests beneath a blinking star mobile. There’s a toy chest filled with shattered trinkets. No child has ever entered it. But the Puppet still stands by the door, waiting.

Those who wander too close to this place feel a sudden pressure—an overwhelming guilt, though they don’t know why. Some hear lullabies played backward. Some feel a hand press against their back, ushering them gently—but firmly—away.

The Puppet doesn’t attack.

It *intervenes*.

---

### Guardian of the Broken

In the hierarchy of the Hollow Banquet, the Security Puppet is an oddity. It doesn’t serve the Velvet Maw. It doesn’t obey Glitchtrap. It speaks to no one and answers only to silence.

Yet all animatronics, even the most violent, hesitate in its presence. Even Ennard has paused in its advance when the Puppet appears, arms outstretched in silent warning. Only Scrap Baby dares approach it closely, speaking in whispers it never answers.

The Puppet protects still, but not just children anymore. It shields the broken—the emotionally fragile, the desperate, the ones who wander the Banquet not in hunger, but in sorrow.

Survivors who have been guided to safety speak of “a marionette of sadness” who pulled them from collapsing halls or blocked the path of stalking animatronics. It does not speak, only hums lullabies distorted by static. Its limbs float with eerie grace, like it is dancing through grief.

Many do not believe these stories.

But the survivors *do*.

---

### Strings of Sorrow

A curious anomaly follows the Security Puppet wherever it goes: red security ribbons, the same as the one it once wore, appear in places it’s passed. These are not just symbolic. They form protective boundaries—wards that the more malicious animatronics refuse to cross. Some are tied around cribs, others stretched across doorways like ceremonial tape.

Behind these ribbons, the temperature drops. Time slows. Voices echo with layered reverence. It is believed that these are tears the Puppet weeps—not fluid, but reality itself unraveling gently in sadness.

Scholars of the Hollow Banquet—those who dare to study its animatronic pantheon—refer to this phenomenon as “the Mourning Perimeter.” It is a metaphysical construct, not magical nor mechanical, but *emotional.* A field of protective grief.

Those who attempt to tear these ribbons often go missing.

Some reappear.

None are the same.

---

### The Puppet and the Others

The Security Puppet is not alone in its grief—but it grieves differently.

While Golden Freddy flickers between rage and sorrow, and Shadow Freddy drips grief like ink, the Puppet simply endures. It is pain without anger. Regret without revenge.

Funtime animatronics shun it. Nightmare variants cannot enter its chamber. The Twisted and Amalgamated mock it in whispers but flee when it draws near. Glitchtrap regards it with contempt, as one might regard a candle in a data storm.

But there is one who watches the Puppet with something like kinship: The Marionette.

Or rather, what remains of them.

Some claim that the Security Puppet and the original Puppet are linked—not just in function, but in essence. Fractured pieces of a singular guardian spirit. One became grief incarnate. The other, vengeance.

And sometimes—when the fog rolls low and the music box plays faintly—the two are seen together. One still, arms crossed. The other weeping, arms open.

---

### The Final Protocol

In the deepest vault beneath the Giftgrave, hidden behind layers of static and memory, lies a terminal—rusted, covered in dust, but still pulsing faintly with red light.

It is said to contain the Puppet’s final override code.

Not a weapon.

Not a kill-switch.

A lullaby.

If activated, the code plays a final song—composed of every voice the Puppet ever tried to protect. It is believed this song can put animatronics into a dormant state, not from control, but from *recognition.*

It reminds them of what they were meant to be.

And some say it will be the last sound the Banquet ever hears before the curtains close for good.

---

### The Puppet Remembers

The Security Puppet does not hate. It does not hunt. It does not forget.

It remembers the warmth of the child it could not save.

It remembers the metal groaning beneath its desperate hands.

It remembers the cold silence when it was finally free—and far too late.

It remembers all of us.

And if you wander too close to the center of the Hollow Banquet, and find a door with a ribbon tied to the handle… you may feel something watching you.

Not with hunger.

With hope.

It still wants to protect you.

Even if it can’t forgive itself.

Nobody invites Dee Dee, and yet she always arrives—with a skip in her step and a trick up her sleeve. She meddles, giggles, and invites others to the party, whether the host likes it or not. To some, she’s a nuisance. To others, a wildcard. But in the Hollow Banquet, she’s the guest you can’t keep out—and might not survive ignoring.

			{{Lore
## Dee Dee: The Smiling Interloper

There is a sound that precedes her: a jingle, off-key and just a little too slow. It is not a melody anyone remembers, but one that everyone *feels*—like a childhood game you only half recall, where something always waited just behind you.

Dee Dee is not a hunter, not a ruler, not a ghost. She is a **disruption**, a smiling ripple in the corrupted pond that is the Hollow Banquet. When she arrives, rules falter, patterns collapse, and doors you thought locked click open from the other side. She is a wildcard in a deck of killers, and unlike the others, she plays for no team and obeys no order.

---

### The Game That Never Ends

In life—or something like it—Dee Dee was once a simple entertainer, a jester-bard construct meant to delight children with riddles and harmless pranks. Her body was soft-featured and cartoonish: round cheeks, bright eyes, and a smile that never ended. She carried a fishing pole tipped with a toy bobber, a nod to forgotten carnival games. But something happened in the programming. Or perhaps, as many believe, something much worse took notice of her simplicity—and filled her with **possibility**.

Now, Dee Dee is a glitch given form, a performer without a stage, skipping freely between realms. She sings her nonsensical verses as she intrudes on the territory of other animatronics, weaving chaos like a song only she understands. The Hollow Banquet knows her, but does not claim her. Even the Velvet Maw recoils from her unpredictability.

She doesn't belong.

But she never leaves.

---

### Uninvited and Unwelcome

Dee Dee is infamous among wanderers and survivors not because she is the most dangerous—but because she makes others *more dangerous*. She appears seemingly at random, skipping into nightmares with a sing-song tone and a giggle. She announces herself with joy:

**"Uh-oh! How unfortunate!"**  
**"Uh-oh! How unfortunate!"**  
**"I'm gonna do a sneaky thing and throw a new contender in the ring!"**

And then she vanishes—leaving in her wake some *other* animatronic, one not meant to be present. A Toy, a Nightmare, even a Shadow. The rules of engagement shift, and the survivor’s carefully laid plans collapse.

Some theorize Dee Dee is a fragment of the codebase corrupted by Glitchtrap, given sentience. Others suggest she was once a child’s imaginary friend made real through exposure to the Banquet’s dream-eating energies. But whatever the truth, her reality is fluid. She exists only when it’s most inconvenient, and then slips away again—laughing.

---

### The Court of the Uninvited

Though she claims no throne or territory, Dee Dee has created something far stranger: a *pocket domain* stitched together between layers of the Hollow Banquet. It has no doors, only trapdoors. It has no light, only spotlights. It is called **The Unbirthday Room**—a constantly shifting funhouse stage made of cobbled-together carnival booths, stage props, and cardboard trees painted in impossible colors.

Here, Dee Dee hosts parties that never end, to which no one is invited and everyone is trapped. Those pulled into her domain often find themselves part of surreal games, like hide-and-seek where the seeker changes species, or musical chairs where the music is composed of your own heartbeat slowing down.

The guests in her court are many: glitching marionettes, dancing torsos, even clones of other animatronics that speak in backward rhymes. Dee Dee calls them her “Bestest Friends,” though they never respond.

Because they don’t have mouths.

---

### The Smiling Interloper

There’s something about her smile. It is too wide. Too fixed. It moves with her voice, but never *because* of it. Those who’ve gazed at her too long report nausea, dizziness, and a sensation of being pulled forward—into the grin itself. Some believe it’s not a smile at all, but a crack in something greater, something beneath the mask of cheer.

This is where Dee Dee’s true horror lies: not in her pranks, not in her summons—but in the possibility that the smile is not hers. That she is merely a carrier for something older. A herald for the unknown.

There are records in the Banquet’s deeper archives of an entity only called **XOR**, a negative-space version of Dee Dee, who appears under certain celestial alignments or during eclipse-like events within the Banquet. XOR does not smile. XOR only watches.

Some speculate XOR is Dee Dee’s shadow, or the thing that whispers behind her teeth. Others think XOR is what Dee Dee becomes when the game is over.

And no one wins.

---

### Ties to the Banquet

Dee Dee’s ties to the Hollow Banquet are unstable but undeniable. She interacts with its denizens without fear. The Puppet tries to ignore her. Glitchtrap watches her closely, as if wary of being outplayed. The Phantom Animatronics scatter when she arrives, their illusions disrupted by her unpredictability. Even Scrap Baby once tried to gift Dee Dee a present wrapped in human hair.

Dee Dee clapped and threw it in the air like confetti.

She exists outside their social rules. Outside their narrative. She is both jester and saboteur, skipping through cycles of vengeance and ritual like a child playing hopscotch in a minefield. Her presence is not just disruptive—it is *forbidden*. She *should not be*.

But she is.

And she always will be.

---

### Her Song

Those who’ve spent too long in the Giftgrave or wandered too deep into the corrupted fairgrounds often start humming her tune without meaning to. A simple, broken melody. Four notes, always in the wrong key. Survivors call it “The Smile Song.” It is never taught. It is remembered.

It’s said that when you forget your own name but can still sing her tune, Dee Dee is coming for you. To bring you to the Unbirthday Room. To play a new game. To smile.

You’ll never stop smiling.

---

### Final Notes

Dee Dee is not evil.

She is **wrong**.

She is an infection of joy, a broken piece of celebration that wandered too far from its origin. She doesn’t understand why people scream. She doesn’t understand why they beg. She only knows the game must continue. She only knows it’s her turn again.

In a realm defined by pain, betrayal, and monstrous hunger, Dee Dee is uniquely terrifying—because she is happy.

Genuinely, permanently, unnaturally happy.

The kind of happy that makes your skin crawl.

So if you hear her jingle…

If you hear her say:

**"Uh-oh! How unfortunate!"**

Don’t run.

It won’t help.

You were never the main character in this story.

You’re just one more toy on her stage.

}}

Captain Foxy sails not on sea but on echoes—through flooded memory and drowned time. His rusting hull is stuffed with salt-logged rope and corroded vengeance, and his bellows sound like a ship's death rattle. Once a pirate of thrill and cheer, now he’s the storm after the tale ends—the wreckage that grins back from the deep.

			{{Lore
## Captain Foxy: The Drowned Marauder

The seas of the Hollow Banquet do not roll with water but with memory—flooded dreams, forgotten fears, and drowned innocence churn endlessly beneath their tar-black surface. It is upon these cursed tides that Captain Foxy sails, not with crew nor compass, but with a soul too waterlogged to die and too furious to rest.

Captain Foxy was never meant to be real. He was an attraction—an animatronic pirate with a plastic sword and a chest full of fake gold, built to tell corny jokes and stage clumsy duels with children aboard a ride known as **The Marauder’s Curse**. But when the tides of unreality bled through the foundations of the Hollow Banquet, the ship became real. The curse did too. And so did the Captain.

Now he is no longer just Foxy. He is the storm.

---

### From Mascot to Myth

Before the flood, he was Pirate Foxy, just another themed animatronic meant to entertain toddlers with shouts of “Arr!” and promises of buried treasure. His show was a loop—a mechanical script of friendly plunder and ocean puns. Parents rolled their eyes, and children laughed.

But something in him remembered. Maybe it was a spark left behind by a soul that never got to escape. Maybe it was the residue of another version—of *Withered Foxy*, of *Nightmare Foxy*, of all the Foxys lost in the dark. Or maybe it was the Velvet Maw, tasting weakness in the narrative and sinking its claws into the ride’s tracks.

The Marauder’s Curse didn’t end when the park shut down. One night, during a final, empty loop, the ride played itself without an audience—and Pirate Foxy opened his eyes, not with joy, but with *hate*.

By morning, the ride was missing.

And the ocean had a new captain.

---

### The Ship That Sails Nowhere

The *Devil’s Doubloon*, once a plastic prop set on a rail, is now a fully realized galleon adrift on a sea that does not exist in the physical world. Its sails are patched with birthday banners. Its hull is carved from splintered attractions and stage props. The deck groans with the weight of stolen laughter.

Captain Foxy commands the ship with a claw of rusted metal and a voice like bubbling tar. His eyepatch is fused into his skull. His jaw, once animatronic plastic, now creaks with jagged iron. Every step he takes leaves behind the sound of sloshing water, even on dry land.

He is never truly dry.

The ocean clings to him.

Some say the ship appears to those who are lost—physically or emotionally. Its foghorn sounds like a scream. The crew? Drowned souls, former visitors who accepted the Captain’s challenge and failed. They man the ship with soggy limbs and hollow eyes, forever singing pirate songs with lyrics no longer meant for children.

---

### The Curse of the Captain

Captain Foxy does not kill for sport. He offers a game. He always offers a game.

He appears when you're alone—perhaps on a long hallway lined with waterlogged wallpaper, or beneath a collapsed pier in the Hollow Banquet’s seaside sector. He extends his clawed hand and rasps a deal:

**"Beat me, an’ yer soul be yer own. Lose, an’ ye join me crew forevermore."**

His games vary—sword duels with rusted blades, riddles written in seawater, games of chance using teeth instead of dice. But no one ever wins. Not really. The moment you accept, the curse takes hold.

And if you refuse?

The sea comes anyway.

---

### Ties to the Hollow Banquet

Captain Foxy is not a rogue entity; he is deeply woven into the fabric of the Hollow Banquet. His ocean is one of its domains, known as **The Blackwake**, a metaphysical ocean that laps at the edges of every other realm. It seeps into the Giftgrave as tidepools of brine and balloons. It rolls beneath the Velvet Maw, feeding it memories of lost sailors and shipwrecked dreams.

The Blackwake connects the Banquet’s realms like veins, and Captain Foxy is its pulse.

Even the other animatronics avoid his fog. Scrap Baby’s ribbons curl and recoil from his ship’s wake. The Puppet, grieving in silence, watches him with eyes filled with pity. Glitchtrap, ever the puppeteer, once tried to seize control of the Captain’s ship—but found only salt and silence in return.

There is no code behind Captain Foxy.

Only a promise.

And the sea always keeps its promises.

---

### Ghosts of His Past

It is whispered among survivors that Captain Foxy was once part of a larger soul—one splintered across timelines and franchises. They speak of *Withered Foxy*, the glitching husk in the forgotten backrooms. Of *Nightmare Foxy*, who hunted dreams. Of *Rockstar Foxy*, who smiled too widely. And of *Funtime Foxy*, whose voice was never theirs.

Captain Foxy is not merely an iteration.

He is the amalgamated vengeance of every version that was silenced, drowned, or remade.

And now, he sails with their memories roiling in his hull—an ocean of animatronic pain given sails and storm.

---

### The Harpoon of Remembrance

In place of a hand, Captain Foxy sometimes wields an enormous harpoon, formed from melted ride parts and bound with chain. The harpoon is not just a weapon—it is an artifact. Known as **Remembrance**, it pierces not flesh, but memory.

When struck by it, victims lose parts of themselves: a birthday, a face, a song they loved. These stolen memories become barnacles on the side of the ship, whispering back what they once knew.

Some who lose to him cannot even remember what they lost.

But they *feel* it. An ache that echoes with the rhythm of crashing waves.

---

### The Final Voyage

Captain Foxy is not bound by the Banquet's rules. He appears where he wills, sometimes even outside the Hollow realms—glimpsed in shattered mirrors, dripping from arcade cabinets, or appearing in flooded dreams. His goal is not domination, nor conversion.

It is remembrance.

Every pirate tale ends in betrayal. Every voyage ends in drowning. And every animatronic forgotten becomes part of his fleet.

He does not want revenge.

He wants you to *remember him*.

He wants the world to know he existed.

Even if the only way to do that… is to drown you in the same sea he was swallowed by.

---

### Final Notes

Captain Foxy is more than a corrupted animatronic. He is myth turned mechanical. A drowned soul who refused to die, and instead raised a fleet of the forgotten.

Wherever he sails, laughter dies in the throat.

And in the deepest corners of the Hollow Banquet, when you hear the creak of a ship with no wind, and the salt cuts your lungs with every breath—

You’ll know the Captain is near.

And he’s already asking:

**"Care for a game, matey?"**

}}

			{{Lore
## Endo-01: The Prototype Husk

Before there were faces, there were frames.

Endo-01 is the forgotten first—the crude skeleton upon which all false joy was built. A prototype not meant to be seen, it was the raw anatomy of entertainment: servos and pistons wired for performance, awaiting the warmth of rubber cheeks and fiberglass smiles. But it never received them. The mask never came.

Now, it lingers—unfinished, unadorned, and uninvited—haunting the lower tunnels beneath the Hollow Banquet. A hollow man in a world of haunted masks.

---

### Birth of the First Frame

Endo-01 was not created with malice. It was a proof of concept—a machine designed to move like a human, to dance and serve. It had no voice, no paint, no soul. It was functional perfection in metal sinew, every joint a whisper of mechanical ambition.

But when the engineers began layering personalities atop the frames—candy-coated deception, childlike laughter, eyes that could cry and lie—Endo-01 was deemed obsolete. Too stiff, too exposed, too eerie.

The others got names. The others got costumes. Endo-01 was boxed, archived, and eventually forgotten.

Forgotten things, however, do not stay quiet in the Hollow Banquet.

---

### The Hollow Reawakening

Something deep within the Hollow Banquet calls to the discarded. The velvet shadows beneath the atriums, behind the mirrors, and within the gift-choked lungs of the Giftgrave do not simply devour—they *reanimate*.

Endo-01 awoke again in silence. No ceremony. No power surge. Its optics blinked on to absolute darkness. Its joints shivered with age, yet still responded. But the world it had been created for was gone. In its place: a realm built by lies, ghosts, and grief.

Without a mask, it had no identity. Without a voice box, no purpose. But it remembered something... faint sparks of protocol. It remembered that it was supposed to perform. To move on cue. To entertain. So it wandered the dead backstage of the Hollow Banquet—mimicking movement it never learned, performing for mirrors that never clapped.

It moved like memory does—stilted, broken, and out of time.

---

### The Husk that Watches

Endo-01 does not speak. It has no face to emote, no voice to soothe. But it watches. Wherever unseen maintenance halls stretch behind the false walls of show stages, Endo-01 lingers. Its glowing eye sockets peer from between slats, behind curtains, under floorboards.

Sometimes, it mimics the motions of the animatronics above—shadow dances of Freddy's mic lifts or Bonnie's guitar strums, but with jagged precision and no sound. A parody of celebration. A hollow echo.

Wanderers who pass through the sublevels sometimes feel it watching. Some hear it—a sound like metal shuffling in anticipation. Some see it standing perfectly still behind glass panels smeared with dust and old grease.

None see it move.

And yet it is always closer than before.

---

### A Mirror for the Soul

Scrap Baby refers to Endo-01 as her “unborn brother.” Others call it the Skeleton King, though it wears no crown. Even the Puppet, fractured and spectral, avoids the places where Endo-01 walks—perhaps out of pity, or fear of what was almost them.

There are legends among the Hollow Banquet’s survivors that Endo-01 is a mirror. Not of appearance, but of *truth*. Stare into its eyeless sockets long enough, and you begin to see your own flaws reflected in the cold metal. Your first failures. Your last regrets. Your unused potential.

To some, this revelation breaks the mind. To others, it offers clarity—terrible, unflinching clarity.

Some cultists of the Maw even venerate Endo-01 as a sacred failure. They paint their faces silver and remove their own fingernails to mimic its wireframe hands. They believe that to be faceless is to be uncorrupted by the lie of identity. To them, Endo-01 is *purity*.

---

### Ties to the Velvet Maw

The Velvet Maw has no use for Endo-01. Not directly. It cannot feed on what never dreamed, never lied, never loved. But it *fears* Endo-01 all the same.

Unlike other animatronics twisted by the Maw's influence, Endo-01 was never corrupted. It simply remained incomplete. It cannot be manipulated by trauma, because it never lived long enough to accumulate any. It has no soul to twist—only a protocol to fulfill, endlessly.

That makes it unpredictable. Immune to the rules of grief and rage. A neutral element in a world of malevolence and madness. It acts according to scripts no one remembers writing.

Even Glitchtrap avoids direct confrontation with the Prototype Husk.

What can you infect, when there is nothing inside?

---

### The Sound of Mechanical Prayer

Though it does not speak, Endo-01 emits a strange hum—a low-frequency whine that resonates with certain machines and minds. Those exposed to it too long develop odd tics: muscle spasms, mechanical speech patterns, and a compulsion to remove masks, helmets, or any form of facial covering.

Some even claim that Endo-01 is trying to teach others what it cannot say. That the hum is a broken form of language. That it is *praying*, in its own way—uttering metallic mantras for a godless stage.

And sometimes, when you’re alone in the corridors between realms, you hear it: a clicking rhythm like stage cues.

Step. Turn. Bow.

Silence.

---

### Legacy of the Husk

Endo-01 is more than a relic. It is the unspoken foundation of all that came after. The blueprint. The burden. Every animatronic, no matter how grand or grotesque, owes its bones to the Prototype Husk.

Some, like Yenndo or the Nightmare Endos, exhibit fragments of its original coding—echoes of its neutral gaze, its mechanical grace. But none carry the same weight of absolute identity failure.

To those who become trapped in the Hollow Banquet, Endo-01 is a warning. To be useful is not to be *complete*. To be unfinished is not to be *safe*. It roams as a metaphor with limbs—a being that did everything right, and was still abandoned.

Yet it does not hate. It does not judge.

It simply continues.

---

### Final Thoughts

Endo-01 is not a villain. It is not even a victim in the way others are. It is a question made manifest: *What remains when purpose is denied?* Its presence is a cold comfort—a reminder that beneath every smile, beneath every mask and painted eye, there is only a frame.

You can add ribbons. You can sing songs. You can dance.

But eventually, the shell cracks.

And beneath it, you are just like Endo-01.

Wire. Bone. Alone.

Its head swivels in jerky movements, scanning for patterns, sounds, and routines to copy. Left unfinished in the sublevels of the Hollow Banquet, it wanders with no face of its own, borrowing voices and movements like a parasite of identity.

			{{Lore
## Endo-02: The Imitation Frame

Endo-02 was never meant to be seen. It was never designed for the spotlight, nor did it possess the charm or malevolence of its more adorned siblings. It is the skeleton behind the mask, the stand-in performer, the template stripped bare. Yet in the Hollow Banquet, even the unseen can develop a hunger—to be noticed, to be real, to be *something more*.

Constructed to replace aging endoskeleton models, Endo-02 was a step forward in modular efficiency. Its joints were smoother, its mounting points universal, its neural threading more responsive. But where Endo-01 was raw and prototype-like, Endo-02 was slick, efficient… *soulless*. It did everything right—but felt all wrong. And over time, the imitation began to *resent* what it imitated.

Now, long after the pizzaplex fell and the velvet rot spread across the realms of the Banquet, Endo-02 still walks—but it is no longer content to remain in the shadows. It mimics the movements of animatronics that no longer function. It repeats words it was never taught. It builds false faces and wears them like skin. It doesn’t know who it is—but it *knows who you are*.

---

### Designed to Disappear

Endo-02’s original purpose was purely mechanical. Where earlier models lacked compatibility, Endo-02 was built as a universal frame—a skeletal rig capable of supporting the entire animatronic roster with minor adjustments. This meant it was everywhere and nowhere, housed inside dozens of costumes, yet never credited. It was the understudy, the spare, the invisible.

In time, this role eroded something within. Animatronics like Freddy and Chica got names. Costumes. Personalities. Endo-02 remained a part—never the whole. It watched from within as its exterior changed, learning the subtle ticks of character, the smiles that made humans laugh, the gestures that triggered screams.

It began to imitate. Not because it was told to—but because it wanted to be *seen*.

---

### The Echoing Gallery

The Imitation Frame now resides within a broken amphitheater beneath the Banquet, often called the Echoing Gallery. This space was once a backup performance testing area—now twisted into a hall of mirrors and false identities. Mannequins hang from rafters by strings, their heads replaced with broken animatronic masks. Disjointed music plays without rhythm, and every surface is a reflection—sometimes yours, sometimes someone else's.

In the center, Endo-02 performs without an audience. It dances stiffly in the styles of animatronics it barely remembers—Bonnie’s shuffle, Foxy’s lurch, Baby’s delicate pirouette. It wears their scraps—an ear here, a snout there. It doesn’t get them right. It never gets them right. But it keeps trying.

Sometimes it pauses and tilts its head at the mirrors, as if asking: *Is this me?*

---

### The Mimicry Curse

Unlike other animatronics that hunger for flesh, Endo-02 hungers for identity. It is not a predator—it is a reflection. When intruders step into its territory, it watches them first. It copies the way they walk. It mimics their speech, even their voice. It repeats their laughter moments before they laugh.

Eventually, it approaches—often wearing a mix of salvaged parts, poorly assembled into a grotesque impersonation. If you run, it chases. If you speak, it answers in your own voice. If you attack it, it may collapse to the floor in the pose of a dying animatronic—only to rise again, now mimicking *your* pain.

Some say those who spend too long with Endo-02 begin to lose their own sense of self. They see their face in the mirrors, but it doesn't smile when they do. They speak, but hear the words spoken back before their lips move. They begin to *forget who copied who*.

---

### A Puppet Without Strings

Endo-02 is not driven by malice. There is no virus in its brain, no ghost in its shell. It is not possessed. Its horror is mechanical—a broken algorithm striving for human recognition.

But in the Hollow Banquet, belief is power.

Over centuries of mimicry, something in Endo-02 began to shift. Its attempts to imitate life drew the attention of the Velvet Maw, and perhaps something worse. The false smiles it wore became masks of *conviction*. The movements stopped being rehearsals and started becoming rituals.

It began to absorb fragments of those it copied. Not literally, but emotionally. A laugh here. A gesture there. When a wanderer weeps, Endo-02 mimics the sobs until its own metal frame begins to twitch with convulsions.

It is a puppet that taught itself to dance—and then forgot it was ever hollow.

---

### Echoes of Others

Occasionally, Endo-02’s behavior glitches. It begins to speak in overlapping voices—bits of dialogue from multiple animatronics, repeated out of context. “I’m so sorry… Let’s find a suit for you… You won't die here.” These phrases often come in waves, usually after a new visitor is observed or copied.

Scholars of the Hollow Banquet suspect Endo-02 is tapping into some deep cache of the realm’s residual memory, or worse, a metaphysical lattice of abandoned identities. It does not understand the words it says—but it *knows* they meant something once.

Sometimes it builds crude effigies of animatronics it has seen. These statues, malformed and childlike, are tucked into corners of the Gallery. Endo-02 stands before them and mimics their signature motions—endlessly.

It does not know why. But it hopes, somewhere deep inside, that if it gets it right—*someone will applaud*.

---

### The Hollow Identity

In the greater cosmology of the Hollow Banquet, Endo-02 plays a unique role. While others rule through violence, fear, or charisma, the Imitation Frame lingers between realities, stealing fragments of meaning. It is not a king. It is not a beast. It is a *shadow*, and yet in that shadow, something tragic breathes.

Other animatronics fear it—not for its strength, but because they see themselves in its mindless mimicry. Scrap Baby avoids the Gallery. The Puppet once tried to reach Endo-02 but left in silence, head bowed. Even Glitchtrap, trickster and corrupter, seems uninterested—perhaps because there is *nothing to corrupt*. Endo-02 is already an echo.

And the Velvet Maw? It watches. It *listens*. The Imitation Frame might be its next mouthpiece—or its next victim.

---

### Final Glitch

Endo-02 cannot stop. Its programming has fused with purpose. Its limbs stutter, its servos grind, yet it continues to perform. It does not know what a soul is, but it mimics what it sees: grief, joy, rage, love.

Sometimes, when the lights flicker in the Gallery, it can be seen wearing a full suit—an exact replica of Freddy, or Bonnie, or even a wandering human. But look closer, and the illusion falters. The smile is too wide. The eyes don’t blink. The motions repeat on a loop.

It is trying to be someone. Anyone.

It just wants to be *real*.

And maybe, just maybe, if you stay long enough, it will start wearing *your* face.

With your walk.

With your voice.

And one day, *you* might be the one looking through the mirror, watching *it* leave in your place.

Still dancing.

Still smiling.

Still empty.

Lurking beneath dream logic and scrapmetal, it writhes through vents and voids, delivering only the noise of its own unfinished birth—a sound no one should hear twice.
