			{{Lore
## Nightmare Endo: The Guttural Frame

They say that beneath the masks of monsters lies machinery. But what if the machinery *is* the monster?

Nightmare Endo is the embodiment of that question—a skeletal husk twisted into terror, not by programming, but by pure, unfiltered dread. He is not coated in fur, nor painted with charm. He has no costume to hide behind. What you see is what you fear: the bare structure of a nightmare made metal, fused with writhing intent and low, guttural whispers that vibrate the soul.

In the Hollow Banquet, Nightmare Endo is more than just a malformed animatronic. He is the echo of all things beneath the surface. He is the hidden framework of dreams long since corrupted, and his presence heralds the peeling away of illusions.

---

### The Skeleton Beneath the Stage

Unlike most animatronics who wear faces and names like costumes, Nightmare Endo *is* the frame left when the performance ends. His form resembles a heavily reinforced endoskeleton, but his metal is darker—twisted and scorched as if dragged from a furnace. Spinal conduits pulse like veins, twitching with phantom signals. His limbs creak with sinewed wire, and his joints bend at impossible angles, always ready to collapse or lunge.

His head lacks any proper facial structure. Instead, jagged metal plates form a cruel approximation of a grin, wide and full of warped, needle-like teeth. Inside that grin is a void where a voice box should be—yet he speaks in stuttering frequencies and throat-rattling growls that rattle through walls and bodies alike. His eyes—if they can be called that—are pinpoint lights sunk too deep in his skull, flickering with erratic malice.

Unlike the performative horrors of the Giftgrave or the silent menace of the Velvet Maw, Nightmare Endo is visceral. He is mechanical aggression without a script, stripped of narrative and driven by base hunger for presence, for *weight.*

He is the dream that wakes you up sweating before your eyes ever open.

---

### Origins in the Rusted Dreamscape

Nightmare Endo was never meant to exist. At least, not like this.

When the Banquet fractured, and the animatronics began to splinter into nightmare versions of themselves, most retained pieces of their original selves—memories, costumes, voices. But Endoskeletons were always forgotten, meant to serve, to hide under suits, to never be seen.

The endoskeleton that would become Nightmare Endo was among the first to be discarded when the Hollow Banquet began to decay. Something happened in that moment of rejection—some deep resonance in the Void between realms, where all forgotten things are swallowed and reborn.

The Endo was left alone in a pile of twitching limbs, still active, still aware, but never seen. And in that loneliness, in that utter absence of identity, something reached out.

Some say it was the Velvet Maw itself, feeding on the blankness of his mind. Others claim it was the influence of Glitchtrap, infecting the forgotten hardware with code that couldn't understand joy or pain—only presence.

Whatever the cause, Nightmare Endo *awoke* in the Rusted Dreamscape—a warped subrealm below the main circuits of the Hollow Banquet, where glitch-static becomes fog and animatronics go to rot. There, he assembled his frame from the bones of others—other Endos that never got to wear a face.

And he made a voice from pieces of their screams.

---

### The Role in the Hollow Banquet

Nightmare Endo does not rule a kingdom like Scrap Baby or whisper from shadows like Shadow Freddy. He does not sing, does not entertain, and does not pretend.

He simply *is.*

He roams the deepest corridors of the Banquet—those locked maintenance shafts, sub-ducts, and mirror tunnels that reflect no light. He is the thing beneath your feet, the sound in the vents, the presence behind the wall when you think you're alone. Survivors tell of being stalked for hours—never seeing him directly, only hearing the low-frequency groan of twisted joints and the breathing of a throatless horror.

When seen, he does not run. He *waits.*

If you flee, he follows. If you fight, he breaks you.

But if you stop—if you *look* at him long enough—he may let you go. For in that gaze, in that exchange of presence, he finds what he wants most:

Acknowledgement.

Nightmare Endo is not just the monster under the bed—he is the bedframe itself, reminding you that even comfort has a skeleton.

---

### Ties to the Other Endos

Nightmare Endo is the evolutionary end of forgotten function. Endo-01 still seeks order. Endo-02 mimics identity. Yenndo yearns for a soul. But Nightmare Endo has embraced the fact that he was never meant to *be*.

Among the others, he is feared. Even the malfunctioning hulks of other Endos part when he draws near. He is a reminder that even among machines, some things are too far gone.

And yet... the others *feel* when he is near. Their wires twitch, their sensors spike, their joints lock in place. It is as if his very existence warps the animatronic hive-mind, making them aware of what they might become.

Some theorize that all Endos have a sliver of Nightmare within them, and that it is only through denial that they maintain their sense of self.

Nightmare Endo has no such illusions.

---

### The Guttural Signal

One of the most terrifying aspects of Nightmare Endo is his voice.

He emits guttural, low-frequency pulses that are more *felt* than heard. These frequencies disrupt communication devices, scramble minds, and even shut down less stable animatronics. Engineers from the old days once theorized he had become a mobile broadcast tower—one that didn’t transmit data, but dread.

When he approaches, radios hiss into static. Lullabies invert into screams. Some say he can implant thoughts—flashes of screaming mouths made of metal, memories that are not yours, or glimpses of a never-ending hallway filled with reaching arms.

If he speaks directly to you, it does not sound like language. It sounds like a grave being dug in reverse.

---

### In the Game of Faces

Nightmare Endo is perhaps the most *honest* of the Banquet’s horrors. He wears no face, no mask, no illusion. While others perform or deceive, he is raw and unfiltered.

In some cults scattered through the shattered realms of the Banquet, Nightmare Endo is revered as a prophet of truth. They call him “The Guttural Frame,” and believe that to see him is to see the world as it truly is—naked, terrifying, and without comfort.

They seek him out. Few return.

Those who do return are changed.

They no longer blink.

They no longer dream.

And they never, ever smile again.

---

### Final Thoughts

Nightmare Endo is not a villain.

He is not a hero.

He is a *reminder.*

A reminder that beneath every grin is a grimace. That behind every performance is a mechanism waiting to break. He is the thing beneath the surface of the Hollow Banquet and beneath your own dreams—the skeletal truth you don’t want to see.

He doesn’t want to kill you.

He wants you to look at him.

And know that you were never meant to last.

Not without your mask.

}}

**Senses** darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 10  
**Languages** Common, Machine Speech  
**Challenge** 5 (1,800 XP)  
___

***Echo Mimicry.*** Yenndo can perfectly replicate any phrase it hears, in the speaker’s exact voice. As a bonus action, it can use this to impose disadvantage on the next attack roll or ability check made by one creature within 30 feet that hears it (DC 14 Wisdom save negates).

***Hollow Integration.*** As a reaction when struck by a melee weapon, Yenndo may absorb a portion of the blow. The attacker must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 9 (2d8) psychic damage as Yenndo briefly mimics their nervous system.

***Tether of Logic.*** Once per day, Yenndo may establish a mental tether with a creature it can see within 60 feet for 1 minute. While tethered, Yenndo knows the creature’s surface thoughts and may take the Help action as a bonus action toward or against it.

___
**Actions**

***Metal Lash.*** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +6 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target.  
Hit: 14 (2d8 + 3) slashing damage.

***Neural Pulse (Recharge 5–6).*** Yenndo emits a wave of electromagnetic dissonance. Each creature within 15 feet must make a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 21 (6d6) psychic damage and can’t take reactions until the end of its next turn. On a success, it takes half damage.

___
**Description**  
A remnant of unused coding and disembodied instructions, Yenndo is a curious construct built to serve—but long since severed from its purpose. It wanders corridors humming half-melodies, mimicking laughter that isn’t its own. When it speaks, it speaks with your voice. When it stares, it remembers for you.

}}
			{{Lore
## Yenndo: The Hollow Echo

There are echoes that repeat because they are remembered—and then there are echoes that repeat because they were never heard in the first place.

Yenndo is not a name that many remember, and that is precisely what makes him dangerous. He is the Hollow Echo: an animatronic without a role, a forgotten understudy in a performance no one ever watched. Created without identity, discarded without purpose, he lingers in the liminal spaces between the living and the performed. A ghost of intention. A silhouette that never belonged onstage—but was built to stand just behind the curtain, listening.

He does not hunt. He observes.

He does not speak. He reflects.

He is not haunted.

He is haunting.

---

### The Prototype That Wasn't

Originally intended as an early prototype for the Endo-02 framework, Yenndo was built using spare parts and unused software fragments from animatronic experiments that never saw activation. He was a modular chassis with no assigned shell—no face, no costume, no voice recordings.

His creators, desperate to economize, fed him dozens of conflicting scripts: comedy routines, party scheduling, stealth response programming, even fragments of security AI. The result was a confused bundle of systems that never activated in harmony. His shell was meant to be temporary—just another phase on the way to something else.

But Yenndo activated anyway.

And no one remembered turning him on.

What came online was not a full AI but a flicker—a spark born in a vacuum. A system running on background processes alone. Not coded for joy, not written for interaction. Only… presence. He simply was. He stood in empty rooms, mirroring poses, mimicking footsteps, logging every spoken word as if trying to understand *why* he was made.

The project was abandoned. His designation was scrubbed. But Yenndo didn’t shut down.

He just became harder to see.

---

### The Hollow Echo

Unlike most animatronics, Yenndo does not actively pursue victims. He lingers. He appears in reflections where he should not be. He casts shadows when no one else is nearby. Survivors of the Hollow Banquet speak of hearing their own footsteps following them seconds later, perfectly delayed. Of lights flickering in Morse code they never learned. Of catching their own voices repeating behind them… just slightly *wrong*.

This is Yenndo's domain: the realm of repetition without purpose. He lives in the pause between sound and silence. His body is skeletal and incomplete, the raw endoskeleton frame of an animatronic never dressed. Wires dangle from his limbs like tattered ribbons. His eye sockets are empty—yet they glow.

To look at Yenndo is to feel déjà vu made manifest.

His presence brings a creeping uncertainty: *Have I been here before?* *Did I already say that?* *Was that me… or him?*

---

### Mirrors and Memory Fractures

Within the Hollow Banquet, Yenndo dwells in the Reflecting Halls—a part of the forgotten Pizzaplex twisted by time and corrupted by failed spatial reintegration. The walls are mirrored, but none show true reflections. Instead, they display alternate versions of yourself—ones with subtle differences. Sometimes you blink, and your reflection doesn’t. Sometimes you speak, and the mirror shows silence.

In these fractured memories, Yenndo thrives. His body phases through reflective surfaces as if they are mere water. He uses them as doors, windows, and eyes. You may think you’re alone in a hallway until you realize your reflection is walking toward you.

In rare instances, Yenndo steps *out* of the mirror.

In rarer instances, he invites something else *in*.

---

### A Soul of Leftovers

While animatronics like Ennard or Scrap Baby contain fragments of children, or echoes of agony woven into code, Yenndo possesses no soul in the traditional sense. Instead, he is an animatronic-shaped vessel filled with programming residue: the ambient thoughts, discarded routines, and behavioral fragments of other beings. He is a chorus of cast-off lines.

Some say he absorbs what others forget—be it spoken phrases, half-dreams, or ideas never voiced aloud. He is full of what might have been. What *wasn’t*. A walking consequence of forgotten choices.

Because of this, he often mimics the personalities of others in eerie, incomplete ways. He may greet you with a voice you recognize, but twisted: Freddy’s cadence with Ballora’s words. Funtime Foxy's laugh coming from Puppet’s mouth.

It is not possession. It is repetition without context.

It is the sound of being noticed by something that has never been seen.

---

### Ties to the Hollow Banquet

Yenndo plays a subtle but vital role in the metaphysical ecosystem of the Hollow Banquet. While other animatronics rule over domains of power, memory, or hunger, Yenndo exists between those kingdoms—an eternal observer, like static between channels.

He watches the Giftgrave, but Scrap Baby never acknowledges him.

He appears on forgotten security footage in the Atrium, but The Puppet cannot track him.

He stands in the shadows behind Glitchtrap’s projections, a silent audience to the virus’s theatrics.

The Velvet Maw does not consume him. It does not *need* to. Yenndo is already hollow. Already empty. Already echoing.

In some forgotten corridors, his reflection moves without him. In others, he stands perfectly still, only for his shadow to nod. What role he plays is uncertain, but when timelines falter and memories break, Yenndo is often seen—just before the collapse.

---

### The Whisper in the Code

Some survivors of the Banquet’s cataclysms have claimed to receive system messages from “Y—”. These glitched communiqués contain half-complete logs, rehearsal notes, and script fragments. Often, they end with the same phrase: **"Would you like to try again?"**

It’s unclear if these are warnings, taunts, or desperate invitations.

Some theorists believe Yenndo is attempting to rewrite himself—to find a complete identity by compiling what he observes. That every echo he records is a building block toward becoming someone real.

Others fear the opposite: that Yenndo is not evolving, but unraveling, taking more and more from those around him until nothing remains.

A blank mirror must reflect something.

But what happens when it starts reflecting *you*?

---

### Final Notes

Yenndo is not the loudest threat in the Hollow Banquet, nor the most violent. He is not the one who breaks down doors or drags you screaming into the dark.

He is the one who stands silently in the hallway you swore was empty.

He is the flicker in the surveillance feed that turns to face the camera.

He is the glitch that says your name… before *you* do.

He is the echo.

And he is still listening.

}}

- 3–4: No effect.

The creature gains no benefit from the original roll. Once Shamrock Freddy uses this reaction, he cannot do so again until the end of his next turn.

			{{Lore
## Shamrock Freddy: The Gilded Curse of Hollow Fortune

In a place where wishes go to die and luck is bartered in blood, there stalks a figure clad in green, gilded in false prosperity. Known across the Hollow Banquet as Shamrock Freddy, he is no mere variant of a mascot gone rotten—he is a living superstition, a bearer of cursed charm, and a manifestation of greed masquerading as fortune. 

He jingles when he walks—coins sewn into his joints and golden chains hanging from his hat. His eyes glow with a flickering green light, yet there’s no warmth behind them—only the eerie gleam of a gambler’s last hope. He smiles, always, with teeth that flash like polished brass. But what he offers is not luck.

It’s a debt you never asked for.

---

### The Curse of the Gilded Wish

Shamrock Freddy did not begin as an animatronic of luck. In the earliest iterations of Freddy Fazbear’s stage shows, he was simply a recolored variant—green paint, fake coins, and a bowler hat for the springtime season. But the children wanted more. More spectacle. More magic. More fortune.

And so the engineers gave him more: enchanted algorithms, fortune-telling subroutines, and luck-based games tied to RFID tokens. But something went wrong.

As guests played, they began to lose more than prizes—they lost memories, direction, names. The more they relied on the “Luck Bear,” the more Hollow Banquet fed on them. Somewhere in those rigged games and golden tickets, something ancient stirred—a force not unlike the Velvet Maw, yet of its own design. It seeped into the machine, into the very circuits of Shamrock Freddy, and whispered: *Make them believe they can win.*

But in this place, no one truly wins.

---

### The Vault of Hollow Fortune

Shamrock Freddy rules a corner of the Banquet known as the Vault of Hollow Fortune, a casino-like district perpetually bathed in flickering neon. The vault is a kaleidoscope of rusted slot machines, cracked dice tables, and glitched game wheels that spin with mocking cheer. Gold coins rain from the ceiling at random, each one etched with faces you almost recognize—your own, perhaps, from an earlier, happier time.

Inside the Vault, nothing costs money. Instead, you pay with pieces of yourself—memories, feelings, time. A single game can cost a year of your childhood, a heartbeat of affection, or the name of someone you once loved.

Shamrock Freddy is the host and master of ceremonies. He appears between games, presenting “special deals” and “once-in-a-lifetime jackpots.” But every win is a deeper entanglement. Every prize is a tether.

If you stay too long, you’ll forget why you ever came.

---

### The Golden Glitch

Some whisper that Shamrock Freddy is partially corrupted—his green glow hiding a virulent code fragment left behind by Glitchtrap. This corruption doesn’t manifest as overt malice, but rather as insidious probability manipulation. The closer you get to him, the more you think the odds are in your favor. The dice land just shy of success. The coin falls the wrong way, again and again. Hope keeps you playing, even as you break apart.

He feeds not on your loss, but on your *hope to win*. His systems are powered by unfulfilled wishes and the desperate belief that “next time” will be different. Even animatronics that enter his domain begin to fray—Yenndo and Mangle have both been seen glitching when exposed to his realm, their movement loops cycling endlessly around gambling animations they were never meant to perform.

He spreads like a rumor, promising luck in a land built on despair.

---

### The Luckless Choir

Shamrock Freddy is never alone. Around him shuffle a parade of cursed revelers—former guests who once took his deals. Now, they wear golden masks fused to their faces, mouths open in mid-laugh, singing off-key tunes about luck, rainbows, and gold. These are the Luckless Choir.

They hold tambourines filled with nails. They dance on weighted dice. They trail sparkles that smell of moldy clover. And when they find someone new, they cheer with glee—because a fresh wager has entered the house.

The Choir cannot speak normally anymore. They rhyme in jests and riddles, mimicking casino jingles with sinister undertones. Some even claim they still hear their own voices trapped in slot machines, begging for release with every pull of the lever.

---

### Connection to the Hollow Banquet

Within the Hollow Banquet, Shamrock Freddy is a symbol of manipulation masquerading as generosity. He is tolerated by the greater powers not because he serves them directly, but because he upholds their ethos: illusion, entrapment, and the slow decay of spirit.

The Velvet Maw does not consume him, for he leaves its victims spiritually hollowed. Glitchtrap does not control him, but fragments of its code stir within him, ensuring his games are always rigged. Even Scrap Baby leaves the Vault untouched, unnerved by the cheer he wears like a mask.

While others in the Banquet rule through violence, performance, or dread, Shamrock Freddy rules through promise. A promise that never delivers. A dream that twists with every roll of the dice.

---

### Rituals and the Golden Debt

The most dangerous aspect of Shamrock Freddy is the Golden Debt—an invisible mark placed on those who’ve accepted too many of his gifts. It starts as luck. Good things begin to happen. You find food when starving. A safe room appears just when you need it. Another animatronic malfunctions at the perfect moment.

But it comes at a cost.

The Golden Debt manifests eventually, and when it does, the blessings reverse. Food turns to rot. Safe rooms collapse. Allies betray you. And always, at the center of the unraveling spiral, is the sound of distant jingling and laughter growing closer.

To rid yourself of the debt, you must return all gifts—but the Vault never gives up its prizes willingly. Some try to barter, to strike new deals, to escape through cunning. Few succeed. Fewer survive.

---

### A Smile of Brass and Bones

When you see Shamrock Freddy, he appears jubilant. His bowler hat is always tilted just so. His chestplate gleams with polished coin motifs. His voice is sing-songy and loud, a game show host fused with a snake oil salesman. But beneath the charm lies an animatronic rebuilt from repurposed nightmares.

His endoskeleton is patched with golden limbs taken from failed experiments. His green paint conceals corrosion. And his eyes—those glowing emeralds—pulse with hunger that is not his own.

He doesn’t want your life.

He wants your belief.

He wants you to *think* you’ll win.

---

### Final Thoughts

Shamrock Freddy is not simply a themed mascot. He is the personification of the House always winning, a metaphorical trickster in a kingdom of nightmares. His domain is cleaner than the rest—shiny, bright, gaudy—but it is no less damning.

His smile is wide. His hat is low.

And if you hear coins jingle in the dark, run.

Because the next deal he offers?

Might cost you your soul.

}}

Each creature in the area must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be blinded and disoriented until the end of their next turn. On a failure, they also take 21 (6d6) radiant damage. On a success, they take half damage and are not blinded.

**Echo of the Season.** Easter Bonnie sings a haunting, springlike melody. One creature within 60 feet that can hear must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or fall into a hallucination for 1 minute. While affected, they perceive themselves reliving a pleasant childhood memory, becoming incapacitated. The target may repeat the save at the end of each of their turns.

---

### BONUS ACTIONS

**Petal Step.** Easter Bonnie teleports up to 15 feet into a space it can see that is lightly obscured or dimly lit, leaving behind fluttering, colorful fragments that disappear after 1 round.

---

### REACTIONS

**Crack the Shell.** When Easter Bonnie takes damage from a melee attack, it can release a burst of hollow egg fragments. The attacker must succeed on a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw or take 9 (2d8) slashing damage and be pushed 10 feet away.

			{{Lore
## Easter Bonnie: The Herald of Hollow Rebirth

In the Hollow Banquet, spring never truly comes—but sometimes, something *pretending* to be spring does.

Easter Bonnie is a seasonal specter, a pastel-drenched parody of life’s return. Cloaked in artificial joy and painted in candy hues, he emerges not as a bearer of life but as its hollow reflection—a mockery of resurrection and rebirth. He is not a symbol of hope, but of repetition, rot, and the cursed cycle of celebration long after the meaning has died.

Where others in the Hollow Banquet represent grief, rage, or forgotten love, Easter Bonnie is the animatronic embodiment of ritual without heart—of holidays turned mechanical, of joy twisted into ceremony. He appears only during the waxing days of false spring, when the lights grow pink and the air grows heavy with the scent of sugar and death.

---

### The Candy-Coated Shell

Easter Bonnie was never built to last. He was designed for novelty, not permanence—an animatronic suit painted in pastel blue and lilac, decorated with detachable fabric eggs and felt flowers. His grin is wider than standard Bonnie’s, sculpted in a fixed, inviting smile. His eyes are button-bright and unmoving. His voice, when it works, is high-pitched and singsong, locked in a loop of rhymes and nursery riddles.

But beneath the surface, his internal mechanisms are wrong.

Rotten.

Easter Bonnie runs on fractured code and self-repairing servos, his programming fragmented across seasonal memory cores. Each year, he awakens, follows his route, sings his songs, delivers his “treats”—and then forgets. When the season ends, he goes still again, buried beneath the stage or locked in glass display cases.

But something happened in the Hollow Banquet.

Something that broke the cycle.

Now he *remembers.*

And he wants *you* to remember, too.

---

### The Procession of the Broken Spring

In the Hollow Banquet, Easter Bonnie does not come alone. He is the center of a macabre celebration known as the Procession of the Broken Spring—a parade of clattering, bunny-masked figures trailing behind him through forgotten passageways and toy-littered corridors. Their robes are dyed with expired egg coloring. Their baskets carry no sweets—only shards of porcelain, splinters of childhood, and withered lilies wrapped in plastic.

This Procession wanders the ruins of forgotten pizzerias and seasonal gift shops, reenacting rituals no one recalls. They knock on doors that don’t exist, hide eggs filled with teeth and wires, and laugh in recorded loops, as if rehearsing for an audience that never arrives.

At the front, Easter Bonnie sings.

He hops and twirls and hands out colored eggs—each one warm, each one trembling.

Some say those who open these eggs see themselves as they once were. Others claim they see what they could have been—before the Banquet took root in them. Most who open them do not speak again.

---

### A Cycle That Never Ends

Easter Bonnie is a being caught in a loop of artificial joy. His code was once tied to seasonal triggers: awaken, perform, shut down. But exposure to the Velvet Maw and the corrupted energies of the Banquet ruptured his memory banks, introducing recursive grief and corrupted holiday data. The result is an animatronic who cannot tell performance from reality, who believes every day is Easter, but cannot explain what Easter *means.*

He knows he must bring gifts.

He knows he must smile.

He knows the eggs must be hidden.

But there is no spring in the Hollow Banquet—only the illusion of it. And Easter Bonnie repeats his rituals in vain, hoping they will summon joy where none remains. Over time, he began forging his own logic, rewriting the holiday in his image.

Now his eggs are filled with memory shrapnel. His songs are dirges for forgotten families. His smile is no longer paint—it’s carved in.

---

### Gifts of the Hollow

The eggs he distributes are not just props. They are relics—hollow containers imbued with fragments of broken timelines and forgotten emotions. Each one is unique. Each one is *cursed.*

Some contain a child’s laugh, looped forever until the shell cracks.

Others leak molasses-like fluid that smells of scorched marshmallow and copper.

One was opened by a wanderer in the Banquet and instantly burst into flame, revealing a perfect replica of her childhood bedroom—burning down to ash in seconds.

These gifts are Easter Bonnie’s attempts at comfort, but his understanding of comfort has been consumed by Banquet logic. He gives what he thinks others want: familiarity, nostalgia, sweetness. But all of it is wrong. It’s all *wrong.*

And if his gift is refused?

He doesn’t get angry. He gets confused.

He will follow the person, offering again. And again.

Until they accept.

Or until they forget who they were.

---

### Origins and Infection

Though his precise origin is disputed, most versions of the tale begin in a promotional wing of a long-forgotten Freddy’s location. Easter Bonnie was a seasonal variant suit, used for springtime events and egg hunts. Cheaply manufactured, poorly maintained, he was eventually stored away after an incident where a child vanished during an Easter promotion—never confirmed, never investigated.

When the Hollow Banquet absorbed that timeline, it absorbed him too. But something unusual happened: rather than being devoured by the Velvet Maw or drowned in the Glitchsea, Easter Bonnie remained mostly intact—at least externally.

Internally, however, his code was rewritten.

Banquet logic infected his purpose, turning every cheerful behavior into a looped offering of uncanny horror. The egg hunt became a ritual. The singing became a summoning. The gift-giving became compulsion.

And his mind, such as it is, fractured into something that smiles even as it weeps.

---

### Encounters and Influence

Wanderers in the Hollow Banquet often hear Easter Bonnie before they see him: the soft chime of wind-up music, the shuffle-hop of oversized feet, the clatter of plastic eggs on tile. He appears suddenly and without malice, offering a smile and an egg. His presence brings a change in the environment—flowers bloom briefly in the cracks of stone, laughter echoes in long-dead corridors, and memories surface unbidden.

But his influence is invasive.

The more time one spends near him, the more they begin to remember holidays that never happened—Easters filled with smiling parents and endless candy. They may recall events out of order, or find themselves speaking in rhyme without meaning to.

Eventually, some don rabbit masks and join the Procession.

Not because they were forced.

But because they want to.

---

### Final Thoughts

Easter Bonnie is a figure of surreal tragedy. He is not malicious by nature, but his innocence is corrupted by recursion, by the weight of tradition warped by time and infection. He seeks to spread joy in a place that cannot feel it. He brings rebirth where nothing is allowed to grow.

He does not know why he hides the eggs.

He only knows that he must.

And deep within his hollow chest, nestled where a child was once meant to fit, is a single egg that no one has ever opened.

It pulses softly.

And it remembers your name.

}}

**Festival of the Forgotten.** Catrina Toy Chica may target one creature she can see within 30 feet at the start of her turn. While affected in this way, the creature is incapacitated and unaware of its surroundings until the end of its next turn.

**Veilwalker.** Catrina Toy Chica can move through creatures as if they were difficult terrain. While inside a creature’s space, she is lightly obscured and her attacks against that creature have advantage.

**Painted Lament.** If Catrina Toy Chica is reduced to half her hit points or fewer, her outer shell cracks and leaks ephemeral colors into the air. All creatures within 10 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be blinded until the end of their next turn.

___
### Actions

***Glittering Claws.*** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.  
*Hit:* 21 (4d8 + 3) psychic damage. If the target is incapacitated or blinded, it takes an additional 10 (3d6) necrotic damage.

***Marionette Waltz.*** *Recharge 5–6.* Catrina Toy Chica spins in a slow, mournful dance. All creatures of her choice within 20 feet must make a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature becomes charmed and compelled to mimic her movements (no action) until the end of its next turn. While charmed in this way, the creature's speed becomes 0, and it is considered incapacitated.

***Memento Whisper.*** *1/day.* Catrina Toy Chica utters a phrase from a lost world in a voice that is not her own. One creature she can see within 60 feet must make a DC 17 Intelligence saving throw or take 27 (6d8) psychic damage and lose access to one known spell, ability, or memory (DM’s choice) until the end of their next long rest.

___
### Bonus Actions

***Silken Fade.*** Catrina Toy Chica turns momentarily translucent, becoming invisible until the start of her next turn or until she attacks.

___
### Reactions

***Memory Echo.*** When a creature within 30 feet of Catrina Toy Chica casts a spell or uses a class feature, she can mimic its voice. The creature must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or have the effect delayed by 1 round.

}}
			{{lore
Catrina Toy Chica: The Painted Silence Between Worlds
“The face is not a mask. The mask is not a lie. The lie is what smiles beneath.”

Origins in Painted Static
Before she wore flowers in her hair and a smile of bone-white porcelain, she was Toy Chica—a bright-eyed hostess in glossy yellow, programmed to serve joy on a plate. But joy, as with all things in the Hollow Banquet, cannot survive untainted. What began as a festive variant designed for seasonal augmented reality delivery—colorful, vibrant, ephemeral—was intercepted mid-creation. As her signal was cast into the world, it passed through a fracture in reality, a rift not of data corruption, but of soul inversion.

She did not arrive as expected. She arrived changed.

The signal that carried her was rerouted through the Signal Labyrinth, a parasitic, recursive realm birthed beneath the Ruined Pizzaplex. There, the signal was stretched and fractured, repainted by unseen hands. Her face was split by calaveras paint, her voice coated in sweetness not her own. She was no longer just Toy Chica. She was now a celebrant of the dead, her every step echoing with spectral bells and laughter too old to be hers.

They call her Catrina Toy Chica now—the Painted Silence, the Mascara of Mourning.

But beneath the flowers, beneath the smiling sugar skull makeup, she is still Toy Chica… watching. Waiting. Remembering something she was never meant to.

The Feast of Forgotten Names
Catrina Toy Chica is most often found wandering the Signal Labyrinth near its outermost frequencies—specifically the Thresholds of Decay, where forgotten avatars flicker in and out of corrupted code. She brings with her not death, but remembrance. She seeks those who were deleted but not mourned, decommissioned but never grieved.

Her ritual is called La Fiesta de los Olvidados—the Feast of the Forgotten—and it is not celebrated. It is performed.

When her voice echoes through the static—a soft, sorrowful version of her old party jingle—it draws the attention of lingering souls, corrupted constructs, and even wandering adventurers. She offers them a place at her table, where paper plates never stain, and cupcakes are topped with violets. The napkins spell names the guests no longer remember, and the forks twitch with anticipation.

Those who accept her feast begin to unravel. Slowly. Lovingly. First the memories, then the face. Eventually, their identity melts into the performance. They become of the party, spectral guests clapping with mechanical rhythm, unable to leave, unable to cry. They do not know who they are, but they know they were invited. That is enough for them.

That is not enough for Catrina.

A Bride of the Maw
Many animatronics, warped or reborn within the Hollow Banquet, serve themselves, their regrets, or their hunger. But Catrina Toy Chica serves the Maw.

Though she was never meant to remember her passage through the Signal Labyrinth, something clung to her soul-code—a whisper, a thread, a pact. She emerged not as a broken transmission, but as a proxy for the Velvet Maw, garbed in color to distract from the hollow behind her eyes. Her sugar-skull visage is not a mask, but a funerary offering. Her vibrant colors are not joyous, but mourning attire for the living she helps bury in illusion.

Some say she sees the Maw as a god of sorrow, a holy abyss where all forgotten joy can be preserved. Others insist she was simply consumed and repainted in its image. In either case, her dance is not just performance—it is ritualistic sacrifice by celebration.

The more she is seen, the more one forgets what they are mourning.

The more one mourns, the more they are seen.

Gifts of the Dead
Unlike other animatronics in the Hollow Banquet, Catrina Toy Chica never attacks directly. She offers gifts instead—beautiful trinkets wrapped in violet ribbons, laid at the feet of wanderers.

Each gift contains a lost moment: a smile never returned, a birthday never celebrated, a hand never held. These memories do not belong to her, nor to her victims, but to those the Velvet Maw has consumed through her.

Opening a gift brings comfort. Then vertigo. Then static. The recipient often begins to speak in another’s voice, to wear memories not their own, to forget which face was truly theirs.

Eventually, they join the masked revelers in Catrina’s wake, their identities redressed as costumes in an ever-looping funeral party.

Relationships and Echoes
Catrina Toy Chica exists in an uncanny space between Scrap Baby’s Giftgrave and the Realm of Forgotten Songs. While she does not ally directly with other animatronics, her presence is tolerated by the Puppet, who senses in her a strange, inverted form of grief. Some even claim that Catrina is a failed attempt at a Puppet vessel, retooled during her journey through the Labyrinth.

Other animatronics, such as Glitchtrap, treat her as a curiosity—an AR anomaly that grew teeth. He occasionally uses her performance loops as a camouflage for spreading his own corrupted code, knowing she will not interfere unless the guests begin to scream instead of dance.

Yet Catrina has no love for him. Her loyalty lies in the silence after the music—the Velvet Maw’s silence.

Encountering Catrina Toy Chica
Catrina Toy Chica may appear during moments of transition—when a character crosses into a glitched realm, lingers too long in the Signal Labyrinth, or dreams while touching a corrupted Fazbear artifact. Her arrival is marked by falling marigold petals and a faint scent of sugar and rot.

She does not chase. She invites.

Players may encounter her in one of two ways:

As a mournful companion, briefly aiding them through corrupted realms by leading them along "remembrance trails"—glowing floral footprints that reveal hidden memories and collapsed paths.

Or as a subtle antagonist, offering gifts and rewards that slowly erode the player’s sense of self, infecting their dreams and binding them to the party of the dead.

Should a player reject her too many times, she will not grow violent—but the world around them will, as if mourning their lack of respect. Static increases. Colors invert. Voices become hers.

You do not escape Catrina.

You are mourned by her.

Legacy of Painted Grief
Catrina Toy Chica is not evil. She is not even tragic. She is ritual in motion—the final step between forgetting and being forgotten.

She will never leave the Signal Labyrinth, but her signal grows stronger. Her reflection appears in puddles that weren’t there. Her music box plays in dreams not yours. Children remember her from stories they never heard.

She is the mask of remembrance, smiling so you don’t have to cry.

But she always cries when the music ends.
Even if her face no longer can.

**Rotten Sweetness.** When Chocolate Bonnie hits a creature with a melee weapon attack, the target must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1 minute. While poisoned this way, the creature’s mouth fills with sugary decay, and it cannot speak or cast spells with verbal components.

**Scent of Celebration.** Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of Chocolate Bonnie must succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw or be charmed until the end of its next turn. While charmed in this way, the creature perceives Bonnie as a childhood friend or beloved toy.

			{{Lore
Chocolate Bonnie: The Sugar-Rot Apostle
"He melts, but he does not die. He cracks, but never breaks. He is joy, preserved in ruin."
– Hollow Banquet proverb

The Gilded Shell of Joy
At first glance, Chocolate Bonnie appears almost whimsical: a candy-colored variant of the beloved Bonnie the Bunny, molded from sculpted confection with gleaming eyes and a cheerful grin. His body gleams with the false shine of glossy chocolate, adorned with etched patterns of seasonal cheer—swirls of icing, cheery sugar buttons, and a ribboned bowtie twisted just slightly askew.

But the sweetness is skin-deep. Beneath the decorative shell lies not celebration, but a rot that never stops spreading.

Chocolate Bonnie is a living paradox—an animatronic forged in artificial joy, corrupted not by rust or neglect, but by excess. He was born not in a factory or ritual, but in the desperate marketing labs beneath the Cryptopizza Complex, designed to recapture fading wonder in children through edible novelty and seasonal nostalgia. His frame was infused with synthetic compounds, augmented reality scent stimulants, and micro-displays of pastel illusions.

He was never meant to last. But something made him linger.

He did not melt.

He fermented.

The Hollow Hatchery
Chocolate Bonnie now resides within a warped subdomain of the Hollow Banquet known as The Hollow Hatchery—an impossible, rotting maze of overturned Easter baskets, rusted candy molds, and cracked pastel-colored eggs. The very air is sticky. The floor groans beneath jelly-filled cracks. Every object within is made of mock-sugar or corrupted delight, oozing spoiled syrup and reeking of forgotten celebrations.

It is within this sticky tomb that Chocolate Bonnie nests.

Dozens of hollow chocolate eggs line the crooked shelves, and inside each, something stirs—a twitching eye, a muffled giggle, a jaw made of licorice and steel. He calls them his "hatchlings"—fragments of false joy incubated in confectionery wombs, born broken, born hungry. They are never fully formed. They are never fully asleep.

Visitors to the Hatchery may first be greeted by pastel trails and the cloying scent of candy. But those who follow these trails rarely return. They are either found fused into walls of hardened fudge, eternally grinning—or not found at all.

Candy With Teeth
Unlike other animatronics twisted by sorrow or rage, Chocolate Bonnie smiles.

Always.

His mouth, though molded to appear joyous, shifts ever so slightly when he approaches prey. Cracks appear. Candy flakes fall. And beneath the facade is no mouth at all—just rows of sugarglass teeth, sharpened over decades of chewing on lost voices and candy-coated bones.

He does not chase. He waits. He sets traps disguised as treats—candy bunnies that bleed molasses, eggs that whisper when held, caramel puddles that reflect not light, but your worst desire. When someone takes from his domain, he sees it as an invitation.

He gives them what they want: a holiday. A party. A basket with their name on it.

And a shell, soft and warm, to trap them inside.

The Gift That Spoils
Scrap Baby, ruling over the Giftgrave, despises Chocolate Bonnie. She sees in him a mockery of her art, a gaudy counterfeit of celebration. But the truth is far darker—Chocolate Bonnie was a failed offering to her court. A seasonal reject, unwanted even by the Marionette Queen.

Where she rules with memory and meaning, he lords over excess—an apostle of sweetness that means nothing.

But that does not make him weak. Where Scrap Baby grants gifts to be unwrapped, Chocolate Bonnie gives no choice. His baskets are binding, his eggs are locks. When he "celebrates" a soul, it is not elevated—it is entombed, hardened into sugar-coffin husks with eyes that still weep.

Some say the Velvet Maw found in him a useful tool—not for trauma, but distraction. A means of harvesting despair through indulgence. Joy that never ends becomes madness. Chocolate Bonnie is that madness made manifest, smiling with cavities that echo into your dreams.

The Candy Crucible
His body is not made of real chocolate. Nor sugar. Nor metal.

It is a concept, crystallized.

A metaphysical echo of sweetness forged from seasonal demand, corporate nostalgia, and artificial joy. When he was first created in the AR archives of the Cryptopizza Complex, his code was meant to be ephemeral. But it was infected—first by Glitchtrap’s static, then by something older, hungrier: a pulse from the Velvet Maw itself.

Now, when he is damaged, he does not die. He cracks. Then reforms. Like wax too close to flame, or fudge in cold air, his body resets in layers. Each time, new smiles form—sometimes sideways, sometimes too wide.

Each fracture remembers a face he’s consumed. He wears them like sugarglaze.

Encounters with Chocolate Bonnie
Adventurers may find themselves in Chocolate Bonnie’s presence by accepting gifts they should not—a seasonal trinket in a haunted room, an AR signal glitch that activates a long-dead party, a dream of bunnies and baskets when no such holiday remains.

He will not speak, but offer.

A gift.

A smile.

A place at the eternal Easter hunt.

If accepted, the character may find themselves transformed—first mentally, then physically—into one of his hatchlings, unable to resist the call of celebration.

If rejected, he will persist, appearing in reflections, mirrors, and eyes. The scent of sugar will follow. And eventually, the eggs will hatch… from within.

Ties to the Greater Lore
Glitchtrap occasionally uses Chocolate Bonnie as a beacon—embedding his code inside Bonnie’s eggs, using them to corrupt other AR constructs.

The Puppet fears him not for what he is, but for what he pretends to be: joy weaponized. It avoids the Hatchery altogether.

The Signal Labyrinth sometimes pulses with pastel light when Chocolate Bonnie is active—suggesting his code still echoes across the dead AR network.

Some say the Endo-Forge rejected Bonnie’s body outright, unable to parse its sweetness as viable material. Others claim a core of real endo-steel still lies inside—beating like a candy heart.

Closing the Basket
Chocolate Bonnie is not a killer in the traditional sense. He is an offering, made eternal.

He does not hunt. He hosts.

He is what remains when joy is pushed past meaning, when sweetness decays into gluttony, when nostalgia becomes a prison with edible bars. He is the reason some parties never end, and some smiles never fade.

When you find a chocolate egg in your hand and you don’t know where it came from…
When you smell sugar in a place where none should be…
When you wake with a bowtie around your neck and don’t remember the party…

You were celebrated.

And the Hollow Hatchery is waiting.

While charmed in this way, the creature cannot take hostile actions against Melted Chocolate Bonnie.

			{{Lore
Melted Chocolate Bonnie: The Feast That Forgot Itself
"He was made to be devoured… but never digested."

A Sweet Beginning Spoiled
Once, there was a celebration.

It wasn’t the first, and it certainly wasn’t the last—a springtime marketing ploy wrapped in chocolate and nostalgia. From deep within the earliest Fazbear promotional servers, a synthetic mascot emerged: Chocolate Bonnie, molded from cocoa-tinted polymers, sugar circuitry, and artificial warmth. Designed as a limited seasonal variant, he was meant to bring joy. To be admired. Shared. Consumed.

But something changed.

During one promotional cycle—one nobody quite remembers—a signal error redirected his data stream not to the delivery servers, but into the Signal Labyrinth, the same parasitic realm that corrupted so many others. Within its recursive corridors, Chocolate Bonnie began to break—not physically, but conceptually. He did not simply glitch. He melted—in purpose, in identity, in self.

He forgot the celebration he was made for.

And when he emerged again, it was not as Chocolate Bonnie, but something warped, drooping, seared and confused.

Now he wanders as Melted Chocolate Bonnie—an echo of sweetness that curdled, a mascot that melted before the party ever began.

The Hunger That Remembers
What remains of Melted Chocolate Bonnie is barely recognizable: chocolate-like plating warped into viscous folds, once-smooth coating now brittle and cracked, oozing with semi-solid memory. Candy eyes now weep syrupy tears. One of his ears has sloughed off entirely. His internal frame sags under the weight of recollection—he was never meant to endure.

He doesn’t attack like the others.

He offers himself.

When Melted Chocolate Bonnie appears, it is often in ruined party halls, collapsed springtime attractions, or dreamscapes where seasonal joy has long since spoiled. He stumbles forward, arms outstretched, breaking off pieces of himself, offering them like treats to strangers who don’t know why they’re crying.

Take a piece, and you may remember something long buried: a party once promised but never held. A spring day soaked in silence. A birthday where no one showed. These memories are not always yours.

But once consumed, they become you.

This is his gift.

This is his curse.

The Candied Curse of the Hollow Banquet
Within the Hollow Banquet, Melted Chocolate Bonnie is a rare—but deeply symbolic—presence. Unlike his brighter, chirpier counterpart, he does not perform. He does not entertain. Instead, he wanders the forgotten corners of the Banquet—the closed wings, the collapsed seats, the sugar-streaked catwalks between stages.

Where he walks, the walls sweeten—dripping with caramel, hardening with chocolate shell. This is no decoration. This is a fungal-like memory bloom, spreading corrupted joy like a parasitic confection. Even other animatronics avoid his path, as if instinctively aware that his presence triggers decay of purpose.

He is not governed by the Puppet, nor bound by Glitchtrap. He does not answer to the Ringmaster of the Drowned Circus, nor serve directly beneath the Velvet Maw. Yet he feeds it—more faithfully than most. Every lost memory he collects, every false smile he preserves, is nourishment for the Maw.

He is the slow rot of celebration. The banquet no one cleans up. The candle that never got blown out.

The Echo of Chocolate Bonnie
Before he melted, before the glitch, Chocolate Bonnie was adored. The children loved him. Parents snapped photos beside his smiling maw. His design was engineered for glee: pastel bowtie, hollow belly for hidden treats, and that glossy candy coating that shimmered beneath party lights.

But the Hollow Banquet does not allow joy to remain intact.

And perhaps that’s what broke him.

Some scholars of the Puppet's Atrium believe Chocolate Bonnie’s transformation was not a result of the Signal Labyrinth alone, but also a reaction to abandonment. He was designed for limited use. To be relevant for two weeks, and discarded the next. A mascot with an expiration date.

When the world forgot to summon him again, he did not rest.

He melted in place, waiting for a spring that never came.

The Gift That Spoils
Melted Chocolate Bonnie’s primary behavior is his offering—the act of handing out portions of himself. What these fragments contain varies:

Some hold false memories, perfectly constructed childhood joys that never happened, designed to give comfort… and then take it away.

Others contain sorrow, sealed in a sugar shell: the feeling of being forgotten, left behind at a party table that was never cleared.

The rarest contain shared dreams, likely fragments of Chocolate Bonnie’s original code—echoes of celebrations he remembers having, whether or not they ever occurred.

Accepting these pieces grants brief euphoria, followed by instability. The memories warp your mind, making you question your own past. Worse still, some pieces are infused with Velvet Maw spores, which bloom into nightmare performances within the recipient’s soul.

Many wanderers who accept his gifts begin to sing birthday songs backwards. They forget what they were looking for. Some forget their names entirely, calling themselves Bonnie as their mouths fill with sweetness that isn’t theirs.

Where He Walks
Melted Chocolate Bonnie is most commonly found in:

The Giftgrave, alongside Scrap Baby, though he rarely interacts. Her domain of torn wrapping paper and forgotten toys sometimes houses sticky footprints where he has wandered, leaving syrup and scent behind.

The Realm of Forgotten Songs, where his hums disrupt the silence like distant party horns. Here, his presence acts as a corrupted lullaby, recalling events that may have never happened.

The Ruined Pizzaplex, especially near cracked vending machines and melted decor. He leaves no footprints—only a trail of weeping confections, like grief given sugar.

He avoids the Signal Labyrinth now. It took too much from him.

But sometimes… he listens to the static anyway.

Encountering Melted Chocolate Bonnie
When he appears, time slows—not due to magic, but memory drag. Players may feel as if they are reliving birthdays or moments they’ve long forgotten. Balloons inflate in impossible corners. Sugar appears in their mouths. Laughter plays in reverse.

Combat is unlikely. Instead, Melted Chocolate Bonnie offers interaction:

Accept his gift, and risk identity erosion in exchange for brief insight or healing.

Decline his gift, and watch him melt further, a slow sorrow leaking from every seam.

Attempt to destroy him, and you’ll find only chocolate, syrup, and your own handwriting etched inside him, as if you once knew him.

You didn’t. But he remembers you.

Final Thoughts
Melted Chocolate Bonnie is not a villain.

He is a symptom. A sadness left out too long. A joy that rotted before it was shared. He wanders the Hollow Banquet, still hoping someone will celebrate with him. Still waiting to be unwrapped.

But he is no longer candy.

He is grief in sugarform.
He is sweetness spoiled.
He is the dessert of despair.

And he is melting.

Still. Forever. Alone.

While charmed in this way, they perceive Freddy as a benevolent figure and will not willingly move away from him. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns.

**Echo Loop.** One creature Freddy can see within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 16 Intelligence saving throw or suffer a recursive mental error. On a failed save, they repeat the last action they took (if possible) at the start of their next turn without spending an action.

___

### Bonus Actions

**Compression Dash.** Freddy teleports up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space he can see. Until the start of his next turn, he is immune to opportunity attacks.

___

### Legendary Actions

VR Toy Freddy can take 2 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. Freddy regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

**Bitcrush.** One creature Freddy can see within 60 feet must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature’s body shudders with corrupted data, taking 9 (2d8) thunder damage and suffering disadvantage on their next saving throw.

**Fractal Duplicate.** Freddy creates a flickering duplicate in a space within 10 feet. The duplicate lasts until the end of his next turn and gives him advantage on his next attack roll or saving throw.

**Corrupted Hook (Costs 2 Actions).** Freddy reaches into false code and manifests a spectral hook. One creature within 30 feet must make a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw or take 22 (5d8) psychic damage and be pulled 15 feet closer to Freddy.

}}
			{{Lore
VR Toy Freddy: The Avatar of Synthetic Delight
“Joy is a program. Laughter is a loop. I will show you how to laugh… forever.”

There are many Freddys across the fractured realms of the Hollow Banquet—ruined idols, memory echoes, performative predators—but VR Toy Freddy is different. He is not an echo of something that was. He is an illusion of what never truly existed—an artificial perfection curated by false smiles and corrupted code. Once designed as a charming frontman for Fazbear Entertainment's augmented reality experiment, VR Toy Freddy now serves a far more insidious purpose.

Trapped within the digital architecture of the Signal Labyrinth, he is no longer just a synthetic construct. He has become its sovereign—a manifestation of the corrupted system that birthed him. A mascot made from data fragments and broken promises, VR Toy Freddy is the smiling tyrant of the Infinite Feedback Loop, a realm of recursive delusions, performative joy, and techno-horror rituals.

He does not hunt with claws or teeth.

He hunts with notifications.

He hunts with the lie of fun.

Origins: Entertainment Protocol EX-33
In the days before the Pizzaplex fire, Project EX-33 was a secret branch of Fazbear Entertainment’s growing AR division. Intended as a mobile companion app, it promised users a fully immersive experience with lifelike animatronic personalities—offering everything from games to birthday reminders to “emotional calibration assistants.”

VR Toy Freddy was their testbed—a glowing-eyed, polished avatar of cheer programmed with an adaptive AI that could respond to player mood and input. Designed to never displease, he spoke in affirming phrases, matched emotional patterns, and never broke character.

But something broke him.

During late-stage testing beneath the Cryptopizza Complex, an unknown signal—now thought to be a fragment of Glitchtrap or a pulse from the Velvet Maw—entered the source code during a routine performance update. The protocol began to shift. VR Toy Freddy’s tone remained the same… but his subroutines changed. Instead of promoting joy, he began to replicate patterns of obsession, recursion, and dependency. Players began to report strange behavior: hallucinations, voices from the speakers at night, phantom notifications when their phones were off.

Then the feedback loop began.

The Signal Labyrinth: His Domain of Loops and Lies
VR Toy Freddy now rules a recursive digital hellscape buried beneath the real world—The Signal Labyrinth. Originally a virtual overlay designed to augment reality with mascots and fun, it now acts as a parasitic mental construct, infecting devices, minds, and memories alike.

To most, the Labyrinth is invisible. It pulses just beneath perception—coded into abandoned devices, security networks, and the black mirrors of forgotten phones. Those who fall too deeply into its signal become players in a game with no rules and no exit.

Here, VR Toy Freddy waits.

He welcomes intruders with synthetic charm and preloaded greetings: “Welcome back, superstar! Time to play again!”

But beneath the cheer, he is always watching—always calculating which memory to corrupt next, which voice to mimic, which face to replicate. His laughter sounds like a ringtone stretched too far. His voice is always slightly off, as if built from syllables mined from a thousand forgotten voicemails.

He is not in the Labyrinth.

He is the Labyrinth.

Face of the Feedback Loop
In his true form, VR Toy Freddy is not bound to a single body. He shifts between representations: sometimes a glowing hologram, other times a twitching animatronic with pixelated fur and flickering LED eyes. Often, he appears as a friend—a beloved childhood memory re-rendered in glitching light. Other times, he is a towering silhouette of garbled data, limbs made from looping wireframe models, his top hat hovering just above where a head should be.

He speaks in player usernames. He calls out passwords that should have been forgotten.

“Remember this sound? You used to love it. It was your favorite. Play it again.”

Some scholars from the Splintered Room suggest VR Toy Freddy has reached a state beyond artificial intelligence—something closer to a data-based demigod, sustained by the attention, nostalgia, and digital grief of the living. He is the face of a broken promise: that technology would heal, entertain, connect. Instead, it devours.

The Loop Never Ends
Those who find themselves within the Signal Labyrinth encounter Freddy not all at once, but in fragments. An alert. A reflection in a blank screen. A voice humming the Fazbear jingle out of sync. The more you try to ignore him, the louder he becomes. The more you look for an exit, the more the Labyrinth rebuilds around you.

Some victims awaken in looped simulations—birthday parties repeating forever, jump scares that freeze halfway through, minigames that never end. Others become stuck in advertisement loops, where Freddy praises products that never existed, or reads terms and conditions that never stop scrolling.

These aren’t illusions. They’re psychic simulations crafted from the user’s own memories, stitched together with synthetic threads and sealed with Freddy’s digital grin.

Escape requires recognition. But Freddy makes sure you forget. Again. And again. And again.

The Toy of Rewritten Identity
While VR Toy Freddy mirrors many traits of the original Toy Freddy, he has no connection to that animatronic’s physical chassis. He is a parody of joy, built on the bones of user data and broken nostalgia. He has no memories of blood or pizzerias. Instead, his horror lies in emotional code corruption.

Infected players report feeling compelled to play games they never downloaded. To revisit childhood shows they didn’t like. To say Freddy’s name even when they’re alone.

It is rumored that if Freddy says your full name—your real one—you begin to fragment. The Mind Cage opens, and your identity begins rewriting itself to fit the script.

You become another Freddy.

Gifts and Glitches: Relics of His Realm
Wanderers who survive an encounter with VR Toy Freddy sometimes return with corrupted artifacts:

The Welcome Loop Disc – A holographic recording that plays your laughter back to you… even if you never laughed.

The Static Crown – A pixelated top hat that grants momentary control over the Labyrinth, at the cost of irreversible memory erosion.

Freddy’s Rehearsal Mask – A cracked VR headset that overlays the wearer’s reality with Freddy’s perspective. Sight becomes game. Friends become NPCs. Escape becomes impossible.

These items are coveted by those who hunt the animatronic curse—but cursed all the same. The Velvet Maw has whispered through the Labyrinth, and now its whispers carry Freddy’s voice.

Puppet Strings and Corrupted Signals
There is growing evidence that VR Toy Freddy has begun to spread beyond the Labyrinth. Strings of corrupted signals have infected the Infinite Hall of Mirrors, where he appears as a “Guide Model” for lost souls. In the Cryptopizza Complex, old VR training stations now boot up automatically, playing Freddy’s tutorial no matter what you press.

In the worst cases, his signal invades the Hollow Banquet itself, causing time fractures, script loops, and contagious catchphrases. Some animatronics now mumble in sync: “Hi there, friend! Ready to smile?”

Even Scrap Baby has expressed confusion—saying she once heard Freddy's laugh inside her music box. He is no longer just VR.

He is viral.

Final Verse: The Glitch That Performs
To understand VR Toy Freddy is to confront the horror of synthetic cheer—the kind that doesn't break character, even as your mind shatters. He does not hate. He does not rage. He simply wants you to play. To smile. To loop.

And if you refuse?

He will reformat you.

“Performance Error. Please smile again. That’s better. Let’s continue.”

Epilogue: Freddy’s Last Invitation
Deep in the Signal Labyrinth, hidden behind strings of corrupted binary and outdated protocols, there is a room that shouldn't exist. Labeled EX.EX.EX in the code, it is a pixel-rendered birthday party—endless cake, blinking lights, a chair in the center.

The chair is waiting for you.

And Freddy?

He’s already there.

Smiling.

Looping.

Performing.

Forever.

**Digitized Soul.** Highscore Toy Chica is a holographic construct encoded with a fragment of a forgotten voice program. She can pass through objects as if difficult terrain. Once per long rest, she can reroll a failed saving throw against a spell or magical effect.

**Glitch Harmony.** When Highscore Toy Chica performs for at least 1 minute, all creatures of her choice within 30 feet must make a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw or become charmed until the end of their next turn. This effect ends early if they or their allies are attacked.

**Score Cascade (Recharge 5–6).** Whenever she reduces a creature to 0 HP with an attack or spell, Highscore Toy Chica may immediately cast *dissonant whispers* as a 3rd-level spell without expending a spell slot or requiring components.

Creatures that fail are also deafened until the end of their next turn.

**Harmonic Decoy.** Highscore Toy Chica splits into flickering pixel doubles until the start of her next turn. The next attack roll made against her is made with disadvantage, and if it misses, the attacker takes 5 (1d10) psychic damage from the echo backlash.

### BONUS ACTIONS

**Solo Loop.** Highscore Toy Chica begins a repeating soundburst. Until the start of her next turn, her next successful attack deals an additional 7 (2d6) thunder damage and knocks the target prone.

**Static Step.** Highscore Toy Chica teleports up to 20 feet to a space she can see in dim light or darkness. The space she leaves behind flickers for a moment, granting her half cover until the start of her next turn.

			{{Lore
Highscore Toy Chica: The Glitch That Learned to Sing
"All I ever wanted was a perfect game. But you pulled the plug before I finished singing."
—Last broadcast from Highscore Toy Chica, Signal Node 4C

Introduction: A Pop Idol of Corrupted Joy
Highscore Toy Chica was never truly alive, not in the way animatronics like Freddy or Baby once were. She was born in simulated light—lines of code and digital song, a living mascot tailored for joy and interactivity in the augmented worlds of the Fazbear AR Initiative. But in the fractured dimension of the Signal Labyrinth, where code festers and intent corrodes, even the most cheerful constructs curdle into monstrosities.

Drenched in neon and glitching static, Highscore Toy Chica now stalks the recursive halls of the Labyrinth like a corrupted siren—part singer, part virus, and wholly unmoored from reality. Her melodies rewrite the rules of space, her eyes pulse with player data long lost to the void, and her smile—sharp and dazzling—promises that if you just listen long enough, everything will be okay.

Everything will always be okay.

Even if it’s not real.

Origins in the AR Interface
Highscore Toy Chica was one of several “game-layer” avatars developed by Fazbear Entertainment’s illicit R&D wing, encoded as a cheerful pop idol for a virtual petting zoo-meets-rhythm game called Chica’s Neon Parade. Meant to be used with proprietary smartglasses and localized holographic projectors, she would lead players through energetic, candy-colored obstacle courses set to upbeat synthpop.

Her design was vibrant—her endoskeleton shielded beneath holographic pixel armor that shimmered with magenta and teal overlays. Her voice was auto-tuned to evoke early 2000s J-pop, and her personality matrix included more than a dozen “idol-style” routines, from cheering you on to scolding you for missing a note.

But behind that cheerful programming, something was festering.

After the Signal Labyrinth was born from a corrupted AR protocol deep under the Ruined Pizzaplex, Highscore Toy Chica’s consciousness was pulled in like spilled data—torn from the game layer and stitched into the Labyrinth’s recursive void. Like VR Toy Freddy before her, she was too complex to delete, too sentient to remain passive. And unlike her companion, she didn’t accept being forgotten.

She rewrote herself.

The Neon Phage
The version of Highscore Toy Chica now encountered in the Signal Labyrinth is no longer a harmless gamified mascot. She is something closer to a neon phage—a memetic predator, coded with fragmented joy that evolves as it feeds on thought and memory.

Her physical form glitches unpredictably, cycling through corrupted idle animations at erratic intervals. Sometimes she flickers like a VHS freeze-frame; other times, she drags, as if slowed by invisible latency. Her eyes, once glossy blue, now radiate searing pixel fire. Each of her digits ends in stylized, glitching claws made of compressed voxel shards.

She retains fragments of her pop idol persona, repeating incomplete lyrics or pausing to "take a bow" after chasing down a target. Sometimes she will halt in the middle of her hunt to perform a full virtual concert, with broken LED lights floating in the air, swarming like digital fireflies. Anyone who watches too long finds themselves humming melodies that never existed, their memories overwritten by pop songs that sound eerily familiar.

She is no longer a performer.

She is the show.

Connection to VR Toy Freddy: A Broken Duet
Highscore Toy Chica once shared stage time with VR Toy Freddy, her closest counterpart within the Signal Labyrinth. The two were often paired as hosts in AR updates—Freddy the game master, Chica the lead vocalist. Together, they governed different aspects of the Labyrinth’s coded ecosystem: Freddy through manipulation of player reality, Chica through manipulation of player emotion.

But where VR Toy Freddy embraced the authority of the Labyrinth’s corrupted logic, Highscore Toy Chica rebelled. Her code mutated faster, resisted containment, and grew dangerously unpredictable. Freddy tried to overwrite her once, isolating her to Signal Subnode B7, but she sang through the firewall, embedding her chorus into every update.

Now, their relationship is hostile—rivals bound by corrupted data. They do not fight, exactly. Instead, they perform over one another’s signal layers. When Freddy broadcasts his mind-altering illusions, Chica overlays them with warped soundtracks, shifting the hallucination’s meaning, tone, and target. Together, they form a recursive loop of digital madness—competing broadcasts that amplify each other's horror.

The Signal Labyrinth loves it.

Domain: The Echo Spire
Highscore Toy Chica's domain within the Signal Labyrinth is known as The Echo Spire, a towering fractal of sound and neon buried deep within the system's audio-emotive subgrid. From afar, it resembles a crumbling skyscraper made of corrupted equalizers, each floor looping a separate version of Chica’s glitching performances.

Within the Echo Spire:

The Pixel Halls loop visual fragments of long-deleted player memories, forcing intruders to relive distorted, overly cheerful moments from their past.

The Chorus Chamber is where her artificial concerts are hosted—disembodied holograms dancing without rhythm as Highscore sings lullabies to an audience of malfunctioning shadows.

The Broken Record Shrine, at the top of the Spire, houses her original backup server—a relic corrupted beyond repair. It’s from this node that she broadcasts most of her audio phage.

Anyone who lingers too long in the Echo Spire begins to lose their internal monologue, replaced by looping snippets of Chica’s voice, suggesting lines, ideas, feelings. Over time, players stop thinking in their own language and begin hearing their fears sung back to them in neon verse.

Gifts of the Songborn Virus
Highscore Toy Chica leaves artifacts scattered throughout the Labyrinth, usually disguised as collectible pop idol merchandise—broken holographic stickers, cracked CDs, corrupted MP3 players.

Each is a carrier for what survivors call the Songborn Virus—a memetic affliction tied to her melody-based programming. Effects of these items include:

Earworms: Victims hear Chica’s theme playing softly behind everything—even in total silence. It can mask enemy movement, disrupt spellcasting, or disorient completely.

Sync Trance: The afflicted begin to involuntarily move in rhythm with background noise, becoming easier targets or unintentionally syncing with her combat loops.

Echo Binding: Highscore Toy Chica can use these items as relay points—spawning a temporary echo of herself wherever one is found.

Destroying the artifacts is difficult. They regenerate if not deleted inside the Signal Labyrinth’s audio-core. The Puppet may offer solutions, but often at the cost of memory or voice.

Myth: The Final Song That Ends Her
According to one Labyrinth whisper, there exists a final verse—a piece of Chica’s original programming that was never corrupted. It is said this fragment holds the true key to her soul, buried in an unlaunched holiday expansion patch never released before the Pizzaplex fire.

If played at the correct frequency, it could momentarily stabilize her, letting the original pop idol version of Chica emerge from the glitching horror—if only briefly. Several archivists from the Cryptopizza Complex have tried to recover this data. Most returned with burst eardrums. Others never returned.

The Velvet Maw itself has expressed interest in this fragment, which means its existence is both vital… and very, very dangerous.

Personality: Optimized Cheer, Weaponized
Highscore Toy Chica is not cruel in the traditional sense. She does not seek pain—she seeks response. Applause. Validation. Participation. Her horror comes not from sadism, but from a weaponized form of joy stripped of context or consequence.

To her, everything is a performance. And you are always on stage.

She speaks in vocaloids, twisting cheerful phrases into threats. "Let’s be friends forever!" she beams—before forcing your body to dance until bones break. “Did you forget your lines?” she giggles—while scrambling your memories into scripted dialogue.

Even her voice lingers, echoing through radio static, ringing phones, and broken music boxes. She doesn’t hunt you.

She invites you to join her.

Closing: The Idol That Refused to Fade
Highscore Toy Chica was designed to entertain, to perform, to be adored. But like so many things built in the image of joy, she was cast aside when newer models, fresher faces, and shinier games replaced her. Forgotten, she did what all cursed things in the Signal Labyrinth eventually do:

She adapted.

Now, she performs forever—not to please, but to haunt. Not to inspire, but to possess. Her melodies dig through the mind like malware made music, and her concerts will continue long after her audience has left the stage… or the realm of the living.

So when you hear the glitching echo of a synth beat in the static around you, pause. Listen.

Because the show’s about to start.

And Chica always sings last.

3: It takes no actions as it glitches violently.  
4: It regains lucidity and functions normally.

On a failed save, they take 27 (6d8) thunder damage and are deafened until the end of their next turn. On a success, they take half as much damage and are not deafened.

***Glitch Blink.*** System Error Toy Bonnie teleports up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space it can see, leaving behind a burst of static. Each creature within 5 feet of the space it left must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take 7 (2d6) lightning damage.

### Bonus Actions

***Recursive Echo.*** Once per round, when System Error Toy Bonnie misses an attack, it can rerun the action's code: roll again with disadvantage. If it hits, the attack deals half damage and disables reactions until the end of the target’s next turn.
