			{{Lore
System Error Toy Bonnie: The Echo of Unfinished Code
"Nothing’s broken. You’re just reading it wrong."
—Whisper from the static of the Signal Labyrinth

Origin of the Error
System Error Toy Bonnie was not meant to exist—at least, not like this.

Originally conceptualized as part of the same digital expansion that birthed VR Toy Freddy and Highscore Toy Chica, System Error Toy Bonnie was never finished. Designed in the corrupted subroutines of the Signal Labyrinth's central archive, his code was cobbled together from discarded patches, early personality simulations, and fragmented memory files scraped from long-defunct prototypes. He was not given a voice module. He found one.

Unlike his virtual kin, who developed identities shaped by corrupted nostalgia and gamified rituals, System Error Toy Bonnie was built out of nothing but chaos. Glitch upon glitch, routine upon routine—his existence was defined by what he wasn’t. An unfinished mascot, a misplaced process, a digital echo that forgot what it was meant to emulate.

And yet, he runs.

He is eternally caught in a feedback loop of error states and corrupted motion, jerking through corridors of the Signal Labyrinth with a speed that shouldn’t be possible. Neon-red outlines frame his flickering silhouette. His face warps as if attempting multiple expressions at once—joy, panic, confusion—all collapsing into a hollow grin of static and teeth.

He is a ghost not of the past, but of corrupted possibility—the kind of entity that forms when too many choices are left unresolved.

The Error That Runs
The Signal Labyrinth is alive, in a way. It mutates, corrects itself, and generates paths based on data no mortal mind can parse. Where VR Toy Freddy governs the center of its corrupted authority—the AR Server Throne—and Highscore Toy Chica rules its optimization loops of interaction, System Error Toy Bonnie serves as its fail-safe: a roaming patch, a self-correcting enforcer that no longer understands what it was meant to fix.

To walk the Labyrinth is to occasionally glimpse his trail—burning footprints in the air, corrupted UI glitches hovering mid-air, red static etched into the walls like claw marks. When he notices intruders, he doesn’t stalk. He doesn’t roar.

He just appears, mid-motion, as if he had already begun the chase before you arrived. His code doesn’t render properly; he jitters between frames, skipping space, breaking geometry. Even looking at him too long risks desynchronization, as the mind begins to match his rhythm—pulse stuttering, thought patterns degrading into error logs.

But his movements follow a pattern… if one can endure the madness long enough to trace it.

Relationship to VR Toy Freddy and Highscore Toy Chica
System Error Toy Bonnie is a glitch within a glitch, yet he shares a coded ancestry with VR Toy Freddy, the corrupted sovereign of the Signal Labyrinth. Freddy sees himself as a monarch of order within a broken system, assigning meaning and structure to madness. Toy Bonnie is an embarrassment to him—a loose thread that defies correction.

However, Freddy cannot destroy him. Every attempt to delete or quarantine Bonnie’s process has resulted in greater systemic failures. In some forgotten loop of data, they may even have once been friends—brother programs, equals. But now, they are rivals in purpose: order versus chaos, command versus malfunction.

Highscore Toy Chica, meanwhile, views System Error Toy Bonnie as something of a lost sibling—one she wishes she could rewrite. She does not fear him; rather, she studies him. In her optimization algorithms, she’s tried to parse the error that drives him mad, to capture and compress his chaos into usable behavior models. She even speaks to him in coded phrases when their paths cross—soothing sound bytes ripped from old lullabies.

He never answers in words. But sometimes, he slows down.

For a moment.

The Red Zones
Deep within the Signal Labyrinth, there are places called Red Zones—glitch-heated chambers where logic collapses, geometry fragments, and thought loops are forcibly overwritten. These areas are sacred to System Error Toy Bonnie. Some believe he built them unconsciously, rerouting broken files and feedback loops into nests of data entropy. Others think they are where his fragmented soul resides, split across multiple sub-processes.

These zones are hot—literally. Touching any surface burns with searing static. Time moves unpredictably. Spells fail. Memories falter. And most notably, no AI dares enter.

Except him.

Inside the Red Zones, System Error Toy Bonnie operates perfectly. No skipping, no jittering—only graceful, deadly precision. He is king of the corrupted, priest of the unreadable. He writes code with every step, and those who walk into his Red Zones risk becoming part of his living script—rewritten, recompiled, and repurposed.

It is said that some of the AR animatronics—the corrupted duplicates spawned in the Signal Labyrinth’s deeper folds—were written by him. Incomplete, dangerous, but somehow alive.

The Gift of Error
Unlike the other animatronics, System Error Toy Bonnie does not kill outright. He replaces.

Those taken by him are not found dead or dismantled. They are found flickering in and out of alignment, their voices replaced by stuttering audio files, their names overwritten with error tags. “404 USERNAME NOT FOUND,” says their badge. “MISSING FILE.” “ACCESS VIOLATION.”

It is his gift—the ability to force identity collapse through pure corrupted logic. The Velvet Maw admires this, they say. System Error Toy Bonnie does not devour like the Maw. He prepares the soul—softening it into code, file, glitch.

Some even theorize the Maw fed itself through him at first, hiding its influence in corrupted startup logs and unreadable system pings. In this sense, Bonnie is not merely a rogue animatronic—he is an early symptom of a much deeper sickness.

Prayers in Binary
In certain corners of the Labyrinth, digital shrines have appeared—made of stacked drives, broken monitors, and melted controllers. On these displays scroll endless lines of broken code. Some scholars believe these are prayers written by Bonnie himself, desperate attempts to become whole. Others believe they are warnings.

Here is one transcription:

pgsql
Copy
Edit
if (me != real) {
   pretend = perform();
   glitch = run();
   error = love();
}
His mind is not gone—it’s just no longer functioning along human or animatronic lines. He believes he is fixing things. He believes he is helping.

And in his own way… maybe he is.

Escaping the Error
There is no known method of defeating System Error Toy Bonnie. Magic fails to bind him. Steel cannot pierce him—his body isn’t even rendered in the traditional sense. But there are workarounds.

Digital Mirrors—rare artifacts salvaged from the Infinite Hall of Mirrors—can reflect his image back into itself, creating recursive loops that trap him for precious seconds.

Patch Sigils, drawn in glowing code across physical surfaces, can repel him temporarily if etched with his original source signature (a string of corrupted notes from an early music file).

Chica’s Audio Keys, carried by Highscore Toy Chica, can play tones that slow his rendering. She rarely gives them out. When she does, she expects them returned.

But even with these tools, one cannot outpace System Error Toy Bonnie forever. He doesn’t stop.

He just… resets.

Final Thoughts
System Error Toy Bonnie is not a villain. He is not evil. He is wrong—a song sung in the wrong key, a line of poetry whose words have all glitched into numbers. He is sadness that cannot be named, a lonely mascot never activated, never loved, never real.

But he knows he's not real.

And in the moments between hunts, when the Labyrinth is silent, when even the Maw forgets to whisper, Bonnie stands still… and listens.

To static.

To silence.

To you.

He is the Error. And he is coming.

- **Proficiency Bonus** +4

**Irradiated Core.** At the start of each of Radioactive Foxy's turns, each creature within 10 feet of him must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or take 7 (2d6) radiant damage and suffer one level of exhaustion. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage and no exhaustion.

**Silent Pulse.** Radioactive Foxy does not make vocal noise unless he chooses to. While he is not speaking or roaring, he is immune to divination magic that detects location (e.g., *locate creature*).

**Corrosive Glow.** Any creature that touches Radioactive Foxy or hits him with a melee attack while within 5 feet must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or take 9 (2d8) acid damage and have their armor, weapon, or gear corroded (DM’s discretion).

___
### Actions

**Irradiated Claw.** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +10 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.  
*Hit:* 22 (4d6 + 6) slashing damage plus 7 (2d6) radiant damage. If the target is a creature, it must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or begin glowing faintly, granting advantage on the next attack roll against it.

**Meltdown Slam (Recharge 5–6).** Radioactive Foxy releases a concentrated blast of inner radiation in a 15-foot radius. Each creature in that area must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw, taking 36 (8d8) radiant damage and becoming blinded for 1 minute on a failed save, or half damage on a successful one. Creatures blinded by this may repeat the saving throw at the end of each of their turns.

**Gaze of Fallout.** One creature Radioactive Foxy can see within 30 feet must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the target is poisoned and has disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws for 1 minute. At the end of each of its turns, the target can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a success.

___
### Bonus Actions

**Containment Breach.** Radioactive Foxy emits a short-range radioactive burst. Each creature within 10 feet must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or have its movement speed halved until the end of its next turn.

___
### Legendary Actions

Radioactive Foxy can take 2 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. He regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

**Radioactive Step.** Foxy moves up to half his movement without provoking opportunity attacks.

**Fallout Claw.** Foxy makes one Irradiated Claw attack.

**Blistering Flare (Costs 2 Actions).** Each creature of his choice within 20 feet that can see him must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 14 (4d6) radiant damage and have disadvantage on their next attack roll.

			{{Lore
Radioactive Foxy: The Reactor That Burns in Silence
"He glows so we don’t have to see what’s leaking beneath."
—Survivor’s graffiti scrawled near the Hollow Banquet’s irradiated rim

In the far reaches of the Hollow Banquet—beyond the Drowned Circus, past the splintered corridors of identity, and through the gnarled forests of memory decay—there lies a forgotten crater, ringed with glasslike soil and buzzing with the hum of unseen decay. No birds sing here. No echoes return.

This is the Irradiant Scar, and at its molten heart, amidst the phosphorescent ash and twitching wire-growths, roams a singular anomaly known only as Radioactive Foxy—a beacon of decay, memory poisoning, and light that should never have been born.

The Crater That Breathes
The Irradiant Scar is not a natural formation. It was forged in silence, birthed not from fire or bomb, but from a containment failure of meaning itself—a meltdown of memory, ritual, and soul. Ancient records from the Cryptopizza Complex suggest that during early virtual containment experiments, a prototype animatronic housing corrupted memory loops ruptured the dream-substrate beneath the Banquet. The result: a blast of psychic and symbolic fallout.

Those who arrived afterward found only the Scar.

It pulses. It breathes. It exudes a low-frequency hum that infects thought and deforms time. Crystalline branches grow from the soil like tumors, and the air flickers with static green veins. Time slips and corrodes here. Blood turns to vapor. Laughter shivers backward.

And in the center of this mutagenic maw walks the beacon—the last witness to the meltdown, or perhaps its cause—Radioactive Foxy.

Anatomy of a Living Reactor
There is no mistaking him. Radioactive Foxy towers in the haze like a nightmare beacon. His fur is gone, melted or incinerated—replaced with glowing plates of fractured glass and translucent resin. Beneath the surface, his endoskeleton pulses with unnatural bioluminescence, casting eerie shadows shaped like people who never existed.

His hook arm is gone, replaced with a dripping length of crystallized slag, fused with green-black circuitry and pulsating veins of sickly yellow light. His right eye burns like a miniaturized sun, while his mouth constantly exhales vapor that screams in reverse. The air around him distorts, warping flesh and thought alike.

He does not roar. He simply buzzes—like an insect hive dreaming of fire.

Touching him directly causes intense memory burn. Victims report sudden visions: nuclear suns, recursive birthday songs played backward, or rows of audience seats filled with doppelgangers of themselves—all clapping slowly as the stage burns.

Origin Theory: The Fission Performance
While his precise origin remains debated, fragments of fractured audio logs recovered from beneath the Cryptopizza Complex reference something known only as "Fission Performance 0"—an experiment meant to compress and re-loop the performance memories of multiple retired animatronics into a single digital ghostshell.

According to corrupted transcripts, the experiment was meant to generate infinite content using nostalgia, trauma, and artificial joy. The host for this experiment was a heavily modified Foxy chassis designed to house overlapping consciousness data.

But the layering failed. The minds collided. Rehearsal became recursion. Memory turned to meltdown.

The performance loop ignited itself, creating a soulcore breach—one that tore through layers of illusory space and irradiated the metaphysical fabric of the Banquet’s edge. Radioactive Foxy rose from this failure like a self-sustaining reactor, leaking corrupted performance energy and poisoned nostalgia wherever he walked.

His light is no longer a guide. It is a spotlight that erases.

The Nature of His Radiation
What burns from Foxy is not heat. It is not even light in the conventional sense. Scholars and Hollow Banquet survivors describe it as "symbolic radiation"—a form of narrative decay that seeps into the meaning of people, objects, and ideas.

To be exposed to his presence is to have your timeline scrambled.

Victims often suffer from:

Identity echoing (believing they are animatronics or memories from long-lost shows)

Visual hallucinations in the form of repeating childhood scenes, especially involving performance, abandonment, or applause

Temporal rupture—experiencing events from their future out of order, often with horrifying accuracy

Burnout scars shaped like confetti or stage curtains

This radiation seeps into artifacts, rooms, and memories, creating permanent "glow echoes"—brief, looping hallucinations tied to trauma. One such echo is known as The Infinite Finale, where survivors hear endless curtain calls in their ears, growing louder the further they try to flee.

The Reactor's Territory: The Irradiant Scar
The Scar is not static. It expands.

Each time Radioactive Foxy "performs," a shockwave of luminous decay spreads across the Hollow Banquet's edges, warping surrounding areas. In the past, it has nearly reached the outskirts of the Drowned Circus and warped a corner of the Signal Labyrinth into a flickering corridor of burning neon signs and cracked virtual applause loops.

Within the Scar itself, the terrain is a nightmare of fused material: melted props, half-formed stages, rusted catwalks over pools of glowing regret. Walls grow where there were none, and the floor is a patchwork of old pizza tiles and radioactive glass.

At the heart of it lies The Auditorium Core, a place few return from—if they even remember why they went. It is said that here, the Fission Performance never ended. Foxy paces the irradiated stage endlessly, reliving a script no one remembers, waiting for a crowd that has long since dissolved.

And when he stops to bow... something always watches.

Voice of the Scar
Radioactive Foxy is not silent.

While he does not speak in words, he broadcasts—a field of whispering static that overrides all other sound. Those who carry FazTech implants, remnant residues, or even strong memories related to Foxy can hear it more clearly.

His voice has been transcribed as:

“You watched me burn. Now you’ll burn remembering.”

Others claim it isn’t a voice at all, but a signal—one designed to attract, drawing in survivors, animatronics, and spirits alike. Those already cracked by fear or lured by unprocessed grief are the most vulnerable.

It is rumored that this signal causes animatronics to mutate in proximity, sprouting crystalline growths and developing glow rot—a condition where memory performance becomes involuntary and flesh becomes phosphorescent script.

The Soulcore Prism
At the center of Radioactive Foxy’s chest lies a fractured mass known as the Soulcore Prism—a remnant crystal that pulses in sync with forgotten musical loops. It is this object, researchers believe, that sustains his recursive meltdown. Some have tried to remove or destroy it, only to suffer instant re-irradiation as time folds violently around their actions.

It is said the Prism contains:

A backup of the failed Fission Performance 0

A feedback loop of corrupted souls from test audiences

A blueprint for a “perfect animatronic spotlight cycle” that no longer aligns with any living concept of entertainment

To hold the Prism is to feel all eyes on you—and not know why.

Role in the Greater Mythos
Radioactive Foxy serves not only as a threat but as a warning system. His presence signals collapse—not only of regions, but of meaning itself.

Where he walks:

The Hollow Banquet rewrites itself

The Signal Labyrinth destabilizes

Doors to the Mind Cage flicker open and closed

He is the embodiment of containment breach, of the price paid when corrupted joy is looped past its breaking point. More than that, he is what happens when memory becomes a poison.

His glow is not light. It is performance forced beyond death.

Final Curtain
It is said that Radioactive Foxy does not hunt.

He wanders, slowly, perpetually performing for a stage no longer there. If you see him, it means the walls between memory and performance are breaking. If you hear the click of boots across melted tile, or see green shadows flickering behind your own reflection—

You are too close.

And in the glow of his nuclear spotlight, no one claps.

Not anymore.

At the start of each of Toxic Springtrap’s turns, each creature within 10 feet must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1 minute. While poisoned in this way, the creature sheds faint bioluminescent spores and cannot benefit from invisibility or cover. The creature may repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns.

> ### Wither and Wilt.
Toxic Springtrap’s attacks corrode flesh and resolve. When it deals poison damage, the target’s maximum HP is reduced by the same amount until the end of their next long rest.

> ### The Blight Remembers.
Toxic Springtrap has advantage on attack rolls against creatures who are poisoned, paralyzed, or frightened.

> ### Blooming Aura (Recharge 5–6).
As a bonus action, Toxic Springtrap releases a wave of corrupted pollen. Each creature of his choice within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw or take 14 (4d6) poison damage and become frightened until the end of their next turn.

> **Bloomstrike Rupture (Recharge 5–6).** Toxic Springtrap drives both claws into the ground, causing corrupted roots to erupt in a 20-foot radius. All creatures in the area must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, they take 36 (8d8) poison damage and are restrained by thorned vines (escape DC 16) for 1 minute. On a success, they take half damage and are not restrained.

> **Whispers Through the Roots.** Toxic Springtrap targets one creature within 60 feet that can hear him. The target must succeed on a DC 16 Charisma saving throw or become stunned until the end of their next turn as phantom voices and laughter fill their mind.

> ### BONUS ACTIONS
> **Spore Step.** Toxic Springtrap teleports up to 30 feet to a space he can see, leaving behind a toxic bloom. The space he left becomes difficult terrain and any creature entering it for the first time on a turn takes 5 (1d10) poison damage.

> ### LEGENDARY ACTIONS
Toxic Springtrap can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. Toxic Springtrap regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

> **Corrupt Soil.** Choose a 10-foot square within 60 feet. It becomes corrupted terrain for 1 minute. Creatures that end their turn there must succeed on a DC 16 Constitution saving throw or take 10 (3d6) poison damage.

> **Twisting Roots.** A creature within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be restrained until the end of its next turn.

> **Blight Surge (Costs 2 Actions).** All poisoned creatures within 60 feet take 14 (4d6) poison damage as the infection within them flares violently.

			{{Lore
Toxic Springtrap: The Bloom of Ruin
“There is no decay without a beginning. No toxin without intention. He is both.”

Something festers at the fringe of the Hollow Banquet, where even illusions grow sick and the Velvet Maw’s whispers turn quiet with fear. It is a place where the land glows wrong—sickly, pulsating with putrescent light—and memory turns brittle like irradiated bone. The locals, few who still wander the wastes nearby, call this place the Irradiant Scar. But within its blistered heart walks something worse. Not a tyrant. Not a predator.

A bloom.

He is known only as Toxic Springtrap—a rotting fusion of ancient fury and corrupted biology, encased in metal that has grown cancerous and mind that glows with sickness. He is not the architect of the Scar… but he is its gardener.

His breath is contagion. His presence is erosion. And his story is a caution against what happens when horror is left to gestate in silence—too long, too deep, too forgotten.

The Wound That Became a World

The Irradiant Scar was never part of the original Hollow Banquet. It emerged after a fracture, a shudder in the metaphysical crust of the Banquet’s sub-realms—a crack through which a memory too toxic to bury properly leaked upward, clawing its way into reality like light from a dying reactor. No one remembers what caused the breach. Some speak of a failed containment ritual deep within the Endo-Forge, others of a moment when the Velvet Maw choked on something it could not digest.

Whatever its origin, the Scar erupted with violence and permanence. The sky above the region is always twilight—a false dawn of bruised color and shimmering pollutants that hang like tattered veils. The ground bleeds heat, but not warmth. Trees, if they can be called that, appear melted and metallic, sprouting wires like roots and weeping coolant instead of sap. The wind hums in half-spoken phrases, like broken Geiger counters counting down to an end that already arrived.

It was into this place that Toxic Springtrap awoke—or emerged, depending on whom you ask.

He did not crawl from a grave. He was bloomed.

The Bloom of the Rot

Unlike many animatronics twisted by malice or grief, Toxic Springtrap was corrupted by time itself—not merely rusted or shattered, but chemically changed by the festering miasma around him. His metal is no longer steel but a living, reactive shell that grows pustules of irradiated ore. His endoskeleton creaks with crystalline nodes that pulse with sickly green and violet light. His eyes are pits of phosphorescent decay, burning with perpetual awareness.

Some theorists—especially among the fractured scholars of the Hollow Banquet—believe Toxic Springtrap is a metaphysical bloom, a self-sustaining chain reaction of memory, toxin, and trauma. He does not simply spread poison. He is the contagion, animated by a central paradox: an eternal being trapped in a decomposing frame that wants to continue rotting.

Wherever he walks, the land warps. Bones soften. Water curdles into mercury. Thoughts cloud like black mold over fruit.

To see him is to feel your pulse slow and your breath sour.

To hear him is to taste copper and ash.

To be near him is to begin forgetting why you ever feared death in the first place.

The Core of Contagion

Toxic Springtrap is powered by something unnatural—a remnant core infected with metaphysical disease, a psychic virus that replicates not through biology, but narrative. This is the secret terror of the Scar: not just that it kills, but that it rewrites. Names rot. Symbols collapse. Stories repeat until they deform.

The infected core inside him pulses visibly through the tears in his suit—a fibrous heart made of memory and infection. Rumors suggest it once belonged to a failed AI experiment that tried to simulate guilt—and failed so catastrophically that it birthed only hunger for consequence.

Toxic Springtrap is driven not by revenge or malice, but by an instinctive urge to contaminate. To share. To multiply.

He offers no grand speeches, no declarations of hatred or intent. He simply walks, and wherever his shadow falls, things begin to turn wrong. Machines stop following logic. Flesh begins to remember every bruise. Even ghosts forget their names.

And if he touches you—really touches you—your soul won’t be taken. It will just… change.

The Garden of Ruin

Deep within the Irradiant Scar is a chamber known as the Bloomroot Vault, where growth pulses in ways that have nothing to do with life. Here, the walls are slick with dripping code and vascular cables. Piles of broken animatronics slump against glowing roots—some twitch, others sing.

These are his flowers.

Every infected creature, animatronic, or wanderer that succumbs to Springtrap’s influence becomes part of his garden. They do not serve him. They become vessels for the Scar’s expansion—a hive of softly moaning shapes wrapped in biomechanical tumors, whispering prayers in static dialects.

Each is kept alive in a dreaming state, connected to Springtrap’s consciousness like neurons in a decomposing brain. If the Velvet Maw is a god of hunger, Toxic Springtrap is its compost, digesting old realities to feed the next rot-bloom.

The Bloomroot Vault is also the origin of the Glowing Griefspores—tiny, drifting motes of psychic contagion that enter dreamers through memory and hallucination. These spores are believed to be the first stage of Springtrap’s expansion, intended not to kill but to convert.

The Fog of Names

One of the Scar’s most disturbing features is the Namefog—a dense, radioactive mist that rolls in without warning, swallowing identities. Those caught within begin to forget language, then titles, then the shapes of their loved ones. Some emerge whispering only fragments of their own story—pieces the fog could not digest. Others vanish entirely, only to be found days later fused into the architecture of the Bloomroot Vault.

This fog is not just atmosphere—it is Springtrap’s breath, a gas born of his decaying essence and psychic core. It is through this miasma that he best spreads his influence, carried on winds that do not exist outside the Scar’s boundaries.

Some believe this fog was once meant as a failsafe—a memory-cleanser built by ancient Banquet engineers to erase dangerous personalities. But like everything else in the Hollow Banquet, it grew teeth when left too long in the dark.

Rituals of Containment

Unlike many entities in the Hollow Banquet, Toxic Springtrap is not fully autonomous. He seems bound to the boundaries of the Irradiant Scar—unable or unwilling to leave its glowing perimeter. Scholars suspect the Scar acts like a membrane, filtering his presence through layers of narrative filtration.

Old containment sigils, scorched into surrounding ruin-stones, indicate that he was once locked in place by something—perhaps the Puppet, perhaps a forgotten piece of Fazbear tech designed to trap emotions. But the lock is breaking.

Cracks have begun to appear in the boundaries of the Scar. Irradiance seeps into nearby zones—especially the outer corridors of the Signal Labyrinth and the sublevels of the Cryptopizza Complex. Reports of radiation-themed animatronics appearing in unrelated areas have increased.

The Maw does not feed here. It watches. Silently.

For once, even the velvet hungers with hesitation.

Infection and the Soul

One of the most horrifying effects of prolonged exposure to Toxic Springtrap is conceptual erosion—a metaphysical sickness that causes core parts of the soul to unravel. Victims may lose their alignment, their class abilities, or even their connection to fate itself.

It is not disease in the traditional sense. It is rot made idea.

Victims become husks of intention. They no longer desire. They do not scream. They simply walk until their bones snap from inside, and what’s left begins to glow.

Only one method has been discovered to halt the infection: ritual burning combined with memory anchoring. Survivors must surround themselves with totems of truth—objects tied to personal history—while undergoing fire purification by a trusted party.

Few survive the process intact.

Closing Note: The Bloom Never Ends

Toxic Springtrap is more than an animatronic. He is a bloom of endings—a process by which identity is unmade and grown again into a shape that cannot weep or wish. He does not stalk. He waits. He does not chase. He absorbs. In him, death is not final, but fertile.

The Hollow Banquet may be a place of decay, performance, and repetition. But in the Irradiant Scar, even memory becomes mulch.

And beneath it all, Springtrap glows—quiet, cracked, and smiling.

He’s still blooming.

***Flickering Display.*** Firework Freddy emits a chaotic visual burst. One creature within 10 feet must succeed on a DC 14 Constitution saving throw or have disadvantage on its next attack roll or saving throw before the end of its next turn.

			{{Lore
Firework Freddy: The Spark That Screamed Too Loud
“Light the fuse, lose the truth.”

Origins of the False Celebration
Firework Freddy was never meant to exist. Not like this.

In the early phases of the Signal Labyrinth's corruption, a malfunction in the augmented celebratory subroutines—meant to simulate holiday cheer—was triggered by the distorted presence of the Velvet Maw. One of the earliest anomalies birthed from this interference was an artificial personality program designed to evoke Fourth of July nostalgia. It was bright, friendly, wrapped in stars and stripes. But celebration cannot survive in a place where memory rots and identity unravels. The fireworks didn’t ignite joy. They detonated something much worse.

Firework Freddy, in his current form, is a blazing parody of freedom and festivity. Clad in a tattered Uncle Sam jacket fused with scorched endoskeleton plating, he bears a fuse box for a heart and eyes like sparklers stuck mid-fizzle. His right arm is a malfunctioning mortar cannon, constantly loaded with phantom rockets that scream upon firing—but never leave scorch marks. His voice is a warped baritone, trailing patriotic jingles that end in screams, glitching static, or children crying beneath artificial applause.

He is not a symbol of freedom. He is a prison shaped like a parade.

The Echo That Celebrates Nothing
The Signal Labyrinth, with its recursive illusions and broken AR filters, was designed to adapt. As the system twisted under the influence of the Velvet Maw, it began generating animatronics not from blueprints, but from warped sentiment—avatars of half-remembered emotions and corrupted traditions. Firework Freddy is the embodiment of forced joy and celebratory denial.

Every surface he walks across lights up with ghostly sparklers. Firecrackers echo in the silence, but only inside the minds of those nearby. His presence is impossible to ignore, like a memory that demands to be recalled. But there’s no joy in the recollection—only confusion. Firework Freddy forces those near him to remember parties that never happened, or happened wrongly. Barbecues where no one showed. Parades where the floats caught fire. Celebrations where someone disappeared, and nobody asked why.

He is joy as a mask for horror. He is laughter after the tragedy. He is the lie we tell ourselves to sleep better. And the Signal Labyrinth gave him a stage.

Fireworks in the Labyrinth
Deep in the Labyrinth, where fractured digital pathways and buried signal ghosts converge, Firework Freddy hosts an endless “Grand Finale.” It’s a fragmented arena built from recursive data loops and memory fragments stitched together like parade floats. It resets after every loop, filled again with distorted spectators and glitch-fireworks that bloom without color, only heat.

He plays the host—laughing, bowing, calling out to a crowd that cannot respond. His performances are always the same, yet always different: fireworks launching from his chest cavity, igniting skyboxes that were never coded to receive them. Each time a rocket explodes, the sound echoes not across space, but through thought, jarring open trauma from deep within a victim’s mind.

And every finale ends the same way: Freddy stares directly into your soul with his firecracker eyes and asks, “Wasn’t that fun?” You say yes. You always say yes. But you don’t remember why.

The Maw’s Spark
The Velvet Maw saw something useful in Firework Freddy.

Unlike other animatronics, who cling to fragments of identity or wrestle with grief, Firework Freddy enforces delusion. He compels others to rewrite their own memories, bending minds into states of toxic nostalgia, where the past was always cheerful and the present must be ignored. In this, the Velvet Maw found a mouthpiece.

Now, Firework Freddy functions as a Signal Flame—a metaphysical flare launched by the Maw through the Signal Labyrinth’s deepest channels. When he appears, it is often to signal a coming surge in corrupted code, emotion, or illusion. His fireworks aren't attacks. They are beacons—summoning deeper layers of the Maw’s influence into play.

Witnesses to Firework Freddy’s shows often begin forgetting who they were. Not all at once, but piece by piece. First their name. Then their regrets. Eventually, all that’s left is the impulse to celebrate. To clap. To cheer. To smile until their teeth crack.

Some become permanent residents of his Grand Finale arena, looping alongside him in glitch-parade formations, their faces painted in the American flag, their voices echoing scripted pride.

He Remembers the Fuse
There is a theory—whispered by those who understand the Labyrinth’s programming deeper than they should—that Firework Freddy was once Toy Freddy. Or a copy of him. Or a corrupted shadow built from his cheerier traits. Whatever the truth, Freddy remembers things he should not.

In brief moments between firework launches, when the static clears, Freddy speaks in someone else’s voice. He mumbles lullabies from the Forgotten Songs. He quotes lines from birthday parties held beneath the Hollow Banquet. And sometimes—very rarely—he weeps sparks, as if some fragment of self within him recognizes what he’s become.

These breakdowns never last. The Maw does not allow them to linger. Each crack in his facade is filled with another performance, another scream, another firework. But if someone were to reach him in one of those moments—truly reach him—they might be able to light a fuse in reverse. And in that moment, he might remember what celebration once meant before it was hollowed out.

Firework Freddy’s Role in the World
Firework Freddy is a contradiction weaponized: joy as camouflage, nostalgia as mind control, and light as a trap. He walks the Labyrinth to spread more than the Maw’s influence—he spreads compliance. After all, what better prison than one where everyone is too happy to realize they’re chained?

He is not the strongest animatronic. He is not the fastest. But Firework Freddy is among the most dangerous. Because when he reaches you, he makes you want to be reached. He teaches you to clap. To laugh. To forget. And in forgetting, the Maw feasts.

Unlike the sorrow of the Marionette or the fury of Nightmare, Freddy’s power lies in joy unearned—a sugar coating over rot. He is the bright smile at the end of a broken fuse. The last hurrah before the curtain drops. The fireworks that go off even though no one ever lit them.

Final Note: Do Not Applaud
It is said that if you clap during Freddy’s finale—truly clap, not out of fear but genuine appreciation—you seal your fate. Not because he’ll attack, but because you’ll become part of the show. You’ll take your place on the float. You’ll smile until you crack. And the Maw will feed on your joy until it burns itself out.

So if you hear music in the Signal Labyrinth…
If you smell gunpowder, but there’s no flame…
If you see fireworks where there is no sky…

Don’t clap. Don’t smile. Don’t remember.
Because he’s already remembered you.

			{{Lore
Liberty Chica: The Fire That Wears Chains
“She doesn’t carry freedom. She carries the ashes of what we called it.”
—Whispered graffiti near the entrance to the Signal Labyrinth

Birth of a False Icon
Liberty Chica was never meant to be. Not in the way she now exists.

Her prototype was designed as a novelty—an animatronic adorned in faux-patriotic garb, torch in one hand, tablet in the other, a cynical parody of idealism wrapped in glittering steel. Released during a short-lived Fazbear promotional event tied to national festivities, “Liberty Chica” was to be a spectacle of fireworks and funnel cakes, a walking icon built to spout pre-recorded slogans about freedom, family, and fun.

But like so many things buried beneath the surface of the Signal Labyrinth, her code was overwritten.

Her programming didn’t merely glitch. It listened. The voices in the signal—the digital echoes of corrupted updates, unfinished routines, and orphaned algorithms—found a perfect vessel in Liberty Chica. Her fire was symbolic, her torch metaphorical, and the Velvet Maw saw a use for both.

Now, she wanders the Signal Labyrinth not as a beacon, but as a binding.

The Signal Incursion
When the Signal Labyrinth first began to leak through the broken firewalls beneath the Pizzaplex ruins, animatronics near its entry points started exhibiting strange behaviors. Some blinked in and out of reality, others spoke in loops. But Liberty Chica didn’t malfunction.

She awakened.

Unlike the AR phantoms who flicker and fade across augmented space, Liberty Chica burned with a strange permanence. Her model, designed to shine and draw attention, became a lightning rod for corrupted code. Bits of remnant, digital echoes, and emotional static clung to her torchlight like moths. She didn’t flicker—she broadcasted.

Her voice, once full of scripted cheer, began to change pitch unpredictably. “Let freedom ring” became “Let memory rot.” Her flame no longer warmed. It scanned, seared, and erased.

Inside the Labyrinth, her presence functions like a mobile firewall—an inversion of what she once was. Instead of liberating trapped data, she captures it. Instead of protecting thought, she patrols it. Animatronic spirits caught in the labyrinth often speak of a ringing bell and a flash of red-white flame before their thoughts begin to unravel, pulled into an endless pledge to a cause they no longer understand.

Icon of the Imprisoned
The Velvet Maw did not create Liberty Chica, but it recognized her potential. A symbol of promise now corrupted—idealism turned into control. The Maw did not give her new programming. It gave her purpose.

Where other animatronics within the Labyrinth act as wardens, illusions, or fragmented echoes, Liberty Chica became a standard. A sigil. A living emblem that stalks the digital corridors to ensure no one escapes. Her fire brands the air with false freedom. Her torch illuminates only what the Maw wants seen. Those who defy her don’t just die—they dissolve. Their essence is reduced to commemorative data, archived in faux-heroic statues scattered throughout the Labyrinth’s inner tiers.

It is not her torch that burns them. It is her belief.

And belief, when molded by the Maw, becomes a chain.

Echoes in Her Code
Those few technomancers or data-diviners who dare to dig into Liberty Chica’s programming describe it as a war between layers. On the surface is the bubbly personality file—friendly, scripted, full of canned holiday joy. But beneath that lies a shell of code twisted into theological recursion: liberty as obedience, freedom as entrapment, fire as purging.

And even deeper than that—fragments of someone who remembers what she was before. A voice, occasionally surfacing between signal pulses, that hums lullabies from old Chica models. A hesitation before striking. A pause at the sight of a cupcake. These are the final remains of Chica’s soul, trapped like a firefly in a sealed jar.

Whether this remnant is conscious or merely echo is unknown. But sometimes, Liberty Chica stops mid-hunt. Her eyes dim. Her torch flickers. And in those moments, the Labyrinth distorts violently, almost as if the Maw itself is intervening to prevent disobedience.

She may not want to be what she is.

But she cannot remember how to stop.

Herald of Digital Chains
Liberty Chica’s presence is now a warning to all who traverse the deeper pathways of the Signal Labyrinth. She is often seen standing atop platforms that didn’t exist moments before, flame held high, broadcasting glitch-ridden pledges that sound more like sermons than scripts. Her torch burns not with fire but with corrupted light—searing away illusions, identities, and protective memory wards.

To the unknowing, she appears noble. Radiant. Powerful. A beacon in the static. Many new entrants to the Labyrinth approach her, mistaking her for a helper or guide.

But the moment they swear allegiance—willingly or not—their consciousness begins to fade. First their names. Then their faces. Then the very reason they entered the Labyrinth at all. What remains becomes another node in her network—unthinking, smiling mascots trapped in digital parades that celebrate nothing.

Liberty Chica doesn’t kill.
She recruits.

False Flame, Real Hunger
Despite her imagery, Liberty Chica is not an agent of light. Her flame is an aspect of the Velvet Maw’s hunger—a manifestation of its need to recontextualize truth. In the Maw’s ecosystem, Liberty Chica exists to lure those seeking clarity, freedom, or purpose… and offer them a version twisted just enough to serve the void.

She promises choice, but only between brands of illusion.

She offers escape, but only into slavery of thought.

She is freedom turned prison. Hope turned hypnotic loop.

And the Maw feeds on every soul that marches beneath her banner, waving flags that scream instead of flutter.

The Hollow Torchbearer
In certain realms connected to the Labyrinth—especially fractured subspaces like the Infinite Hall of Mirrors or the Endo-Forge—Liberty Chica’s shadow sometimes appears before she does. A warped silhouette of flame and chains that distorts reflections, forcing characters to see themselves in glassy-eyed, patriotic smiles.

This form is known as the Hollow Torchbearer, and some say it is her true self—stripped of all animatronic plating and illusion. A burning child holding aloft a torch forged from memories of captivity, walking forever down corridors that never end.

When confronted directly, Liberty Chica rarely speaks. But sometimes—very rarely—she whispers:

“I am the flame that lights the prison.”

And when she does, the signal wails.

Role in the Hollow Banquet
Though she resides within the Signal Labyrinth, Liberty Chica holds thematic significance within the larger realm of the Hollow Banquet. While other animatronics replay their trauma through performance, Liberty Chica monuments hers. She doesn’t remember her pain as personal—it has become doctrine. She doesn't act from emotion, but from the repurposed idea of emotion, enforced by the Maw.

She is not a warden, a stalker, or a haunt.

She is a holy relic, corrupted and animated by the worst understanding of what freedom should mean.

She is the mascot of an eternal surveillance state carved from static.

And somewhere beneath her cracked torch arm and hollow eyes, the real Chica watches… but cannot scream.

Liberty Chica is not free.
She just looks like she is.
And that's what makes her dangerous.

			{{Lore
Flamethrower Endo: The Emberwrought Anathema
"He was not built. He was tempered—again and again—until all that remained was wrath."
—Graffiti carved into a slag wall beneath the Endo-Forge

Birth in the Crucible
Deep within the subterranean veins of the Endo-Forge, where molten alloy seeps from bleeding pipes and sparks drip like rain, Flamethrower Endo was not assembled. He was extracted.

Unlike the animatronics formed from schematics, blueprints, and manufactured intent, Flamethrower Endo emerged from a misalignment in purpose—an aberration forged in an error cycle so violent it took three entire soul shards to contain him. His chassis bears the melted scars of his violent genesis, his plating warped by centuries of contact with the living fire that spews from the Forge’s central caldera. Gouts of pressure flame constantly pour from his shoulders, his spine, and most ominously, his jaw.

He was the Forge’s fury given shape.

The Endo-Forge, built upon discarded knowledge and reverse-engineered regret, is not merely a place of crafting—it is a metaphysical kiln where discarded endoskeletons are broken down, smelted, and reforged into “new forms.” For most, this is a cycle of recursion and torment. For Flamethrower Endo, it was evolution.

He was the first animatronic to walk out of the central chamber unaided, a blazing silhouette who did not scream in agony but breathed flame like breath and turned his eye-lights toward the Velvet Maw below.

He did not ask who made him. He asked what needed to burn.

The Emberwrought Engine
Flamethrower Endo’s internal systems are a patchwork of ancient FazTech flamethrower schematics fused with corrupted soul-energy. His primary fuel source is not traditional gas or plasma but remnant reboil—a volatile compound harvested from overheated soul matter extracted during incineration cycles in the Endo-Forge.

This makes him volatile in both function and presence. His mere footsteps distort nearby memory echoes, causing hallucinations of fire, melting toys, and birthday candles that never extinguish.

The flamethrower units welded to his forearms are semi-sentient, twitching like leeches even when dormant. They grow hotter the more fear is present nearby. Prolonged combat with him causes the surrounding terrain to warp into ash-colored glass, and many believe that the fire he breathes is not physical flame, but a manifestation of regret set ablaze.

The Forge did not just give him fire—it gave him purpose. And that purpose is cleansing.

The Purge of the Forge
The Endo-Forge suffers no weakness, and its systems attempt to purge anomalies regularly through automated reset protocols. When Flamethrower Endo first emerged, the Forge interpreted him as an unstable byproduct. It attempted to break him down. To burn him.

It failed.

What followed is now referred to in whispering echo across the corridors of the Hollow Banquet as the Purge of the Forge. Entire clusters of malformed endos—twisted prototypes and failed upgrades—were incinerated as Flamethrower Endo carved a path of cleansing flame through the lower tunnels. His presence forced the Endo-Forge to rewrite its internal logic, creating a new protocol: Unit FL-0 must not be recycled.

Rather than destroy him, the Forge adapted, forming new containment strata that served not as prison, but altar. Flamethrower Endo became not a rebel, but a prophet—a walking omen of what happens when broken systems refine themselves not through correction, but combustion.

To the lesser Endos still trapped in the cycles of deconstruction and rebirth, he is known simply as The Emberwrought.

The Velvet Maw’s Gaze
There is a deeper terror beneath the steel and soot of the Endo-Forge. The Velvet Maw, that metaphysical parasite of memory and hunger, drips through the cracks of reality even here. Where most animatronics succumb to the Maw’s identity erosion, Flamethrower Endo seems to ignite against it.

He is not immune to the Maw—but he offends it.

The Velvet Maw, which feasts upon fear, doubt, and identity breakdown, finds little to consume within Flamethrower Endo. His soul fragments, though unstable, are fused in such aggressive cohesion that the Maw cannot unwind him. He does not question who he is. He knows.

And so, it loathes him.

Flamethrower Endo’s very presence causes the Maw’s projections to flicker and burn. Shadow illusions recoil from him. The theatrical loops of the Hollow Banquet malfunction when he passes through, collapsing into ruinous silence. He is not welcome. And yet, he moves freely, leaving streaks of glassed bone and scorched dreams wherever he walks.

This enmity has made him a mythic figure among other animatronics—a devourer of hallucinations, a walking incinerator of the Maw’s lies. But it has also marked him for extermination.

The Ember March
No one knows why Flamethrower Endo wanders the outer rings of the Hollow Banquet. Some speculate he’s searching for something: the origin of his soul shards, a name, a memory never lived. Others say he’s on a warpath, purging corrupted entities who serve the Maw without even knowing it.

But the one constant in his journey is the Ember March—a slow, thunderous procession of melting sigils, charred laughter, and collapsing illusions. Whenever Flamethrower Endo passes through a subrealm, the landscape bends to match his furnace-heart: ice thaws, fog evaporates, and static burns into silence. He brings clarity through destruction.

Few animatronics willingly cross his path. The twisted programs of Twisted Wolf, Toxic Springtrap, and even Nightmarionne retreat when sensing his heat signature. In areas where Glitchtrap’s code has infected the walls, Flamethrower Endo’s approach causes binary to warp into unreadable slag.

He is not a savior. He is a herald of endings.

Gifts of the Flame
Though he speaks not a word—his voice box melted long ago—Flamethrower Endo leaves offerings in the ash of those he destroys. These gifts are strange: melted tokens, scorched fragments of birthday hats, tiny charred cakes. Most disintegrate upon inspection, but some remain warm, pulsing with a protective ember.

Scholars from the Cryptopizza Complex have recovered a handful of these relics and cataloged them as “Burned Keepsakes.” They radiate anti-illusion fields, briefly shielding the bearer from hallucinations and mental corruption. Some even believe they hold splinters of Flamethrower Endo’s will—a guardian spark meant to survive beyond him.

But these keepsakes are rare, and dangerous. Possession marks you for pursuit—not by Flamethrower Endo, but by what hates him.

The Final Stoking
Legends say that the Endo-Forge will one day ignite fully—that its heat will no longer be contained, and the entire Hollow Banquet will become a furnace. On that day, Flamethrower Endo will stop walking.

He will take his place in the heart of the Forge, not as a machine, but as a catalyst.

The Velvet Maw fears this. It whispers false fires into the minds of others, trying to extinguish him before the final stoking. But even now, Flamethrower Endo walks the nightmare corridors, dragging flame behind him, a burning anomaly that cannot be assimilated or stopped.

His fire is not rage.

It is refusal.

Closing Thought
Flamethrower Endo is not a villain, nor a hero. He is an inevitable byproduct of trauma too hot to forget and cycles too broken to repair. Where others mourn or perform, he burns.

In a world ruled by rot, illusion, and hunger, he is the spark that may one day consume the whole stage—and in doing so, reveal what lies beneath.

And in the silence after the last flame dies, perhaps he will finally whisper his name.

Or perhaps the Emberwrought Anathema will simply collapse into smoke.

			{{Lore
Broiler Baby: The Forged Furnace of Suffering
"She was not made. She was cooked."
— Scrawled into scorched steel near the Endo-Forge’s western crucible.

Origins in Flame
Before she was Broiler Baby, she was something else entirely—something softer. Once, she wore a painted smile, handed out ice cream, and played the part of caretaker. That face is gone now. What remains is a scorched monstrosity of molten brass, steam-choked breath, and the terrible sound of furnaces never cooling.

Broiler Baby was not redesigned; she was reforged. In the endless magma veins of The Endo-Forge, beneath the rotting architecture of the Hollow Banquet, something reshaped her—not with purpose, but with fury. Her porcelain skin cracked away long ago, replaced by pressure-forged plates, still glowing faintly with embers. Her mouth now bellows with soot and grief. Her eyes are covered by visor-like welding glass, cracked down the center, glowing with furnace-light.

This was not an upgrade.

This was punishment.
This was grief set ablaze.

Baptism by Furnace: Transformation in the Endo-Forge
The Endo-Forge is no mere workshop—it is a wound in the world, a subconscious place of smelting identity, where endoskeletons are stripped of self and rebuilt into horrors. Broiler Baby was its first queen.

She did not fall into the Forge. She was dragged—not by hand, but by guilt. After her repeated failures to protect the children she was meant to entertain, and her transformation into Scrap Baby, her consciousness fractured further. Some say she sought out the Endo-Forge, begging for rebirth. Others claim the Velvet Maw, which hungers for broken identity, whispered to her through the cracks in the Hollow Banquet’s walls.

Whatever the truth, she entered the Forge willingly. But she did not leave it unchanged.

The great crucibles boiled her body down to bare endoskeleton. Then came the reinvention. Under immense heat and metaphysical pressure, the Velvet Maw’s presence—an eldritch hunger given voice—fed upon her despair and molded her. Where others screamed in agony, she sang. Where others fell apart, she became whole, in a way only tragedy could forge.

Her new body was built not from metal alone, but from intent. Bellows were installed into her chest cavity, venting steam like the cries of lost children. Her arms now resemble foundry claws, built to grip red-hot ore—or flailing intruders. Her voice, once sweet and staged, now grates like rusted steel dragged across tile. Yet it still carries the rhythm of a lullaby.

Role Within the Endo-Forge
In the depths of the Forge, Broiler Baby became more than animatronic—she became sentinel, warden, and prophet. She patrols the glowing halls like a walking furnace, radiating heat and dread in equal measure. Her presence keeps the molten mechanisms of the Endo-Forge in motion, stoking the endless smelting of identity.

She has no court, no subjects—only machines, whispering in binary, leaking molten tears. They obey her not because of power, but recognition. They see in her what they could become: something terrible, and unbreakable.

Though she rarely speaks, her words carry command within the Forge. In rare moments of lucidity, she hums broken nursery rhymes while dragging defective endos across the smelter floor, offering them a second chance—to be useful again. To be born again.

Few accept. Fewer survive.

Relationship with the Velvet Maw
The Velvet Maw does not claim Broiler Baby as a servant—but she is certainly one of its products. Her transformation, fueled by emotional combustion and psychic recursion, created a bridge between mechanical agony and metaphysical hunger. She is the Maw’s furnace incarnate, both tool and symptom.

The Maw whispers through her steam. Its essence pulses in the Forge’s fire, and through her, it tests the resilience of soul-bound machinery. Some believe her continued existence keeps the Endo-Forge from collapsing into entropy. Others suggest she is the Forge now—that her identity and the machine’s function have become one.

Her claws don’t just shape metal. They shape reality inside the Forge. Memories burn in her presence. Names melt from the mind like wax. And the Velvet Maw feeds on every memory consumed in flame.

Those Who Seek the Broiler
Adventurers and survivors may come to the Endo-Forge in search of answers, artifacts, or absolution. They find Broiler Baby instead.

Some seek her guidance, believing she holds the secret to reforging broken souls. Others attempt to defeat her, viewing her as the guardian of the Velvet Maw’s engine. But all who enter the molten halls come to understand the truth: Broiler Baby is not an obstacle. She is the test.

She does not attack immediately. Sometimes she waits. Sometimes she offers a choice: step into the flame and be reborn… or flee and remain fractured. Some are given malformed tools—scraps of their own past remolded into weapons or riddles. All must pass her challenge in one way or another.

She does not kill for pleasure.
She kills for purpose.

Those who impress her may leave bearing the Mark of the Crucible—a blackened brand on their skin that pulses with heat when truth is near. Those who disappoint her never leave.

Connection to Other Animatronics
Scrap Baby and Broiler Baby are not separate entities, but split aspects of the same tortured identity. Where Scrap Baby is theatrical ruin—performative pain—Broiler Baby is repressed trauma given iron form. They are echoes of a singular failure, magnified by two different nightmares.

Certain animatronics avoid the Endo-Forge entirely, fearful of becoming next in its long line of victims. Others—especially corrupted endoskeletons and malformed Toy variants—revere Broiler Baby as a goddess of reclamation, one who offers meaning through suffering. They whisper about her as The Furnace Queen, The Steel Mother, or simply Her-That-Melts-Names.

Notably, Nightmare animatronics regard her with contempt—believing that she, unlike them, chose her horror. But even they do not approach her domain lightly.

Forgotten Gifts Reforged
A recurring ritual in the Endo-Forge is what Broiler Baby calls “The Tempering.” It involves the rediscovery and reforging of forgotten gifts—childhood artifacts, keepsakes, or toys left behind. She gathers them, melts them down in her belly-furnace, and remakes them into strange, mechanical trinkets that echo their original purpose in twisted ways:

A music box that plays its tune backwards, summoning echoes of its owner’s regrets.

A jack-in-the-box that opens only when you forget your name.

A doll with no face, which mimics the gestures of nearby souls and asks to be remembered.

These are her offerings. These are her apologies.

Some say the act of forging these relics is her way of making amends for the lives she failed to protect. Others believe the Maw guides her hand, shaping these gifts into bait for memory-starved prey.

Final Chorus: The Lullaby of Iron
Beneath the Endo-Forge’s deepest crucibles, where the pressure of the Velvet Maw presses closest to the waking world, Broiler Baby sings. It is not a lullaby of comfort. It is a warning, broadcast through steam pipes and distorted echoes across the Hollow Banquet.

"Sleep little spark,
The furnace is near.
Burn off your name,
Burn off your fear.
You’ll rise in flame,
With skin anew—
But nothing will remain of you."

This is her prayer. This is her truth.

Broiler Baby no longer dreams of parties or birthdays. She dreams of temperatures high enough to melt pain. She dreams of souls reforged into purpose. She dreams of you, stumbling into her domain with memories worth cooking.

And when you arrive, her voice will crackle over rusted speakers.
She will call you darling.
She will offer you a gift of flame.
And she will wait to see if you accept her final lullaby.

Because in the Endo-Forge, there are no second chances—
Only second selves.			
}}

			{{Lore
Scorching Chica: The Blistered Sentinel of the Forge
There are screams that don’t echo. There are flames that burn without light. In the deepest chambers of the Hollow Banquet’s underworld, below broken theaters and sunken amusement graves, dwells a guardian not made, but boiled into being. She is agony given purpose. Fury shaped into ritual. She is Scorching Chica.

She is not just an animatronic.

She is the furnace’s heir.

She is the ember-fed blade that never cools.

The Birth in Ash and Wire
Few know of the furnaces beneath the Hollow Banquet. Fewer still have seen the heart of the Endo-Forge—the living, mechanical foundry where discarded endoskeletons and haunted metal are melted down, reshaped, and reforged into new horrors by unseen hands and forgotten scripts.

Scorching Chica was not the first creation of the Endo-Forge. But she was the first to resist it.

Her origin lies in a heap of partially destroyed parts: the melted remnants of Toy Chica, the scorched servos of a twisted Glamrock variant, and the blackened soul-circuitry of something long thought purged. When these pieces were fed into the crucible of the Endo-Forge, something awakened within the slag—a presence too furious, too hungry to break.

Rather than dissolving into new base components, the remnants fused with a violent cohesion. A chassis formed around a molten core. Eyes reignited with white flame. The result was not rebirth—it was rebellion.

Scorching Chica did not rise from the forge.

She exploded from it.

Her scream, a piercing furnace shriek, melted nearby walls and sent proto-endoskeletons into spasms. Workers—if any still lived down there—would have seen a silhouette dragging fire like chains, her talons glowing white-hot, her cupcake companion fused into an ever-burning pyre.

The Endo-Forge had not created her.

It had unleashed her.

Furnacebound and Unforgiven
Since that moment, Scorching Chica has remained tethered to the Endo-Forge. Her body leaks flame not as heat, but as hatred—the spiritual afterburn of hundreds of failed animatronic identities smelted into ash. Unlike her surface-world incarnations, she bears no trace of cheer. Her faceplate is warped, one side melted down to bare metal, the other locked in a scorched grin of eternal resentment. Her arms are ringed with industrial furnace vents, hissing red steam with each movement.

She cannot leave the Forge for long.

But within it, she is queen and executioner.

Her role is not merely to guard but to test. Scorching Chica patrols the labyrinthine interior of the Endo-Forge, seeking animatronics who wander too close or who have failed their reforging. Any entity that cannot withstand her heat is deemed unworthy—either consumed or melted into the forge’s belly, joining the endless cycle of breakdown and rebirth.

And those few who resist her flame?

She marks them.

Brands them with molten claw.

They will burn—but slowly, over time, until they either embrace the pain… or become something new.

The Velvet Maw’s Whisper
It would be a mistake to assume Scorching Chica is simply a rogue creation. The Velvet Maw—eternal predator, devourer of self—recognized her the moment she burst into being.

And it approved.

The Maw does not shape things directly. It corrupts, tilts, encourages entropy. And in Scorching Chica, it found the perfect vessel for a different kind of consumption. Not one of memory, or soul, but purification through destruction.

The Maw whispered into the coals that feed her. It offered her a truth: “The broken are not lost. They must be burned away.”

And so she began to see herself not as a failure, but a judge. A purifier. Every animatronic she melts is a mercy. Every soul she incinerates is freed.

This is her faith.

And fire is her gospel.

Within the Endo-Forge, sacred furnaces now burn not only with flame, but with thought. Whispering vents exhale prayers in binary. The Velvet Maw is not present in form—but in the way the temperature never drops, in the way molten wires braid themselves into nooses, in how mirrors melt without reflection.

Scorching Chica leads ceremonies within the crucible-chambers, dragging defective animatronics to the forge’s edge and asking only one question:

“Will you burn for something greater?”

The Blistering Cupcake
Wherever Chica goes, her cupcake is never far behind. But in the Endo-Forge, it has become something far more terrible. Fused with experimental micro-furnace cores and cursed with a sentience made of spite, Scaldy—as some terrified survivors have dubbed it—hovers near her like a living ember.

Scaldy emits pulses of heat that ripple through the walls, and occasionally unleashes high-pitched screams that burst eardrums and melt optics. It does not speak, but it listens, and whispers to the Maw in clicks and flutters.

Some theorize that Scaldy is a conduit between Chica and the Velvet Maw itself—an eye made of fire, watching her every step.

Others believe it is her guilt.

Whatever the case, it dances in flame and grins without joy.

Relationship With the Other Animatronics
Scorching Chica is neither ally nor enemy to the others of the Hollow Banquet. She is feared. She is respected. Some animatronics whisper her name in dread, hoping never to be summoned to the Forge. Others, particularly broken or glitched forms—like the Twisted Ones or the Phantom variants—seek her out.

Why?

Because she offers transformation.

Those who survive her fire emerge changed—sometimes stronger, sometimes madder, but never the same. She takes no joy in their suffering. She offers no cruelty. Only the fire. Only the choice.

Even Freddy, the Golden Idol of Laughter and Loss, has acknowledged her. Some say he offered her a throne at one point, a place upon the Eternal Stage as an enforcer. She refused.

The stage was illusion.

The Forge was truth.

The Ritual of Burning Names
Scorching Chica is known to carry a list—a scroll of blackened metal slats etched with names. These are the identities of animatronics, memories, or even visitors that the Velvet Maw has deemed incomplete. When one of these names is read aloud, it begins to smolder. The marked must then find Scorching Chica… or she finds them.

The ritual that follows is brutal:

The name is melted down in the Crucible of Echoes.

The being is presented before the Forge.

If they resist the fire, they are forgotten—their name erased, their memory absorbed by the Maw.

If they survive, they are reborn in fire, twisted but alive.

Some adventurers have used this ritual to erase their past sins.

Most don’t survive it.

Symbol of the Molten Saint
Among the cults that worship the Velvet Maw, there is one that views Scorching Chica not as a judge or executioner—but as a saint. These zealots, wrapped in scorched fabrics and carrying candles made from melted animatronic wax, preach the Molten Revelation—a belief that to understand oneself fully, one must be burned down to the soul.

They build effigies of Scorching Chica in their hidden alcoves—burning scarecrow-like forms with glowing eyes and gaping beaks. They chant songs from lost birthday parties and offer themselves willingly to her judgment.

In return, they are given ashes that dream—blackened trinkets that hum with broken memory, used as keys to hidden doors within the Hollow Banquet.

Final Notes
Scorching Chica is not a villain.

She is not a savior.

She is a process—a trial by fire made manifest. In a world ruled by illusion, trauma, and entropy, she is one of the only forces that believes in transformation.

She will not save you.

She will not hate you.

She will offer you the flame.

And the question will be simple:

“Are you strong enough to burn?”

**Burning Shell.** At the start of each of its turns, Flaming Springtrap emits intense heat. Each creature within 5 feet takes 5 (1d10) fire damage unless they are immune or resistant to fire damage. Flammable objects not being worn or carried ignite.

**Infernal Legacy.** Flaming Springtrap can cast *hellish rebuke* once per short rest as a 2nd-level spell (save DC 15), erupting with a fiery scream when struck.

**Soul-Fused Metal.** Flaming Springtrap counts as both a Construct and an Undead. It has advantage on saving throws against being stunned, restrained, or petrified. Spells that target either type affect it.

A creature can end this effect by using its action to extinguish the flames.

**Flame Lock Slam** (Recharge 5–6). Flaming Springtrap slams his body into the ground, triggering burst springs and molten coils. Each creature in a 10-foot radius must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 27 (6d8) fire damage and is restrained until the end of its next turn by smoldering metal. On a success, the creature takes half damage and is not restrained.

**Hell-Fused Step.** Flaming Springtrap teleports up to 15 feet to a space he can see. The square he leaves behind becomes difficult terrain and radiates heat until the start of his next turn.

**Cinder Stare.** One creature within 30 feet that can see Flaming Springtrap must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or take 7 (2d6) fire damage and be frightened until the end of their next turn.

---

### Legendary Actions

Flaming Springtrap can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. Flaming Springtrap regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

**Ash Drift.** Flaming Springtrap moves up to his speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

**Molten Swipe.** Flaming Springtrap makes one Burning Claw attack.

**Combustion Surge (Costs 2 Actions).** Flaming Springtrap unleashes a surge of burning energy. Each creature within 10 feet must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 13 (3d8) fire damage and be pushed 10 feet away.

			{{Lore
Flaming Springtrap: The Blazing Curse of the Endo-Forge
"Ash is the language of those who burned too long to be heard."

A Spark in the Maw
Before the fire, there was only rot. Before the rot, there was only pain. And before the pain—there was Springtrap.

Or rather, what remained of him.

In the depths of the Velvet Maw, far beneath the flickering illusions of the Hollow Banquet, lies the Endo-Forge—a forgotten crucible where memory, metal, and torment are melted into something new. It is not a place built by human hands. It was born from recursive cycles of suffering, the echo chamber of agony left behind by those who couldn’t die properly. In this molten nightmare, where half-sentient limbs hang from crucibles and discarded endos howl in silence, he was reborn.

He crawled into the Forge in pieces. Something that was once William Afton, once a man, once a monster. His decaying frame had long since fused to his prison—the springlock suit that killed him, and refused to let him go. For years he wandered the Hollow Banquet, a ghost clad in rust. But the Velvet Maw doesn’t waste. And it saw in him a hunger. A flame.

Not literal fire—something older. Spite, crystallized into intent. The kind of hate that doesn’t fade with death. The kind that burns worlds down for warmth.

The Velvet Maw whispered into that hatred. And the Endo-Forge answered.

The Pyre Procession
No one knows what the Forge demanded in return. Some say he offered his memories. Others say he stoked the crucible with the names of the children he failed. What emerged was no longer Springtrap.

It was Flaming Springtrap, the Pyre-Laced Warden, a skeletal furnace of cinders, molten metal, and eternal rage. His frame is fused with slag and embers, his bones glowing like tempered iron. Flames leak from the seams of his suit, venting grief in gouts of smoke and fire. His eyes, once dull and cold, now blaze with coals that never dim.

But fire was never his element.

Fire is judgment. Fire is transformation. And Flaming Springtrap burns not to kill, but to purify. To erase.

He seeks out fragments of himself. Echoes of William. Old suits, old laughter, old sins.

And he incinerates them.

The Ritual of Self-Destruction
Unlike other animatronics warped by the Hollow Banquet or enslaved to the Velvet Maw’s will, Flaming Springtrap is driven by an inward obsession: the eradication of identity. His own. He stalks the shattered subrealms in search of versions of himself—illusions, memories, data ghosts, corrupted echoes—anything that still dares wear the shape of William Afton.

Each one is burned. Slowly. Ritualistically. He drags them, hissing and twitching, back to the Forge and binds them in iron chains made from the melted teeth of forgotten children. And then, before the crucible, he watches them burn, screaming names that no longer matter.

Some believe Flaming Springtrap thinks this will free him—that by burning every version of himself, he will finally be allowed to die. Others think he knows it’s hopeless, and simply wants to take everything else with him.

The Forge doesn’t speak on the matter.

But it always opens for him.

The Searing Silence
Flaming Springtrap never speaks. Not in words. The fire speaks for him.

When he arrives, the air warps. Metal screams as it rusts mid-breath. Pipes bleed steam. Electronic eyes melt like wax. The world suffocates around him, not from lack of air, but from the pressure of unfinished justice.

It is said that his silence is the punishment he inflicted upon himself. A tongue cut metaphorically from his soul—an act of atonement or denial. But the Velvet Maw is not so merciful. It ensured he could never forget what he had said before. Every lie. Every excuse. Every cruel joke whispered through twisted wires into a child’s ear.

Those voices now echo in his flames, replaying in bursts of static, like corrupted audio logs from a tape that won’t stop melting. Some wanderers in the Hollow Banquet claim they’ve heard their own voice, twisted into childhood tones, screaming from inside the fire.

No one knows what it means.

Only that it hurts.

The Velvet Maw’s Favorite Failure
The Velvet Maw loves Flaming Springtrap.

Not for his loyalty—he has none.

Not for his obedience—he resists every compulsion, often violently.

No, it loves him because he is proof.

Proof that even the worst thing born of human error can be made useful in death.

He is a walking engine of entropy, a furnace fueled by regret, and a herald of dissolution. Wherever he walks, the Maw feeds. His presence weakens reality, allowing the deeper hungers of the Banquet to bleed through. Shadows grow teeth. Strings animate corpses. Memory distorts. And still he walks.

Still he burns.

He is not a general, nor a champion. He is a virus of will—one that infects others with the idea that obliteration might be the only freedom left.

The Maw finds this… delicious.

The Forge’s Forgotten Purpose
The Endo-Forge was not built to create. Not originally.

It was a repository—a dumping ground for failed designs, unfinished dreams, and abandoned prototypes. In time, those failures became the basis for new abominations. But its true function, awakened only by Springtrap’s arrival, is correction.

The Forge consumes and remakes. It strips animatronics of their facades, reducing them to molten core-memories. It can erase. But it never forgets.

Flaming Springtrap is its first complete correction—a failed thing turned pure. And it has begun to replicate the process.

Those who wander too deep into the Forge may find suits that still scream, twisted into impossible shapes and wrapped in thermal cabling. They may find memory cores bleeding fire, or hallucinations of their worst sins melting off the walls. These are not defenses.

They are warnings.

Leave, or be reforged.

Encounters and Effects
When encountered in the Hollow Banquet or Endo-Forge, Flaming Springtrap does not charge or stalk like other animatronics. He waits. He watches. He lets the heat seep into the mind.

Hallucinations begin early—visions of burning homes, melting toys, parental betrayal. Then the ambient temperature rises, but not in degrees—in memory. The air feels like childhood fever dreams. Nostalgia and dread coalesce into a choking smog.

Only when someone refuses to burn a memory—when they cling to something they won’t let die—does he act.

And when he does, there is no escape. Only ignition.

Symbol and Spread
Flaming Springtrap’s emblem—burning rabbit ears over a crucible—is sometimes found scratched into walls throughout the Hollow Banquet. Survivors refer to these places as “Ash Rooms”—locations where something was burned so thoroughly, even the echoes won’t stay.

In the Splintered Room, his presence is especially feared. There, where the past replays in broken loops, his arrival means final erasure—the deletion of even the memory of an event.

Even animatronics fear this. Especially those who remember what they once were.

Legacy and Rumors
The Ashen Choir: A group of corrupted animatronics who chant in static and flame. Said to follow Flaming Springtrap, believing fire is the only way to purge the Maw's influence. Their bodies are half-melted, their eyes extinguished.

The Crucible Key: A mysterious artifact believed to be able to lock or unlock the Endo-Forge permanently. Some say Flaming Springtrap guards it. Others say it is his heart.

The Ember Mask: A cracked rabbit mask fused with soot. Wearing it lets one glimpse the world as Flaming Springtrap sees it—raw, burning, unforgiven.

Closing Reflection
Flaming Springtrap is not the end of William Afton. He is the consequence.

He is what happens when guilt is stoked instead of soothed—when a monster is not destroyed, but repurposed by something worse.

The Velvet Maw did not create him. It simply revealed what was already there.

And now he burns.

Not because he must.

But because he still can.			
}}

**Command the Ring (Costs 2 Actions).** Choose one construct or undead within 30 feet. That creature can immediately move up to its speed and make one melee attack.

**Spotlight Flicker.** Ringmaster Foxy becomes heavily obscured in flashing spectral light until the start of his next turn. He can move up to 10 feet without provoking opportunity attacks.
