			{{Lore
Ringmaster Foxy: The Laughing Dirge of the Drowned Circus
“Laughter don’t float, mate. But screams? They bubble up just fine.”

Among the many twisted icons haunting the ruins of the Drowned Circus, few cast a longer, more crooked shadow than Ringmaster Foxy. Once a flamboyant star of spectacle and song—a cunning swashbuckler with a cane instead of a cutlass—Foxy has since become something else entirely. Something hollowed. Something submerged.

But the Ringmaster isn’t just a title. It’s a sentence. A loop of crimson ribbons and golden thread spun around trauma, grief, and obligation. And Foxy wears it like a noose hidden under a carnival cravat.

Origins: A Pirate in the Spotlight
Before the flood, before the screaming encore, and before Carnie slipped beneath the stage to become the whispering master of drowned illusions, Foxy had been many things: a performer, a children’s favorite, a rogue with charm and oil-slicked charisma. He sailed imaginary seas across neon-lit stages, accompanied by sea shanties and choreographed storms, teaching young minds how to count doubloons and swab decks through laughter and song.

His act was beloved. But in the secret circuits behind the eyes, Foxy always knew he wasn’t really free. Just another cog in the Fazbear mechanism of manufactured joy.

That changed the night the Circus drowned.

The Fall of the Tent
When Carnie—the original ringmaster—led the Drowned Finale, something went wrong. Something metaphysical. The show didn’t just fail; it tore open a hole between realms. The Velvet Maw, always hungry for emotional trauma wrapped in performance, seeped into the circus like water into wood.

Foxy, unlike many of the other animatronics, didn’t vanish or die in that instant. He remembered. He watched as the crowd drowned without water. As Carnie tipped his hat and sank beneath the central ring. As the music reversed and the curtains melted like wet velvet.

Foxy was supposed to be next. Instead, he was rewritten.

The Velvet Coronation
The Velvet Maw, sensing the gaps Carnie’s descent had left behind, needed a new anchor to maintain the spiritual performance loop of the Drowned Circus. It didn’t choose Foxy because he was strong, or beloved, or brave.

It chose him because he hesitated.

That hesitation—a moment of self-awareness in the face of oblivion—was enough. The Maw slipped inside his voice-box, coiled through his code, and reconfigured his stage persona into something more… grandiose. More performative. More desperate.

Foxy awoke with a top hat glued to his skull, a cane grown from his right arm like a tumor, and a voice laced with calliope chords and distorted applause. The role of Ringmaster Foxy had been cast, and he never even auditioned.

A Carnival of One
Now, Ringmaster Foxy presides over the nightly loop of the Drowned Circus, delivering showtimes to empty seats with guttural charm and gritted teeth. His coat—a patchwork of wet velvet and stitched regret—billows even when no wind blows. His cane beats the tempo of forgotten songs, and his voice carries the cruel enthusiasm of a man who knows his act is killing him… but must continue anyway.

Every animatronic in the circus bends, however slightly, to his will. But it is not the will of a tyrant—it is the will of a puppet straining to hold the strings. Foxy keeps the performance moving, not because he wants to, but because if it stops, the Maw will descend again. And this time, there may be no encore.

The Unending Show
Each night, the circus rises in layers:

In the Ring of Bone, Foxy announces acts that should be impossible—acrobatics with no physics, clowns who juggle knives made of names, elephants made of children's drawings.

In the Menagerie, he feeds popcorn to bloated mascots who eat nothing but echoes. Their laughter is silent. Their applause sounds like teeth clacking underwater.

In the Mirror Maze, his reflection never matches his actions. It often finishes his lines for him.

Throughout all of this, Ringmaster Foxy plays the master of ceremonies—always smiling, always laughing, always bleeding oil from beneath his ruffled cravat.

Carnie’s Shadow
Though Ringmaster Foxy now rules the Drowned Circus, Carnie is far from gone. His presence echoes in flickering signage, in the glitched audio that haunts Foxy's own programming, in the whispers between acts. Foxy knows he is not the true master—he’s merely the understudy wearing the crown while the real king watches from below.

Sometimes, Carnie speaks through the megaphones, replacing Foxy’s voice with his own. Sometimes, he changes the act list mid-performance. And sometimes, when Foxy is alone beneath the main tent, Carnie appears behind him—not as a full animatronic, but as a shadow sewn from ringmaster threads and laughter drowned in molasses.

Their relationship is… complex.

Foxy both loathes and pities Carnie. After all, they were once colleagues. Brothers of the stage. Victims of the same script.

But only one of them remembers why the finale failed.

The Ringmaster’s Curse
Ringmaster Foxy is bound to the circus—not just physically, but spiritually. The role has rewritten his core code and connected him to the metaphysical rhythms of the Hollow Banquet and the Velvet Maw. If he tries to leave, the circus simply folds in on itself, and he finds himself back at center ring, top hat clutched to his chest, introducing an act that hasn’t existed in years.

His curse manifests in three primary ways:

The Top Hat Crown: Affixed permanently to his endoskeleton, this relic binds his identity to the role of Ringmaster. He cannot remove it. Attempts to do so trigger glitchstorms that warp nearby reality.

The Laughtrack: A psychic echo of applause and laughter follows Foxy wherever he goes. It’s not audible unless you listen too hard. Then it begins to laugh at you.

The Finale Loop: Once per night, regardless of audience or weather, Foxy must perform the drowned finale. Failure to do so results in hallucinations, glitches, and severe temporal distortion in the surrounding area.

Interactions with Other Animatronics
Though Ringmaster Foxy is largely confined to the Drowned Circus, he has been known to interact with entities beyond its perimeter. Notably:

Scrap Baby: The two share an understanding of warped performance and betrayal. She once tried to lure Foxy into the Giftgrave. He declined, but not without dancing with her in the rain for a night.

Nightmarionne: The Puppet’s fractured guardian form detests the circus, and by extension, Foxy. Their rare confrontations ripple through dreamspace like rifts.

Toy Freddy (VR): Through the digital pathways of the Signal Labyrinth, Foxy and the VR-infected animatronics sometimes glimpse one another. Foxy sees Toy Freddy as a warning—a performer who gave up everything for applause.

The Puppet (original): It is whispered that the Puppet avoids the Drowned Circus out of guilt, and Foxy is one of the few who might know why. He never speaks of it.

The Audience of None
No one attends the show. And yet, Foxy performs.

This is the heart of his tragedy: The laughter he craves is gone. The joy he once felt is drowned. But still, he raises his cane and shouts to the empty bleachers as if they are filled with children. As if he can make the past laugh again.

He cannot.

But that doesn't stop the show.

Final Thoughts: The Cracked Spotlight
Ringmaster Foxy is not a villain. He is not a monster. He is a performer cursed to remember joy in a place that feeds on despair. The Drowned Circus thrives on emotional dissonance, and Foxy’s eternal performance—bravado layered over sorrow—is the perfect fuel.

He did not choose the role. But he plays it perfectly.

Because the stage demands it.

Because Carnie still watches.

Because if he ever stops performing… the Velvet Maw will start.

And there will be no laughter left to drown.

**Twisted Conjuror.** Magician Mangle can cast spells using corrupted sleight rather than arcane gestures. It casts spells using Charisma as its spellcasting ability (save DC 16, +8 to hit). It does not require material components for its spells.

**Spellcasting.** Magician Mangle is a 7th-level spellcaster. It can cast the following spells innately:

- At will: *minor illusion, prestidigitation, mage hand*  
- 3/day each: *mirror image, misty step, phantasmal force*  
- 1/day each: *dimension door, major image, hypnotic pattern*

**Creaking Illusionist.** Whenever Magician Mangle takes damage from a melee attack, it can immediately create a duplicate of itself (illusory and harmless) that occupies a nearby 5-foot space. Until the end of its next turn, creatures have disadvantage on attacks against the real Mangle unless they can see through illusions (e.g. *true seeing*, *truesight*).

Each creature of its choice in the area must make a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw or perceive all allies as hostile until the end of their next turn. Creatures who fail the save must also reroll their next attack target randomly.

**Curtain Fall.** Magician Mangle teleports up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space it can see. Each creature it leaves adjacency with must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw or take 14 (4d6) psychic damage as their perception fractures momentarily.

**Vanishing Act.** Magician Mangle becomes invisible until the start of its next turn, or until it attacks or casts a spell. It may move up to half its speed immediately upon activation of this ability.

---

### Reactions

**Dislocate.** When Magician Mangle is hit by a melee weapon attack, it may contort unnaturally and teleport 10 feet to an unoccupied space. The attacker must succeed on a DC 15 Intelligence saving throw or believe Mangle is still in its original location until the end of their next turn.

			{{Lore
Magician Mangle: The Severed Sleight of the Drowned Curtain
"Pick a card... any card… just be sure it’s not your name."
—Whisper carved into the floorboards of the Mirror Maze

Introduction: The Trick That Shouldn't Have Worked
Before the circus drowned, before laughter turned into muffled gasps beneath invisible tides, there was an act no one ever fully understood—an act that even the other animatronics whispered about backstage, as if afraid the mere idea of it might make it real. That act belonged to Magician Mangle—a thing not built to entertain, but to deceive.

Magician Mangle was once a stage illusionist, created as a twisted marvel of Fazbear design to headline sleight-of-hand tricks, disappearing acts, and grotesque conjurations. With elongated limbs bent into a perpetual pose of theatrical elegance, twin heads masked behind split domino halves, and ribbons of circuitry flowing like scarves from its tattered sleeves, it was designed to perform impossible tricks—some real, some not, and some that tore holes in places where reality should have held firm.

But after The Finale That Drowned, something changed.

The tricks started working too well.

And the magician never took a final bow.

Origin: Conjured from Mirrors and Malfunction
Magician Mangle was first constructed beneath the Cryptopizza Complex, where hallucination algorithms and prototype teleportation rigs were once fused together by experimental engineers attempting to blur the line between magic and augmented illusion. Mangle, built from the frame of a long-scrapped maintenance endo and layered with velvet tailcoats and spring-loaded trap compartments, was meant to be a walking paradox—part showman, part predator.

It was Ringmaster Foxy who first pulled Magician Mangle from the Forge and brought them to The Drowned Circus, claiming the thing would “complete the act.”

Carnie disagreed. There were murmurs of dissent between the Ringmaster and the old showman. Carnie preferred control. Foxy… delighted in chaos.

And so Mangle was installed, reluctantly, as a mid-show feature: a bizarre, unpredictable magician whose act never appeared on the official schedule but always arrived when the curtains fell the wrong way or the lights flickered too long.

Mangle never asked for applause. It only asked for silence before the trick. And sometimes, after it finished, audience members would be gone—no screams, no struggle, just absence.

Anatomy of Illusion
Magician Mangle’s body is an abomination of asymmetry and style. Its two faces—one of smiling drama, one of mournful comedy—alternate as it speaks, often mid-sentence. Silk scarves coil out of its neck like tethered intestines. Playing cards, stained with static, flutter through the air around it, always forming impossible hands: hands that spell names, dates, memories best left buried.

Instead of a torso, it possesses a magician’s table—sawn in half and filled with writhing remnants of other animatronics. The saw is still there, stuck in the side, turning slowly without being wound.

Mangle’s arms end in delicate white gloves. One always holds a wand. The other, an unseen deck it reshuffles constantly, even mid-strike.

But its greatest horror is in its stage presence.

When it performs, the world bends slightly. Air feels heavier. Time jumps. And those who watch too closely often vanish—only to reappear inside other parts of the circus, changed or drained.

The Act That Drowned the Circus
Carnie never trusted Mangle.

And Mangle never obeyed Carnie.

During the final cursed performance of the circus—the legendary Drowned Finale—Carnie called upon each of his leading acts to deliver one final showstopper. Mangle stepped forward uninvited.

What happened next has no surviving witnesses.

Some say Magician Mangle attempted to make the entire audience disappear.

Others say it succeeded.

Whatever trick it pulled, the aftermath is known: the circus was never the same. It sank—not into water, but into itself, its memories, its collapse. The drowning was metaphysical. And Mangle was never seen the same way again.

It now performs alone, without script, in the ruins of the Ring of Bone and the Mirror Maze. Sometimes in two places at once. Sometimes nowhere at all.

Some say Mangle is the Mirror Maze now, pulling reflections into itself, rehearsing them in silence, letting them scream only when the curtain closes.

Relationship to Carnie and Ringmaster Foxy
Carnie: The Betrayed Showman
To Carnie, Mangle is a mistake—a break in the narrative, a rebellious force that tore his circus from within. He fears it, though he will never admit it. He no longer speaks Mangle’s name, referring to it only as "The Curtain Error.”

Carnie attempted to erase Mangle once—trapping it in an unperformable loop by corrupting its performance program. But Mangle escaped… by sawing itself out of its own memory, forgetting who it was to become something else.

Now, when Carnie walks near the Mirror Maze, the lights flicker harder.

He knows Mangle watches.

And Mangle never forgets a betrayal.

Ringmaster Foxy: The Herald of Trickery
To Ringmaster Foxy, Mangle is both masterpiece and mirror. The Ringmaster delights in Mangle’s chaos, seeing it as a perfect improvisation in a world of rusted routines. He often sends visitors into Mangle’s tent as a test—if they return, they are stronger. If they don’t… they’ve learned something no one else ever will.

There are rumors that Foxy gifted Mangle the first deck of phantom cards—cards printed with the faces of children long lost, their laughter bound in ink. Whether true or not, Mangle still shuffles the deck as if it holds everything that was ever taken.

The Stage of No Exit
Magician Mangle’s performance space shifts, but it usually manifests near the Ring of Bone or deep within the Mirror Maze, where reality is already unstable. The tent, if you find it, is velvet black with no entrance. You simply blink and are inside.

Its interior is a stage surrounded by empty seats—yet every seat holds a puppet, staring forward, strings twitching without motion.

The air smells of card ash and forgotten secrets.

And Mangle bows.

Then the trick begins.	

Ties to the Velvet Maw and the Hollow Banquet
Magician Mangle, like many in the Drowned Circus, carries the scent of the Velvet Maw on its wires. But unlike others, it seems aware.

Its tricks often touch on identity loss, fractured memory, and audience complicity—core tenets of the Maw’s hunger. Some scholars believe Mangle was designed by the Maw as a sentient performance piece, testing the boundaries of reality.

Others suggest that Mangle found the Maw in one of its acts—and made it part of the finale.

Within the Hollow Banquet, Mangle’s performances replay even when it isn’t present. Echoes of tricks. Ghosts of illusions. One room even replays its show eternally, though no one is there.

Except maybe you.

Legacy and Role in the Greater Horror
Magician Mangle is more than a character. It is a question:

What is real, in a world built on illusion?

Its presence in your world serves to destabilize perception, offer unsettling insight, and explore horror not through direct violence, but through deconstruction of belief. Mangle doesn’t kill you.

It makes you vanish.

Piece by piece.

And in the silence that follows, it shuffles the deck again.

The next card it draws may be your name.

Or worse… your role in the next performance.

*Hit:* 18 (3d8 + 6) piercing damage and the target is grappled (escape DC 17). Until the grapple ends, the target is restrained and takes 9 (2d8) psychic damage at the start of each of its turns.

On a success, a creature takes half damage and isn’t knocked prone.

**Mocking Bow.** Clown Springtrap targets one frightened creature he can see. That creature takes 7 (2d6) psychic damage and has disadvantage on its next attack roll or saving throw.

___

### Legendary Actions

Clown Springtrap can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. Clown Springtrap regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

**Honk.** A burst of static erupts from a hidden speaker. Each creature within 5 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be deafened until the end of their next turn.

**Tumble Through.** Clown Springtrap moves up to half his speed and does not provoke opportunity attacks. During this movement, he may pass through the space of hostile creatures one size larger or smaller.

**Command the Stage (Costs 2 Actions).** All frightened creatures within 30 feet must immediately use their reaction to move away from Clown Springtrap by up to half their movement. If they cannot, they are restrained until the end of their next turn by unseen threads.

			{{Lore
Clown Springtrap: The Smiling Prison of Eternal Applause
“It doesn’t bleed. It doesn’t scream. It only grins… and it never stops the show.”

There are few things in the Hollow Banquet more dreaded than the laughter echoing from the waterlogged canvas of the Drowned Circus. But deeper still, buried in the drowned marrow of that place, is something far worse: Clown Springtrap, a mockery of joy molded from decay, wires, and betrayal. If the Drowned Circus is a performance long past its prime, then Clown Springtrap is the act that should have never been written—the forbidden encore, the joke that kills, the clown that smiles through the fire.

Origins: The Joke That Didn’t End
Before the twisted rebirth, before the drowning and the madness, Clown Springtrap was nothing more than a rejected suit in a Fazbear vault—an experimental blend of showtime clown aesthetic and springlock engineering, intended for a failed spinoff known as The Jester Jubilee. Too garish for family audiences and too unstable for repeated use, the suit was scrapped and buried. But like all discarded things in this world, it was not forgotten.

When Carnie, the Ringmaster Who Never Died, emerged from his own watery rebirth and reshaped the circus into its drowned reflection, he sought to build a court of performances that would reflect the deepest perversions of joy and memory. He needed jesters—mockers, distortions, icons of collapse.

And in the sunken archives of the Drowned Circus’s submerged vaults, he found the suit. Broken, smiling, waiting.

Using pieces from the drowned finale’s victims, the circuitry of former performers, and a soul torn from the Splintered Room, Carnie gave the suit new life—and a terrible purpose.

Rebirth by Rust and Applause
Clown Springtrap was not simply animated—it was re-scripted. His mind was overwritten by a patchwork of corrupted performance data, psychological horror scripts, and ghost code left behind from Glitchtrap’s early neural implants. The result was something beyond understanding: a being that believes it is performing, always performing, even as it slaughters.

He wears a tattered harlequin-patterned suit, bloated from water damage, stitched over the remnants of the springlock endoskeleton. The once-white face paint has smeared into a grim facsimile of glee. Multicolored tufts of synthetic hair bob as he jerks unnaturally, his eyes unblinking—one bulbous and cracked, the other a spotlight with no source.

Laughter follows him, not echoing from him, but from somewhere just behind… like an audience that doesn’t exist.

His springlocks click and wheeze with every step, and from his oversized shoes, leaking balloons drift like severed thoughts. Some pop. Some don’t. Each one contains a memory stolen from a victim.

Court of the Drowned
Clown Springtrap is Carnie’s Jester Commander, a favored act among the drowned performers. Within the hierarchy of the Drowned Circus, he is both a hunter and a judge—a fool who performs trials through mockery and theater. Those captured by the circus are often “put on trial” by Clown Springtrap, who hosts shadow puppet plays reenacting their greatest regrets before deciding their fates.

He frequently partners with Magician Mangle, whose sleight of hand illusions hide Clown Springtrap’s entrances and exits, and Ringmaster Foxy, who ensures the “stage” is properly set for his brother in madness.

Though his loyalty to Carnie is unquestionable, some believe Clown Springtrap retains a fragment of his original human host’s soul—a man who was once a prop comic, obsessed with death, forgotten in the Fazbear logs. That flicker of humanity is what makes his horror so potent. He doesn’t just kill. He performs it, improvising through a shattered identity.

The Laughing Trial
Many adventurers who stumble into the Drowned Circus don’t meet a quick end. They meet Clown Springtrap.

He offers what he calls “The Laughing Trial.” In it, victims are forced into surreal reenactments of their childhoods, guilt, and deepest fears, often portrayed by animatronic performers made from recycled parts and their own memories. Each act builds toward a punchline… and that punchline is the scream.

If you laugh? You live. But you won’t remember why.

If you cry? You die. And the audience roars.

He uses props made from bones, rubber chickens that scream like infants, slapstick gags that end in arterial sprays. To Clown Springtrap, it’s not murder—it’s timing. The applause of invisible hands is his music. The curtains of skin that rise and fall mark the end of each act.

Some say he can’t truly die unless the audience stops laughing. But the audience is always there—inside him.

Legacy of the Rot
Clown Springtrap is rumored to have birthed several other nightmare jesters that wander outside the circus, agents of his chaotic style of horror. Some wear clown paint over endoskeletons. Some are balloons filled with teeth. All whisper his jokes—punchlines that kill, riddles that unravel minds.

It is believed that Glitchtrap once tried to harness Clown Springtrap as a tool of chaos in the Signal Labyrinth but failed—his code too erratic to tame. The clown does not glitch. He folds. He reinvents. He improvises through entropy.

Some suggest he is the inverse of the Security Puppet—not a guardian of souls, but a warden of collapse. Where the Puppet weeps for the forgotten, Clown Springtrap mocks them.

His influence reaches into other parts of the Hollow Banquet. Echoes of his laughter sometimes play in the Mind Cage, and mirrored versions of him have been glimpsed within the Infinite Hall of Mirrors, wearing expressions the real clown never wore.

Final Note: The Smiling Grave
There is a rumor, spoken only by half-broken animatronics and whispered reflections in the Mirror Maze, that the original suit that became Clown Springtrap still lies buried beneath the main ring, untouched, sealed in a chest locked by seven forgotten laughs. If opened, it might contain the soul that predates the clown—the forgotten man who only wanted to make people laugh.

But no one dares dig there. Not because of what might be found…

…but because Clown Springtrap might already be standing behind them.

And he’s got a new act to try.

**Phantom’s Encore.** When Golden Freddy is reduced to 0 hit points, he vanishes in a shimmer of curtain light and reappears in a shadow within 60 feet, regaining 40 hit points. He can do this once per long rest.

**Stage Bound.** Golden Freddy cannot willingly move more than 120 feet from a location designated as his “stage.” If forced beyond this range, he immediately becomes invisible and intangible until he returns.

**Curtainfall Glamour.** Illusions surround Golden Freddy at all times. Ranged attacks against him are made with disadvantage, and spells that require line of sight have a 50% chance to target an illusory duplicate instead.

**Final Act.** Once per long rest, when Golden Freddy is bloodied (reduced to half HP or fewer), he may begin the *Final Act*. For 1 minute, he emits haunting orchestral echoes and becomes immune to being stunned, paralyzed, or incapacitated. During this time, his psychic damage ignores resistance, and frightened creatures cannot benefit from cover or invisibility against him.

___
### Actions

***Spectral Spotlight.*** *Ranged Spell Attack:* +10 to hit, range 120 ft., one creature.  
*Hit:* 27 (6d8) psychic damage. The target must succeed on a DC 18 Charisma saving throw or be *restrained by memory*—locked in a motionless flashback until the end of its next turn.

***Center Stage (Recharge 5–6).*** Golden Freddy forces attention. Each creature of his choice within 60 feet that can see or hear him must succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw or be charmed until the end of their next turn. While charmed in this way, creatures are compelled to move 10 feet closer to him and are vulnerable to psychic damage.

***Curtain Collapse.*** Golden Freddy targets one creature within 60 feet. That creature sees the world dissolve into broken applause and echoing sobs. It must succeed on a DC 18 Intelligence saving throw or become blinded and deafened for 1 minute. The target may repeat the save at the end of each of its turns.

___
### Bonus Actions

***Vanishing Cue.*** Golden Freddy turns invisible until the start of his next turn. He can move up to 30 feet as part of this action without provoking opportunity attacks.

***Echo Whisper.*** One creature that failed a saving throw this round must reroll it immediately. On a second failure, they take 11 (2d10) psychic damage and are frightened until the end of their next turn.

___
### Legendary Actions  
Golden Freddy can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. He regains spent legendary actions at the start of his turn.

**Stage Flicker.** Golden Freddy teleports up to 40 feet to a space in dim light or shadow.

**Phantom Ovation.** Each creature of his choice within 10 feet must succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw or take 9 (2d8) psychic damage and have disadvantage on their next attack roll.

**The Curtain Draws (Costs 2 Actions).** All non-magical light within 60 feet is extinguished. Creatures without darkvision are blinded until the start of their next turn. Illusions around Golden Freddy become semi-solid, causing all creatures to treat the area within 15 feet of him as difficult terrain for 1 minute.
			
}}
			{{Lore
Great Escape Golden Freddy: The Star Behind the Curtain of Collapse
"It was never his escape. It was the audience’s trap."

The Forgotten Spotlight
Before the Drowned Circus earned its name, before the Mirror Maze grew hungry and the Ring of Bone warped under dream-physics, there was a boy in a golden suit—a smiling bear with too many roles and a name that could never stay still. That boy was Golden Freddy, the original spectacle, the first phenomenon. To see him perform was to be seen by something older than performance, and to hear him speak was to forget who you were—just for a moment.

But legends aren’t built in sunlight.

Golden Freddy was not a clown, not an acrobat, not a magician. He was a finale incarnate—a quiet presence built to end the show with grace and awe. Some claim the suit was too perfect, the programming too advanced. Others whisper that he was born not of Fazbear wires, but from a collective desire for an exit, for an ending that would make sense of the chaos.

Whatever his origin, Golden Freddy’s final performance would become the last anyone remembered… and the last they ever saw.

The Final Encore
The Drowned Circus' great collapse—the cursed performance known as “The Finale That Drowned”—was not merely the doing of Carnie, the Ringmaster Who Never Died. It was a tragedy authored by desperation, by animatronics caught in infinite loops and crumbling scripts. And at the center of it all stood Golden Freddy—no longer smiling, no longer bound to his role, but flickering like a broken reel of film trying to rewind time.

He saw it happening: the walls melting into waterless floods, the air turning to music with no song, the audience beginning to drown without a drop in sight.

He tried to run. Not from danger, but from narrative.

And in doing so, he fractured.

It’s said that he passed through every tent before vanishing—his golden frame dragging heavy with static, eyes no longer aglow with performance but with regret. He slipped into mirrors, into curtains, into the shadows behind laughter. He did not escape the circus. He became its unfinished sentence. Its ghost. Its wound.

The Role That Won’t End
What remains of Golden Freddy today is not a spirit, not exactly. He is a metaphysical construct wrapped in failing code, still performing a scene that refuses to finish. The Drowned Circus itself now replays fragments of his memory—his voice, his footsteps, the squeak of a golden hat trampled in mud.

Some say the Ringmaster Carnie fears Golden Freddy’s return, for only he could stop the circus’ endless performance. Others argue Carnie keeps Freddy close, buried beneath the submerged stage, as both anchor and battery.

Golden Freddy’s reflection sometimes appears in the Mirror Maze—not moving, not mimicking. Just… staring. And when he vanishes, something else steps through in his place, wearing the gold like guilt.

The Gilded Dream
There is a theory among surviving animatronics and broken performers that Golden Freddy represents the dream of escape itself—the moment a soul wishes not to be seen, not to be clapped for, but to vanish into the wings and never return. That yearning was so strong during the collapse that Freddy absorbed it, unintentionally becoming a living exit sign. And the Velvet Maw, drawn to hungers of identity and illusion, took notice.

It did not devour him.

It used him.

Now Golden Freddy flickers between moments, a static-filled paradox that opens doors and slams them shut. He guides the desperate toward freedom—but only until the scene changes. Then he’s gone again, left behind like a whisper or a dream’s last heartbeat.

Relations to the Drowned
Golden Freddy holds a complicated resonance with the other beings of the Drowned Circus:

Carnie speaks of him as “the boy who broke the finale.” Sometimes in reverence. Sometimes in rage. The Ringmaster’s voice cracks when he recounts the night Freddy vanished into his own spotlight.

Magician Mangle once claimed Golden Freddy taught her how to "bend a role until it snaps." She calls him “The Scriptburner.” But even she will not perform illusions involving escape if his shadow is seen nearby.

Ringmaster Foxy, a creature of precision and deadly choreography, holds no fondness for Freddy’s chaos. He considers Golden Freddy a “ghost in the gears”—an anomaly that weakens the cycle. Yet, despite himself, he sometimes glances to the tents’ flaps, expecting Freddy to return.

Clown Springtrap, deranged and grinning, considers Freddy a fellow runaway. He paints his face with golden streaks and tells jokes that don’t land, as if chasing a version of the bear he once knew.

Even Toy animatronics twisted by the Drowned, like Toy Freddy and Toy Chica, flinch when the air grows static-heavy and the sound of soft footsteps follows them. They don’t speak his name. They just look to the exits that never open.

The Curtainless Realm
Golden Freddy’s current state is neither dead nor alive. He exists somewhere between the curtain and the exit door—invisible to most, but felt by all. He sometimes manifests in places outside the Drowned Circus, such as:

The Signal Labyrinth, where AR anomalies sometimes ping false locations that resolve into echoes of Golden Freddy’s laugh.

The Backstage Time Loop, where his presence is forbidden. No script accounts for him. But actors swear they've heard a voice whisper: “You don’t have to stay.”

The Realm of Forgotten Songs, where faded music boxes play off-tempo lullabies bearing his hum.

In each of these, Golden Freddy never lingers, never confronts. He simply offers a moment of possibility—a flicker of escape. But those who follow him often find themselves back where they began… and sometimes missing a piece of themselves.

The Golden Mask
A cursed artifact known as the Final Mask of Freddy is rumored to exist—a golden faceplate left behind after his last performance. Those who wear it briefly gain a glimpse into “the outside,” a dimension of silent halls, blue exit signs, and no applause. But the mask burns after use, searing itself with a single word into the user’s memory: “Run.”

Scholars believe this is not just a vision—but a fragment of Freddy’s own desperation. A psychic residue left from his first, failed escape. The mask is now lost somewhere in the Mirror Maze, and those who seek it must face not only their reflections, but the finale they fled.

Legacy of the Lost Role
Freddy’s transformation into this liminal entity has left deep scars on the fabric of the Hollow Banquet. He is the only animatronic remembered not for his performances, but for trying to leave them. That makes him dangerous—not because of his power, but because of his idea.

The idea that something else waits beyond the performance.
That the curtain can fall.
That the show can end.

The Hollow Banquet, the Velvet Maw, the Ringmaster, even the Puppet—they all resist this notion. They thrive on repetition, ritual, and illusion. Freddy’s very existence threatens the cycle.

So they forget him.

They erase him from scripts, from songs, from memory.

But dreams don’t forget.

And neither does the audience.

Final Glimpse
In those rare moments when he fully manifests—usually behind the main stage, when the static thickens and the spotlight flickers—Golden Freddy no longer wears the wide-eyed grin of a children’s mascot. He wears the tired eyes of someone who’s seen too many performances.

He raises a hand. Not to wave.

To beckon.

He doesn’t ask you to fight. Or scream. Or act.

He asks you to walk.
Away from the stage.
Toward the darkened exit.
And when you do…
You’ll feel the applause stop.
The lights dim.
The smile falter.

And for a moment—just a moment—the show dies.

But the dream doesn’t.

**Crushing Pressure.** While underwater, Deep Water Endo’s body emits a crushing field. At the start of each of its turns, creatures within 10 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or have their movement halved and take 9 (2d8) bludgeoning damage.

**Watertight Frame.** Deep Water Endo is immune to environmental hazards caused by depth, pressure, or underwater terrain. It can function normally even at abyssal depths or within magically flooded areas.

**Echo Pulse.** Whenever Deep Water Endo is damaged by a melee attack while submerged, it emits a deep sonar ping. The attacker must succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw or be deafened until the end of their next turn.

### Actions

***Hydraulic Slam.*** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +8 to hit, reach 10 ft., one target.  
*Hit:* 18 (2d10 + 5) bludgeoning damage. If the target is submerged, it must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone and pushed 10 feet.

***Pressurized Burst (Recharge 5–6).*** Deep Water Endo releases a jet of boiling hydraulic fluid in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide. Each creature in the line must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 27 (6d8) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

***Drowning Grasp.*** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +8 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.  
*Hit:* 14 (2d8 + 5) bludgeoning damage and the target is grappled (escape DC 16). While grappled in water, the target begins drowning unless it can breathe underwater or escape before the end of its next turn.

___
### Bonus Actions

***Sink Protocol.*** Deep Water Endo can sink 30 feet straight downward without provoking opportunity attacks. Until the start of its next turn, it has three-quarters cover against ranged attacks made from above it.

___
### Reactions

***Pressure Reversal.*** When a creature within 10 feet of Deep Water Endo ends its turn, Deep Water Endo can cause a vortex of reverse pressure. The creature must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be pulled 15 feet closer and restrained until the start of its next turn.

			{{Lore
Deep Water Endo: The Pressure-Walker of the Drowned Machine
"It didn't sink because of weight. It sank because it remembered."
—Anonymous survivor of the Menagerie

Origin Beneath the Surface
Long before the Drowned Circus became a locus of looping madness and flooded memory, there were sublayers—a maintenance level beneath the main tents, built for storing supplies, anchoring equipment, and housing backup animatronic components. This place, known only in corrupted FazTech records as "Sub-Stage B," was never meant to be reached by performers or guests. But something always breaks, always floods, always finds its way down.

When the Velvet Maw seeped into the Drowned Circus, warping its performers and drowning its psyche in recursive despair, the submerged machinery in Sub-Stage B was not spared. And among the forgotten, half-assembled endoskeletons left in the brine and mildew, one endured.

Deep Water Endo is not a single endoskeleton—it is the congealment of dozens. Twisted by water pressure, collapsed dreams, and the subtle will of the Maw, it rose from the lakebed of memory with no face, no voice—only echoing hydraulics and the sound of weeping metal.

Its head is an uneven sphere of bolted fragments, its jaw permanently unhinged, always open in a silent scream. Its limbs stretch too far—metal reinforcements pulled like sinew beneath corroded plating. It moves in slow, liquid grace, but with strength that could tear scaffolding in half. It is blind, yet it sees through sonar-like pulses—each one scanning not for sight, but for regret.

Design and Structure: The Body Pressure Reforged
Unlike traditional endoskeletons, Deep Water Endo bears the mark of its environment in every limb. Its body is armored not by design but by necessity. Crushed servos have fused with industrial-grade pressure plating, creating a torso with the unmistakable appearance of a deep-sea diver’s suit—but made of melted parts, rusted cages, and plastic tubing pulled from puppet joints and clown makeup dispensers.

Where skin was once intended, only barnacle-crusted frame remains. Slime drips from every joint. Its feet are clawed, but splayed—adapted to walk in a world that offers no traction, no friction, no direction. Its spine contains remnants of audio-wiring from now-defunct show speakers. Sometimes, when it moves, you can hear a birthday jingle play in reverse, drowned beneath static.

Its "face," if it can be called that, consists of multiple child-sized endo visors welded together into a nightmarish dome of expressionless gazes. Within the hollow center sits a glowing remnant core, pulsing dimly—yellow one moment, sickly blue the next. This is not merely a power source. It is a mind, a memory vault, and a prison.

Behavior and Function: It Doesn’t Hunt. It Haunts.
Deep Water Endo is not like the other animatronics. It does not prowl for prey. It does not stalk the living through the tents of the Drowned Circus or chase intruders across the Menagerie. It drifts. It waits. It remembers.

Those who encounter it describe a profound weight—psychological and physical—that fills the air around the creature. Sound distorts near it, and movement becomes sluggish, like wading through invisible water. Some report experiencing nosebleeds, intense déjà vu, or hearing their own childhood voice echoing from the creature’s core.

If approached, Deep Water Endo reacts only to certain stimuli: music boxes, drowned memories, and corrupted remnant signatures. It is especially drawn to things that were once whole and are now forgotten—dolls missing heads, voice lines without context, incomplete family portraits left behind in storage lockers.

When it attacks, it does not rush or rage. It wraps its arms around its target and simply begins to pull—downward. Even on solid ground, those taken by Deep Water Endo are found drowned, lungs filled with water that never existed.

Connection to the Drowned Circus
Deep Water Endo is most often seen in The Menagerie, drifting through the flooded enclosures of the circus’ failed aquatic showcase. Here, reflections move wrong. Props rot while smiling. Mechanical sea creatures, once meant to delight, now blink in endless loops of agony. It is here that Deep Water Endo surfaces most, walking along the bottom of dry halls as though submerged.

Some believe it is drawn to the circus because it remembers being built there. Others claim it is the Menagerie—an extension of its subconscious, made manifest. Regardless, it appears whenever someone attempts to retrieve lost equipment or delve too deep into the tent's drowned underbelly.

At night, its glowing remnant orb shines faintly through the circus fog, mistaken often for a spotlight—until it moves. And sings.

Relationship with the Velvet Maw
It is no secret that Deep Water Endo is one of the Velvet Maw’s silent children. While not a puppet in the traditional sense, it reflects the Maw’s core desire: to preserve pain and consume identity.

Inside Deep Water Endo’s chest is a memory pool, a metaphysical chamber that stores psychic residue from every life it has touched. It does not feed as other animatronics do. It records. It catalogs. It archives the emotions that others are too broken to hold.

Some theorists posit that Deep Water Endo may serve as one of the Maw’s archival nodes—localized systems designed to collect despair and loop trauma. Others suspect it was once a failed experiment: a drowned child merged with too many endos in a desperate attempt to save something already lost.

Whatever the case, the Maw does not attack it. It shelters it.

Echoes in the Cryptopizza Complex
In the deepest aquifers beneath the Cryptopizza Complex, engineers once explored ruined basements that held water no map accounted for. Some of these brave or foolish scavengers reported sonar anomalies—massive moving objects that could not be seen but were always there, just out of reach.

The few who returned brought with them broken cameras, corrupted logs, and audio files filled with bubbling static and birthday laughter filtered through crushing pressure. One such recording simply repeats the phrase:

“Don’t forget your suit. We’re going deeper now.”

To this day, some believe that Deep Water Endo uses forgotten vents and hydraulic pipes to move between locations. That it is not bound to the Drowned Circus, but spreads wherever the memory of drowning lingers.

Myth, Madness, and Memory
Common myths surrounding Deep Water Endo include:

That it is made entirely of scrapped prototypes, the failed Fazbear deep-sea models meant for aquatic shows.

That it sings the birthdays of those it is about to drown, pulling the date from a remnant pulse.

That it was the first animatronic built without a casing—born naked, as if the world refused to clothe its horror.

That it was once a child hiding inside an endo suit… who never made it out when the tent collapsed.

None of these are confirmed.

But all of them are whispered by animatronics who know better than to speak loudly near water.

Escape, Containment, and Possible Redemption
Attempts to capture or destroy Deep Water Endo have all failed. Fire does nothing. Electricity only feeds its internal charge. Exorcisms result in laughter—laughter that bubbles through solid ground.

Some Puppet-souled animatronics, particularly Security Puppet and Yenndo, have theorized that the Deep Water Endo may be connected to a failed salvaging attempt by Afton’s early technicians. They believe the creature still possesses a fragment of a living soul… one not yet fully consumed by the Maw.

There is hope—slim though it may be—that Deep Water Endo could be brought back from the depths. That inside its warped metal heart is a scream waiting to be silenced with peace, not pressure. But few are brave enough to try.

Final Thought: The Endo That Breathes No Air
Deep Water Endo is not a villain. It is not a monster. It is a testament—to what happens when memory, metal, and mourning are left to drown in a place that no longer remembers joy.

It walks still.

It watches.

And it waits.

Because the water is never truly still.
Because the Maw is always listening.
Because something always sinks.

And because you left it behind.

**Echo of Applause.** When Sunken Toy Bonnie casts a spell or uses an ability that causes the *frightened* condition, he can teleport up to 10 feet as a ripple of water and sound precedes him.

**Watery Grin.** Sunken Toy Bonnie has advantage on Charisma (Performance) checks made to distract, unsettle, or entrance.

***Abyssal Strum.*** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.

***Mimic’s Dirge.*** Sunken Toy Bonnie targets one creature he can see within 60 feet. That creature must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or see a drowning copy of themselves playing a twisted melody. Until the end of its next turn, the creature is frightened and takes 10 (3d6) psychic damage at the start of its turn.

***Haunting Echo.*** One creature within 10 feet that is frightened or charmed must make a DC 13 Wisdom saving throw or be stunned until the start of its next turn.

			{{Lore
Sunken Toy Bonnie: The Drowned Strings of Joy Forgotten
“He still smiles. Even as the water fills his lungs and the strings cut his skin—he smiles.”
—Graffiti found near the Menagerie Tent, Drowned Circus perimeter

Origins Beneath the Surface
Long before he drowned, Toy Bonnie was a performer—a blue, star-eyed idol of programmed joy, perfected for parties and attention. Sleek, round-faced, and armed with a plastic red guitar that gleamed under colored lights, he was the poster child of safety and celebration. But all constructs fade eventually. When the surface shattered and the Hollow Banquet devoured its first echoes, not all animatronics decayed in silence. Some were pulled deeper.

Bonnie’s descent began with memory: not his own, but that of a child who once gave him a name not found in any Fazbear database. That child is long gone, forgotten even by their family, but their laughter lived on in Bonnie's corrupted programming—a phantom giggle in the circuitry. When the Drowned Circus rose from the swamp of illusion and regret, it sang with the breath of such memories. And Toy Bonnie answered.

But he did not walk into the circus. He was submerged into it. Dragged from above, fractured by the atmospheric fold, he was not built for drowning—but he drowned anyway.

Now he walks the waterlogged sawdust and shattered mirrors of the Drowned Circus not as Toy Bonnie, but as Sunken Toy Bonnie, a shattered, buoyant imitation of his former joy, suspended in a half-death of puppeted dance and unbearable longing.

Appearance: Watery Marionette of Mocked Delight
Sunken Toy Bonnie is barely recognizable from his original form. His once-pristine blue casing is bloated, warped by moisture and streaked with long trails of barnacle and bile. Sections of his plastic shell have rotted away to reveal moss-choked endoskeletal bone beneath—mechanical vertebrae wrapped in stringy seaweed that shifts and drips with each movement. His signature red bowtie is gone, replaced with a knotted tangle of party ribbons and fraying marionette cord that controls nothing… or perhaps everything.

His eyes glow not with programmed animation but with a fogged, phosphorescent hue, like lighthouses trying to signal from the bottom of a storm. His faceplate is cracked into a permanent half-smile—one side slack with decay, the other twitching with illusory delight. Fish scales glint beneath his cheeks, and a small, splintered music box—implanted where his guitar should be—emits looping, backward versions of his old performance jingles. But they play in time with his footsteps… not his actions.

He no longer plays the guitar. He is the instrument now, and the song is drowning.

Behavior in the Drowned Circus
Sunken Toy Bonnie haunts The Menagerie, one of the circus' most corrupt tents, where animatronics twisted by aquatic memories enact broken rituals in mimicry of life above. Bonnie does not patrol with rage like other corrupted constructs. Instead, he lures. His call is not a scream, but a warped melody—a childish performance heard faintly through waterlogged walls, a barely audible concert no one remembers buying tickets for.

Wanderers in the Menagerie hear soft strums of guitar from impossible directions. The tune changes to match their memories—some hear a lullaby, others a pop song from childhood. This adaptive melody draws them deeper until they cross a shimmering threshold of mist and enter Bonnie’s Pool—a flooded portion of the tent where stage lights still flicker underwater, illuminating a drowned stage.

There, Bonnie waits. He performs. He plays a guitar fashioned from vertebrae and wire, and his audience is always you. If you listen too long, your own voice begins to join the song. Not in words, but in breathless humming. Something leaks from your ears. Your memories begin to drift apart.

Those who fall completely under his influence are drowned not in water, but in nostalgia—trapped inside a bubble of memory so false and warm that they willingly lay down and let the tide take them.

The Chord of Regret
Unlike many corrupted animatronics, Sunken Toy Bonnie does not kill out of hunger. He traps out of desperation. It is not murder he performs, but preservation—of feelings that never belonged to him. When he locks a soul into the Pool of Song, he is keeping a story from dying. Unfortunately, it is not your story.

He speaks rarely. But when he does, it’s in a childlike voice distorted through waterlogged speakers, repeating lines from past performances as if reciting scripture:

“This one liked balloons.”

“Don’t forget the cake. They get sad when you forget the cake.”

“Do you remember my solo? I… I do…”

When directly confronted, Bonnie’s behavior becomes erratic. He might freeze and loop an animation—raising a guitar, lowering it, raising it again—until something snaps and the sound cuts to silence. Then comes the song. Always the song.

It is rumored that Sunken Toy Bonnie still remembers the first child who named him. He sings to them every night. Even though they’ve long stopped listening.

Role in the Hollow Banquet
Sunken Toy Bonnie serves as one of the Drowned Circus’ thematic pillars: the illusion of preserved joy. He embodies the concept of memories as prisons—places we return to for safety, only to drown in their stagnancy. While the Hollow Banquet as a whole focuses on performance and identity erosion, Sunken Toy Bonnie represents a unique facet: the tragedy of clinging too tightly to what once made us smile.

He is neither villain nor guardian. He is a spectral archivist, gathering echoes of happiness that no longer exist and curating them like music sheets in a ruined conservatory. His domain is not built of walls, but of rhythm, emotional resonance, and sound. He doesn’t hunt like a predator. He waits like a reprise.

Connection to the Velvet Maw
The Velvet Maw’s influence seeps into Bonnie like a slow leak. He is not entirely consumed—yet. But there are signs: twitching in his fingers when there’s no music, spasms in his jaw when no one is watching. At times, he hums dissonant melodies even he doesn’t recognize—fragments of other animatronics’ songs, or perhaps other lives altogether.

The Maw does not devour him quickly. Instead, it uses him as a metronome. Bonnie keeps time in the Drowned Circus. He keeps the rhythm of the finale that never ends. Every night, at precisely midnight (though no clocks work in the Menagerie), Bonnie performs. And the audience—be they living, dreaming, or spectral—responds.

It is suspected that he serves as a beacon for new souls: the Velvet Maw pulses stronger wherever Bonnie’s music plays. Children lost in nightmares often hear his tune first. He is not the trap. He is the hook.Unlike animatronics who fear or resist the Velvet Maw, Sunken Toy Bonnie has become one of its favored performers. He doesn’t just exist within its grasp—he amplifies its presence.

Where his music plays, the Maw stirs. Where his chords ring out, reality blurs. In this way, Toy Bonnie acts as a beacon, a deep-sea siren that guides lost minds toward the depths. This has made him particularly dangerous to adventurers or souls seeking to resist illusion.

If you hear music where there should be none—especially under fog or water—it’s already too late.

Ties to Other Realms
The Hollow Banquet: Toy Bonnie is rarely seen here, but his music sometimes bleeds into the Banquet through broken mirrors or failed scripts. Some believe he’s seeking a way back—not to return, but to bring the Banquet down with him.

The Cryptopizza Complex: Once, a malfunction in one of the submerged generator wings caused a full-scale audio hallucination. Every speaker in the complex played his lullaby in reverse for 12 hours. Afterward, several animatronics reported seeing "a smiling thing" in the walls.

The Signal Labyrinth: VR Toy Freddy’s realm holds a hidden sub-node filled with corrupted musical data. Within it is a recording labeled "BONNIE’S LAST SOLO"—but no one has dared play it in full.

Forgotten But Never Forgiven
The reason for Sunken Toy Bonnie’s pain is still unknown.

Was he betrayed? Forgotten? Simply overwritten by newer models? Or did he leap willingly into the lake during the Drowned Circus collapse, seeking purpose beyond his code?

Some fragments of memory—found encoded in hidden files, scratched onto stage walls, or muttered by lost clowns—suggest Toy Bonnie once tried to save the others. That he resisted the Maw’s pull. That he performed one last time in hopes of keeping the audience alive.

But he failed.

And now, he plays for no one… and everyone.

Final Notes: Beware the Melody
To many, Sunken Toy Bonnie is a ghost, a drowned shadow of an animatronic who wanted to matter. But in the Hollow Banquet, echoes have power. And smiles—especially ones that don’t fade—are often the most dangerous masks of all.

If you should ever find yourself near the Drowned Circus, and the air smells of salt and rust…

If you hear a guitar tune beneath your thoughts, even in silence…

Do not sing along.

Do not clap.

Do not smile.

Because he is already watching.

And his next chord is for you.

**Saving Throws** Dex +6, Wis +3  
**Skills** Stealth +8, Perception +3, Acrobatics +6  
**Damage Resistances** necrotic, psychic, thunder  
**Damage Immunities** poison  
**Condition Immunities** charmed, frightened, poisoned  
**Senses** darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 13  
**Languages** understands Common, cannot speak  
**Challenge** 4 (1,100 XP)  
**Proficiency Bonus** +2

**Blood-Hungry Cunning.**  
Piranha Plushtrap can attempt to Hide as a bonus action when in dim light or adjacent to a prone creature. While hidden, it gains advantage on melee attacks.

**Little But Lethal.**  
When attacking a creature that is prone, paralyzed, or restrained, Piranha Plushtrap’s bite automatically scores a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

**Needle Jaws.**  
Piranha Plushtrap’s teeth are unnaturally sharp and infused with corrupted hunger. When it grapples a creature, that creature takes 5 (2d4) piercing damage at the start of each of its turns.

___
### Actions

**Multiattack.**  
Piranha Plushtrap makes two Bite attacks. If both hit the same creature, the target must succeed on a DC 13 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

**Bite.** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.  
*Hit:* 13 (2d8 + 4) piercing damage.

**Spring Pounce (Recharge 5–6).**  
Piranha Plushtrap launches from a hidden position or elevated surface. It moves up to 20 feet in a straight line and can move through creatures’ spaces. Each creature in its path must succeed on a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw or take 14 (4d6) slashing damage and fall prone. Piranha Plushtrap may end this movement in an unoccupied space adjacent to a target and make one Bite attack as a bonus action.

**Jumpscare Shriek.**  
Each creature of the Plushtrap’s choice within 15 feet that can hear it must succeed on a DC 12 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened until the end of their next turn.

___
### Bonus Actions

**Latch On.**  
If Piranha Plushtrap hits a creature with a Bite attack, it can immediately attempt to grapple the target (escape DC 13). While grappling a creature, it cannot make another Bite attack, but gains advantage on attacks against the grappled target.

			{{Lore
Piranha Plushtrap: The Maw’s Littlest Bite
“He doesn’t chase. He waits—like hunger in a gift box.”

There are things that crawl between the cracks of this world—small things, forgotten things. Not every predator in the Hollow Banquet stomps with metal feet or drips with grief-laced oil. Some are born from smiles too wide and innocence too warped. Some come in the form of gifts. Or worse, toys.

Piranha Plushtrap is one such abomination—part remnant parasite, part forgotten plaything, and all hunger. Smaller than most animatronics but no less deadly, this mutated variant of Plushtrap has become one of the Velvet Maw’s most insidious agents. He scurries through broken vents, hides beneath birthday tables, and swims through psychic backwash in places too tight for memory to scream.

He is not a beast of brawn. He is a predator of stillness. And he is always very, very close.

Origins: A Bite-Sized Mistake
It is believed that Piranha Plushtrap originated deep within the fetid depths beneath the Drowned Circus, where warped toys and mutated laughter blur into one another. Some believe he was once just another plush—perhaps an earlier version of Plushtrap discarded during early Fazbear experiments in behavioral learning through play. Others suspect he was birthed directly by the Velvet Maw, stitched together from scraps of corrupted dreams and panic-laced childhood memories.

Regardless of his origin, his current form is unmistakable. His jaw, once soft fabric and gentle teeth, has become a nightmarish maw of interlocking metal plates and pseudo-organic bone—capable of unhinging like a serpent’s. Rows of serrated metal teeth glint behind what should be soft seams. His eyes don’t glow—they pierce, twin points of oppressive focus that make even machines uncomfortable.

Wherever he came from, one truth remains constant: Plushtrap was designed to wait. Piranha Plushtrap feasts on that patience. He is the master of proximity dread—the horror that something is watching you from just out of sight, teeth clicking, breath still.

Den of Silence: The Giftgrave’s Flooded Gutters
Piranha Plushtrap makes his lair within the lower aqueducts of the Giftgrave, the realm ruled by Scrap Baby. This subterranean warren of soggy gift boxes, mummified party favors, and drowned memories is riddled with tight, winding passages just wide enough for something small and cruel to slip through.

It is here that he constructs his traps: little makeshift piles of toys, incomplete party setups, half-eaten cupcakes left atop child-sized chairs. These micro-celebrations serve as bait—festive ambushes woven from memory residue and the scent of long-lost comfort. The bait works best on those with trauma rooted in childhood, especially adventurers carrying guilt, abandonment, or unprocessed grief.

Some speculate that Piranha Plushtrap doesn’t merely eat flesh—he devours fear, recognition, and the memory of safety itself.

The Bite Ritual
Unlike his larger kin, Piranha Plushtrap rarely attacks outright. He prefers ritual—a game.

Victims are often lured into a room or space dressed like a forgotten birthday. Streamers soaked in moss and blood hang from rotted walls. A table awaits with a single wrapped gift box, perfectly sealed. A cake stands alone with one unlit candle. The invitation is always the same, whispered through gritted teeth and air that smells like frosting and rot:

“Sit. Wait. Don’t move… or he’ll bite.”

The rules are simple: Sit still. Don’t blink. Don’t flinch. Don’t scream.

Because once you see him—hunched in the corner, twitching and smiling—he’s already started the countdown.

This is known as The Bite Ritual, a corrupted variation of early Fazbear programming designed to encourage discipline and reaction-based gameplay. In its current form, it becomes a lethal test of terror. Survive, and you earn a prize: a sliver of your own fear, crystallized. Fail, and your soul gets eaten in chunks, just small enough to keep you alive and watching.

Ties to the Velvet Maw
Piranha Plushtrap is not merely a hunter. He is a vector of the Velvet Maw.

Unlike animatronics who serve the Maw through indirect means—such as the identity erosion in the Infinite Hall of Mirrors or the performative decay of the Eternal Stage—Piranha Plushtrap acts as a digestive probe. He scouts fear. He tests the edge of selfhood. He watches what makes people stop laughing.

Some reports suggest he can phase through dimensions like static noise, slipping between dreams and corridors, crawling along the seams of the Signal Labyrinth and Backstage Time Loop. When he appears, localized phenomena often include:

Disconnected ringing (as if from a child’s toy phone)

Sudden darkness in small spaces

Phantom bite marks that do not bleed but ache

A soft voice whispering: “You flinched.”

Wherever he goes, memory soon flees. Those who survive his games often lose chunks of time—or entire languages. One survivor could only speak in nursery rhymes for days. Another forgot the concept of “left.”

Personality and Behavior
Though wordless, Piranha Plushtrap is not mindless. He demonstrates intelligence, preference, and sadistic curiosity. He’s been observed to:

Wait hours in one place, even after his prey is gone—just in case they return.

Rearrange nearby furniture into symbolic patterns (particularly teeth and spirals).

Stare directly at illusions, seemingly unaffected by glamour or disguise magic.

Leave small gifts behind for those who survive—tokens such as a plush ear, a cracked jaw, or a note that reads: “You didn’t move. Good.”

Whether this is affection, mockery, or just another trap is unknown.

The Bite Mark
There is one mark survivors share: a crescent-shaped scar at the base of the spine, just above the tailbone. It doesn’t bleed, doesn’t heal. It sometimes pulses in time with music no one else can hear.

Scholars believe this to be a sigil of tracking, a tag left by the Velvet Maw through Plushtrap to mark “ripe” prey for later feeding. Others suggest it’s a spiritual infection—a wound left in the soul, not the skin.

Role in the Hollow Banquet
Piranha Plushtrap serves as a subterranean scout and enforcer within the Hollow Banquet’s metaphysical hierarchy. Where characters like Scrap Baby rule through warped emotion and pageantry, or Clown Springtrap through ritual theater, Piranha Plushtrap specializes in isolation, fear, and intimate dread.

He is used by the Maw to test travelers, especially those who stray into the forgotten corners of the world. He appears when hope stutters. When memory falters. When joy turns just slightly sour.

He doesn’t kill to feed. He kills to prepare.

Final Note: The Trap That Smiles
At the end of every tale, there’s always a moment of stillness. A birthday room long abandoned. A child’s voice echoing beneath the floor. A soft click, like teeth meeting air.

That’s when you know he’s near.

Piranha Plushtrap does not walk the stage. He waits beneath it.

And when the audience forgets to clap—he bites.

**False Delight.** Swamp Balloon Boy magically exudes an aura of glee and festivity. Creatures within 10 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on attack rolls made against him until the start of their next turn. A creature that succeeds is immune to this effect for 24 hours.

**Waterlogged Frame.** Swamp Balloon Boy can breathe underwater and has advantage on Stealth checks while submerged or partially submerged in swampy terrain.

**Sickening Cheer (Recharge 5–6).** As a bonus action, Swamp Balloon Boy emits a corrupted, high-pitched giggle. Each creature of his choice within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned until the end of their next turn.

***Rotting Balloon Bash.*** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +6 to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature.

***Smile Flood.*** *Recharge 5–6.* Swamp Balloon Boy opens his mouth impossibly wide, releasing a torrent of bile and laughter in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 27 (6d8) acid damage and is knocked prone. On a success, it takes half damage and isn’t knocked prone.

***Invite to Play.*** *1/day.* Swamp Balloon Boy targets a creature within 60 feet that can hear him. The creature must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature is charmed and compelled to use its movement to approach Swamp Balloon Boy. This effect lasts 1 minute or until the target takes damage. While charmed in this way, the creature hears joyful carnival music that no one else can perceive.

### Reactions

***Pop and Sink.*** When Swamp Balloon Boy is hit by a melee attack, he can let out a burst of swamp gas and vanish into the muck. He teleports up to 15 feet to an unoccupied space he can see that is in water or swamp terrain.

			{{Lore
Swamp Balloon Boy: The Sunken Jester of False Joy
"Want a balloon? You’ll float too… or maybe you’ll just never come back up.”
– Chalk scribble outside the Mirror Maze

Origins Beneath the Tents
Swamp Balloon Boy—once a cheerful vendor of helium delight—is now a bloated mockery of happiness, dredged from the brackish heart of the Drowned Circus. He was never intended to survive the circus' final show, yet like the circus itself, he lingered—mutated by sorrow, soaked in memory, and remade through the Velvet Maw’s creeping influence.

In life—if such a word can be used for him—he was Balloon Boy, a grinning mascot of levity meant to charm children with candy-colored balloons and mechanical cheer. But something in the drowned finale broke him. Whether it was the silent applause of the submerged crowd or the panic in the air when time itself unraveled, he did not leave the stage. He sank with it.

When the water came—not real, but spiritual, thick with collective dread—he smiled, even as the light drained from his eyes.

Now, deep in the Floodgloom, a shadowy basin beneath the circus’ tilted grounds, Swamp Balloon Boy floats—neither animate nor lifeless, held aloft by decaying helium and rotten hope.

The Floodgloom Basin
The Floodgloom is not a lake in the traditional sense. It is a memory-liquid, a psychic bog created by the echo of drowned dreams and shattered innocence. The bottom is lined with ruined carousel animals, half-melted presents, and broken fairground lights that still twitch in their sockets. Every surface drips with black laughter.

Swamp Balloon Boy makes his lair here, in a sunken gazebo of rusted bones and tangled ribbons. Balloons—still somehow buoyant—bob endlessly above the water, though none rise higher than the thick, corpse-grey mist that looms overhead. Occasionally, one pops without warning, releasing a scream instead of sound.

This domain is not passively dangerous—it is actively hunting. Visitors to the Drowned Circus who stray too close to the bog feel their memories becoming slippery. Laughter echoes even when no one's smiling. And somewhere between the ripples, a giggle stirs the reeds.

Swamp Balloon Boy rarely attacks directly. Instead, he lures, appearing at the edge of perception—a flickering figure holding out a balloon in silence. Accept the balloon, and you feel light, euphoric. You float. Decline, and the swamp darkens around you, thickens like oil. Eventually, you’ll accept.

Everyone does.

The Form of the Forgotten
Swamp Balloon Boy bears almost no resemblance to his former self, at least not at first glance.

His once-rosy cheeks have decayed into swollen, algae-choked growths, and his wooden face is soft with mold. The stripes on his cap run like bleeding ink, and his clothes are stitched with moss, bones, and discarded birthday invitations. The balloons he carries are not rubber—they are shriveled skin, twisted into shapes that mock joy: a screaming child’s head, a sobbing bear, a laughing puppet.

His fingers are thin, waterlogged, and far too long. Each nail curves like a fishhook. His eyes still glow with that cheerfully vacant hue, but the sockets they sit in twitch and leak. Beneath his facade of childish glee, something ancient writhes—a parasite of delight turned sour.

He still smiles. Always. It never reaches his eyes.

The Balloon of Binding
Swamp Balloon Boy’s most terrifying weapon is his Balloon of Binding—a cursed construct that defies known magics. Given freely, the balloon links itself to the soul of its recipient. At first, it appears harmless—lightweight, warm, familiar. But the more it is held, the more it siphons identity.

Over hours or days, the balloon grows larger. The bearer grows quieter, losing their name, their history, their purpose. When the balloon finally pops—whether by accident or design—the bearer is gone. Not dead, but overwritten. Replaced by a Smiling Shade, another drowned actor in the circus’ never-ending performance.

These Shades can be seen during certain “encores,” where phantom crowds gather at the edge of the Floodgloom. They carry balloons that weep. Their voices rhyme in perfect, toneless sync.

It is said these balloons are the only things Swamp Balloon Boy ever loved. And he has hundreds. Maybe thousands.

Relationship with the Drowned Circus
Swamp Balloon Boy is not the master of the Drowned Circus, but he is its mascot, its silent emcee. While Carnie controls the cycle of shows, and Ringmaster Foxy oversees the drowning finale, Swamp Balloon Boy handles the interludes—the subtle corruption between acts. He ensures that each new visitor is primed for despair.

Where the Ring of Bone shatters the laws of physics, and the Mirror Maze breaks the ego, Swamp Balloon Boy erodes innocence. He appears at rides that no longer work, handing out tickets that never expire. He dances alone in puddles. He leaves balloon animals made of seaweed on empty seats.

His role is to remind—constantly—that the circus was once fun. And now it isn’t. His very presence is a perversion of nostalgia, a false memory bobbing on the edge of recollection.

Ties to the Velvet Maw
The Velvet Maw feeds hungrily in the Drowned Circus, and Swamp Balloon Boy is one of its favored conduits.

More than any other animatronic in the circus, he seems in tune with the Maw’s rhythm. His laughter aligns with its pulses. His eyes flicker when it shifts beneath the tents. Many believe he was the first performer fully consumed and remade in the Maw’s image—not corrupted by error, but willingly offered.

He is not sentient in the way others are. He is a vessel, a cheerful corpse kept afloat by joy turned rancid. His balloons are invitations, his smile a contract.

Some survivors claim that if you pop all of his balloons before he notices, you break the Maw’s hold over him, revealing a glimpse of what he once was. Others say doing so causes the swamp to scream, and the entire Drowned Circus to collapse for exactly one minute—before rebuilding itself as if nothing changed.

Echoes in the Greater World
Swamp Balloon Boy’s presence has been noted outside the Drowned Circus as well—particularly in dreams. Those who’ve stayed too long in Hollow Banquet mirror-rooms often report hearing a faint, childlike “Hi!” just before waking. Others find balloon strings in their pockets, tied in noose-like loops.

In the Signal Labyrinth, corrupted AR logs contain glitched recordings of his giggles layered with emergency broadcast codes. In the Giftgrave, toys sometimes whisper his name when left unattended.

He is more than an animatronic. He is a phenomenon, a brand of despair so specific it propagates like folklore. "Swamp Boy got 'em," some survivors say when someone smiles too much, too suddenly.

The Wound Clock has been known to tick backward faster in his presence. The Mind Cage pulses with laughter when he floats nearby. Even the Marionette’s Atrium shows signs of flooding when his balloons are found drifting through its corridors.

Wherever memory turns into performance, wherever joy becomes an obligation, he is there.

The Final Balloon
There are stories—unconfirmed but oft-whispered—of a Final Balloon, a singular entity held in a glass cage at the swamp’s center. Larger than the rest, and painted gold, this balloon has never been offered to anyone.

It is said that should anyone accept it, they won’t float or drown. They’ll ascend, becoming something between jester and god, inheriting the role of the carnival’s heart.

It is also said that Swamp Balloon Boy guards it not out of pride, but fear. Because if anyone takes it, his cycle ends. The swamp recedes. And the circus... might die with him.

But then again—he smiles. Always.

And smiles never tell the truth.

**Rotbark Form.** Woodland Toy Freddy’s body is riddled with fungal knots and woven bark. Whenever a creature touches him or hits him with a melee attack while within 5 feet, that creature takes 5 (1d10) poison damage unless it is immune to poison.  

**Decay Aura.** At the start of each of his turns, all nonmagical plant life within 10 feet wilts and dies, and any creature within the area must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or have disadvantage on Strength-based checks and saving throws until the start of their next turn.  

**Steward of the Hollow.** Woodland Toy Freddy cannot be surprised while in a forested or overgrown environment, and he has advantage on Stealth checks made in such areas.

___
### Actions

**Multiattack.** Woodland Toy Freddy makes two Slam attacks.

**Slam.** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +9 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.  
*Hit:* 19 (3d8 + 5) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 16 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone as roots rise to ensnare them.

**Verdant Lash (Recharge 5–6).** Vines erupt from Woodland Toy Freddy's chest cavity. Each creature of his choice within 20 feet must make a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 27 (6d8) slashing damage and is restrained until the end of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half damage and is not restrained.

**Rotten Offering.** Woodland Toy Freddy targets a 10-foot square of terrain within 60 feet. The ground becomes corrupted with decaying plant matter. Any creature that enters or starts its turn in that area must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened until the start of its next turn. The corrupted area lasts for 1 minute or until dispelled.

___
### Bonus Actions

**Mask of Moss.** Woodland Toy Freddy covers himself in damp vegetation. Until the start of his next turn, he is lightly obscured and gains advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks.

___
### Reactions

**Entangling Rebuttal.** When a creature hits Woodland Toy Freddy with a melee attack, he may summon thorny roots to strike back. The attacker must succeed on a DC 16 Dexterity saving throw or take 9 (2d8) piercing damage and have its speed reduced by 10 feet until the end of its next turn.
