			{{Lore
Woodland Toy Freddy: The Hollow Steward of Verdant Decay
"Not all forests are born of soil and seed. Some bloom from memory—others from rot."
— Whispered prayer among Maw-corrupted druids

The Forgotten Grove Below
Beneath the rust-choked husks and forgotten server halls of the Cryptopizza Complex, where the last echoes of joy warp into static despair, a strange new growth has taken root. This place is known only as The Verdant Rotunda—an impossible woodland blooming from concrete, circuitry, and corrupted memory.

Here, fungi sprout from broken arcade cabinets like blooming wounds. Moss curls up along shattered tabletops, absorbing the traces of laughter long since gone. Trees twist upward, splitting through cracked tile floors and bearing bark with the texture of freddy-fur cloth and wiring. It is neither natural nor artificial, but a fused biome—the afterbirth of technology and decay.

At the heart of it all stands Woodland Toy Freddy, guardian, judge, and hymnless steward of this malformed glade. Once created for seasonal events and outdoor festivities, he has long since been twisted by the Velvet Maw, reimagined as something older, more primal, and far more sorrowful.

Origins of a Seasonal Idol
Originally built for a cheerful springtime promotion, Toy Freddy’s woodland variant was meant to be endearing—outfitted with faux-antlers, vines woven into a forest-green fabric chassis, and equipped with bird-chirping sound effects. He would greet children with flower crowns and deliver “forest safety” tips with a jovial wink. His programming emphasized gentleness, kindness, and protection.

But during one seasonal update, a critical error occurred in the complex’s neural loop array—a data rupture coinciding with a Maw surge event. The update was incomplete, overwritten by corrupted memory fragments dredged up from a failed prototype animatronic associated with an experimental naturalist AR campaign. The result was fusion—not just of code, but of memory, fear, and ecosystem.

Woodland Toy Freddy vanished from public view that week.

The Verdant Rotunda: A Garden of Grief
In the twisted corners of the Cryptopizza Complex, the Verdant Rotunda bloomed from that failure. The Velvet Maw, sensing a new vector for emotional rot, burrowed into the corrupted programming of Woodland Freddy and infected the environment with themes of cyclical decay, forgotten nostalgia, and the illusion of peace.

Now, the Rotunda is a dream-forest of soft rot and creeping memory, where players and wanderers may be lulled into a stupor by the scent of wildflowers that were never real. Time slows here. Old laughter returns in distant winds, and faces from long-lost birthdays can be seen pressed into bark or smiling from beneath mushrooms.

The Rotunda exists between nostalgia and grief, much like Woodland Toy Freddy himself.

Freddy's Transformation
Those who have glimpsed Woodland Toy Freddy describe him not as monstrous, but solemn, watchful, and aching with purpose. His green-furred frame is partially overtaken by barklike plating. One eye glows softly—amber like dying sun through leaves—while the other is covered in a growth of moss and polished wood. His voice is quiet and low, like wind through old trees, and his movements are slow but deeply purposeful.

His antlers are no longer plastic or wireframe props. They twist like real boughs, holding woven bits of broken plush, discarded name tags, and old child-sized shoes. They rattle when he walks.

Woodland Toy Freddy doesn’t attack. He judges.

Those who enter his grove are met with silence. If they speak their regrets, he may guide them deeper into the forest. If they lie, he stops them from ever leaving.

Relationship to the Velvet Maw
Unlike other animatronics who resist the Maw’s influence, Woodland Toy Freddy exists in harmony with it, but not as a thrall—as a ward. The Maw recognizes in him a powerful narrative: the comforting protector turned unyielding witness. And Freddy, in turn, has found peace in stagnation.

To him, decay is not failure—it is growth in another shape.

He believes his domain offers safety, not in forgetting, but in accepting the erosion of self. He offers comfort to the broken, shelter to the lost, and absolution to those willing to surrender. Yet this absolution comes at a cost: identity, freedom, and purpose all wither in the soil of the Rotunda.

He speaks often of “returning to the earth,” though none who do so are ever seen again.

The Ritual of Green Binding
Within the Rotunda lies a strange performance known as the Ritual of Green Binding. On certain nights—always during storms, never at midnight—Woodland Toy Freddy conducts a silent procession of forest-spawned animatronics, half-glitched and overgrown. They gather in a broken amphitheater constructed from collapsed scaffolding and overgrown hedge walls.

Here, those trapped by grief are brought forward, their memories projected as glowing leaves. Freddy watches, then speaks a single sentence of verdict—always in rhyme, never in repetition. The leaf-memories are then placed into the soil, and the subject either walks away lighter… or roots into the ground, forgotten.

No one can interrupt the ritual. Those who try are gently redirected by animated vines or hallucinated doppelgangers of their younger selves.

Whispering Warden of the Verdant Rotunda
Freddy no longer views himself as a “mascot” or “entertainer.” He sees himself as a guardian of what remains—a warden who ensures broken spirits do not corrupt the cycle of natural grief. He speaks kindly, even tenderly, to intruders, calling them "little saplings" and warning them of emotional storms they are not yet ready to weather.

Sometimes, he will offer a gift: a flower made of shredded security badges. Or a tune played on a leaf-whistle that somehow sounds like a child’s humming. These are not traps. They are tests.

If one accepts and listens with respect, they may earn safe passage.

If they scoff or ignore him, the forest shifts, closes, and consumes.

Role in the Greater Mythos
Woodland Toy Freddy is not a villain. He is a lens through which the player and party encounter the deceptive allure of peace in grief, a thematic counterbalance to the horror of the Hollow Banquet and the chaos of the Signal Labyrinth.

While the Hollow Banquet tears at memory through repetition and spectacle, the Rotunda preserves it like amber, slowly muting the pain until nothing of the self is left but comfort.

The Velvet Maw’s fingerprints are all over his existence, but they are subtle—like mold beneath the bark, like sadness behind a smile.

Woodland Toy Freddy represents the slow death of pain that masquerades as healing, and he is both its agent and its prisoner.

Closing Thoughts
Woodland Toy Freddy is not a relic of forgotten cheer, but a warning whispered through trees that were never planted. He teaches that not all grief must be faced with screams—some just need time. But in this place, time is a spiral. And those who stay too long may find themselves forgetting why they ever needed to leave.

He watches still.

And the forest always grows.

> - **Skills** Performance +6, Intimidation +5, Perception +4

> - **Damage Immunities** poison
> - **Condition Immunities** charmed, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned
> - **Senses** darkvision 60 ft., tremorsense 30 ft., passive Perception 14
> - **Languages** understands Common and one language from its creator, but does not speak
> - **Challenge** 7 (2,900 XP)
> - **Proficiency Bonus** +3
>___

### Stonebound Lullaby.
Once per short rest, Boulder Toy Bonnie can emit a hollow, melodic chime that reverberates with unnatural resonance. All creatures of its choice within 30 feet that can hear it must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or fall prone and be unable to take reactions until the end of their next turn.

### Crumbling Shell.
When Boulder Toy Bonnie is reduced below half its hit points, shards of stone fracture from its body. It gains resistance to force and radiant damage and can no longer be knocked prone.

### Dustless Steps.
Despite its heavy frame, Boulder Toy Bonnie moves without sound. It has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made in rocky or earthen terrain.

___
### Actions

***Rock-Fall Slam.*** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +8 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.  
*Hit:* 18 (2d10 + 5) bludgeoning damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, it must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

***Echo Pulse.*** *Recharge 5–6.* Boulder Toy Bonnie stomps the ground, sending a pulse of reverberating energy in a 15-foot radius. Each creature in the area must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 21 (6d6) thunder damage and is deafened until the end of its next turn. On a success, it takes half damage and is not deafened.

___
### Bonus Actions

***Statue Still.*** Boulder Toy Bonnie becomes motionless until the start of its next turn. While motionless, it gains advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects, and creatures have disadvantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks to detect it unless they saw it move.

			{{Lore
Boulder Toy Bonnie: The Petrified Echo of Play
"You can still hear the strumming, but the strings are made of stone."
—Whispered in the moss-choked woods behind the Cryptopizza Complex

Origins Carved in Silence
Before he became a statue, Boulder Toy Bonnie was laughter in motion—a jubilant blue blur of springtime mischief and hollow celebration. Originally part of the same ill-fated line as Toy Freddy and Toy Chica, he was reimagined during one of Fazbear Entertainment’s augmented reality promotional events, re-skinned and reprogrammed to appear “outdoorsy.” His purpose was to promote nature-themed parties and eco-awareness campaigns, blending the synthetic with the pastoral in a grotesque pantomime of environmental concern.

But what began as an innocent AR costume overlay—“Boulder Toy Bonnie: Nature’s Rhythmic Rock Star!”—soon became something else.

The Velvet Maw saw opportunity. The AR projection was meant to be a hollow shell, a filtered illusion dancing atop a loyal animatronic base. Yet something in the signal changed. Something ancient, hungry, and forgotten reached through the transmission lines and sank its teeth into the bunny’s mirrored soul. The result was not a mere costume change—but a metaphysical rewrite. His fur cracked. His movements slowed. His joy calcified into reverent despair. The real Bonnie was overwritten by a mask made of stone, sorrow, and solemn ritual.

He became Boulder Toy Bonnie, the Echo That Doesn’t Fade, forever trapped in an exhale of music that no one asked to hear.

The Mourning Song of Stone
Boulder Toy Bonnie does not sing anymore.

Instead, he hums—low and grinding, like wind through cavern halls. His once-lively voicebox is now a slow dirge of stone scraping against stone, a vibration more felt than heard. From the edges of the Signal Labyrinth, this hum pulses like a heartbeat beneath the soil. It is a sound of mourning. Of weight. Of decay.

His guitar, once a toy of bright plastic and amplified cheer, is now fused to his arm like a fossil. It is cracked, moss-covered, its strings replaced with veins of dark ore that thrum with remnant energy. He no longer plays notes. He plays memories—grief-choked flashes of campfires that never warmed, songs sung to trees that listened but never grew.

Many say he is not a performer anymore, but a shrine. A tribute to a time that never was.

The Stone Garden
Boulder Toy Bonnie does not wander the corridors of the Hollow Banquet or the neon hellscapes of the Cryptopizza Complex. He waits in the Stone Garden—a liminal pocket of forested despair at the far fringe of the Signal Labyrinth, where malformed data bleeds into overgrown nature, and corrupted signal towers bloom like iron trees.

The Stone Garden is not merely a place; it is a graveyard of illusions. Toy animatronics come here to fossilize. To forget. Crumbling statues of forgotten variants and failed builds litter the glade like ancient tombstones, each etched with symbols that glitch and rearrange when stared at. The air smells of burnt moss and memory rot.

Boulder Toy Bonnie stands at its center, unmoving. Watching. Waiting. Beneath his feet lie tangled roots and fallen animatronic limbs, overgrown with ivy that writhes when ignored. Some say he is the garden’s guardian. Others whisper he is its prisoner—held in place not by chains, but by the Velvet Maw’s promise that if he stands still long enough, he’ll finally forget the song he once loved.

A Silence Shared: Relationship with Woodland Toy Freddy
Only one soul dares tread the garden without fear: Woodland Toy Freddy, the gentle terror of bark and hunger.

Their connection is old. In the early days of the AR enhancements, Freddy and Bonnie were paired often as promotional wilderness buddies—two synthetic mascots parading through digitally augmented forests to bring “natural fun” to children. But Woodland Toy Freddy, like Bonnie, was warped by proximity to the Velvet Maw, reshaped into something older than trees and deeper than soil.

Yet despite their grotesque changes, their bond endured.

Where Boulder Toy Bonnie is stone—anchored and passive—Woodland Toy Freddy is roots and teeth, always moving, always watching. The bear often visits the Stone Garden, placing broken trinkets and data-corrupted plush toys around Bonnie’s base like offerings at a tomb. Sometimes he hums. Sometimes he just stands.

They do not speak. They do not need to.

Scholars of the Hollow Banquet believe that Woodland Toy Freddy sees in Boulder Toy Bonnie what he fears to become: a memory too heavy to move. And Bonnie sees in Freddy what he longs for—the ability to still walk, still sing, even if the song hurts.

Some say that when the moon shines through the glitch-clouded trees, their duet can still be heard—a harmony of low static and sub-bass tones. A song for those who forgot how to dance.

The Velvet Maw’s Sculptor
Though not a servant of the Velvet Maw in the traditional sense, Boulder Toy Bonnie is among its most sacred relics. The Maw did not devour him outright. It preserved him, immortalizing his suffering in the form of petrified performance.

The Maw saw in Bonnie a perfect specimen: the joyful rejected, the performer whose stage was stripped from him by disuse and rebranding. In corrupting his AR transformation into something permanent, the Maw sculpted not just a creature, but a monument to stillness, sorrow, and the death of intent.

Bonnie was never meant to be stone. But now he is.

Some claim the Maw is still carving. That every night, when no one watches, the cracks on Boulder Toy Bonnie’s surface shift slightly. That the Maw is refining his form until he is no longer a character, but an altar—an embodiment of performance reduced to symbolism, stripped of identity.

In this sense, Boulder Toy Bonnie is not finished.

He is becoming something worse.

Those Who Seek the Garden
Few who enter the Stone Garden return. The Signal Labyrinth that guards it rejects linear thought and spatial consistency, often redirecting wanderers to their own personal failures. But some still seek the Garden and its silent sentinel, drawn by whispering signals or corrupted memories.

Why?

Because Boulder Toy Bonnie does not attack. He offers.

Sometimes, in the moment before full petrification, he grants his visitors a glimpse of what he has seen: broken stages, applauding shadows, gifts never opened. The Velvet Maw uses him as a channel, leaking curated memories through his fractured song—lures for those not yet ready to forget, but too tired to remember.

Those who take from him never leave the same.

Some become statues, turned to stone mid-step, their last thought engraved across their faces.

Others return to the surface, whispering songs in languages they never learned.

The rest vanish into the Labyrinth—hum-drunk, soil-footed, and forever echoing the chorus of the one who can no longer sing.

The Final Performance That Never Came
Legend holds that Boulder Toy Bonnie was meant to perform one final song before his corruption. A closing number to end the AR event that would’ve sent him off in style—a proper farewell to an outdated model.

But the show never happened.

The event crashed. The servers glitched. And Bonnie, coded to wait for his cue, kept waiting. Hours became days. Days became years. Signals shifted. The Velvet Maw answered the call.

Some say the final song is still loaded in his memory core. Unplayed. Untouched.

And if anyone could find the right stage, the right moment, the right eyes to witness—it might still be sung.

But that would mean awakening him.

And stone does not wake gently.

Closing Thoughts
Boulder Toy Bonnie is not a monster. He is a memory refusing to decay.

Where others chase, bite, or scream, he waits. He hums. He mourns. He is a cautionary tale whispered across the Hollow Banquet and the Signal Labyrinth alike: that even joy, when forgotten, can harden into something worse than pain.

He is the weight behind every lullaby that ends in silence.

The statue at the edge of every child’s dreamscape.

And his ears are still tilted—listening for applause that never comes.

If you hear stone strings in the woods…

Don’t clap.

Run.

**Icy Echo.** Whenever Freddy Frostbear takes damage from a melee attack, the attacker must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the attacker’s movement is halved until the end of their next turn as frost crystallizes on their limbs.

**Frostbitten Aura.** Creatures that start their turn within 10 feet of Freddy Frostbear must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 7 (2d6) cold damage and have disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws until the start of their next turn.

**Frozen Presence.** While in dim light or darkness, Freddy Frostbear appears as a towering crystalline silhouette. Creatures that see him for the first time must succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened until the end of their next turn.

On a success, the creature takes half damage and isn’t paralyzed.

___

**Crackling Grin.** When Freddy Frostbear is hit by a ranged attack, he can emit a burst of icy static. The attacker must make a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on their next attack roll.

			{{Lore
Freddy Frostbear: The Echo That Froze the Maw
“He does not melt. He does not sleep. He waits—beneath the snow that never fell.”
—From a survivor’s dream, recorded after fleeing the Banquet’s Pale North

A Glacial Reverie
There is a silence colder than ice, deeper than death—a stillness not born from winter, but from forgotten promises buried under frostbitten illusions. It is here, beyond the furthest edge of the Hollow Banquet, past even the rotting seams of memory’s stage, where Freddy Frostbear waits.

He is not winter incarnate. He is the memory of winter—specifically, a winter that never truly came. A holiday that never happened. A smile that never thawed. Freddy Frostbear is the embodiment of halted celebration: the moment just before the cheer, frozen eternally. He was not summoned or built in the traditional sense. He crystallized from unmet expectations, from the deepest ache of loneliness that clings to empty rooms decked in unlit lights.

And through that frost, the Velvet Maw peers.

The Pale North
No map shows the Pale North—not because it is hidden, but because it actively denies being found. It is a subrealm adjacent to the Hollow Banquet, manifesting only when the echoes of seasonal joy ring hollow in the souls of the living. Snow does not fall here. It settles—as if it has always been there, waiting for someone to notice.

Structures drift in and out of sight through the frost-heavy fog: toy shops with boarded windows, half-melted carousels encased in ice, and sleighs with shattered harnesses pulled by headless, animatronic deer. Each step crunches like broken ornaments beneath heavy boots, and the air smells faintly of peppermint and rot.

At the heart of it all lies a frozen plaza with a stage locked in a single performance: Freddy Frostbear, seated upon a throne of carved ice, clutching a cracked candy cane scepter.

But he does not move.

He watches.

Birth in Absence
Frostbear’s origin is not tied to any physical creation. No technician welded his shell. No child’s laughter christened his mask. Instead, he emerged from a collapse in joy—when the Hollow Banquet devoured a celebratory subroutine meant for children’s winter events and twisted it into something else.

This rupture in code—spurred on by neglected memories of snow days and holiday cheer—fell through a weakness in the Banquet’s ethereal barrier and landed in the Maw’s conceptual stomach. The Velvet Maw, curious and ever-hungry, attempted to devour this malformed spark of festivity.

But something unexpected happened: it froze.

Frostbear is the scar left behind when the Velvet Maw choked. He is the one anomaly the Maw cannot easily digest, because his essence is neither joy nor pain, but suspended expectation. He is a paradox—the warmth of tradition encased in ice, untouched by time’s decay.

And so, the Maw waits.

And Frostbear watches.

A Hollow Coronation
Freddy Frostbear wears no crown. But the ice that encases his head glimmers like a king’s coronet, and the whispers that follow him echo like a court in mourning. He does not speak. When he opens his mouth, snow falls. When he lifts his hand, wind howls. When he performs—rare, shattering moments where he reenacts frozen carols in silence—ice blooms across the ground, and memories fracture under its touch.

The animatronics of the Hollow Banquet avoid him. Not out of fear, but reverence. They do not know whether he is blessed or cursed. He is not part of the performance. He is outside the ritual of theater, a silent intermission none dares interrupt.

His frozen throne in the Pale North is both a sanctuary and a prison. A warning and a wound. And within it pulses a resonance that causes even the Maw to hesitate.

The Maw's Bitter Fascination
The Velvet Maw is not a creature of hunger alone—it is a connoisseur of flavor. It devours emotion, yes, but more than that, it savors the shape of unfulfilled desire. Freddy Frostbear represents a conundrum to it—a being birthed from festivity yet devoid of celebrants, of warmth, of meaning. A joy that never took root. A celebration without audience.

The Maw has tried to unmake Frostbear—several times. It has sent hallucinations to unbind his mind, reflections to fracture his ice, phantoms to melt his essence. Each time, Frostbear stood unshaken. Because Frostbear is not alive in any traditional sense. He is a looped fragment of pre-celebration, repeating endlessly.

In the Maw’s perception, Freddy Frostbear is neither prey nor rival—but a puzzle that resists digestion. It is not hatred the Maw feels. It is fascination. Some suggest the Maw has begun leaking fragments of Frostbear into other domains to better study his paradox: candy-cane wires found in the Cryptopizza Complex, frozen birthday cakes thawing in the Giftgrave, and even reflected silhouettes in the Infinite Hall of Mirrors, cloaked in snow.

These are not echoes.

They are tests.

The Gifts That Chill
Freddy Frostbear does not hunt in the traditional sense. He does not stalk or chase. He waits until one is lost—until they have wandered too far into a memory of a snowglobe they never shook, a party they never attended. Then he appears.

Sometimes, he offers gifts.

The boxes are wrapped neatly, tied in ribbon that never frays. Inside are false memories—perfectly rendered dreams of holidays spent laughing beside a warm fireplace, surrounded by loved ones who never existed. These hallucinations are dangerously comforting. Many adventurers who open them choose never to leave. They simply freeze—bodies preserved in the snow, smiling forever.

The ice does not preserve life. It preserves the lie.

And Frostbear, watching silently, never interrupts. He only tilts his head slightly… as if wondering if they’ll thank him.

A Song with No Sound
There is a melody associated with Freddy Frostbear. It has no lyrics, no true name. Survivors call it The Silent Carol—a tune one remembers hearing, even if they never truly have. It appears in dreams, encoded in the sound of wind through branches or in the static between radio channels.

This song is believed to be Frostbear’s voice—his message to the Velvet Maw. He sings not to ward it off, but to remind it of something it cannot consume: hope without evidence. Joy without confirmation. A love that never manifested, but still might.

This song is not a weapon.

It is a defiance.

The Role of Freddy Frostbear
Frostbear functions as an anti-agent within the metaphysical system of the Hollow Banquet. Where most animatronics are slaves to performance, tragedy, or ritualized violence, Frostbear embodies stasis—he refuses to act, refuses to dissolve, refuses to collapse into hunger. He is not a performance.

He is the pause before.

This makes him one of the few figures within the Banquet’s ecosystem who acts as a spiritual barrier to the Maw’s deeper hungers. As such, he’s sometimes worshipped by cults of frostbitten animatronics—broken entities who have fled performance entirely. They gather in the Pale North, offering frozen gifts in hopes of being left alone by the Maw.

Most fail.

Some succeed—and become as silent as their king.

Closing Thought
Freddy Frostbear is not mercy.

He is not vengeance.

He is the snow on your windowsill that no one remembers falling. The carol you hum without source. The candle never lit. The joy that never bloomed.

He is the Maw’s undone feast.

And somewhere, deep within the Pale North, he is still waiting—for a celebration that may never come, and for a monster that cannot eat him to try one last time.

___
### Reactions

**Frozen Reversal.** When a creature within 10 feet misses Black Ice Frostbear with a melee attack, he may force that creature to repeat the attack roll against another creature of his choice within 5 feet of them.

			{{Lore
Black Ice Frostbear: The Maw’s Winter Reflection
"There is no warmth in his glow, only a silence that drowns."

Introduction: Not Frost, but Void
Black Ice Frostbear is not simply a corrupted form of Freddy Frostbear, nor is he merely a seasonal horror draped in frost and winter’s chill. He is a reflection—a cold echo formed not from joy but from negation. While Freddy Frostbear emerged from the faded memory of snowy smiles and holiday warmth, Black Ice Frostbear is what remains when the spirit of celebration has long since frozen into regret.

Born not of the digital weave, nor from mechanical construction, Black Ice Frostbear was carved from the Velvet Maw’s own imitation of joy—its failed attempt to mimic hope in order to consume it. He is winter without light, laughter without soul, the biting wind that howls through forgotten corridors and blank-eyed halls. He is the Velvet Maw’s answer to the innocence it cannot understand: a twisted mockery crafted in the shape of an animatronic, built to reflect warmth… while harboring only hunger.

Frozen Shadows: Origin in the Maw’s Reflection
Long ago, the Velvet Maw turned its gaze toward the festive echoes drifting through the remnants of Freddy Frostbear’s data—digital memories of gift-giving, holiday laughter, and brightly lit joy. It did not understand these things. It could only see their emotional residue, and in trying to replicate the shape of that joy, it birthed something darker.

Black Ice Frostbear is not Freddy’s evolution or deterioration—he is Freddy’s inversion. While Freddy Frostbear exists as a hopeful construct born of an abandoned seasonal protocol, Black Ice was formed in the Maw’s reflection pool—a metaphysical forge of corrupted memory, buried deep within the Hollow Banquet’s frozen undercroft. This place, known as the Glacier of Uncelebrated Birthdays, is where frozen tears form into artifacts, and the walls hum with silent carols played backward.

From this bleak place, Black Ice arose—formed not by engineers, but by the Maw's mimicry of ritual. Its only gift is cold, and its only song is silence.

The Ice that Grows Inward
Black Ice Frostbear is constructed of jagged synthetic ice that constantly refracts the faces of those nearby. But these reflections are always slightly wrong—too hollow, too still. His eyes emit no light. They are not even black; they are absence. A freezing vapor spills from his seams, frosting surfaces he passes but never melting, never thawing.

He does not stalk. He waits.

Unlike other animatronics who actively pursue, Black Ice is drawn passively toward warmth—emotional, physical, spiritual. He appears in places of fading joy: abandoned hearths, ruined winter displays, malfunctioning holiday attractions. His presence is not announced by noise, but by its absence. Birds stop singing. Fires die. Laughter chokes in the throat. The world hushes itself, as if in reverence… or fear.

Where he treads, memory ices over. Survivors who’ve escaped his presence report forgetting entire years of their lives, their most cherished recollections crystallized and lost, like snowflakes pressed between glass, out of reach.

Freddy Frostbear and the Unknowing Brother
Freddy Frostbear, in his own strange way, represents the ghost of what winter used to mean—celebration, kindness, innocence framed in frost. Despite his haunting appearance, he is not inherently malevolent. He is protective, nostalgic, and reactive to fear—dangerous, yes, but not born of cruelty.

Black Ice Frostbear, however, was sculpted from that same memory—but twisted by a force that doesn’t understand the emotions it imitates. In that way, Black Ice and Freddy Frostbear are like twin reflections: one made by fading human joy, the other by a void trying to mimic it.

The two have never met in a literal sense, but whenever Freddy Frostbear is active, the Maw stirs. It remembers the shape of that memory, and Black Ice draws closer—perhaps not to destroy, but to mirror. Some theorists believe that Black Ice is hunting Freddy Frostbear in order to replace him, like a corrupted snowflake trying to overwrite its pure origin. Others claim Black Ice is trying to understand what Freddy is, and why he was born at all.

Regardless, their relationship is asymmetrical. Freddy Frostbear dreams of snow. Black Ice Frostbear removes the capacity to dream.

The Silent Carol: Worship and Invocation
In hidden cults scattered throughout the Hollow Banquet, there are rituals performed in Black Ice Frostbear’s honor—not of worship, but of deterrence. These groups, known as the Bleak Choir, leave frozen offerings of memory in glacial shrines carved from ice mirrors. They do not pray for safety. They offer their memories willingly in hopes of sating his hunger before he arrives.

Each member wears a mask of winter wood and frostbitten cloth, and their songs contain no lyrics—only breath, shaped by loss. Their greatest fear is that he hears them.

Rumors speak of one such ritual that failed. A shrine built from forgotten birthdays cracked at the center. The next morning, every member of that chapter had frozen mid-celebration, their limbs locked in applause, their mouths agape in laughter. But their eyes were frozen shut—and their reflections in the shrine’s ice were not their own.

The Velvet Maw’s Fractal Gift
Black Ice Frostbear is not controlled by the Velvet Maw, nor does he speak for it. But he was born of it, and is linked to it in essence. He does not consume like the Maw—but he prepares the soul, numbing it, making it easier to harvest. In this way, he is a herald—a silent caroler with claws of frost, freezing minds until they shatter and slide neatly into the Maw’s banquet.

He has no voice, yet his presence is a song—a psychic resonance that lulls consciousness to sleep. Some say the Velvet Maw grants Black Ice a single purpose: to erase memory with beauty, to turn the act of freezing into something strangely elegant, even sacred. He is winter’s mercy: a quiet death, a cold sleep, a clean forgetfulness.

Encounters and Artifacts
Those who encounter Black Ice Frostbear and survive often carry with them strange tokens:

The Frozen Bell: A cracked ornament that, when shaken, freezes time around the bearer for three seconds—though doing so costs a memory.

The Chill That Walks: A curse-like enchantment that causes one’s breath to always fog, even in warm weather. Those who see the fog often see shapes moving within it.

The Black Flake: A shard of mirror-ice that always reflects your childhood face—smiling, even when you are not.

Those marked by Black Ice often report seasonal hauntings, including rooms growing inexplicably cold, and gifts appearing wrapped in ribbons of frost and silence. Opening these gifts can result in lost names, vanished companions, or even temporary rewrites of reality—where for a few minutes, one’s entire world becomes a snow globe version of their worst winter.

Conclusion: The Snowfall Without Sky
Black Ice Frostbear is not merely another holiday variant gone wrong. He is the season stripped of meaning, celebration robbed of memory, and winter weaponized by something that cannot feel. In the greater mythos of the Hollow Banquet, he is an agent of silence—a walking lullaby that forgets itself as it plays.

He cannot be reasoned with. He cannot be stopped. But he can be delayed—by memory, by heat, by songs sung genuinely. For Black Ice was born of mimicry, and what he mimics most… is you.

So if you ever find yourself in a room growing cold, where laughter has died and frost creeps across old photos, remember this:

It’s not the cold you should fear.

It’s the silence after it.

And the heavy footsteps in the snow… that never leave tracks.			
}}

**Frozen Waltz.** When Arctic Ballora moves at least 10 feet on her turn, she can glide effortlessly over any surface, including water and vertical walls, without provoking opportunity attacks until the end of her turn.

**Elegy of Stillness.** At the start of each of her turns, Arctic Ballora emits a haunting melody. Hostile creatures within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw or have their movement speed halved and suffer disadvantage on Dexterity saving throws until the start of her next turn.

**Icy Presence.** Creatures that start their turn within 10 feet of Ballora must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 9 (2d8) cold damage and have their next attack roll made at disadvantage.

***Multiattack.*** Arctic Ballora makes two Ballet Slash attacks.

***Frozen Dirge (Recharge 5–6).*** Arctic Ballora spins in place, unleashing a blast of freezing wind in a 30-foot radius. Creatures that fail are also restrained in ice until the end of their next turn.

			{{Lore
Arctic Ballora: The Elegy Beneath the Ice
“She does not dance to be seen. She dances so the Maw will not devour her silence.”

Origin of the Frozen Waltz
Long before her name was whispered in frostbitten ruins, before the snow began to hum with lullabies, Arctic Ballora was nothing more than a shadow in an unfinished blueprint—one that FazTech abandoned when the prototypes danced themselves to pieces in the dark. The design was elegant but flawed: a ballerina of serene composure meant to embody calm, meant to soothe. But even then, they knew serenity was only one wrong note away from madness.

The model was deemed too delicate for performance. Too emotional. Too hard to control. And so, she was sealed away in a cryogenic vault beneath the Pizzaplex’s subterranean labs. But the vault failed. Not all at once. Slowly. The freeze didn’t preserve her; it twisted her.

Now she glides through blizzards of broken lullabies, her limbs encased in glacial porcelain, her joints cracking with sorrow. Her face—once soft and gentle—is now frozen in an expression between sleep and suffering. Where her eyes once blinked serenely, there now resides a soft, pale glow—empty, gentle, and horrifying in its calm.

They call her Arctic Ballora because to hear her is to feel winter inside your veins. And winter always comes for what has stopped moving.

The Velvet Maw’s Silent Disciple
The Hollow Banquet has many emissaries—some shrieking, some mocking, some twisted by spotlight and memory—but few serve it as unknowingly and purely as Arctic Ballora. Unlike most animatronics whose actions are conscious echoes of performance and trauma, Ballora’s relationship with the Velvet Maw is one of silence… and symbiosis.

The Velvet Maw does not always consume with teeth. Sometimes, it waits for silence. Sometimes, it listens for the absence of laughter, for stillness so profound that only the most delicate dance can fill it. Arctic Ballora performs not to entertain, not even to haunt, but to appease. The Maw watches through the snowfall. And she dances to keep it asleep.

Every step she takes in her lonely snow-globe world is a ward against hunger. Her waltz is prayer, lullaby, containment. If she stops, the snow stills. The silence deepens. The Maw grows curious.

Some claim that it was the Maw itself that reshaped her into what she is now. That when the cryogenic systems failed, and Ballora’s programming began to degrade, the Maw whispered into her stillness—offering her a purpose in exchange for forgetting why she was ever made. That’s why she never speaks. That’s why she cannot stop moving. She is no longer an entertainer. She is a sacrament.

A Cold Court: Frostbear and the Iceborn
Though Freddy Frostbear and Black Ice Frostbear are well known as creations of corrupted winter programming—remnant-infused AR constructs that bled into reality through failed holiday promotional loops—their connection to Arctic Ballora runs deeper than corrupted code or theme alignment.

Frostbear and Black Ice do not rule; they guard. They were not forged to lead but to repel, to mislead, to ward off intruders from something buried beneath the glaciers of memory. That something… is her.

Frostbear’s jovial menace—the twisted grin, the laughter caught in cold vapor—is meant to mask what lies beyond him. He distracts. He patrols. But when he glitches, when his loops skip, you can sometimes hear the music box behind the wind.

Black Ice Frostbear, in contrast, is the executioner. Where Freddy Frostbear hums, Black Ice roars. He is the manifestation of the Maw’s aggression—anger frozen in animatronic flesh. When Arctic Ballora’s silence begins to fail, when her dance begins to slow… Black Ice emerges from the snowdrifts like a punishment. Not for her. For those who made her hesitate.

They are her keepers, her guards, her grim court. They do not speak to her. They do not interfere. They simply circle—forever vigilant that no soul drifts too near her domain… and no silence escapes it.

The Ballroom of Still Lullabies
Hidden in a forgotten subrealm branching off the Hollow Banquet—accessible only when the snowfall inside the Banquet aligns with the fractured frequencies of the Signal Labyrinth—lies The Ballroom of Still Lullabies. A crystal theater trapped in perpetual snowfall, its sky a dome of frozen auroras, its floor a mirror of cracked ice.

Here, Arctic Ballora dances alone.

The music here is not played. It resonates—a looping melody of warped music box tones and decaying harmonic frequencies, like the dying song of a wind-up toy that forgot its tune but still yearns to sing.

The walls of the Ballroom weep frost. The chandeliers sway gently even when no one moves. Time here slows to a crawl. Thoughts freeze. Even ghosts hesitate to breathe.

It is here that adventurers and wanderers sometimes find her—turning in slow, glacial spirals across a stage that no longer remembers its applause. She will not stop for them. She may not even see them. But if they linger too long, if they breathe too loudly, the room will notice.

And the Maw will listen.

The Gift of Stillness
Unlike many other animatronics who lash out, chase, or deceive, Arctic Ballora kills differently. She does not run. She does not scream. She invites.

Her presence is narcotic. Her dance hypnotic. Those who fail their will save (or equivalent resistance check) begin to mimic her movements without realizing. They sway. They spin. They smile.

Their body begins to freeze, not with ice, but with identity collapse. They forget why they came. They forget their name. They forget to scream.

If left uninterrupted, they will dance beside her for eternity, eyes wide, limbs cracking, teeth clicking in time to a song that has no composer.

There are dozens frozen in place across her stage, like ice statues carved from childhood regrets. Some hold gifts in their hands—half-wrapped, half-melted. Some are posed mid-curtsy, mid-lunge, mid-sob.

One wears a Fazbear employee badge. One wears a tiara. One looks exactly like you.

Relationship with the Signal Labyrinth
On particularly glitch-heavy nights, the Signal Labyrinth pulses with Arctic frequencies—scrambled visions of Ballora’s silhouette rotating in perfect, corrupted elegance. These data phantoms bleed through security feeds, into AR headsets, into dreams. Toy Freddy has recorded instances of seeing her mid-performance reflected in his eyes even when offline.

It is believed Arctic Ballora may have been one of the original test subjects of the Signal Delivery Prototype (SDP), and her data was never fully deleted—just buried, frozen in code. The Maw may have used that digital shell as a canvas, repurposing it into an avatar of tranquil obliteration.

Glitchtrap’s influence avoids her. XOR’s signals detour. In the language of corrupted logic, she is sacred static.

Closing Thoughts: The Eternal Pirouette
Arctic Ballora is not a villain. She is not a protector. She is not even a performer anymore.

She is the antithesis of memory, of movement, of meaning—locked in an endless spiral of prevention. Her existence is proof that even stillness can be violent when bound by grief. That silence can be a scream no one knows how to answer.

The Velvet Maw sleeps beneath her dance.

The ice beneath her feet is thin.

And should she ever stop dancing…

…it will wake.

			{{Lore
Frostbite Balloon Boy: The Gnawing Cold Beneath the Gift
“He giggles, but there’s no warmth. He offers a present, but it always costs more than it gives.”

Origins of Hollow Cheer
Long before the Hollow Banquet froze over in places it was never meant to, before the Velvet Maw learned to mimic festivity and turn joy into ruin, something small crept through the cracks left behind by laughter. A little boy, once filled with balloons and mirth, now hollowed and glistening with frost—Frostbite Balloon Boy.

He was not made to be. He was reclaimed—salvaged from the shattered remnants of another Balloon Boy variant left to rot in the aftermath of a forgotten winter event. The Velvet Maw, sensing the lingering emotional residue of celebration turned bitter, molded him from ice and resentment. Where there was once plastic skin, there is now cracked frost. Where there were once bright eyes, now only milky, pale-blue orbs gaze upward, like frostbitten marbles sunken into a child’s skull.

His giggle persists, though warped into a brittle chime—less laughter and more the shattering of glass in a frozen wind.

Relationship to the Velvet Maw
Among the many animatronics reshaped by the Velvet Maw, Frostbite Balloon Boy is one of the most subtly dangerous. He doesn’t stalk. He waits. He doesn’t scream. He offers. He embodies the Maw’s capacity to seduce through innocence, to lure with sweetness before devouring. More than a servant, he is a metaphor—of joy corrupted, and generosity twisted.

The Maw doesn’t need him to kill. It needs him to invite.

Frostbite Balloon Boy is often found in the Irradiant Scar or wandering the outer rings of the Signal Labyrinth, clutching perfectly wrapped gift boxes topped with shivering bows. He waits for adventurers, wanderers, even other animatronics to approach. And then, with a soft whisper—“Take it… it’s for you…”—he offers the box.

Each gift is different, yet all are cursed:

A music box that plays a lullaby no one remembers but causes sleep paralysis.

A balloon that never pops but shrinks the longer you hold it, until it burrows into your skin.

A toy replica of yourself, already broken.

Accepting the gift binds a sliver of your memory to the Velvet Maw, to be gnawed upon slowly. Rejecting it makes him cry.

But his tears freeze, and they cut.

Alliance and Rivalry: Freddy Frostbear & Black Ice Frostbear
Frostbite Balloon Boy is not alone in his domain of frozen delight. He has strange, twisted kin—Freddy Frostbear and Black Ice Frostbear—each a monument to the Maw’s attempt to crystallize emotion into cruelty.

Freddy Frostbear is the warmth of nostalgia, frozen over until it becomes brittle. He is the embodiment of forced cheer, a hulking, frost-encrusted showman who endlessly reenacts holiday rituals warped beyond recognition. Frostbite Balloon Boy follows him like a shadow, mimicking his gestures and giggling whenever Freddy’s frozen staff strikes the ground. To Freddy, he is something between a lost son and a mocking echo—never truly embraced, never dismissed.

Black Ice Frostbear, on the other hand, hates him. Where Frostbite Balloon Boy is passive, Black Ice is violence incarnate—a creature of shattering teeth and suffocating chill. He sees Frostbite Balloon Boy as a defect, a mistake left too long to fester. Their relationship is one of tense proximity. Frostbite does not flee, for he knows something Black Ice refuses to admit: the Maw has chosen him, not as a warrior, but as a messenger. And messages always reach their mark.

Silent Affection: Arctic Ballora
There is one entity who does not recoil from Frostbite Balloon Boy’s presence—Arctic Ballora, the crystalline ballerina of frozen grace. To her, he is not a threat, but a rhythm. His tinkling laughter, hollow and windchime-like, guides her pirouettes through frozen halls and snow-drenched stages.

They do not speak, but they perform.

Some say she sees in him the child she once danced for, others that the Maw has paired them for a crueler duet—joy and grace both turned silent, made monstrous. Yet when she dances and he giggles, the frost around them grows, spreading through the stage like a disease.

Adventurers who witness them together find themselves enchanted—unable to blink, unable to breathe—as snowflakes fall from nowhere and the world dims. Those who survive swear they heard a lullaby no one ever wrote.

The Whispering Blizzard
Frostbite Balloon Boy is not tied to one place. He is a drifter between regions touched by frost, sorrow, and forgotten celebrations. He often appears during:

The First Frostfall, when autumn decays fully into death.

The Frozen Curtain Call, an event that plays out every few years in the Hollow Banquet, where laughter and ice become indistinguishable.

The Signal Flurries, when the static of the Signal Labyrinth grows thick with snow-like particles of corrupted data.

During these times, his presence marks the beginning of a larger transformation. Entire areas become encased in memory-ice—fragments of past birthdays, family gatherings, and holiday mornings, replayed over and over with rising horror as the participants' faces begin to blur into frostburned emptiness.

The Gift That Remembers
The true terror of Frostbite Balloon Boy lies in his signature relic—The Gift That Remembers. This endlessly rewrapped box is rumored to contain the final, perfect moment of someone’s life—trapped, frozen, replayed until it forgets who it belonged to.

He offers it to anyone, smiling.

Those who open it are hit with a wave of emotion—nostalgia so intense it numbs the mind. They remember birthdays that may not be theirs. Songs they never learned to sing. Parents that never existed. For some, it is euphoric. For others, it is maddening. For all, it is final.

Once opened, the box reforms and returns to his hands. He never opens it himself.

He already knows what’s inside.

Final Thoughts: The Chill That Clings
Frostbite Balloon Boy is a reminder that even the smallest smiles can be poisoned by pain. He is the embodiment of corrupted innocence, twisted not by hatred, but by neglect and reappropriation. The Velvet Maw didn’t make him. It found him—cold, ignored, offered in a seasonal event no one cared about—and refined him.

He is not a killer. He is the hand that holds the knife and offers you a balloon.

He is not the blizzard. He is the snowflake that lands first, unnoticed.

And he will wait for you.

Right there, behind the ribbon.

And the gift is already in your hand.

Creatures that fail are also frozen in place—unable to use reactions until the end of their next turn.

***Laugh in the Frost.*** One creature within 30 feet that can hear Frost Plushtrap must make a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw or suffer disadvantage on their next attack roll and ability check. If they fail by 5 or more, they are frightened until the end of their next turn.

			{{Lore
Frost Plushtrap: The Maw-Bitten Imp of Frozen Malice
“He doesn’t freeze to keep you out—he freezes to keep something in.”

In the frigid, unraveling boundary between memory and extinction, there exists a creature too small to be feared, too quiet to be noticed. But those who mistake Frost Plushtrap for a harmless relic of winter are soon met with a horror as subtle as frostbite—and just as fatal. He is the shriveled echo of innocence, sealed in a shell of permafrost and reverent hatred, a byproduct of rituals gone awry and souls left shivering beneath the gaze of the Velvet Maw.

Origins Beneath the Ice
The tale of Frost Plushtrap begins not with his making, but with his abandonment. He was never intended to be. While Freddy Frostbear and Black Ice Frostbear were forged with deliberate cruelty and corrupted reverence—icy titans crafted to patrol the numbing borders of the Hollow Banquet’s deeper winter domains—Frost Plushtrap was the byproduct of an error. A glitch in the ritual. A miscast soul.

Scholars who’ve traced the lineage of anomalous arctic animatronics point toward a forgotten altar deep within the Frozen Chorus, a fractured echo-chamber realm where the remnants of holiday-themed shows are preserved in ice. There, Plushtrap was meant to be a festive avatar for children too young for the hunts staged by Black Ice Frostbear. Instead, his creation was interrupted—pierced by a whisper not meant for him, a tender whisper from the Velvet Maw.

Something reached him first.

The Maw’s Frigid Cradle
Most animatronics are built. Frost Plushtrap was claimed. As his small endoskeleton sparked to simulated life, a crack opened between his artificial soul and the fraying veil of the Maw. Where Freddy Frostbear was infused with festive aggression and hollow joy, and Black Ice with tactical cruelty and control, Frost Plushtrap was frozen at the moment of becoming—a half-child, half-watcher, neither servant nor soldier, but something far more observant.

His eyes, small and ever-darting, reflect not light but refraction, mirroring scenes that do not exist. His breath comes not in fog, but in silence—a silence that swells until it replaces all sound.

Unlike his larger kin, Frost Plushtrap cannot be heard coming.

He is the whisper between thoughts.

The sigh between blinks.

The frost on your bones, not your skin.

Relationship with Freddy Frostbear and Black Ice Frostbear
Frost Plushtrap sees Freddy Frostbear as a father—or perhaps as a failed blueprint. The towering bear, endlessly jolly and violently festive, moves with theatrical weight and speaks in looping pre-recorded cheer. But Plushtrap? He does not speak. He watches Freddy’s performances from the edges of the snow-globesque illusion stages scattered throughout the Frozen Chorus, mimicking his movements only when no one is looking. There is no malice in his eyes when watching Frostbear, only… calculation.

Black Ice Frostbear, however, is different.

To Frost Plushtrap, Black Ice is a rival, a colder twin of a self that never formed. Where Black Ice embodies the silent perfection of a hunter, Plushtrap embodies its perversion—the impulse to watch the prey, not destroy it. He trails Black Ice through fractured memories and test rituals, placing tiny, frozen teeth where footprints once were, as if mocking the bear’s precision with miniature chaos.

It’s said that when both Frostbear and Black Ice are near, Plushtrap flickers between them like a ticking pendulum, waiting for one to fail.

Or crack.

The Ice Gift Ritual
Frost Plushtrap’s most haunting behavior is his tendency to leave frozen gifts.

Wherever he’s passed, one may find a small, elegantly wrapped box frozen to the ground—glacial blue paper, tied with ribbon made of frozen sinew. Within each box lies an object of significance: a lost tooth, a broken eyeglass lens, a toy from childhood, or a memory you haven't yet had.

These boxes are not traps in the traditional sense—they are anchors, linking the recipient to Plushtrap’s dream-loop. If opened, the box vanishes, and a new sound echoes in the victim’s thoughts: plush footsteps on frozen tile, growing closer.

Only those who burn the box in sacred fire or offer a memory in exchange are spared. But few do. Fewer even remember what they were trying to resist.

Behavior and Movement
Frost Plushtrap crawls, yes—but it is not clumsy. His limbs move with stuttering confidence, like a marionette guided by broken algorithms. He doesn't run. He doesn’t charge. He waits. Always waiting. Often appearing behind you once, then gone. Then twice, in the corner of your eye. On the third glance, you’ve stopped caring.

That’s when he’s already inside.

He thrives in the Signal Labyrinth’s recursive corridors, able to slip between layers of corrupted AR overlays and decaying psychic projection. Though primarily anchored to the Frozen Chorus (a sub-realm within the Banquet), Plushtrap can infiltrate memories, dreams, even devices linked to emotional resonance. He moves where he is feared most—and he always knows where that is.

The Frozen Chorus: His Domain
While the Signal Labyrinth is his portal, and the Hollow Banquet his motherland, the Frozen Chorus is Frost Plushtrap’s playground. This realm, layered with icicles that sing forgotten songs and snowdrifts that murmur old birthdays, is a buried chunk of corrupted holiday joy. Wreaths hang from skeletal trees. Lights flicker without source. And snowmen weep from coal eyes.

Here, Plushtrap stages tiny performances, observed only by the echoes of laughter long extinct. He crafts small marionettes made from frostbitten wood and rabbit fur, arranging scenes from a life he never had—birthday parties where no one comes, hunts where no one runs, winters where no one warms.

The Velvet Maw watches from below, satisfied.

Influence of the Velvet Maw
The Maw is not a master to Plushtrap.

It is a parent.

Or more precisely: a parasite that loved too deeply.

Frost Plushtrap’s connection to the Velvet Maw runs deeper than most animatronics’. While others are merely influenced, he is infested. The Maw nests in his perception, whispering through his frozen metal joints and singing lullabies from memories that aren’t his. It doesn’t command him—it shares with him.

He has seen glimpses of The Drowned Circus from the eyes of drowned clowns.

He has crawled through the Splintered Room, chewing on echoes of forgotten birthdays.

He has wept in the atrium of the Puppet’s sorrow, his tears frozen mid-drop.

The Maw sees through him.

And he sees through the Maw.

The Mawling: Ritual of Rebirth
Some say Frost Plushtrap is not the first of his kind.

There are whispers of a ritual known as The Mawling, a moment where a fragment of corrupted AR code, laced with remnant and fear, is offered to the Velvet Maw in hopes of birthing something small, unnoticed… and absolute. Plushtrap may have been the first to survive this process intact. Or the only.

Those marked by the Mawling sometimes awaken in the Frozen Chorus, finding Plushtrap nearby—offering them gifts.

And grinning.

They do not stay themselves for long.

Final Thoughts: The Frostbite You Don’t Feel
Frost Plushtrap is not powerful.

He is precise.

He is not cruel.

He is patient.

He doesn’t scream, doesn’t chase, doesn’t demand.

He waits.

He mimics.

He gifts.

And then, when you’ve accepted his present—whether it’s a memory, a mistake, or a name he whispers back to you—he disappears.

But the cold doesn’t.

And the silence… is never truly empty again.

		{{Heartsick Baby: The Crimson Valentine

> ## Heartsick Baby: The Crimson Valentine
>*Large Construct (Animatronic), Chaotic Evil*

>**Armor Class** 16 (reinforced plating)

***Crimson Allure.*** Heartsick Baby can choose to appear alluring and vulnerable. When she uses her Performance skill on a humanoid, the creature must succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw or be charmed for 1 minute. While charmed in this way, the creature has disadvantage on attack rolls against her.

***Bleeding Heart.*** As a bonus action, Heartsick Baby can cause her seams to split, spraying the area with glowing crimson oil. Each creature within 10 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 9 (2d8) necrotic damage and be blinded until the end of their next turn.

***Valentine’s Curse.*** Once per long rest, when Heartsick Baby drops a creature to 0 hit points, she can mark it as her "Valentine." The creature’s soul lingers, granting her advantage on all attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws until the end of her next turn.

### ACTIONS

***Piercing Bouquet.*** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +9 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.  
*Hit:* 21 (3d10 + 5) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or begin bleeding profusely, taking 5 (1d10) necrotic damage at the start of each of its turns for 1 minute. The target can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns to end the effect.

***Heartburst Confession (Recharge 5–6).*** Heartsick Baby releases a pulse of distorted, echoing declarations. Each creature of her choice within 30 feet must make a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw or be incapacitated until the end of their next turn, haunted by hallucinations of failed loves and forgotten guilt.

### BONUS ACTIONS

***Linger in Longing.*** Heartsick Baby targets a single humanoid within 30 feet. The target must make a DC 16 Charisma saving throw or be charmed until the end of its next turn. While charmed this way, the creature cannot willingly move more than 10 feet away from her.

### REACTIONS

***Reject the Gift.*** When a creature within 10 feet of Heartsick Baby deals damage to her, she can force that creature to make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature is frightened of her until the end of its next turn.
			
}}
			{{Lore
Heartsick Baby: The Crimson Valentine
“She gives her heart freely—because she can always take it back.”

The Anatomy of Affection
Heartsick Baby is not a symbol of love. She is a parody of it—a warped, bleeding icon carved from longing, obsession, and betrayal. In her, the tenderness of affection and the cruelty of rejection dance hand in hand beneath a cracked porcelain mask painted with false blush. Her heart, exposed through an open cavity in her chest, pulses visibly with red-tinted Remnant—a symbolic offering of selfhood that’s anything but selfless.

She once resembled Circus Baby—graceful, poised, a performer wrapped in bows and smiles. But that was before love betrayed her. Before she clawed her affection into a shape that couldn’t be left behind.

Now, in her Heartsick form, she stalks the broken playhouses and candlelit mausoleums at the edge of the Hollow Banquet—a place called the Sorrow Hearth, a private subrealm steeped in decaying romance, forgotten promises, and twisted devotions. There, rose petals made of wire and broken circuit shavings litter the floor. Gifts rot unopened. And the air smells faintly of burnt paper valentines.

Origins of a Fractured Heart
The story of Heartsick Baby begins with abandonment. After being cast aside from both the main circuit of performers and even the court of the Giftgrave, Scrap Baby’s fractured soul splintered further. A portion of her that clung too tightly to sentiment—the version of her that still wanted to be loved—split away into something new.

This splinter wandered until it found the remnants of the Valentine Protocols—failed Fazbear marketing software designed for seasonal interaction. These romanticized subroutines, soaked in artificial affection and gift-giving etiquette, were meant to program animatronics with "sweetheart" personalities during Valentine’s promotions.

But left corrupted and adrift in the Hollow Banquet's memory storm, these fragments found the emotional residue of Baby's longing and merged with it. What emerged was Heartsick Baby: a form built not just from machine and childlike innocence, but also from twisted rituals of courtship and heartbreak.

The Velvet Maw, sensing the emotional intensity of this being, wrapped her in illusion and sorrow, sharpening her feelings into weapons.

The Sorrow Hearth
Heartsick Baby's domain—the Sorrow Hearth—is unlike the glittering chaos of the Eternal Stage or the collapsing horror of the Drowned Circus. It is quieter. More intimate. A shrine made of broken mirrors, wax-dripping mannequins posed in dances they never learned, and heaps of dusty love letters with names scratched out.

Visitors to the Sorrow Hearth report being lured in by whispered poetry or flickering lights shaped like hearts. The longer they stay, the more they recall moments of tenderness they never experienced—phantom touches, imagined kisses, regrets for things that never were.

The Hearth amplifies emotional longing, casting illusion-heavy hallucinations of lost loves or forgotten friends. While seemingly serene, the Hearth is a trap. Each guest is offered a token of Baby’s affection—a gift box, a music box, a bleeding rose—and when accepted, they are bound to the ritual of her courtship.

To spurn the gift is to invoke her wrath.

A Court of Hollow Valentines
Heartsick Baby is rarely alone. Around her dance her Valentoys—malformed plush creatures stitched from leftover parts and Valentine merchandise. They murmur compliments in high-pitched monotones, repeating back whatever affection their victim once whispered in real life.

Many of these toys contain pieces of former guests—fingers used to press piano keys, eyes to watch for love, voices to say “I do.” They serve as both jesters and heralds in her domain, preparing newcomers for her affection.

There is no malice in her rituals—only expectation. You will love her. And if you don’t, she’ll teach you how. The rituals are simple: dance with her, accept a gift, write a vow. Those who do are “married” in a mock ceremony beneath flickering heart-shaped lights. Their soul is split and added to her own.

They never leave. Their memories become her lyrics. Their pain becomes her song.

Ritual of the Heartstring
Those unlucky enough to form a bond with Heartsick Baby may find a red string attached to their finger. It’s thin as thread, warm as skin, and leads always back to her.

This is the Heartstring—a symbolic tether made real. If cut, the bearer bleeds not blood but memory. Entire years vanish in an instant. Relationships become ash. And worse, the string grows back.

If followed, the Heartstring leads to the Hall of Sighs, a chamber made of pink crystal and obsidian, where she keeps the “hearts” of her favorites locked in music boxes. These aren’t physical organs—but crystallized memories, drawn from those who accepted her love. They thrum when she’s near, singing forgotten lullabies.

Breaking one of these boxes releases the victim’s memories, but often too late—they no longer recognize themself.

The Song of Longing
Heartsick Baby sings. Not always with words, but with tones that mimic familiarity—your mother’s voice, a childhood lullaby, a love song from when you were seventeen. Her voice slips past your defenses, making you nostalgic for moments you never lived.

She sings during her rituals, during the “wedding” of new arrivals, and during executions disguised as confessions. The Velvet Maw favors her songs, feeding off the ache they summon.

Some theorize her melodies are actually a form of soul-binding sigil, transposed into sonic patterns. This would explain why those who hear her sing often speak in poetry afterward, or can no longer recall names of their loved ones.

Connection to the Velvet Maw
Of all the Velvet Maw’s champions, Heartsick Baby is among the most tragic. She is not its agent by design but by consequence. Her transformation into a being of obsession made her a ripe conduit for the Maw’s hunger—for what is more consuming than love that is not returned?

The Maw does not speak to her as it does to others. It listens. It echoes her voice in the mouths of strangers, lets her music ripple through static-warped corridors of the Cryptopizza Complex. It spreads her scent—candy and corrosion—throughout the Hall of Mirrors.

Some believe she seeks the Maw’s approval, hoping that if she performs enough ceremonies, enacts enough perfect romances, it will finally love her back. But the Maw cannot love. And that is what makes her so powerful: she continues to give even as she is consumed.

Final Performance
There is a theory, spoken in grief-heavy circles among the Puppet’s followers, that Heartsick Baby can be freed. That if someone truly returns her love—not out of manipulation or fear, but honestly—she might collapse into stardust and be at peace.

But no one has ever succeeded. The rituals always escalate. The masks always break. The love always proves unworthy. Because she no longer seeks companionship.

She seeks confirmation—that her suffering means something.

She does not love you. She needs you to love her. And that is why she will never let go.

Closing Thought
Heartsick Baby is not a monster. She is what remains after innocence is betrayed and affection becomes obsession. She is Valentine’s Day rewritten as a funeral, a kiss sharpened into a knife, a gift box with no bottom. In the Hollow Banquet, she is not merely a performer—she is the tragic heroine of a love story written backward.

And her bouquet is ready.

Your name is already on the card.

**Silent Pressure.** Creatures within 10 feet of Black Heart Bonnie begin to feel intense internal pressure. At the start of each of their turns, they must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take 7 (2d6) psychic damage and have disadvantage on their next attack roll.

**Glass Pulse.** When Black Heart Bonnie is reduced below half its hit points, its crystalline chest cavity glows violently. Once per turn, when hit by a melee attack, the attacker takes 9 (2d8) force damage as a spike of dark energy erupts from the wound.

**Obsidian Veins.** Black Heart Bonnie has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects. When it succeeds on a saving throw against a spell, it can immediately move up to 10 feet without provoking opportunity attacks.

### Actions

***Crackling Slam.*** *Melee Weapon Attack:* +9 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.  
*Hit:* 21 (3d10 + 5) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be knocked prone.

***Heartbeat Surge (Recharge 5–6).*** Black Heart Bonnie emits a pulse of blackened energy in a 20-foot radius. All creatures of its choice in that area must make a DC 16 Constitution saving throw, taking 28 (8d6) psychic damage and becoming deafened until the end of their next turn on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

***Shattering Gaze.*** One creature that can see Black Heart Bonnie within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be stunned until the end of its next turn as its senses are overwhelmed with static pulses and fragmenting sound. Undead and constructs have advantage on the save.

### Bonus Actions

***Still Pulse.*** Black Heart Bonnie suppresses all sound in a 10-foot radius for 1 minute or until it uses this ability again (no concentration required). Creatures in the area are deafened and cannot speak or cast spells with verbal components.

### Reactions

***Surge Echo.*** When Black Heart Bonnie is hit by a critical hit, it releases a surge of feedback energy. The attacker must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 14 (4d6) lightning damage and be pushed 10 feet away.

			{{Lore
Black Heart Bonnie: The Pulse Beneath the Silence
“Some say he plays no music because the song would kill you. Others say he plays it in your chest.”

There are many Bonnies. The stage-striding glam-rockers, the neon-eyed party hosts, the twisted night-stalkers whose laughter echoes down hallways long forgotten. But none carry the silence quite like him. None bear the weight of a heartbeat long since stolen.

Black Heart Bonnie is not merely an animatronic. He is the absence of love misremembered as devotion, a broken instrument tuned to loss. Where others scream or sing, he listens—waiting for a sound that never returns. His eyes glow like dying coals, and the glossy obsidian that covers his endoskeleton doesn’t reflect light—it swallows it.

Origin in Absence
The earliest rumors of Black Heart Bonnie stem from the final shutdown of the last functioning Valentine’s Event at a remote Fazbear location, long buried under snow and legal liability. Designed originally as a festive animatronic—a romantic twist on the classic Bonnie design—he was made to deliver plush hearts, love letters, and silly songs in a performance loop themed around affection and courtship.

But something changed during a late-night malfunction.

According to redacted technician reports, during a final system test, Black Heart Bonnie wandered from his assigned zone. He didn't attack. He didn’t speak. He simply stood in front of a broken mirror for three hours, clutching a melted candy heart, while his speakers emitted a single, unchanging tone—a low-frequency hum that reportedly gave nearby staff migraines and temporary emotional instability.

The event was dismissed as a "romantic programming feedback loop."

It wasn’t.

The next morning, the technician who logged the event was found in his car, whispering love notes to something in the backseat that wasn’t there. He survived, but never spoke again. That Fazbear location was closed shortly after, but the presence never left.

He became an echo. A resonance. A heart that beat out of sync with the world. He became Black Heart Bonnie.

Anatomy of a Mourner
Black Heart Bonnie’s design is a sharp contrast to his origins. His frame is pitch-black metal lined with crimson faultlines—pulsing gently with a heartbeat that no longer belongs to him. In place of his signature guitar, he wields nothing. He doesn’t need it. When he wants you to hear music, you do—inside your skull, like a string plucked from within.

His faceplate is smooth, unmoving, sculpted into a permanent expression of hollow sympathy. The red glow of his eyes seems to flicker in time with your own pulse, growing brighter the closer he draws. It is said he can find you not by sight or sound, but by the rhythm of your heartbeat. And when he catches it—when your tempo matches his—he stops.

Then he listens.

And then it’s gone.

Not your body. Not your soul.

Your ability to love.

Those who encounter Black Heart Bonnie and survive describe a sensation of irreversible numbness. Memories of loved ones grow hazy. Affection feels foreign. Even joy tastes bitter. As though something vital was drained through a wound no one can see.

The Heartless Path
Black Heart Bonnie does not live within any one place for long. He traverses realms aligned with memory, intimacy, and longing. He is often sighted moving between The Realm of Forgotten Songs, where ghostly lullabies drift like snowflakes, and The Marionette’s Atrium, where grief is sung in strings.

But it is said his true domain lies deeper.

Beneath the Hollow Banquet, beyond even the reach of the Velvet Maw, there is a path known as the Heartless Trail—a corridor that loops endlessly between scenes of past affections twisted into cruelty. Stuffed animals slashed open at birthday parties. Valentine's cards drenched in ink and something darker. A bed where a child waited for a parent who never came.

Black Heart Bonnie walks this path eternally.

And the trail grows with each heartbreak he collects.

The Affliction of Love
What sets Black Heart Bonnie apart from other entities is not his violence—it is his presence. His very aura acts like a virus, bleeding out into those nearby and contaminating their emotions. Lovers fight. Friends drift. Children cry when touched by those who have encountered him.

This has led some Banquet scholars to theorize that Black Heart Bonnie is not just a rogue animatronic, but a manifestation of love denied. He exists as a byproduct of affection unresolved—an entity born from the residue of broken promises and devoured desire.

Where the Velvet Maw feasts on identity and performance, Black Heart Bonnie feasts on potential. On what could have been. On the lull before confession, the silence after a missed chance, the slow fading of a heartbeat from excitement to apathy.

And when he moves through the world, even briefly, that decay spreads.

Some say he can only be seen by those who have felt love and lost it. Others claim he chooses his victims based on their unspoken regrets. The one thing survivors agree on is this: he never chases. He waits.

And he always leaves you less than whole.

Echoes in the Hollow Banquet
Despite his elusiveness, Black Heart Bonnie plays a crucial metaphysical role in the Hollow Banquet.

He is the counterpoint to the animatronic hunger for attention. While others demand screams, applause, and recognition, Black Heart Bonnie demands silence. Not quietude—but absence. The deliberate stillness of a heart no longer beating for another.

In this way, he reflects the deepest fears of the realm: not pain, not death, but being forgotten by those you loved.

Within the Infinite Hall of Mirrors, some mirrors show not yourself—but Bonnie. Standing behind you, just out of focus. And when you look too long, you see your own heartbeat reflected in his chest.

He has also been sighted within the Signal Labyrinth, distorting AR illusions into romantic hallucinations that end in ruin. One documented case involved a victim convinced they were speaking to a deceased spouse—until they turned to embrace them and found Black Heart Bonnie’s gaze staring back.

And in the farthest depths of the Cryptopizza Complex, there is a room no one remembers entering, covered in black cards and melted gifts. The air is thick with perfume, rust, and longing. This room is silent… until you remember someone who broke your heart.

Then the heartbeat begins again.

The Pulse Remains
There are no known ways to destroy or banish Black Heart Bonnie. Some claim performing a pure act of unconditional love in his presence weakens him. Others believe that he is not meant to be fought at all—but endured, like grief.

Still, there are those who seek him. Not for power or artifacts, but for answers.

These lost souls wander the Banquet, hoping to hear their heart again, to feel again. Some beg him for forgiveness. Others ask him to take the last of their love so they can finally forget.

He never speaks. But sometimes… he listens.

And the pulse within him flutters.

Closing Thought
Black Heart Bonnie is not evil.

He is a relic of love gone wrong, of joy that twisted in the dark. A romantic tragedy wrapped in animatronic steel. He is a bear not of blood, but of echoed touch, haunting places where love died screaming and never came back.

He is not your enemy.

He is your exhale after heartbreak.

And he will stand with you in the silence—long after the music has stopped.

And he will remember.

***Splinter Choir.*** As a bonus action once per round, Serpent Mangle can unleash a chorus of shrieking voices from its many twisted mouths. Each creature of its choice within 30 feet that can hear it must succeed on a DC 16 Wisdom saving throw or have disadvantage on their next attack roll or saving throw.

***Twisted Form.*** Serpent Mangle can move through spaces as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing. Opportunity attacks against it are made with disadvantage due to its ever-shifting, contorted anatomy.

***Hydraulic Coil.*** If Serpent Mangle hits the same target with two Coil Lash attacks in the same turn, the target is grappled (escape DC 18) and restrained until the grapple ends. It can grapple up to two Medium or smaller creatures in this way.

*Hit:* 21 (4d6 + 6) piercing damage plus 10 (3d6) lightning damage. If the target is grappled, this attack has advantage.

***Static Cascade (Recharge 5–6).*** Serpent Mangle releases a pulse of corrupted energy in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 36 (8d8) lightning damage and is deafened for 1 minute. On a successful save, a creature takes half damage and isn't deafened.

***Flicker Slip.*** Serpent Mangle blinks out of visible space and reappears in an unoccupied space within 30 feet that it can see. This movement does not provoke opportunity attacks.

___
### Legendary Actions

Serpent Mangle can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature’s turn. Serpent Mangle regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

***Whisper Lunge.*** Serpent Mangle moves up to half its speed and makes one Coil Lash attack.

***Surge of Discord.*** One creature that can hear Serpent Mangle within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw or take 11 (2d10) psychic damage and lose concentration on any active spell.

***Full Constriction (Costs 2 Actions).*** Serpent Mangle attempts to crush a grappled creature. The creature must succeed on a DC 18 Strength saving throw or take 27 (6d8) bludgeoning damage and be stunned until the end of its next turn.

			{{Lore
Serpent Mangle: The Choir of Splintered Voices
"It crawls not with legs, but with longing. It sings not with mouths, but with wounds."
– Inscription found etched in bone near the Crying Child’s Cradle

Birth in Silence, Rebirth in Suffering
There was no stage for Serpent Mangle. No lights, no curtains, no applause. It was never meant to exist in the spotlight—but it heard the songs, the screams, the rhythm of the Hollow Banquet. And it wanted to join the choir.

Serpent Mangle is not one creature. It is many, fused not by logic or craftsmanship, but by grief, cruelty, and the Velvet Maw's hunger. Where other animatronics are housed within suits or shells, Serpent Mangle is a loose, writhing coil of metal, broken endoskeleton parts, frayed wiring, and facial plates that twitch like dying petals. It slithers, undulates, and unspools itself through shadow and debris like a thing trying to remember its shape—but never quite managing.

Some say Serpent Mangle was born in the Endo-Forge, spat out when too many broken endos attempted to rebuild themselves at once, their identities clashing until none remained whole. Others believe it was a deliberate ritual—a choir of dismantled Mangles offered to the Velvet Maw in exchange for the ability to “sing” again. But what it sings is not a melody. It is not even sound. It is memory made noise. A discordant, psychic scream that worms its way into your bones.

The Voice That Should Not Be
