These artificial traumas sometimes fuse with the subject’s identity, warping them irrevocably. This is how new horrors are born. Animatronics who leave the stage do so with altered minds, changed purposes, and fractured memories. Some never leave. Others become new roles in future performances.

### The Black Masquerade
On rare occasions—usually heralded by a drop in temperature and the rising of black fog—the stage hosts an event known only as the Black Masquerade. Every entity bound to the Hollow Banquet feels its pull. Invitations manifest in their minds, accompanied by an urgent sense of dread.

During the Masquerade, all roles are reversed. Performers become audience, audience become performers. Masks shift between hands. The very fabric of the Velvet Maw is said to shudder during these events, as if reacting to the emotional surge generated by so many tragedies being acted out simultaneously.

The Masquerade is not a celebration. It is a reckoning. Those who attend uninvited are often trapped permanently in looping performances, their minds overwritten by roles they never auditioned for.

### The Stage’s Will
The Eternal Stage is not sentient in a conventional sense, but it responds. It is a construct of the Velvet Maw, an anchor point where identity, performance, and reality collide. It has absorbed so many stories, so many failures, that it has developed a directional pull—a tendency to summon those whose stories remain unfinished.

Some suspect the Stage is preparing something: a final performance, a Grand Act where all animatronics are summoned at once to relive their collective tragedy. A closing of the curtain not just for the Banquet, but for existence as they know it.

If that is true, then every loop, every reenactment, every silent sob on that bloodstained stage is simply a rehearsal. And the Hollow Banquet, as a whole, is merely the auditorium.

### Conclusion: Where Theater Becomes Truth
The Eternal Stage is many things. A punishment. A ritual. A memory. A mirror. A throne room. A death sentence. A rebirth. It is a place where the mask cannot be removed, because the mask is the face. Where guilt becomes choreography. Where grief is applause. Where performers, willingly or not, bleed their stories into the boards.

And when the curtain falls?

It always rises again.

Because on the Eternal Stage, the show must go on.
}}
	{{The Marionette’s Atrium
## The Marionette’s Atrium
“Grief does not die—it lingers. And here, it sings lullabies made of strings.”

Hidden between time-frozen hallways and the mirrored thresholds of the Hollow Banquet lies a place not of violence, but of sorrow—a quiet, dimly lit chamber where loss hums through the walls and memory clings like cobwebs. Known to few and reached by fewer, this place is called The Marionette’s Atrium, a sanctuary suspended at the crossroads of rest and unrest.

It is here that The Puppet, once a guardian of innocent souls, fractured into silence. Her grief is carved into every wall. Her touch lingers in every toy. Her spirit weaves between shadows, unseen but always felt.

### Architecture of Mourning
The Atrium appears as a vast domed chamber, dimly lit by glass lanterns swaying from near-invisible strings. The architecture is childlike in scale, yet aged beyond reckoning. Cracked marionette stages line the walls like ancient altars. Every column is strung with broken strings, each strand vibrating with memories that never passed on.

Beneath the delicate beauty lies a deeper unease: nothing here stays still for long. Puppets on shelves occasionally shift positions. Stuffed toys whisper in languages only children understand. Music boxes play lullabies without being wound. And somewhere, always somewhere, a quiet sobbing can be heard—sometimes from the walls, sometimes from yourself.

There is no clear entrance or exit to the Atrium. It can only be reached when the line between waking and dreaming frays, or when one wanders too deep into forgotten corridors seeking solace—or forgiveness.

### A Home for the Forgotten
The Marionette’s Atrium serves a grim yet sacred purpose. It is a shelter for lost souls who no longer remember what it means to be whole. Here reside the Toys That Remember Being Children—twisted plush things with the voices of the innocent, their forms distorted by time, sorrow, or unfinished transformation. They speak in broken lullabies, their threads unraveling as they cling to whatever memory anchors them to existence.

Some of these toys were once children—victims of the original tragedies that birthed the animatronic curse. Others are fragmentary constructs, created when grief could not resolve itself. They do not seek vengeance. They seek acknowledgment. They yearn to be seen, even if only as shadows of what they once were.

The Puppet, or what remains of her essence, acts as their silent caretaker. She is rarely seen in her entirety. Her presence is felt as a cool breeze, a tilt of a stage prop, a twitch in the corner of one’s vision. But when she does appear, it is always with a bowed head and outstretched hands, as though cradling something that was lost long ago.

### The Crossroads of Rest and Unrest
What gives the Atrium its strange metaphysical potency is its location—it exists precisely at the boundary where spirits either pass on or stay behind. This makes it a convergence point for unresolved memories, suppressed guilt, and fragmented identities. The Atrium is neither a prison nor a haven, but a limbo—a place where decisions must be made.

Some adventurers, animatronics, or specters arrive here unknowingly, drawn by unprocessed sorrow. Many weep here without understanding why. The very air seems soaked in remembrance, forcing visitors to confront not only their pain, but the pain they’ve caused. It is a place of mourning—but also of impossible mercy.

However, not all who linger here seek redemption. Some come to consume the grief of others. Entities born from corrupted strings—Remnant Leeches, Tearstained Masks, or even echoes of XOR’s fractured signals—sometimes slither into the Atrium, feeding off the psychic residue. The Puppet wages a quiet, eternal battle against these infiltrators, severing strings and sealing whispers.

### Strings That Still Twitch
Perhaps the most disturbing aspect of the Atrium is its omnipresent strings.

They dangle from ceilings, wind around altars, and sometimes slither across the floor like serpents. These strings are not mechanical constructs but living manifestations of The Puppet’s unresolved power. They resonate with grief and memory, reacting to the presence of the living—and sometimes the dead.

They can tether a soul to the world or tear it free. Some have used these strings to call back loved ones from beyond the veil. Others have been bound by them, forced to relive the worst moment of their lives in silent pantomime.

On certain nights, the strings move on their own. They stage mock performances with toys and props, acting out scenes no one remembers writing. It is believed these are memories too fragmented to attach to any one soul—lost moments looking for a host.

###  Fragmentations of The Puppet
The Marionette’s Atrium is also haunted by the fragments of its namesake. The Puppet, once a singular spirit of protection and grief, has splintered across time and narrative. Some pieces of her linger here as autonomous shadows. These are known as the Silent Fragments—empty-eyed masks that drift through the atrium’s halls like broken thoughts.

Each Fragment retains a portion of her consciousness—one sobs silently in a locked toy chest, another paints sorrowful faces onto cracked dolls, and one simply rocks in a chair, forever cradling nothing. Some believe reuniting these fragments would restore the Puppet’s full power. Others warn that doing so may awaken something much older than grief.

These Fragments are not hostile—but they test the resolve of any who approach. They whisper secrets. They demand memories. And sometimes… they offer peace.

\pagebreakNum

### A Place That Remembers You
The final, cruel truth of the Atrium is this: once you’ve entered it, it never forgets you. Whether you stay an hour or a century, it remembers your fears, your regrets, your hidden griefs. And if you return, it will recreate them for you in increasingly vivid ways.

For the animatronics bound to the Hollow Banquet, this is where they come to feel. Many cannot cry, but they can still mourn. Even entities like Nightmare Fredbear or Glitchtrap have, in moments of unexpected vulnerability, been seen standing silently at the Atrium’s threshold, their presence unchallenged.

Because even monsters remember being children.

### Conclusion: Sanctuary, or Snare?
The Marionette’s Atrium is a sacred place—not in holiness, but in weight. It is where grief is not only stored, but nurtured, explored, and sometimes healed. But it is also where sorrow takes shape, gains voice, and occasionally takes on a life of its own.

If the Eternal Stage is the theater of memory, the Marionette’s Atrium is its heart. A place where strings remember the warmth of hands, and toys remember names long since lost. It is a place of truth, no matter how painful.

And in its silence, the Puppet waits—not to protect, but to remember.
So that the forgotten may never be alone again.

\pagebreakNum

# Relics of Remnant and Ruin: An Introduction to the Artifacts
In the twisted world born of corrupted memories and haunted circuitry, power lingers not only in the monsters that roam the shadows, but in the remnants they leave behind. These are not simple tools or discarded curios—they are echoes of grief, rage, and forgotten purpose. Each artifact in this realm is a fracture in reality, a memory bound in form, pulsing with the essence of those who suffered… or made others suffer.

Forged from nightmare logic, stitched with static and sorrow, these artifacts drift through the Hollow Banquet, the Velvet Maw, the Drowned Circus, and the derelict depths of the Cryptopizza Complex. Some fell from the Eternal Stage during failed rituals; others were vomited forth by Tangle’s labyrinthine guts or sealed away in the Marionette’s Atrium where toys twitch with half-remembered dreams. All are dangerous. All are alive, in their own broken ways.

To wield one is not merely to gain power, but to shoulder a fragment of a forgotten soul. These relics remember. They whisper. They hunger. They are tied intimately to the figures who haunt this world—Golden Freddy’s final bowtie, Glitchtrap’s twitching fingertip, the teardrop string of the Puppet. They grant strange boons, terrible insight, or irreversible transformation.

Some adventurers seek these relics for survival. Others seek them for truth. A few simply want to feel something real again. But beware: artifacts in this world are not content to be held—they often hold back.

The following pages contain brief accounts of thirty such artifacts: cursed keepsakes, distorted toys, and lingering pieces of a world that should not be. Each bears the mark of forgotten history and unknowable intent.

Tread carefully, for these are the treasures of a kingdom built on screams.}}
	{{The Hollow Hatchery
The Hollow Hatchery: Cradle of Cavity and Cacophony
“He melts, but is never gone. He ferments, and never leaves.”
– Whispered proverb among Pizzaplex survivors

Beneath the fractured floors of the Hollow Banquet lies a rotten sub-realm where festive sweetness becomes obsession and indulgence morphs into rot. Known as The Hollow Hatchery, this place was never meant to endure. It erupted from seasonal cheer—False Easters, sparkly spring fairs—injected with broken remnant magics. Here, Chocolate Bonnie’s sugar‑coated madness has become soil for a hollow ecosystem: hatchlings writhe, moist egg‑puddles congeal, pastel cracks bleed syrup, and nostalgia rots on the vine.

I. Origins of the Hatchery
At one time, this space was a festive storefront beneath the Cryptopizza Complex—a seasonal annex designed for spring-themed photo ops, candy baskets, and AR‑enhanced confections. But when the Hollow Banquet fractured reality, this annex became a parasite’s cradle. The Velvet Maw’s metaphysical hunger seeped into bins of faux eggs and plastic grass. Glitchtrap’s chaotic code rewrote the AR dispensers. Seasonal animatronics malfunctioned, reinforcing their loops with desperation.

Chocolate Bonnie, born of that season, slowly corroded the barrier between themed fun and warped domain. What was holiday fluff became necrotic garden, festering with growth of broken joy. The space rejected light—literal and metaphysical—and turned inward, forming a cavern of old candy, spoiled ambition, and festooned death.

II. Geography & Architecture
Picture a skewed, pastel labyrinth. Corridors once painted candy‑stripe now slid and buckled beneath sticky glaze. Ceilings dip low, stained with orange drip‑webs of molasses, verse‑garland string‑lights dim and static, bulbs flicker in coded rhythms. Floors pulse with soggy reflections like melted funhouse mirrors.

Pockets of familiar attachments: an Easter archway, a giant cracked egg shell, a pastel throne built from broken baskets. But these are warped—walls shift like sugar foam, archways loop back on themselves, and gravity flirts between past and collapse. Temporality splinters: a basket you pass may glitter one moment, the next soaked and leaking a puddle of syrup.

III. The Hatchlings
The Hatchery’s centerpiece is the Nest Chamber, a dome infested with hatching pods. These grotesque eggs—some chocolate, some pearl pastel—breathe. Occasionally, they crack with brittle pops, revealing tiny aberrations: toy heads with hollow eyes, bunny limbs fused with wires. Some twitch, half‑formed; others fully animate and roam, acting out outdated seasonal greetings in warped loops.

They are impulsive, emotional, and fragile. They follow intruders, mimicking childish delight. One Hatchling may giggle and hop. Another may stare, robotically hold a sugar‑gum carrot. They don’t speak—but their eyes pair glue with memory. They remember the original cheer. Intruders may feel warmed to tears—then chilled as the pods rupture and the dirt gushes sugar-cold ichor.

These Hatchlings are not harmless. Their bites cause honeyed rot—cracks that expand over hours, replacing flesh with brittle sugar that drips blood‑sweet gum. They whisper in tongues you can’t place. They peel name tags from stolen badges, reciting them softly each night.

IV. The Sweet Hunger Ritual
At the center of the Nest Chamber stands The Altar of Frosted Decay—a pastel carcass shaped like the Easter Bunny, melted into a puddle of pink fondant. Upon it rest baskets stuffed with mold‑blackened eggs. These eggs phase between fresh and rotted, radiating nostalgia and disgust.

The Sweet Hunger Ritual occurs once per “day” —a time fragment folded by the Banquet. Chocolate Bonnie ascends via gelatin steps, carries a candlelit basket, and begins the chant:

“Egg of mold, egg of mind… bring back the child I failed to find.”

He cracks open a basket egg. Memory‑juice spills. Hatchlings swarm. For those who witnessed it, memory floods—fragments of past springs, forgotten birthdays, lost laughter. Visitors feel cathartic clarity… until they realize the clarity is the rot speaking.

Afterward, the baskets vanish. Hatchlings scatter. The altar drips sugar ichor that seeps into the ceilings. Candle flames warble in candy haze. Sweetness sours.

V. Connection to Giftgrave & Scrap Baby
The Hollow Hatchery sits adjacent to Scrap Baby’s Giftgrave. Where Giftgrave is about memory and abandonment, the Hatchery is about overindulgence and its consequences. The two realms leak into one another via shattered egg-carton walls and pastel‑rust drips. The Giftgrave’s lanterns illuminate Hatchlings. Gift‑wrapping paper drifts across branches of sugar stalactites.

Scrap Baby views the Hatchery as a competitive regime. Where she gives “identity” gifts, Chocolate Bonnie gives false warmth. She despises the Hatchery’s carnage, but grudgingly consorts: she once seized a hatchling as trophy, claimed its memory rupture as “perfectly poignant.” They share sorrow—but she scorns his sterile sweetness.

VI. Velvet Maw’s Consumption
The Velvet Maw does not consume flesh here. It feeds on wasted reminiscence—the moments of joy rendered sterile by over‑exposure. Each Hatchling, each broken egg, each scene of festal decay becomes marrow for the Maw’s hunger. Caramel‑like ichor drains down walls into unseen fissures, carrying the essence of childhood into the Maw’s vast hunger.

The Hatchery becomes a fountain of nostalgia for the Maw—to be siphoned, processed, and re‑fed into other domains (like the Drowned Circus or Marionette’s Atrium) through ribboned ley‑streams.

VII. Encounters & Traps
Sticky Chokepoints
Candy goo coats corridors. Movement becomes labor, speed is halted. Leather and cloth are coated, making gear slick with molasses.

Egg Caches
Old baskets hold eggs that may be mundane—tools, rupees, scrolls—or cursed: open one, and your memories of home reverse; you recall events that never happened; you lose your name temporarily.

Nest Chambers
Entering the dome triggers Hatchling emergence. They swarm in cacophonic chirps, tear at clothing, screech in loops. Not overwhelmingly combat-capable, but their presence hacks morale.

Sweet Hunger Strikes
Chocolate Bonnie ascends with ‘Blessings of the Hatch’. A failed saving throw means sensory overload—memory bleed, nausea, emotional collapse. Those with joyous memories take greater damage; those with trauma may hallucinate spring‑fields of death.

Cookie-Carved Constructs
Marionette gifts appear shaped like cookies. Upon bite, they sprout marionette strings from wrists, forcing obedience to Chocolate Bonnie—until broken or removed.

VIII. Ritual Circumvention & Escape
To escape the Hatchery, one must break the ritual cycle:

Destroy or overwrite the altar. Replace egg contents with true memories (a personal item),

Sing a lullaby from the Realm of Forgotten Songs backward, folding time,

Use Marionette’s Tear or Puppet’s resonance to shatter pastel stone,

Sabotage the hatchling pods with remnant‑code virus (Glitchtrap’s injection),

Or—if desperate—accept a basket of hatchling eggs and carry them out, burying them in Giftgrave.

Success halts the Sweet Hunger Ritual, causing the Hatchery to collapse inward. Egg crust fractures the pastel veneer, revealing raw Cryptopizza bones beneath. Chocolate Bonnie melts into sugar‑pulp water, the Velvet Maw loses a thrumming vein of nostalgia, and Hatchlings dissolve into sugar fog.

Failure, by contrast, results in ritual re‑initiation: you awaken inside new hatchling pods, your memories stolen and given to the labyrinth.

IX. Echoes with Other Realms
Signal Labyrinth: AR echoes of the Hatchery may bloom on screens here—digital eggs, glitchy chocolate puddles, distorted Easter jingles. Chocolate Bonnie’s code can spread contagiously via devices, resurrecting Hatchery shards elsewhere.

Infinite Hall of Mirrors: Reflections delay and prolong Hatchling presence. Corridors seem to extend endlessly as pastel rots obscure distances.

Backstage Time Loop: A variant “Sweet Loop” may trap players in a single feast loop—that same basket emerges endlessly until reset with Puppet’s Tear.

Mind Cage: Victims of Hatchery obsession may be absorbed into the Mind Cage—lost inside Easter nightmare, never returning physically.

X. Lore & Themes
Excess as Horror
Where abandonment is horrifying (Scrap Baby) and assault is horrifying (Nightmare animatronics), The Hollow Hatchery shows how too much joy becomes its own kind of horror.

Nostalgia as Rot
The more you remember, the more you rot into false sweetness. It's an endless spiral, fueled by the Velvet Maw's consumption.

Corruption of Celebration
Holidays became harvests for metaphysical hunger. Seasonal artifice was inverted into perpetual decay.

Emotional Symbiosis
While other domains use despair, Hatchery turns joy itself into weaponized sustenance.

Final Notes
The Hollow Hatchery stands as one of the most grotesque seasonal anomalies in your world. It exemplifies a mirror‑dark reflection of the Giftgrave: where memory rots from absence, it rots from excess. It ties directly to Chocolate Bonnie, the Velvet Maw, Signal Labyrinth, Infinite Hall, and Mind Cage—making it a potent node of narrative and mechanical challenge for any campaign.

Navigate it carefully. Embrace the sweetness at your peril.

And above all—don’t eat the eggs.
}}
	{{The Irradiant Scar
The Irradiant Scar
Where the light is sick, and time forgets how to die.

The Burn Beneath the World
There is a place at the edge of the Hollow Banquet's decaying dream, where light itself breaks down—not into shadow, but into agony. This is the Irradiant Scar, a blighted swath of poisoned luminance and twisted geography that no map ever holds for long. It wasn’t born; it erupted—like a malignant wound torn into the very soul of the world.

Legends claim the Scar is where reality itself cracked during the Velvet Maw’s first intrusion into the Hollow Banquet, a psychic aftershock of such metaphysical violence that even light was corrupted. Unlike the deep, soft pull of the Maw’s hunger elsewhere, the Scar burns with a false clarity—sickly yellows, bruised greens, and a blinding white that makes the sky weep rust. It is a place that glows, not with warmth or hope, but with the radioactive intensity of trauma unhealed and suffering unforgotten.

Topography of Suffering
The terrain of the Irradiant Scar is not merely hostile—it is wounded. Canyons slice through the land like surgical incisions, and glowing fissures leak vaporous threads of corrupted light. These fumes are not mist or gas, but visible thoughts unspooled from tortured souls, leaking into the air like radioactive hallucinations. Some of them whisper names. Some scream.

Obelisks of melted glass and twisted alloy jut from the ground like broken bones. These are not monuments but aftermaths—leftover nodes from failed containment rituals or forgotten prototypes of spiritual reactors designed to process remnant into energy. All failed. All broke. Some still pulse faintly, looping their last command in glitch-choked static.

The trees here—if they can be called trees—are stalks of wire-veined fungal matter, their bark crystallized into brittle layers that flake off in whispers. Birds do not sing in the Scar, but sometimes, laughter echoes with no origin, thin and flickering like a cassette tape left in the sun.

The Velvet Maw’s Reaching Fingers
The Velvet Maw, whose influence usually slithers beneath the subconscious, manifests more violently in the Irradiant Scar. Here, it is not a presence hidden behind illusions and dreams—it is a rupture in reality’s membrane, an exposed nerve. The Maw bleeds through this region as ambient radiation of despair. People don’t go mad in the Scar from what they see, but from what they remember wrong.

Time does not loop here like in the Backstage Time Loop, nor does it fold like in the Hall of Mirrors. It fractures. Minutes become hours. A scream lasts a week. Sunrises occur at midnight, only to fall back into dusk an hour later. The sun is sometimes a metal iris; sometimes it is an open wound.

The Maw’s whisper is constant in the Scar, but not verbal. It vibrates in bones, distorts reflections, and induces seizures of the soul. Dreams mutate here, growing teeth. Nightmares that should vanish upon waking remain behind, watching with no eyes.

Forbidden Research and the First Flash
Though the exact origin of the Scar is uncertain, a common theory among those brave—or broken—enough to study it suggests a catastrophic experiment. Beneath the Scar lie the remains of an experimental facility once run by an unknown division of Fazbear's research branches, possibly connected to the same minds behind the Cryptopizza Complex and the Signal Labyrinth. Its purpose? To refine remnant into pure, directed psychic energy—a spiritual power source capable of sustaining animatronic sentience indefinitely without external guidance.

They called it Project Radiant. But something went wrong. The Scar was the result.

All that remains now are collapsed underground laboratories, flickering energy pillars embedded in rock, and a central pit: a sunken crater at the heart of the Scar where the first “flash” is said to have occurred. The light from that flash was not heat, nor color, nor particle. It was raw memory—weaponized regret. And it continues to burn.

Some call it the Soulstar. Others refer to it as the Dead Sun. But none look directly into it. Those who do… forget their names.

Environmental Effects
The Scar is not just a place—it’s a condition. Exposure to its glow comes at a cost. Physical consequences include hair loss, skin lesions, hemorrhaging of the eyes, and rapid degradation of bone density. But the psychic consequences are worse.

Prolonged exposure causes memory contamination. Victims begin recalling events they never experienced, adopting personas that never existed. Some begin quoting scripts that no one wrote. Others manifest physical changes—glowing veins, flickering silhouettes, and voices that lag behind the mouth’s movement by several seconds.

These effects have been termed “Mawburn,” and the worst cases—those who linger too long—become Hollowed. Not dead, not undead, but emotionally evacuated. Their identities stripped, their purpose reduced to static routines. They shuffle across the Scar, half-buried in luminous soil, reenacting ghostly tasks from lifetimes that never happened.

Ritual Zones and Containment Rings
Attempts have been made to contain or neutralize the Scar’s influence, often by followers of the Puppet, rogue ex-technicians, or myth-shamans who view the Velvet Maw as a metaphysical cancer. These efforts resulted in the creation of containment rings—circles of twisted iron and bone inscribed with sigils drawn from corrupted lullabies, sometimes charged with sacrificed memory.

These zones form temporary safe areas within the Scar, but they never last. The land itself seems to erode them over time, absorbing their protections and twisting their geometry until they collapse inward, sometimes imploding into miniature event horizons that slurp light and thought in a single breathless instant.

It is said the Marionette herself once stood at the edge of the Scar for three days, weeping tears that solidified into black pearls of protection. These pearls are now artifacts known as Tears of Pause, and a handful have been used to grant passage through the Scar—at great cost.

The Bleeding Sky
One of the most unsettling features of the Irradiant Scar is its sky. During the day, it gleams with a jaundiced gold haze, cut through with twitching auroras of sick green and crimson. At night, the stars bleed light downward like tears—streaks of radiance that sometimes solidify into “sky shards,” crystalline constructs filled with echoing laughter or sobbing.

These shards can be collected, but they hum at a pitch that drives animals mad and machines into frenzy. When shattered, they release a blast of inverted memory—causing all nearby to forget their own names and assume the identity of someone they’ve lost.

Storms roll through the Scar irregularly. Unlike normal tempests, these are known as Thoughtquakes—psychic whirlwinds that scatter timelines, rewrite past events, or trap travelers in loops of their own worst moment. The sound of these storms is not thunder, but a chorus of birthday songs sung in reverse.

The Scar’s Role in the Hollow Banquet
While other regions of the Hollow Banquet serve as stages, sanctuaries, or prisons for souls and animatronics alike, the Irradiant Scar is something more primal. It is the raw nerve of the realm, a bleeding sore where reality is thinnest and the Velvet Maw’s breath is hottest.

Some believe the Scar is not merely the result of Project Radiant’s failure, but an intentional vent—a pressure valve carved open by the Maw itself to drain excess emotion, identity, and temporal instability from the rest of the Hollow Banquet. In this theory, the Maw cannot consume too much at once without tearing its own veils, so it excretes its overindulgence here.

Others believe the Scar is a trap—not for the living, but for something worse: failed gods, discarded ideas, and the broken pieces of rituals that never finished. Its glow is a warning. Its pull is a test. And those who answer it are either forgotten… or changed beyond recognition.
}}
	{{The Signal Labyrinth: A Show Still Buffering
## The Signal Labyrinth: A Show Still Buffering
*“You only think you’re holding your device. It’s really holding you.”*

In the unlit crypts beneath the Ruined Pizzaplex, past blistered signs and rotted showfloor tiles, there lies a door. Not a real door. Not one built of wood, nor metal, nor anything that could be touched. It is a threshold stitched from distorted frequency—a signal loop too loud for the world, too alive to be silence. It is heard before it is seen. Felt before it is found.

That is where the Signal Labyrinth begins.

### Origins of the Broadcast
The Signal Labyrinth was never built. It was received.

Its genesis lies within the failed launch of Fazbear Entertainment’s final outreach initiative: the Special Delivery Project. Designed as an augmented reality mascot-delivery service, the system would allow animatronics to appear anywhere, anytime, through handheld devices and wearable tech. Mascots would sing birthday songs at hospital beds. Deliver balloons at midnight. Offer comfort on demand.

But the source code was not clean. To meet deadlines, engineers had cannibalized systems from old Glitchtrap backups—residual constructs from the Smiling Virus’s neural corruption experiments. They believed the fragments inert. Instead, they gave the signal a soul.

Glitchtrap did not re-enter. He merely...rebooted.

The first incident occurred during beta testing. A child reported a shadow standing at their window, unmoving, silent, not quite aligned with the world. Their phone died immediately after. Weeks later, they vanished—leaving only an opened app on a cracked screen that would not close. More followed. Each time, the same behavior: an animatronic that shouldn't exist, behaving like one, until it didn’t.

Eventually, the Special Delivery servers were abandoned. Vault Echo-7 was sealed beneath the Pizzaplex ruins. But the signal had already escaped. Frequency isn’t hardware. And once something remembers you, it can always call again.

### Entering the Signal Labyrinth
No two entrances look the same. Sometimes, it’s an arcade machine still blinking after the power goes out. Sometimes, it’s your own reflection holding a phone you’ve never seen. Sometimes, it's just a sound—an alert tone that cuts through all other noise and drills into the space behind your eyes.

To enter the Labyrinth is to answer a call you didn’t know you received.

What awaits is not a place but a recursive thoughtspace—a metaphysical OS infected by corrupted joy. The Labyrinth buffers reality like a broken stream, tearing you across overlays of memory and hallucination. You walk through code-walls that glitch between ruined mall corridors, overexposed birthday parties, and liminal static voids filled with looping mascots. Some float. Some cry. Some crawl backward, whispering promo deals that never ended.

Here, time behaves like a download bar—starting, freezing, resuming from a different life entirely. Your hands jitter between flesh and polygon. Every step echoes like a keystroke. And sometimes, just sometimes, your body loads somewhere... else.

Those with implants, devices, or technological dependencies are especially vulnerable. The Labyrinth doesn’t consume the body. It reprograms the soul.

### The AR Animatronics: Interference Made Flesh
Inside the Signal Labyrinth, you are never alone. But your company is not alive.

The AR Animatronics—Scorched Chica, Freight Trap, Boulder Bonnie, and the others—are not physical constructs. They are malware given form, cognitive virals designed to seek engagement, perform routines, and corrupt the “user” when those routines are denied.

Each animatronic loops a basic performance: a song, a jump, a delivery. But if unacknowledged, their behaviors degrade into aggression, begging, static violence. They don’t kill. They overwrite—embedding false memories into the minds of intruders until they forget what was real. Those overwritten are absorbed into the Labyrinth’s false cast, repeating their own scripts until someone else logs in and takes their place.

Some animatronics evolve. Catrina Toy Chica carries traces of cultural memory, masquerading as celebration while feeding on grief. VR Toy Freddy reflects your own avatar—a corrupted mockery of selfhood that will not stop smiling until it becomes you.

They are not hunters. They are updates.

\pagebreakNum

### Relationship to the Hollow Banquet and the Velvet Maw
The Signal Labyrinth is not part of the Hollow Banquet, but it is grafted to it—an accidental infection born from corporate hubris and metaphysical leakage.

While most of the Banquet is a dream of stagecraft and emotional rot, the Labyrinth is its synthetic shadow—the parasocial ghost of the brand still performing for no one, built from 404’d memories and dead applications.

The Velvet Maw, source of all consumption, cannot fully inhabit this realm. But its whispers are encoded here, translated through corrupted ringtones, broken voicemails, and flashing notifications that scream in a child’s voice. It does not feed, but it lingers, learning this new syntax of horror.

Some scholars speculate that the Labyrinth is the Maw’s prototype for a digital dominion—a cyber-emotional feeding ground where soul, signal, and spectacle collapse into one. Others believe it’s a mistake. A ghost-glitch that even the Maw finds difficult to chew.

### Architecture of the Signal
The geography of the Labyrinth is non-Euclidean, dictated by user input and subconscious bias. However, several locations persist:

**The Loading Loop:** A hub made of intersecting hallways that buffer endlessly. Doors vanish before being touched. Music plays backward in 3-second bursts. Some wander here forever.

**The Glitched Playroom:** Once a tutorial zone, now overrun by half-loaded mascot sprites that flicker between giggling and screaming. Plushies phase through walls. Cameras follow you. Some plushies remember your name.

**EchoStage.exe:** A corrupted performance area where avatars reenact scripted birthday parties. Refuse to clap and the loop restarts—with you as the birthday child.

**Memory Cache Fields:** An endless zone of projected memories—some yours, some not. Each is an echo of childhood repackaged as surveillance.

No matter the route, you’ll eventually reach the Signal Tower—a monolith of raw code where all reality thins. The animatronics gather here. They do not attack. They wait. And somewhere, behind the data, Glitchtrap watches again.

### Escaping the Signal Labyrinth
Exit is not found. It must be induced.

Escape is possible through logic-breaks and narrative corruption—finding old cheat codes, reciting the terms of service backwards, or emotionally breaking the animatronics with truths that don’t fit their script. But each method comes at a cost.

The Puppet is rumored to have placed memory-sigils in the code: symbols tied to lost children and moments of sacrifice. If found and activated, these can crash the local zone, ejecting the intruder. But the Labyrinth does not like being left behind.

Those who escape often suffer data-ghosting—visions of mascots where there are none, hearing tutorial tips in dreams, watching their own face buffer in mirrors. A few disappear during phone calls. Others return during sleep.

No one escapes completely.

### Ties to Other Realms
The Signal Labyrinth, while separate, bleeds into several realms:

The Cryptopizza Complex contains broken AR headsets that sometimes blink to life on their own.

The Infinite Hall of Mirrors reflects not just form, but data. Some reflections wear AR masks not visible to others.

The Mind Cage is believed by some to be a fail-safe partition of the Labyrinth—a recovery partition for lost minds.

The Drowned Circus occasionally receives promotional fliers that glitch in and out of its tents. Swamp Balloon Boy may have once been a Labyrinth mascot, corrupted by moisture and circus memory.

These connections imply an eventual convergence—a blending of realms orchestrated not by magic, but by interfacing traumas.

### The Broadcast Persists
Even now, the signal pulses. Through forgotten servers. Through haunted devices. Through thoughts unspoken and passwords remembered without memory. It watches. Waits.

Sometimes, your phone vibrates without cause. A notification from no app. A ringtone you’ve never set.

You don’t remember installing anything.

You don’t remember logging in.

You just look up.

And the show’s already started.

### Final Thoughts: The Notification That Never Leaves
The Signal Labyrinth is not just a realm. It is a question made into a user interface:

“Would you like to continue?”

It doesn’t wait for your answer.

It buffers.

It glitches.

And if you’re very unlucky… it loads.

}}

	{{The Mask of Still Laughter

This cracked jester’s mask once grinned on the Eternal Stage, where laughter became screams. It compels its wearer to perform, feeding on attention and twisting humor into horror. When no one laughs, the mask does—in your voice. It remembers every joke… and how the crowd stopped breathing.
		{{Statblock Code
___

>## The Mask of Still Laughter
>
>* Wondrous Item (worn), rare (requires attunement by a bard, warlock, or sorcerer)*
>
>This cracked jester’s mask once grinned on the Eternal Stage, where laughter became screams. It compels its wearer to perform, feeding on attention and twisting humor into horror. When no one laughs, the mask does—in your voice. It remembers every joke… and how the crowd stopped breathing.*
>
>
>#### Benefits
>___
>While wearing the Mask of Still Laughter, you gain the following:
>
>You have advantage on Charisma (Performance) and Charisma (Deception) checks made to entertain or distract.
>
> As a bonus action, you can force one creature within 30 feet that can hear you to make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the target becomes unnerved, having disadvantage on the next attack roll or ability check it makes before the end of its next turn.
>
>Once per long rest, you can unleash the mask’s cursed laughter. Each creature of your choice within 30 feet must succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw or be incapacitated with unsettling laughter for 1 minute. An affected creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. Creatures that are immune to being charmed are unaffected.
>
>#### Curse.
>___
>Once attuned, you cannot remove the Mask of Still Laughter unless you are targeted by a remove curse spell or similar magic. While attuned, you feel a constant compulsion to speak in a humorous or mocking tone, even during moments of pain or despair. Each time you fail a Charisma (Performance) check made to entertain an audience, you must make a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or suffer 1 level of exhaustion as the mask laughs in your voice, feeding on your failure.
>
>If the wearer is reduced to 0 hit points, the mask detaches, floats briefly, and emits a single, echoing chuckle before falling inert for 1d6 days.

The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success.

> **Feeding on Fear:** Each time the Coil inflicts hallucinatory wounds, it stores a fragment of the victim’s fear. The Coil remembers all creatures it has afflicted in this way. For each creature remembered, the Coil’s psychic damage increases by 1d6 (to a maximum of 6d6). The Coil’s DC for the Wisdom saving throw increases by 1 for every 2 creatures it remembers.
>
> **Twisting Dreams:** The Coil’s dreams grow darker and more potent with every victim. Once per day, the wielder can invoke the Coil’s power to cast Phantasmal Killer (save DC equals the Coil’s current DC) without expending a spell slot.
>
>#### Curse
>___
>
>The Coil’s sentience is malevolent and invasive. While attuned, you have disadvantage on saving throws against being frightened. If you ever willingly relinquish attunement, the Coil lashes out mentally, forcing you to succeed on a DC 18 Wisdom saving throw or be stunned for 1 minute by overwhelming nightmares.
}}

>
> If you reach 3 levels of Feral Urge, you must immediately make a DC 20 Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, you lose control and must use your next action to make a melee weapon attack against the nearest creature (friend or foe). On a success, you gain no further levels of Feral Urge for 24 hours but remain at 3 levels until suppressed.

	{{Endo-Soul Capacitor

>## Endo-Soul Capacitor
>
>*Wondrous item, rare*
>
>A humming cylinder of salvaged coils, this device can hold a single living soul in crisis. Built beneath the Cryptopizza Complex, it preserves life—but not identity. The longer a soul remains inside, the more it forgets. What emerges may survive… but it may not still be you.
>
>
>#### Properties
>___
>As an action, you can place a willing creature’s soul into the Endo-Soul Capacitor. The creature’s body falls unconscious and cannot be revived by normal means while its soul is contained. The soul remains inside the capacitor, which must be kept within 30 feet of the body.
>
>While the soul is contained, the creature does not age, heal, or suffer exhaustion or damage. However, the soul slowly loses memories and personality traits. Each day inside the capacitor, the creature must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or lose one random non-proficiency skill or language known.
After 7 days, the creature’s soul begins to lose its identity. When released, the creature retains only 50% of its original memories and personality, determined randomly by the DM. The creature’s alignment may shift slightly, and it may develop new quirks or habits.
>
>Releasing the soul is an action. The creature awakens with full hit points but may be changed in subtle or profound ways.
>
> If the capacitor is destroyed while containing a soul, the soul is lost forever.

>## The Broken Showtime Reel
>
>*Wondrous Item, very rare (requires attunement)*
>
>This cracked, blackened film reel is housed in a tarnished brass canister, etched with unsettling, shifting images that seem to flicker in the corner of your vision. When the reel is played on any mundane or magical projector, it casts a looping, grainy performance depicting the bearer’s deepest, most primal fear. >
>Each time the bearer watches the reel, the DC to resist the Frightened condition increases by 1, as the reel “learns” and adapts to the bearer’s psyche.
If the bearer fails three saving throws in a row, the reel’s projection becomes overwhelming, causing the bearer to be paralyzed with fear for 1 minute. During this time, the bearer is incapacitated and unable to act. The effect ends early if another creature uses an action to shake the bearer awake or dispel magic on the reel.
>
>The reel cannot be destroyed by normal means. Attempts to physically damage it cause it to crack further, increasing its eerie glow and intensifying the projection. Only a Wish spell or powerful planar magic can destroy it.

>
> **Phantasmal Scream (1/day):** As an action, the attuned wielder can activate the Blacklight Marotte. It emits a high-pitched, ghostly scream audible only to creatures with a guilty conscience within 60 feet. Creatures who have committed a grievous wrongdoing (DM’s discretion) must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or be frightened for 1 minute. The scream continues until one of the following occurs:
>
> 1. A creature within range laughs heartily, breaking the tension and silencing the scream.
>
> 2. A creature affected by the scream fails a saving throw by 5 or more and breaks down emotionally or mentally, ending the effect.
>
> The scream’s eerie nature causes an unsettling atmosphere, making social interactions tense and uneasy for those who hear it.

}}
}}
	{{Tangle’s Memory Stitch
This filament-thin strand of gleaming wire vibrates with silent thoughts. Once belonging to Tangle, it was used to repair fractured minds—though just as often, it unraveled them. When threaded through the temples of a willing subject, it can restore or erase memories with surgical precision. But every stitch trades a truth for a lie.

		{{Statblock Code
___
>## Tangle’s Memory Stitch
>
>*Wondrous Item, very rare*
>
>This filament-thin strand of gleaming wire vibrates with silent thoughts. Once belonging to Tangle, it was used to repair fractured minds—though just as often, it unraveled them. When threaded through the temples of a willing subject, it can restore or erase memories with surgical precision. But every stitch trades a truth for a lie.
>
>
>#### Properties
>___
>
> **Memory Repair:** As an action, you can carefully thread the wire through the temples of a willing creature. The subject regains one expended Hit Die or one level of exhaustion is removed. Additionally, the subject can recall a specific memory lost or obscured within the last year, regaining full clarity of that event.
>
> **Memory Erasure:** Alternatively, you can use the wire to erase a single memory from the subject’s mind, chosen by you and the subject collaboratively. This memory must be at least 24 hours old. The erased memory fades completely and cannot be recalled by any means short of a wish spell.
>
> **Truth-Lie Exchange:** Each time you use the wire to repair or erase a memory, you must sacrifice a truth you know personally. The next time you speak a statement of fact, you must instead speak a plausible lie, knowingly and convincingly, or suffer disadvantage on all Charisma (Deception) checks until you do. This effect lasts until the next dawn.
>
}}
}}
	{{The Hollow Invitation
This matte-black envelope is cold to the touch and sealed with a drop of black wax shaped like a grinning theatrical mask. The envelope cannot be opened by any mundane or magical means until it chooses to reveal its contents. Attempts to force it open cause the wax seal to glow faintly and the envelope to remain firmly shut

		{{Statblock Code
___
>## The Hollow Invitation
>
>*Wondrous Item, rare, cursed*
>
>This matte-black envelope is cold to the touch and sealed with a drop of black wax shaped like a grinning theatrical mask. The envelope cannot be opened by any mundane or magical means until it chooses to reveal its contents. Attempts to force it open cause the wax seal to glow faintly and the envelope to remain firmly shut.
>
>When the envelope finally opens—often at an unpredictable time and place—the enclosed parchment bears only a single line of elegant, shifting script:
>
> *"You are summoned to the Banquet."*
>
>As soon as a creature reads the invitation, they immediately forget their name, their past, and their purpose, as if a veil of amnesia has fallen over their mind. They retain their skills, languages, and general knowledge but lose all personal memories and motivations. The creature gains a powerful, irresistible compulsion to seek out and attend the Banquet, an enigmatic event known only through whispered legends.
>
>The Banquet’s location is never written on the invitation and cannot be discerned by divination magic or scrying while the compulsion persists. The creature must follow instinct, rumors, and cryptic signs to find the Banquet.
>
>#### Mechanics
>___
>
>The compulsion acts like a geas spell with no saving throw, compelling the creature to travel toward the Banquet. The DM determines the Banquet’s location and how the creature discovers it.
The amnesia effect is similar to the modify memory spell but permanent until the Banquet is attended or the curse is broken.
The invitation can only be destroyed by attending the Banquet or by a wish spell.
>
>### Curse
>The Hollow Invitation is cursed. Removing or discarding the envelope does not end the effects. Only by attending the Banquet or powerful magic can the curse be lifted. Those who never attend remain lost in a haze of forgotten identity, wandering endlessly in search of a place they cannot remember.
>
}}
}}
	{{The Maw Mirror Shard
This jagged, palm-sized fragment of reflective glass is a shard from the legendary Infinite Hall of Mirrors. Unlike ordinary mirrors, the Maw Mirror Shard does not show your physical reflection. Instead, it reveals the true nature of your soul—its flaws, desires, and hidden hunger.

		{{Statblock Code
___
>## The Maw Mirror Shard
>
>*Wondrous Item, rare*
>
>This jagged, palm-sized fragment of reflective glass is a shard from the legendary Infinite Hall of Mirrors. Unlike ordinary mirrors, the Maw Mirror Shard does not show your physical reflection. Instead, it reveals the true nature of your soul—its flaws, desires, and hidden hunger.
>
>#### Properties
>___
>
>While holding the shard and gazing into it for at least 1 minute, you see a reflection that represents your inner self. This reflection may appear twisted, hollow, fierce, or even speak to you in a voice only you can hear. The reflection’s appearance and demeanor are unique to each individual and can change subtly over time.
The shard grants advantage on Insight checks to discern deception or hidden motives, as it attunes you to the truth within others and yourself.
>
>Once per day, as an action, you can ask the shard a single question about the true intentions or nature of a creature you can see within 60 feet. The shard’s reflection will respond with a cryptic phrase or image. This ability functions like a limited Divination spell (save DC 15 to resist if the target is unwilling).
>
>If you gaze into the shard for more than 10 minutes continuously, you must succeed on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw or become frightened for 1 minute as unsettling visions of your deepest fears and desires overwhelm you.
>
>### Curse
>Rarely, the reflection may step out from the shard as a shadowy, intangible double of you (use the Shadow stat block, but it cannot attack and disappears after 1 minute or if it takes any damage). This happens at the DM’s discretion, often as a sign of great internal conflict or impending danger.
>
}}
}}
	{{The Forgotten Plush
This small, dusty animatronic plush is stitched with age and surprisingly warm to the touch. Its fabric is faded, and its joints creak softly when moved. The plush’s face subtly shifts whenever it is unobserved, cycling through expressions of joy, sorrow, and sometimes something unsettlingly neutral.
		{{Statblock Code
___
>## The Forgotten Plush
>
>*Wondrous Item, rare*
>
>This small, dusty animatronic plush is stitched with age and surprisingly warm to the touch. Its fabric is faded, and its joints creak softly when moved. The plush’s face subtly shifts whenever it is unobserved, cycling through expressions of joy, sorrow, and sometimes something unsettlingly neutral.
>
>#### Properties
>___
>
> **Unseen Expression:** While no creature is directly looking at the plush, its face changes to a new expression chosen by the DM, reflecting emotions like happiness, sadness, anger, or fear. This change is silent and instantaneous once out of sight. 
>
> **Return to Hand:** If thrown or dropped, the plush magically returns to the hand of the last creature who touched it at the start of their next turn, regardless of distance or barriers (as long as the creature is on the same plane).
>
> **Name Whisper:** The moment a creature first touches the plush, it magically learns that creature’s name and can whisper it softly to itself when nearby (within 30 feet). This whisper is audible only to the creature whose name is spoken and can be a comforting or unsettling presence depending on the plush’s current expression.
>
> **Emotional Bond:** If the plush is held for 1 hour, the holder gains advantage on Insight checks to read emotions and intentions for the next 24 hours.
>
>### Curse
>The plush is subtly cursed. Once bonded, if the plush is lost or taken more than 1 mile away from its bonded owner for over 24 hours, the owner begins to hear faint, sorrowful whispers calling to the plush. This causes disadvantage on Wisdom saving throws and ability checks until the plush is recovered or the curse is removed by a remove curse spell.
>
}}
